HEADLINE: CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
Same-Day Delivery From the North Pole

BYLINE: By Jim Gladstone; Jim Gladstone manages events and special promotions for the Philadelphia Free Library System. His fiction has been published in Christopher Street.

 BODY:

HARVEY SLUMFENBURGER'S CHRISTMAS PRESENT
Written and illustrated by John Burningham.
Unpaged. Cambridge, Mass.
Candlewick Press. $15.95. (Ages 5 to 8) 
 THERE are good tidings for parents fed up with the commercialization of Christmas in John Burningham's latest picture book, a hardscrabble but unsentimental tale of the tough work and valiant efforts that go into making the holiday pay off for the kids in these economically strained times. Just as Mr. Burningham's pooped, blue-collar Santa is sacking out after his annual gift-giving run, he notices that a single present for little Harvey Slumfenburger, a poor boy who lives in a hut at the top of the Roly Poly Mountain "far, far away," has gone undelivered. Dragging himself back out of bed, Santa earnestly schleps halfway around the world in order to deliver the precious parcel.
After young readers watch old Santa trudge over tundra, motorbike across ice, skate, ski and scale his way to young Harvey's bedside, they can't help being impressed. They'll realize that some of us work to make Christmas happen. "Harvey Slumfenburger's Christmas Present" is a book that encourages gratitude.
It also encourages careful and repeated readings. Mr. Burningham, whose books, from "Mr. Gumpy's Outing" to "Hey! Get Off Our Train," are enjoyed here and in Britain, has, in fact, tucked plenty of nifty gifts into his prose and illustrations, but they are not wrapped in flash and dazzle. His palette -- ranging from pale washes of pink to daunting black fields -- is richly sophisticated, and his subtly emotive figures are more like the cartoons in The New Yorker than the ones on Saturday morning television. Adults will get great pleasure out of teaching children how much there is to appreciate here.
You can elicit laughter by pointing out the bedpan discreetly provided for the sick reindeer tucked in their cozy beds (the fact that this Santa has only two deer -- and no elves -- suggests that hard times have reached the North Pole, too). You can summon up awe through the vast, Rothko-like sweeps of color signifying the tremendous distances Santa must travel to reach the Slumfenburger home. You can offer a lesson in politeness and modesty when, each time he meets a helpful stranger, Santa reaches out his white-gloved hand and says, "Excuse me, my name is Santa Claus."
"Harvey Slumfenburger's Christmas Present" is at once accessible and challenging, a book with a simple initial appeal that doesn't spoon-feed readers its deeper delights. The detailed texturing of Mr. Burningham's pen and watercolor illustrations, from the beautiful blue striations of sky that Santa traverses in a yellow biplane to the tiny town scratched into the paint at the foot of a mountain landscape, reveals more elements with each examination.
On the last page, curly-haired Harvey wakes up on Christmas morning to receive his one little gift, tagged with his name and wrapped in polka-dotted paper. The parting stroke is Mr. Burningham's refusal to reveal what's in the box. He leaves it to readers to conclude that the real gift, like the bulk of his tale, is in the giving. This is one sweet raisin of a book. Its wrinkle on the holidays is much needed.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Illustration by John Burningham from "Harvey Slumfenburger's Christmas Present.")

HEADLINE: CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
Washington Was a Boys' Club

BYLINE: By Ellen Chesler; Ellen Chesler, author of "Woman of Valor: Margaret Sanger and the Birth Control Movement in America," is researching the evolution of American public policy toward women and families.

 BODY:

ELEANOR ROOSEVELT
A Life of Discovery.
By Russell Freedman.
Illustrated. 198 pp. New York:
Clarion Books. $17.95. (Ages 10 and up)
 
A WOMAN UNAFRAID
The Achievements of Frances Perkins.
By Penny Colman.
Illustrated. 129 pp. New York:
Atheneum. $14.95. (Ages 10 to 14) 
 TWO finely rendered lives of Eleanor Roosevelt (1884-1962) and Frances Perkins (1880-1965), midwives of the modern social welfare state, appear not a moment too soon for young readers who are watching as Hillary Rodham Clinton and Donna Shalala present national health-care reform on Capitol Hill, the talk-show circuit and around the nation.
The role of women in the New Deal has long been slighted, but these two biographies draw on recent scholarly reassessments. Sixty years ago, Roosevelt, the first independent First Lady, and Perkins, the Secretary of Labor and the first woman ever appointed to a Presidential Cabinet, both testified before Congress. They both took part in political strategy sessions. They both traveled the country and were celebrated as gifted public speakers who could explain complicated policy issues in concrete, human terms. They both worked on legislation. In addition, Roosevelt wrote a daily newspaper column, and both she and Perkins published successful books.
Yet neither woman sought the spotlight or ever "cavorted" -- as Perkins liked to say -- before the press. And both cautiously allowed others of the Roosevelt brain trust to take credit for the genesis of historic programs in public employment, relief and Social Security for which they were in large measure responsible -- programs that fundamentally changed the way we define government in this country.
Happily, the charade is finally over, for them and, we hope, for their counterparts in the Clinton Administration. But these books remind young and old readers alike just how hard it has been for the voices of women to be heard in public life, let alone to be granted authority.
The poignant and by now well-known story of Eleanor Roosevelt's triumph over personal tragedy to become the most influential American woman of this century is recounted in "Eleanor Roosevelt: A Life of Discovery," by Russell Freedman, the author of many books for children, including "Lincoln: A Photobiography," which won the 1988 Newbery Medal, and "Franklin Delano Roosevelt." In measured tones he shows how her early work in the progressive settlement houses and voluntary associations of New York City inspired an abiding confidence in the potential of government to do good. We observe her practical political education as her husband's agent in the Democratic Party following his bout with polio in 1921. We learn of her achievements as First Lady on behalf of the country's most needy and underrepresented citizens -- especially black Americans. We follow her through World War II as she won the hearts of American soldiers, then into the postwar period after her husband's death in 1945, when, as a delegate to the United Nations, she became a force in her own right for international peace and human rights.
The personal drama of Eleanor Roosevelt's life also unfolds with unflinching clarity in the text and in the exquisite photographs that accompany it. We are introduced to the troubled and insecure child who emerged from the tragedy of her father's alcoholism and her parents' early deaths. We meet the young wife and mother of five who, with great discipline and determination, overcame the sorrow of her husband's infidelity and in subsequent years forged deep and abiding friendships with a small circle of men and women, each of whom, in a manner Mr. Freedman does not speculate about, fulfilled the need for intimacy her marriage no longer satisfied.
Penny Colman, who has written about Dorothea Dix and Fannie Lou Hamer, is equally thorough, fair and candid in her treatment of Frances Perkins. A native of Massachusetts, Perkins graduated from Mount Holyoke College in 1902 and became a professional social worker in the New York charity world in which Eleanor Roosevelt volunteered. So dogged were her investigations of the garment industry, and so persistent her lobbying for wage and hour reform, that she was first recruited by Gov. Al Smith, and later by Gov. Franklin D. Roosevelt, to work within New York State government, rather than against it. This prepared her to be President Roosevelt's Secretary of Labor, a job which then encompassed health and welfare as well as labor. Perkins's tenure witnessed the greatest period of organization in American labor history. She unequivocally supported the right to organize and bargain collectively, and used her considerable influence with the President to prevent him from restraining strikes by longshoremen and automobile workers. Yet she always had more confidence in the Federal Government than in organized labor as an instrument of social justice, and she devoted most of her efforts to protecting workers through maximum-hour and minimum-wage regulations.
Perkins differed from most of the women professionals of her era in one important respect. She did not sacrifice marriage in order to work. Sadly, her husband, Paul Wilson, an economist, spent much of his life in and out of hospitals, suffering from depression. This difficult dimension of her life is handled tactfully -- he remained in New York City for the 20 years she held Federal posts in Washington.
Both books tell us as well of the vilification that Eleanor Roosevelt and Frances Perkins endured from enemies of the Roosevelt Administration. As women, they were especially vulnerable to personal attack. In 1939 an impeachment resolution was brought against Perkins because she refused to deport the longshoreman and California labor leader Harry Bridges, who was alleged to be a Communist (the Bureau of Immigration was then part of the Labor Department). Though the resolution was dropped after hearings before the House Judiciary Committee, her reputation never fully recovered.
Young readers will learn in these biographies of the immense power that can be brought to bear against anyone in our society -- especially, perhaps, against women, who dare to demand that our politics advance a common good, that it be rooted in morality and not in self-interest. Hillary Rodham Clinton and Donna Shalala, beware!

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1839 words

HEADLINE: PUERTO RICO VOTES TO RETAIN STATUS AS COMMONWEALTH

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 14

 BODY:
Rebuffing their Governor and his efforts to make this Caribbean island commonwealth the 51st state, Puerto Ricans voted narrowly today to continue their existing ambiguous relationship with the United States.
By choosing to maintain the commonwealth status that has been in place here for more than 40 years, Puerto Ricans made it clear that they prefer "the best of two worlds," in the words of a pro-commonwealth campaign slogan, to the prospect of more intimate ties with the United States. By an overwhelming margin, they also rejected independence, the third option that had been offered to them in the nonbinding vote today. 
 With all votes counted, the commonwealth option won 48 percent of the vote, compared with 46 percent for statehood. Independence accounted for about 4 percent of the vote, with a small number of ballots being deliberately cast blank or spoiled as a protest against the plebiscite.
 
Problems of Statehood
 "Commonwealth is the formula that is most convenient for Puerto Rico," said Angel Casanova, a 52-year-old woodworker, after voting this morning in Bayamon, a San Juan suburb. "Statehood would only result in more problems."
Gov. Pedro Rossello acknowledged the defeat in a speech at the headquarters of his New Progressive Party a few hours after the voting ended this afternoon. "The people have spoken, and I have to obey," he said. He added that by turning out in large numbers and peacefully exercising their right to vote, "in the eyes of the whole world the people of Puerto Rico have shown their class and their commitment to democracy."
 
A Majority for Neither
 Nevertheless, the result threatens to usher in a period of political uncertainty here and change Puerto Rico's relations with Washington. Thanks to the showing of the Puerto Rico Independence Party, neither of the two main parties here can claim to represent a majority of the island's 3.7 million people.
In addition, Mr. Rossello and Puerto Rico's non-voting delegate to Congress, Carlos Romero-Barcelo, will now be expected to ask Washington to enhance Puerto Rico's existing commonwealth status after having spent the last three months attacking the status quo as a "shameful" remnant of colonialism.
Tonight, leaders of the pro-commonwealth Popular Democratic Party called on Mr. Rossello to begin discussions with them over how those enhancements should be pursued in Washington.
Since 1952, Puerto Rico has been a commonwealth of the United States, a unique arrangement that gives the residents of Puerto Rico some, but not all, of the rights and responsibilities of American citizenship. With commonwealth status, Puerto Ricans are subject to the military draft, but do not vote in Federal elections and do not pay Federal taxes so long as they live here.
An additional 2.6 million Puerto Ricans live on the American mainland and are treated like all other citizens. Mr. Rossello, who campaigned on a statehood platform when he won office a year ago, had made that one of his main arguments for statehood, saying it was time to end Puerto Rico's "second class" status.
The Popular Democratic Party, in contrast, offered a slightly modified version of commonwealth. They vowed to seek restoration of tax benefits that Congress reduced earlier this year to cut the Federal budget deficit. The party also said it would fight for an increase in Federal aid to the elderly, the disabled and the poor.
Throughout the campaign, backers of commonwealth status also argued that statehood would require Puerto Rico to relinquish both its use of the Spanish language and its cultural identity. They also said that statehood would bring with it a Federal income and increased Federal levies on gasoline, cigarettes and liquor.
Though three former Republican Presidents had urged voters here to choose statehood, President Clinton remained neutral during the campaign, saying only that he would respect the will of Puerto Rico's people. "Whatever they want, I want," Mr. Clinton told the Congressional Hispanic Caucus in September.
What voters apparently did not want was a substantial change, said Representative Jose Serrano, Democrat of the Bronx, who is one of three Puerto Ricans in Congress.
But Mr. Serrano, who did not take a public position on the issue, added: "I question how long we can keep this kind of relationship. Essentially, we have a colony in the Caribbean. We go around the world talking about democracy but we still have a colony. Eventually it's going to be a problem for us."
 
Sparing Congress
 Still, the result of the vote spares Congress the difficult and controversial decision that would have confronted it had Mr. Rossello's party been successful: whether to grant or reject statehood for Puerto Rico. Privately, many members of Congress say they are content with the current relationship and are reluctant to tinker with it.
At a news conference Saturday night and in his speech tonight, Mr. Rossello, a 49-year-old pediatric surgeon, gave no timetable for submitting the "enhanced commonwealth" program to Congress for approval. But he did give one indication of the political difficulties that may lie ahead for the island. He said that since the Popular Democratic Party, which controls neither the commonwealth government nor Puerto Rico's representative in Washington, had offered the winning option in the vote, "it is up to them to keep their word with the people of Puerto Rico."
The plebiscite on Puerto Rico's political status was the first since 1967, when commonwealth won 60 percent of 700,000 votes cast, compared with 39 percent for statehood. The Puerto Rico Independence Party had urged a boycott of that vote, and independence was favored by fewer than one percent of voters.
 
Heavy Turnout
 The last series of public opinion polls taken before the vote today had shown statehood and commonwealth in a virtual tie, with each supported by about 40 percent of voters surveyed. Leaders of both parties were predicting that victory would go to whichever side did the best job in bringing its supporters to the polls.
Turnout for the vote today was higher than in the 1967 plebiscite, when just under two-thirds of registered voters cast ballots. Members of the State Electoral Commission estimated that more than 73 percent of Puerto Rico's 2.2 million voters voted today, a sign of the passions aroused by the issue.
Despite rain that began at mid-morning and continued until the polls closed at 3 P.M. local time, the mood across the island was one of celebration. Cars bearing oversized American flags or the banners of the two main parties raced through the streets during the day and into the evening, their horns tooting and their passengers leaning out the windows to chant political slogans.
At polling places, 5,611 of which were set up at schools around the island, election judges good-naturedly kidded each other about their parties' chances; there were no immediate complaints of voting irregularities. Once the polls closed, supporters of the three options flocked to their respective party headquarters to hear the results come in, dancing, singing, and eating in the 85-degree heat as they waited for the tabulations to be posted.
At one polling place in Carolina, another San Juan suburb, an ambulance drove up around midday, and election officials carried an elderly voter to the booth so that he could vote. Radio stations carried reports of commonwealth party volunteers in many areas ferrying elderly or infirm sympathizers to the polls so they could vote for the status quo.
"I have no doubt the success we are enjoying now is the result of that effort by our members," said Celeste Benitez, director of the commonwealth campaign. She added that "statehooders received a tremendous setback, especially when you consider the economic resources they had at their disposal."
 
Lesser of Two Evils
 But the commonwealth total apparently was also swelled by the adherence of some voters who had declared themselves in favor of independence. Faced with the possibility of Puerto Rico entering the union, they opted for the lesser of what they viewed as two evils.
"In my heart, I've always been for independence," said Carlos Fuentes, a 29-year-old teacher in Carolina. "But the strong campaign effort and ad campaign of the statehooders left me in sort of a panic, and so I voted for commonwealth to make sure that statehood would not win."
At the same time, many voters who last November cast their ballots for Mr. Rossello and the New Progressive Party, giving them control of two-thirds of the island's municipalities, switched parties this time. They made it clear that though they were not critical of Mr. Rossello's performance, they simply could not commit themselves to the drastic change in Puerto Rico's political status that he was advocating.
"I always look for the best candidate, and I thought that was Rossello," said Jorge Valcarcel, a resident of Caguas, about 20 miles south of the capital. "But I believe in commonwealth, and that's what I voted for."
 
 
 
RETHINKING PUERTO RICO, POLITICALLY
 In Sunday's nonbinding plebiscite, Puerto Rico grappled again with whether to remain a commonwealth of the United States, to become the 51st state or to become an independent nation.
 
Political History
 
Puerto Rico became a United States territory in 1898, after the Spanish-American War. It was ruled by a presidentially appointed governor until 1947, when Congress voted to allow Puerto Ricans to elect their own governor.
 
Since 1900, the island has been represented in the United States Congress by a nonvoting, locally elected resident commissioner. The commissioner has a four-year term.
 
Puerto Ricans became United States citizens in 1917, but they cannot vote for President, are exempt from Federal taxes and get limited Federal aid.
 
Commonwealth
 
In 1952 the current Constitution of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico was drafted by its elected Constituent Assembly, approved in referendum by 80 percent of voters and ratified by the United States Congress.
 
As a Commonwealth, Puerto Rico is part of the United States for purposes of international trade, foreign policy and war (including military service), but has its own laws, taxes and representative government.
 
In a plebiscite in 1967, 60.5 percent of voters were in favor of improved commonwealth status rather than statehood or independence.
 
Population
 
Puerto Rico is home to 3.7 million people, of whom 2.3 million are registered voters. The 2.6 million Puerto Ricans living on the United States mainland could not vote in Sunday's plebiscite.
 
Economy
 
The island's annual per capita income in 1989 was $6,200, the highest in Latin America but about half that of the United States mainland. Many manufacturing jobs, notably in pharmaceuticals, depend on Section 936 of the Internal Revenue Code, which shelters profits made in Puerto Rico from Federal taxes.

HEADLINE: Pacific Chiefs to Meet Where 2 Worlds Mix

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Nov. 14

 BODY:
A visitor to Seattle, the largest city in a mythical land called Cascadia, arrives at the airport and is whisked to a baggage area in a subway where the robot voice speaks Japanese, as well as Spanish and English.
About 140 miles north of here, Vancouver, British Columbia, is about to become the first large city in North America with an Asian majority. 
 When President Clinton and the leaders of the major countries of the Pacific Rim arrive here this week, they will find themselves in a land where two worlds an ocean apart are forming a hybrid society.
Cascadia, a realm that seems to be moving well beyond the imagination of the original dreamers, stretches from the rain forests of British Columbia to the pinot noir country of southern Oregon. It is a region united by geography, a distrust of the powers "back East" and a shared vision that the future lies across the Pacific.
In many ways the Asian part of the equation is already here, giving the edge of the continent a polyglot character that goes beyond its quirkiness and trademark gray skies.
"We are less Atlantic in our preoccupation than any other part of the nation," said Bob Kapp, executive director of the Seattle-based Washington Council on International Trade.
"Asians are just not exotic to most people who live here; they are not seen as a threat," said Mr. Kapp, who was instrumental in persuading the State Department to select Seattle as the American host of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum.
 
Ministers of 15 Nations
 Cabinet ministers of the forum's 15 member nations, including the United States and Canada and the powerful economies of the Pacific Rim, will gather here on Wednesday and meet on Thursday. Leaders of those nations, many of which have healthy trade relationships with the Pacific Northwest, will meet on Saturday on an island in Puget Sound off the coast.
In downtown Seattle, the concrete toadstool of the Kingdome is the home of the Mariners, the only major league baseball team that is owned in large part by a Japanese investor. Earlier this month, the voters in King County -- the 12th largest in the nation -- elected a Chinese-American, Gary Locke, as the County Executive.
And in Vancouver, an Asian immigrant from Hong Kong, David Lam, is now winding up his term as the Lieutenant Governor of British Columbia, Queen Elizabeth II's official representative in the province.
A backlash of sorts has developed in British Columbia against the heavy influx of Asians, who make up about 30 percent of Vancouver. And immigration was an issue in the recent Canadian election. In Seattle, Asians are the largest nonwhite ethnic group, accounting for about 13 percent.
 
Age of Pacific Predicted
 But even among those who believe that the flavor of the country has changed too dramatically, no one is fighting the dawn of the long-predicted Age of the Pacific.
The vision for Cascadia is a region that defies traditional borders and markets itself primarily to Asia as a place without clunky historical baggage. The cities are new, clean and green. You defy recycling at your own risk.
Except among the fringe elements, the architects of Cascadia are not talking about secession, but rather about a singular world view and a way of life.
The region has long had somewhat of a shared cultural tradition. The Northwest is a leading regional theater center, the opera company in Seattle is internationally known, and the region defined the "grunge" genre in popular music .
Some of the trappings, of course, are pie in the sky; there is now a contest to come up with an official flag of Cascadia, perhaps a cross between the Maple Leaf and the Stars and Stripes.
But the concept of a singular region with its prosperity and much of its new culture linked across an ocean to the region with the world's fastest-growing economy is reflected in subjects that will be under discussion at the economic meetings this week.
Washington State, which did $74 billion in two-way trade last year, is the most trade-dependent state in the country, with one in five jobs tied to overseas commerce. It is not just that the nation's largest exporter, Boeing, and it largest software manufacturer, Microsoft, have headquarters here, but that the Port of Seattle, the closest inthe mainland United States to Japan and China, does more than 85 percent of its business with Asian countries.
Similarly, British Columbia, Canada's fast-growing province, has received $10 billion in investments from Hong Kong alone in the last eight years. This has led some people to refer to Vancouver, pejoratively, as "Hongcouver."
But the money is welcome. And the cultural obstacles are seen as bumps on the way to a new society wedged against the Cascade mountains, from which it takes its name, and facing across the sea.
"For us, looking inward is not an option, and frankly, I don't think it's much of an option for much of the United States," said Michael Walker, director of the Fraser Institute, a conservative-leaning think tank in Vancouver. "By the end of the century, Vancouver, for all intents and purposes, will be an Asian city."
Such a shift of this continent's focus has long been predicted. "The Mediterranean era died with the discovery of America," President Theodore Roosevelt said nearly a century ago. "The Atlantic era has reached the height of its development. The Pacific era, destined to be the greatest, is just at dawn."
In the Pacific Northwest, the age of the Pacific had to overcome violent hostility toward Asians. Chinese immigrants arriving at the new city of Vancouver about a hundred years ago had to pay a head tax of $500 before they were allowed to get off the boat. In Seattle, a mob rousted Chinese laborers from their beds in the middle of the night, then led them to waiting boats. Only the edict of a Federal judge, standing in the rain in his pajamas, kept the boats from sailing.
 
A Market for Boeing
 The low point was the internment of Japanese-Americans, many of them second-generation residents of the Pacific Northwest, during World War II.
But the war pumped up Boeing, the world's largest airplane manufacturer, and the company became dependent on a global market. Now, Asia is the fast-growing market for Boeing airplanes. China, which is on a course to become the world's second biggest economy, behind only the United States, bought one of every six airplanes made by Boeing workers in Seattle last year.
"If you were to try some kind of protectionism now that affected trade with Asia, this part of the country would go crazy," said Richard Ellings, director of the National Bureau of Asian Research in Seattle.
Pinched by the recession in air travel, Boeing has laid off more than 20,000 workers in the last two years. But the tough economic times, said Mayor Norm Rice of Seattle, have not fostered a tendency to look inward.
"We see this as our time to solidify Seattle's place in the Pacific century," he said.
The Mayor is also the chairman of a commission that is advancing a trade alliance and joint marketing campaign aimed at Asia. The fact that government commissions are now acting on the concept of Cascadia has lent legitimacy to an informal idea that sprouted organically in discussions among academics and business people.
All is not sweet harmony between the two countries in Cascadia, though. Mr. Walker said temporary tariffs on Canadian lumber, instigated by Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, have had "the most singular negative impact of anything on British Columbia forestry."
And Americans have complained loudly about the city of Victoria's barely treated toilet effluence, which is flushed into the Juan de Fuca Strait separating Washington and the Canadian province.
In one respect, the Cascadia movement is a return to earlier boundaries. The old Oregon Territory used to encompass what is now British Columbia as well as the states of Washington and Oregon. It was called Columbia by the British. From the beginning, its economic livelihood was based on trade with Asia -- otter pelts taken by English seamen from the wet coast of the Northwest and sold to Chinese mandarins.
 
Cooperation Across Border
 In contrast with the acrimony along the United States border with Mexico, Washington State has signed two agreements with British Columbia in the last five years that promise cooperation in trade, investment and tourism. The border crossing at Blaine, Wash., is the busiest between the two countries, and it is situated beneath a giant white Peace Arch with the inscription, "Children of a Common Mother."
"Looking at Cascadia as if it were a country, the economy would be a genuine economic tiger of the Pacific Rim," said Bruce Chapman, a former United Nations official who is director of the Discovery Institute, a Seattle think tank. "People know what's driving it."
Respondents to a poll taken in this state last year agreed two to one that trade with Japan does more good than harm.
There are 44 professors who specialize in East Asian affairs alone at the University of Washington, in Seattle, where 16 percent of the student body is of Asian descent.
 
Summit Meeting on Island
 The highlight of the Asian conference here will be the summit meeting on Saturday inside an Indian longhouse on a tiny, uninhabited island, after a midweek meeting of diplomats at the Washington State Convention and Trade Center. The social centerpiece will be a reception at the Seattle Asian Art Museum, one of the city's first cultural landmarks, established more than 50 years ago as showcase for art from across the Pacific.
Noting that Vancouver was host to the mini-summit meeting between President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia earlier this year, the Cascadia proponents see this region as evolving into something they call a Geneva of the Pacific. Seattle is building an international conference center, with simultaneous translation features, to further that goal.
But there remains one subject of lingering insecurity in Cascadia about its new global role -- the weather. It rains less in Seattle and Vancouver than in any city on the American East coast, but a fine mist predominates. When the sun shines, there is a fear that traditional gray must soon follow, almost by punishment.
"The only thing I'm really nervous about is the weather," Mr. Chapman said. "We've had such a nice fall that it will probably be awful during the week of the conference. And then what will they think of us?"

HEADLINE: Newest Corporate Refugees: Self-Employed but Low-Paid

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
When Edward Gray lost his last job, as a patent agent defending filings before the Federal Patent Office, he gave up on corporate America. Converting a bedroom of his Los Angeles home into an office, Mr. Gray, 56, went to work for himself, recruiting inventors as his own clients.
He had tried to avoid self-employment. Most of his career had been spent as a physicist in the military industry, developing rockets and aircraft for General Electric, the Rand Corporation, TRW Inc. and the like. As those jobs disappeared, he took an 18-week course in patent law, passed a Federal exam and joined a law firm in 1991 as a patent agent. But 16 months later, the firm closed Mr. Gray's operation, and seeing no other choice, he became self-employed.
 
Harder Than Old Jobs
 For millions of people like Mr. Gray -- refugees from the corporate world -- self-employment, often as consultants, is turning out to be far harder work than their old jobs. Although many of them are well-educated, skilled and experienced, they have difficulty matching their old incomes when they go out on their own -- and their reduced buying power weakens the economy. 
 "I would certainly feel precarious if I had to depend on this income to live, but I have enough savings," Mr. Gray said. With degrees from Harvard and New York University, he once earned $75,000; his income this year will be less than $40,000. For every 100 potential clients with whom he talks, only one or two give him a job. "If I had the opportunity to rejoin the corporate world," Mr. Gray said, "I would probably like to jump right back into it."
More than 12 million Americans, or 10 percent of the work force, are self-employed. This huge group still includes entrepreneurs with six-figure incomes, in the Horatio Alger mode, as well as doctors, dentists, plumbers and others who have traditionally worked for themselves. But the largest contingent, more than four million people, is composed mostly of people like Mr. Gray, who are victims of layoffs, downsizing, budget cuts and a weak American economy that has tossed a huge number of white-collar workers out of jobs.
More often than not, this highly-skilled contingent of the self-employed is composed of older white men, with backgrounds as managers, professionals and administrators. Their ranks have swelled by 700,000 in the last decade, faster than any other contingent among the self-employed, the Labor Department and Census Bureau report.
The existence of this pool of often under-employed men and women suggests to some economists that the official unemployment rate, now at 6.8 percent, understates the number of skilled people, like Mr. Gray, who are ready to take jobs in the corporate world when the economy strengthens and jobs become much more available. As job openings come back, the competition from these extra workers could dampen American wages for months or years.
"The self-employed are part of the labor reserve and you really don't get into labor shortages until you use up some of this reserve," said Thomas L. Plewes, an associate commissioner of the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics. "It is not that they are not working; it is that they are a flexible labor asset, there to take care of bottlenecks and shortages."
 
Size Underestimated
 The Labor Department may even be underestimating the size of this flexible labor asset. The Internal Revenue Service puts the total at roughly 15 million people who draw nearly all their income from self-employment, without including farmers or the tens of thousands of self-employed in the underground economy who report nothing to the Government. By the I.R.S. count, the self-employed total nearly 13 percent of the work force, three percentage points higher than the Labor Department's figures.
Whatever the estimate, the self-employed have grown as a percentage of the total work force since the early 1970's, reversing a decline that had lasted through most of the century. The rise would probably be even greater if turnover were included in the Government's calculations; that is, the people who become self-employed in, say, February, and go out of business by November. Adding this constant turnover would swell the ranks of the self-employed by nearly 20 percent, said Theresa Devine, a labor economist at Pennsylvania State University.
 
Start-Ups Easier
 "One reason the United States has been able to have a lower unemployment rate than many European nations is that it is far easier in this country to start a business and become self-employed," said David Evans, vice president of National Economic Research Associates, who has published studies on self-employment.
But if starting a business is easy, making a substantial living from it is not.
"On their own, people lack capital and personnel, and they have a constant insecurity about the steadiness of their incomes." said Katherine Newman, a Columbia University anthropologist who has studied the self-employed. "Only people with fairly defined skills in demand, like tax specialists, seem able to make a big success of self-employment," she said.
 
In a Dead Spell
 Mr. Gray has had only 10 clients in 18 months of self-employment. Each paid $4,000 to $5,000 for him to prepare a patent application, a process that took more than 40 hours of concentrated work. He said he hoped there would be additional revenue from these inventors when the time came to defend the applications before the Patent Office. For the moment, however, he has reached a dead spell. "I have not worked on anything in several weeks," he said.
"I thought in September that the fourth quarter would be very productive, because I had all kinds of leads and possibilities, and without exception they have fizzled out," Mr. Gray said. Meanwhile, he is seeking additional clients through advertisements in specialty journals.
Priscilla Claman does not have dead time, but she faces other obstacles. As the president of Career Strategies Inc. in Boston, she provides training programs and counseling on work habits and efficiency at fees of $85 to $125 an hour. She started the firm with a partner four years ago, and has built up enough corporate clients to fill her days and those of three employees -- an unusually large staff for America's self-employed.
 
A Limit on Growth
 She also counsels people who lose or leave their jobs. Often, she tells departing executives to become temporarily self-employed in their chosen fields -- even if they do not have much work to do -- because that can look better on their resumes than an interim period in a lower-wage job as they search for another top position.
Despite her full days, Ms. Claman, 54, faces a limit on her growth. She recently bid on a contract to provide her services to a corporation with offices across the country. "They asked me to bid on it, and I helped to develop the product that they sought," Ms. Claman said, "But I did not win; they thought I was too small."
Ms. Claman came to self-employment from a different route than Mr. Gray. She gave up a job as senior vice president of human resources at the Bank of New England, about six months before a crisis developed there that ended in the bank's failure.
Why did she leave a job that paid $80,000 a year? She said the bank had changed in the eight years she was there, and had become more impersonal and less involved in the activities of the communities where it had branches. Career Strategies allowed her to continue in her specialty. Bank of New England was an early client and other clients came through referrals and a newsletter that Ms. Claman publishes quarterly.
 
Forming an Alliance
 Still, her take-home pay of $60,000 to $70,000 is less than she earned as a bank executive. To get above that level, Ms. Claman says, she would have to add employees -- maybe 10 more people to win the sort of big contract that she recently lost. Unwilling to do this, she is arranging an alliance with Career Development Services of Rochester, a bigger operation that would market for her and join in the bidding for big contracts.
"Someday I expect to make a lot of money from Career Strategies," she said. "If I did not think that, I would pull the plug and go back to work as an executive."
While Mr. Gray and Ms. Claman are still working in professional occupations, Nancy Lockwood, another corporate refugee, has struck out in a very different direction. After 17 years at the International Business Machines Corporation, moving into marketing in her final post, she took a buyout -- more than $45,000 -- and set herself up as an antiques dealer. She left I.B.M. reluctantly, she said, worried that while her job had not disappeared, it might.
 
A 4:30 A.M. Start
 "My job was relatively safe," she said, "but there was talk that there might not be another buyout offer, and I had been playing around with antiques and I thought maybe I could make it."
She specializes in printed cotton tablecloths from the 1940's and 50's, which she searches out at flea markets and resells. "I work harder than I ever did," she said. "I get up at 4:30 A.M. and get out on the road."
Still, her take-home income has shrunk to $1,500 a month, from more than $4,000. The reduced income covers her $1,000 in mortgage and maintenance payments for a cooperative apartment in Tarrytown, N.Y., but leaves only $500 for car costs, meals and other expenses. Meanwhile, she is spending her buyout money. When that is gone, she said, she might take another job if she is still not earning enough from antiques.
"I feel I could get one tomorrow, at least as a secretary," she said. "I could always work for a temporary-help agency."
With earnings of about $18,000 a year, Ms. Lockwood is close to the median income for self-employed Americans, which the Census Bureau estimated at $18,815 in 1992, down from $21,343 in 1989, after adjustment for inflation. The median income for job holders earning wages and salaries also fell during that period, but by much less.
"These numbers clearly bear out that self-employed people are more sensitive to the effects of a weak economy than are job holders," said Charles Nelson, an economist for the Census Bureau.

HEADLINE: Pacific Trade Bloc Is Divided Over Chile's Membership Bid

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
As the leaders of 15 Pacific nations prepare to meet this week in Seattle to debate trade and growth, another issue has split both the group and the Clinton Administration: does the Pacific Rim extend as far as Chile?
The argument is not about geography. It is about whether accepting Chile into the group, the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, or APEC, would give a lift to Latin America's most dynamic economy or whether it would just blur the focus of an organization that is trying to define the relationship between East Asia and the United States. 
 Proponents of membership for Chile say that its recent economic reforms, its 10.4 per cent growth rate in 1992 and its relatively open trade policies make it a model for Latin America. They say that membership in the group is a fitting reward for its policies.
"They've done so much for their economy," one Administration official said. "They deserve it."
 
Chilean Request Refused
 But a number of countries in the group -- most notably Australia -- as well as Winston Lord, the influential head of the East Asia and Pacific Affairs Bureau at the State Department, reportedly feel that the organization is primarily intended to facilitate trade between Asia and Oceania and North America. They see a risk that it would lose its focus if too many countries from the Western Hemisphere were admitted.
American officials told an envoy from President Patricio Aylwin of Chile recently that the Clinton Administration would not lobby the group's members in support of Chile's membership.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher told the envoy, Finance Minister Alejandro Foxley, that if a consensus emerged at the Seattle meeting in support of Chile's application, the United States would support it. But American officials said the Administration would not do anything to help build such a consensus, effectively ending Chile's hopes for membership.
"The position of the United States is that they are keeping their neutrality because they are the host country for APEC this year," said a Chilean Government official who insisted on anonymity. "They said they would only consider Chile if there is a consensus."
Though the Chilean request was refused, the Administration is divided over the issue. While members of the National Security Council staff and the East Asia and Pacific Affairs Bureau favor a neutral American stance on Chile's admission, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and the United States Trade Representative, Mickey Kantor, feel the Administration ought to lobby actively in Chile's favor.
Mr. Bentsen contacted Mr. Christopher several times in recent months to plead on behalf of Chile's application, but to no avail.
APEC is a fledgling organization of 15 countries. Its members are Australia, Brunei, Canada, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand and the United States.
Some economists believe the organization may grow into the world's biggest free trade area.
 
Entry of 2 Expected
 At the meeting of APEC foreign and finance ministers, which will begin Wednesday, the organization is expected to approve the membership applications of Mexico and Papua New Guinea. But some members feel that since the organization is only four years old it ought not to take in any more members after those two countries until it decides what direction it should take.
Other countries, like Peru and Russia, have expressed interest in joining, but unlike Chile they have not made a formal request.
Like the other countries in the organization, Chile would not obtain any material benefitis immediately from membership. President Aylwin and other Chilean leaders see membership as a validation of their economic policies and view the organization as a way of linking Chile's economy more directly with that of Asia.
"The important thing in all of this is that we end up with a membership that makes sense and is in keeping with the original motives that brought APEC together in the first place," said Donald Russell, Australia's Ambassador to the United States.
"If the only critiera is that you can see the Pacific from a tall tree in your country, that's not a good enough reason to be a member in APEC."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Self-employment is a growing refuge for many from corporate life in these tough times of layoffs, restructurings and a weak economy. Although many of the self-employed are well-educated, skilled and experienced, they have difficulty matching their old incomes when they go out on their own -- and their reduced buying power weakens the economy. [Page A1.] 
 Investment patterns emerging in the last few weeks indicate that investors are nervous about the recent rise in interest rates and the lofty levels of the stock market. Many investors and money managers say they have taken money out of bond and stock funds, and homeowners are scrambling to lock in mortgage interest rates in case they rise. [D1.]
 
International
When President Clinton and the leaders of the major countries of the Pacific Rim arrive in Seattle later this week, they will find themselves in a land where two worlds from across an ocean are forming a hybrid society. [A1.] One of the issues the leaders will have to deal with is whether the Pacific Rim extends to Chile. [A8.]
North American Free Trade Agreement supporters and opponents stressed the political, economic and diplomatic stakes riding on the outcome of Wednesday's House vote. Vice President Al Gore maintained that "the consequences of a defeat for Nafta in the foreign policy arena would be really catastrophic." Two Democratic leaders who are opposing the trade agreement, Representatives Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and David E. Bonior of Michigan, said approval of the accord would represent a crushing blow to American workers. [A14.] San Antonio has staked much of its future on the trade accord. More than half of all the goods exported from the United States to Mexico passes through the city, and 1.2 million Mexican visitors a year spend $500 million. [A14.]
 
Companies
The chairman of Viacom is confident he can win his fight for Paramount Communications without raising his bid prior to a crucial hearing in Delaware Chancery Court tomorrow, several executives close to Viacom say. [D1.]
A stormy future at United Airlines is one of the few things that seems certain after an attempt by its pilots and machinists unions to gain control of the carrier failed last week. [D1.]
New England Electric System is allowing a leading environmental group to help develop its new 20-year strategic plan. The plan, which is to be announced today in Boston, emphasizes renewable resources like wind power, and will use a wide variety of small-scale generating options and will recycle waste to produce more electricity. [D7.]
 
The Media Business
NBC's deal for Europe's Super Channel suggests that foreign markets are drawing increasing attention from the three big American broadcasting networks. [D1.]
Cable-TV ratings have declined this fall for the first time since cable began its rapid growth in the 1980's. [D10.]
The sale of Macmillan to Paramount sent tremors through the publishing world as authors, agents and editors bemoaned the concentration of power into fewer companies. [D10.]
New York's tabloids began marking their territories in an escalating turf war for readers. William Glaberson: Press. [D10.]
Some experts question the effectiveness of newspapers ads debating the North American trade pact. Advertising. [D12.]
 
 Today's Columns
Balance sheets are looking healthier, but more work is needed to cut debt ratios. Credit Markets. [D1.]
P.& G.'s double-barreled lobbying for a fat substitute could backfire. Teresa Riordan: Patents. [D2.]
Wall Street has rewarded La Quinta Inns' tight strategic focus on traveling salesmen and saleswomen. Market Place. [D8.]

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Balance Sheets Are Healthier

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
It has been slightly more than two years since Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, looked the huge amount of corporate, consumer and government debt in the eye and likened it to a "55-mile-an-hour headwind" buffeting the economy.
But changes in the last 24 months allowed the cautious Mr. Greenspan to state publicly this fall that the problem is about half as bad as it was. 
 Private analysts agree. From Uncle Sam to state and local governments, from corporate America to individuals, balance sheets look better than they have since the late 1980's. But the picture, while improved, is not yet pretty.
"A lot of work has been done, both in issuing new equity and refinancing existing debt, but I think we still have a ways to go," said Neal M. Soss, the chief economist of CS First Boston.
Still, given the magnitude of the problem, some analysts are amazed that so much has been accomplished so quickly.
 
 
'The Miracle Years'
 A couple of years ago, many analysts predicted that it would take the better part of the decade for the private sector to pare back to manageable levels the mountain of debt taken on in the 1980's. Some say that goal has been reached.
"I refer to the 1991-to-1993 period as the miracle years," said James Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, a monthly newsletter. "And the miracle years have produced a sea change in American credit. There has been an important cure, and I think people's perceptions of the corporate financial system and the banking system has lagged behind the reality."
These are some of the encouraging signs that Mr. Grant sees:
*For the first time since 1984, Moody's Investors Service has upgraded the debt ratings of more companies than it has downgraded. Through October, Moody's has upgraded 133 companies and downgraded 129.
*Thanks in large part to the Federal Reserve, which for the last two years has kept an easy hand on monetary policy, banks are making record amounts of money. Equally important, the number of financially troubled banks and other lending institutions, is dwindling rapidly.
*The prolonged run-up in stock prices during the last two years has prompted companies to raise more than $61 billion in equity capital, according to analysts at CS First Boston.
*Consumer debt, which in late 1988 peaked at 19 percent of personal income, fell sharply in 1991 and 1992 and has been hovering at about 16 percent for much of this year. For an economy that is 30 months into a recovery, analysts say it is highly unusual for consumer debt to remain so stable.
 All of these factors are raising eyebrows in some corners of the credit markets. After two years of seeing a seemingly unending string of poor to mediocre reports on the economy, the recent spate of healthy numbers has been unsettling. And while many economists continue to think that a strong fourth quarter will be followed by slower growth next year, some bond traders -- and Mr. Grant -- are not so sure. Better balance sheets are a reason why.
"I would not say this economy is really off to the races," said Gail Fosler, the chief economist at the Conference Board. "But 1994 will be the best year we have had since 1988."
Despite the optimism, there are reasons to suspect that after two years of reliquifying themselves, companies are about to finance expansion in the debt markets.
For one thing, the improvement in credit quality is spotty.
"The biggest areas of improvement have been with banks and with companies that were rated at less than investment grade," said John Lonski, senior economist at Moody's. "Among investment-grade industrial companies, there are still more ratings downgrades than upgrades."
 At the Standard & Poor's Corporation, through the third quarter the number of companies downgraded this year exceeds those whose debt ratings have been raised, although the gap has narrowed.
Still, the improvement masks a dichotomy, said Edward Z. Emmer, executive managing director of S.& P.'s corporate ratings department.
"Even as the number of corporate upgrades has risen, the dollar volume of debt still seems to be weighted heavily to downgrades," he said. "A lot of smaller, speculative companies have had their ratings upgraded. But a lot of big companies, like I.B.M. for example, have been downgraded. And downgrading an I.B.M. impacts a lot of debt."
Further, even though corporate debt as a percentage of total capital has receded from its peak in 1989, when it reached a staggering 48.8 percent, according to Federal Reserve statistics, it remains very high.
Moody's estimates that through the first half of 1993 the debt-to-capital ratio had fallen to 45.8 percent.
 
 
Some Improvements Made
 "We have improved, but we are not down to the levels of debt protection that were in effect at the start of the previous recovery," in the early 1980's, Mr. Lonski said. "We have not yet gotten to the point we were at the outset of the 1980's leveraging phenomenon."
In 1982, as the economy emerged from the deep 1980-81 recession, the corporate debt-to-capital ratio stood at 33.9 percent.
It also remains to be seen if the stock market will be as receptive to new equity offerings as it has been during the last two years.
But given the amount of equity that was retired in the 1980's through stock buybacks, mergers and other corporate transactions, a friendly equity market, as well as faster economic growth, will probably be necessary to repair balance sheets further.
The $61 billion worth of equity capital that had been raised since early 1991 is a big number. But it pales against the $643.7 billion of equity that was retired from 1983 to the first quarter of 1991.
And it is unclear whether, after two years of tidying up, companies think they have done enough.
"There is an element of faddishness in determining what the correct level of debt to equity there should be," said Mr. Soss of CS First Boston. "In the 1980's, it was fashionable to have more debt. So far in the 1990's, it is to have more equity."

HEADLINE: LAND MINES CALLED A WORLD MENACE

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
Thousands of men, women and children in more than 60 countries are killed or maimed each month by land mines, a panel of experts has reported, and unless drastic international action is taken, the casualty rate promises to grow far worse.
According to a 510-page report published last week by the Arms Project, a branch of the research organization Human Rights Watch, some 100 million mines around the world threaten civilians. Moreover, far more mines are being planted each day than are deactivated in mine-clearing operations, so the casualty toll is steadily increasing. 
 In Cambodia alone, where reasonably comprehensive statistics are available, some 30,000 people have lost limbs, most of them because of mines, according to the report.
Although Italy, China and the former Soviet Union have been the major recent suppliers of land mines to a market that pays up to $200 million annually for the devices, some 100 companies and government agencies in 48 countries have been exporting 340 different types of antipersonnel mines.
 
Senator Seeks U.N. Action
 Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, a leader in the movement to curb or abolish the use of these mines, introduced an American resolution in the United Nations on Thursday that would bind nations to halting the export of these weapons.
He said in an interview that the measure appeared to have strong, but not unanimous, international backing. While most of Western Europe seems likely to endorse the resolution, several nations, including Britain, have withheld support. Britain is believed to be reluctant because of contractual obligations it may have to supply arms to countries in the Middle East.
The Senate has agreed to an initiative by Senator Leahy to include a $10 million appropriation in the current defense bill to advise and assist other nations in efforts to clear minefields. The Senate is also expected to approve a three-year extension of a moratorium, in effect for a year, that bans American export of land mines.
But specialists agree that no international agreement will halt the production and use of land mines altogether.
"What we hope to do is to portray antipersonnel mines as even worse than chemical or biological weapons," said Stephen D. Goose, director of the Washington office of the Arms Project. "Mines have certainly killed and maimed far more people than all the victims of chemical, biological and nuclear warfare put together."
 
Economic Impact Cited
 Senator Leahy, who said he discussed mines with President Clinton and Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel at a lunch on Friday, said that in addition to the human tragedy created by mines, the economic impact on the third world is staggering.
"In countries like Cambodia, a single draft animal may be all a farm family has to work its field," he said. "If that animal is killed by a mine while plowing, the family loses everything.
"In Cambodia, they're clearing mines an arm or a leg at a time."
Senator Leahy and others have said the Defense Department has not wholeheartedly supported their efforts.
"The Defense Department argues that the United States manufactures mines that self-destruct, and that since such mines do not pose a long-term danger to civilians, they should not be banned," Senator Leahy said. "We disagree. We must set an example for the rest of the world, much of which is too poor to buy expensive self-destructive mines. Besides, even if only 10 percent of our mines fail to destroy themselves after a given period of time, 10 percent still represents a terrible danger."
 
Clearing Mines Is Difficult
 Clearing minefields becomes more difficult and expensive each year, specialists say. Armies in many poor countries do not bother to map minefields. Mines increasingly are made of wood, plastic and other materials that cannot be located using metal detectors.
Many mines are scattered by helicopters, planes or artillery projectiles, and some, like the Soviet-made PFM-1, look like toys. These weapons, called "butterfly mines," are made of plastic and have little wings that spin them gently to the ground. Many Afghan children have been killed or maimed by picking them up.
"In the Netherlands, people are still being killed by German mines from World War II," Senator Leahy said. "Think how much worse it is in Afghanistan, Cambodia, Angola, Bosnia and all the other countries that have been heavily mined."

HEADLINE: Signs of Investor Nervousness Grow

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
In the last several weeks, Curt Pippen, a semiretired oral surgeon in Glendale, Ariz., has taken three-quarters of his money out of stocks and put it into a less volatile fixed-income mutual fund, where his investments could earn a lot less but are safer.
"I think interest rates are going to be rising and I am not much of a Clinton fan," said Dr. Pippen, 51, adding that he expected stock prices to tumble soon. "In other words, I'm afraid." 
 Dr. Pippen is not the only one worried about losing money, judging from investment patterns emerging in recent few weeks and the batteries of calls some brokers say they have fielded from investors nervous about the recent rise in interest rates and the lofty levels of the stock market.
According to Fidelity Investments, the largest mutual fund operator in the country, the first six days of November saw the largest average daily net inflows into money market funds in three years. Money market funds pay less than 3 percent interest on average, but because the principal is protected they avoid the losses possible in bond and stock funds if the market turns.
"I think it is probably a sign that people are getting cautious," said Roger Servinson, a managing director in charge of retail sales and marketing at Fidelity.
And the movement of money into money market funds is just one indication of investor nervousness. Many investors and money managers say they have taken money out of bond and stock funds, and homeowners are scrambling to lock in interest rates on mortgages in case they rise.
"I think Wall Street is getting very skittish and nervous," said Susan Abuza, a small money manager based in Rye, N.Y., who invests her own money along with that of clients. "I truly believe that the market is going down 150 to 200 points in the next two months," she said, explaining that she has sold a lot of her stocks and built up her cash position.
In part what is driving fears is that the stock rally that began with America's success in the Persian Gulf war and propelled the Dow Jones industrial average to a new closing high of 3,697.64 points this month, has sputtered in recent days. The Dow closed at 3,684.51 on Friday.
The bond rally, which brought long-term yields to 5.78 percent last month, their lowest level in 25 years, has also reversed, causing yields to rise. The yield on the 30-year bond closed at 6.15 percent Friday.
While this year's stock rally has been interrupted before, investors seem to feel particularly vulnerable now, possibly because the rally is already setting new marks for longevity. And any number of events could shake its footing. A defeat of the North American Free Trade Agreement in the House of Representatives this week could send a shudder through the financial markets because of the possible inflationary consequences of rejecting open markets.
And if the stock market teeters, investors will not have the comfortable haven in fixed-income securities that they have had in the past. "Safe" investments like money market funds and Treasury bills are producing so little income that they are quite unattractive.
Despite the uncertainty, some analysts and investors have remained calm. In fact, the flight of some money to safer money market funds has not stopped the move of money into stocks. Some investors still think the market can move higher and others still cannot abide the low single-digit yields in money market funds.
According to AMG Data Services, which tracks mutual funds, the net weekly flows of money into stock mutual funds averaged $3.33 billion for the four weeks ending on Nov. 10. The one-week flow of $1.99 billion was down from the previous week, but that influx, of $5.62 billion, was the highest since the beginning of September.
Those strategists who claim to be optimistic say the expected jump in economic growth to 4 percent in the last quarter of this year -- one of the factors causing uncertainty in the bond and stock markets -- will be temporary. They are betting that inflation will remain low as growth returns to a pace next year of 2.5 to 3 percent.
Long-term interest rates, therefore, could decline in 1994 or, at the worst, hover around 6 percent.
But David Roche, the international strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company in London, is not comfortable betting on this outlook of low inflation and moderate growth. He sees the possibility of two alternatives that would not be good for stocks.
One is a spurt of economic growth above the 3 percent level, which would push interest rates higher and divert a lot of the funds now propping up stock prices. The second is a flat global economy next year, with talk shifting from a concern about the rise in prices to fears of declines.
"This has made me believe I won't be 30 percent richer again," he said, referring to the gain he made when he sold some of his stocks and raised his cash position to 6 percent. "In a six-month view, I can't see myself richer than I am today."
Signs of investor concern can be seen on several fronts. Mortgage lenders say people are rushing to lock in interest rates for fear the bottom has been reached. For instance, Marlene Brown, a food consultant, cookbook writer and recipe developer in Studio City, Calif., said she was looking at a fixed-rate mortgage of 6 7/8 to 7 percent on Halloween, only to see the rate leap to 7 1/2 percent by the following Tuesday.
Rick Crossano, an executive vice president at Countrywide Funding, a large mortgage lender based in Pasadena, Calif., said in the first week of November the average number of mortgage applications filed daily jumped to almost 2,600, up about 400 a day from the month earlier. "There was a lot of panic submitting of applications," he said.
But even on mortgages the signals are mixed. James Wiggins, a vice president in corporate communications at Merrill Lynch, is betting that if there is an increase in interest rates, it will be slight.
"My gut tells me that money in the pocket now is the way to go," said Mr. Wiggins, who is looking for a variable-rate mortgage for a new apartment in Manhattan. "You are taking the risk that interest rates will move up, but if interest rates do move higher they will only move about a percentage point."
Some money managers, like Mrs. Abuza, say clients who have taken higher risk in search of higher returns -- like those who have moved money from the bank to the stock market -- have needed a lot of reassurance in recent days.
 
Safer Ground
 Some investors have moved on to safer ground. The Dreyfus Corporation said it saw the first significant shift into money market funds in two months in the week that ended on Nov. 5. And AMG Data Services found that for the four weeks that ended on Nov. 10, the average weekly inflow into the 1,100 money market funds it follows was $2.61 billion, up from $1.96 billion the week before and the second-highest weekly average in 12 weeks. Money had been pouring out of these funds in September and the first two weeks of October.
At Fidelity, Mr. Servinson said most of the flow into its money market funds came at the expense of the firm's bond funds, where redemptions or sales of investors' holdings have been picking up, probably showing that some investors have decided that longer-term interest rates have hit bottom.
Other investors have taken refuge in international stock funds. Net inflows into these funds in the first six days of the month are at the highest pace of the year at Fidelity, which could signal that more investors want to protect themselves by diversifying into markets where many analysts still think there is a potential for growth or, at least, less potential for a major decline.
With no consensus on the outlook for interest rates and the stock market, some investors may be calm because they are prepared for what might be ahead.
Tom Delnoce, the president of West America Investment Group in Scottsdale, Ariz., who does some work for Dr. Pippen, said, "The people we deal with are not that worried." He sold most of his own stocks in the last several weeks, raising his cash position to 70 percent.
Taking a safer path can be painful. In a world of declining interest rates, traditionally conservative investors have lost the easy decision of buying Treasury securities that offer liveable, if not large, interest rates.
Just a year ago, a five-year Treasury note yielded 5.88 percent. On Friday that was down to 5.01 percent. Two years ago, the yield was 6.63 percent. An investor cannot get that high a yield today with a 30-year Treasury bond, which is at 6.15 percent, although the risk of loss on the longer-term investment is two and a half times that on a five-year note.
As a result, some investors have taken on substantial risk to increase their return potential. They have put money into hybrid or derivative securities -- or mutual funds that buy them -- that offer high returns if interest rates fall. But if rates begin to rise, such securities or funds yield much less and can quickly eat into the principal.
These derivatives are hard for professionals to understand, so regular investors are likely to be surprised by what happens to their money if interest rates do turn up permanently.
The case of Otis Sinnott, a 73-year-old retired export manager from Eastchester, N.Y., shows the bind that many investors feel they are in. Mr. Sinnott has been worrying about what to do with his money in the bank. "I need more income," he said. But he is scared he could lose some of his capital if he buys Treasury notes.
Yet, at the same time, he is loath to withdraw a much greater amount of money from a stock market he knows is at high levels. "If I take the money out, what do I do with it? Put it in the bank earning 1.5 percent?"

HEADLINE: Merchant Marine Sees Its Academy in Peril

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KINGS POINT, L.I., Nov. 13

 BODY:
The Merchant Marine Academy, whose graduates have played a role in every armed conflict involving United States forces since World War II, is now fighting for its own survival.
The battle began when the Clinton Administration, as part of its budget-cutting bill, proposed a sharp cut in financing for the academy. The move would force the school to close unless it breaks with tradition and bills its students $15,000 a year for tuition, academy officials say. 
 Although the threat eased somewhat on Tuesday when the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee voted unanimously to remove the academy proposal from the bill, the matter now faces scrutiny before the House Ways and Means Committee, which is looking for ways to trim the Federal budget deficit.
Students, many of whom say they chose Kings Point in part because of its free tuition, say they are worried about the academy's future and whether they will have to begin footing steep tuition bills.
 
Tuition Shock
 "I'm still recovering from the initial shock," said Trey Howerton, 18, of Tampa, Fla., a member of this year's freshman class of 270 students.
"Somehow I would try to come up with the money," said Mr. Howerton, who said he passed up other offers for full scholarships to attend the academy. "I love this school and would hate to leave, but I know there are many others who would be forced to go because of the financial hardship to their families."
While the final outcome of the battle remains in doubt, so far no one at the academy has heard a single voice in Congress endorse the Administration proposal.
This has encouraged the 960 students now enrolled at the academy. They first learned of the tuition threat on Sept. 7, when Vice President Al Gore put forward 800 recommendations from his National Performance Review, intended to cut the Federal budget by an estimated $108 billion, or 12 percent, by Oct. 1, 1999.
Among the cost-cutting measures was a 50 percent reduction in financing for the Kings Point academy, which would be phased in over five years and save the Federal Government an estimated $45 million.
The Gore commission has questioned the need for a federally financed academy that duplicates the offerings of schools in five coastal states: Maine, Texas, California, Massachusetts and New York. The State University of New York Maritime College, for example, is at Fort Schuyler in the Bronx, across Long Island Sound from Kings Point. The study also questioned the role of the Federal Government in supporting a school that trains professionals for private industry.
 
Academy Called Crucial
 The academy is now celebrating its 50th anniversary. It was founded on Sept. 30, 1943, by President Franklin D. Roosevelt with the mission of providing the American merchant marine, armed forces and transportation industry with professional officers.
Since then, 19,000 graduates have helped to guide merchant vessels flying under the American flag, working as navigators, engineers and ship captains. But the United States merchant marine industry, which had several thousand vessels in the 1950's, has dwindled to fewer than 400 ships amid increasing foreign competition. That decline has raised concern over the United States's dependence of foreign merchant fleets.
Representative Gary L. Ackerman, whose Congressional district includes Kings Point, a neck of land on the Nassau County border that juts out into the Sound, said that although he understood the Administration's desire to cut spending, he did not believe the academy should be a target.
"I believe it's crucial to our national defense to maintain the academy," he said. "What are we going to do in a time of crisis, hire a navy?"
School administrators said the cut in Federal financing would radically change the student body or even mean the closing of the academy. In the immediate future, they said, they feared that the proposal would discourage prospective students.
Mr. Ackerman said an early recommendation by the commission staff that the academy be phased out by 1998 was rejected by the Administration. The panel estimated that closing the academy would save the Government $27 million a year and create revenue through the sale of the 80-acre campus on the former estate of Walter Chrysler, the industrialist.
 
Cutting Budget in Half
 Instead, the report proposed that the academy's budget be cut in half "as an economy measure," leaving the school little choice but to make up the difference by charging tuition. Tuition, room and board at Kings Point have always been free, as they have at the four other service academies.
"So far, I can't think of any member of the House who has spoken in favor of the marine academy proposal," said Suzanne Waldron, spokeswoman for the Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee, which oversees both the Merchant Marine and Coast Guard Academies.
But she said the legislative process could take many twists and turns and that the measure "needs to be watched closely."
The school's operating budget now totals about $30 million a year, said Capt. Robert Safarik, a spokesman for the academy. He estimated that tuition, if necessary, would be around $15,000 a year.
Mr. Ackerman said he was among more than a dozen members of Congress from around the country who were jointly sponsoring legislation that would "prohibit the imposition of additional charges or fees for attendance" at any of the five academies.
Captain Safarik said that it cost $108,000 to train each student at the four-year school, including tuition, board, uniforms and books. Unlike the other military academies, the Merchant Marine Academy requires students to cover personal expenses, and does not give stipends.
 
Proud of Diversity
 Students come to the academy by way of congressional appointments. Each member of Congress can propose 10 students a year. Their qualifications are then judged by admissions officials at the academy. The students, 10 percent of whom are women, are typically 18 to 22 years old and represent many economic backgrounds.
"Any change in the tuition system would have an impact on this diversity, which is our best asset," said Eric Lindberg, 22, a senior. "I can't imagine the members of Congress turning against us."
In return for their education, the graduates of the academy must serve five years on a merchant vessel and eight years in the Naval Reserve.
During their four years at school, cadets spend one year at sea, working on merchant marine vessels while doing independent study projects, with the ship as their classroom.
Mr. Lindberg, who spent his year at sea sailing from port to port along the Pacific Rim, said, "Throughout history, every nation that's been strong economically has had a strong merchant marine."
"Giving the power to other countries to control your commerce is not a good idea," he said. "And once Congress sees this, and gives the academy a fair trial, I truly believe they'll come down on the side of a strong merchant marine."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Clinton Administration, as part of its budget-cutting bill, is seeking to cut financing for the Merchant Marine Academy in Kings Point, L.I. Students say they worry about the academy's future and whether they will have to begin paying to attend the school, which charges no tuition. (Steve Berman for The New York Times)
