HEADLINE: Clinton's Tightrope;
Presidency Takes on Shifting Politics Of U.S. Role in Curbing Violent Crime

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Early this month, President Clinton was chatting with an old friend, Mayor Kurt L. Schmoke of Baltimore, when Mr. Schmoke described his visit to the family of an 18-year-old man who had been killed on Halloween by a 13-year-old acting on a dare.
Around the same time, Mr. Clinton picked up his copy of The Washington Post and read about an 11-year-old girl in a crime-ridden neighborhood who was planning her own funeral, down to the prom dress she would be buried in. 
 As Mr. Clinton has gone about the business in recent weeks of scraping together enough votes to try to pass the North American Free Trade Agreement and assembling a working majority for his health care plan, these episodes and others have been weighing on his mind, aides said.
The topic has bubbled up in unexpected places, during strategy meetings in the Oval Office, in speeches about other topics, on talk shows and in dinners at the White House with scholars like William Julius Wilson, who wrote "The Truly Disadvantaged," a book about the decline of the black family.
 
'It's an Outer Class'
 Mr. Clinton has even coined a phrase to describe the plight of people who are caught in the cycle of joblessness, crime, violence and despair.
"It's not an underclass anymore," he said last weekend. "It's an outer class."
So with little warning and few notes, Mr. Clinton's growing concern about crime, violence and the dilemmas that face children growing up in urban areas came tumbling out into the laps of a church full of momentarily stunned ministers on Saturday.
They did not stay stunned for long. The ministers, many of whom had been saying the same thing for years in exhortations to their congregations, began to applaud. Then they began shouting back in support.
The politics of crime, once dominated by law-and-order politicians of both parties, have been shifting in recent months, as shown in election results, opinion polls and a new willingness in Congress to consider measures like gun control. Mr. Clinton's speech may reflect that. But by changing the terms in which crime is debated, Mr. Clinton may further change the political equation on the subject as well.
It is significant that Mr. Clinton was standing in the pulpit of a black church when he let loose his torrent of words on crime, violence and the responsibility of black leaders to confront the problems plaguing their communities. Mr. Clinton has often been moved to Scripture and sermonizing when he is speaking at a church, where he is often preaching to the previously converted.
The setting also underscored the tightrope Mr. Clinton must walk on both the policy and politics of this issue. The anti-crime measure now before the Senate, which he is supporting, contains many of the same tough-on-crime elements -- including measures to limit the right of death penalty inmates to sentencing appeals -- that offended liberal Democrats when the Bush Administration supported them. He has also been outspoken in recent months on the subject of gun control, long anathema to conservatives.
And when he makes the delicate link between race and crime as he did implicitly by choosing an audience of black ministers this weekend, he must also tread carefully to avoid slipping into stereotype.
 
Pulpit of the Presidency
 The President concedes that the most a national leader can do to address inherently local issues like violent crime and its relationship to poverty is to use the pulpit of the Presidency to spread a message of hope and responsibility. He has called it a "moral duty."
"I think the President has a pulpit -- Teddy Roosevelt's bully pulpit -- that I have to use and work hard on and try to live by to try to help rebuild the conditions of family and community and education and opportunity," Mr. Clinton said during a White House news conference last week.
Although most senior officials at the White House have been preoccupied with Mr. Clinton's latest high-wire legislative battle over the trade agreement, few were surprised when he dispensed with the issue early in his speech on Saturday and focused instead on crime and violence.
"Washington's kind of a trap," said Stanley Greenberg, the President's pollster. "In the context of Washington, it's hard to be a social critic. So this has been building up."
Mr. Clinton, the aides said, had been searching for a way to climb into his pulpit on this issue for some time. Since the Administration introduced its health care plan, Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary, have made frequent references to the connection between skyrocketing health care costs and the expense of caring for the victims of urban violence.
The President has wrapped the issue into his call for greater national security, linking it with the need for economic revival and expansion. And he quoted the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York and the comedian Bill Cosby on the subject, all the while stressing that most people in poor neighborhoods "never break the law, work for a living for modest wages, pay their taxes" and are "trying to do the right thing by their kids."
"We have to rebuild families and communities in this country," Mr. Clinton said during a recent news conference that was intended to promote the trade agreement. "We've got to take more responsibility for these little kids before they grow up and start shooting each other. We have to find ways to offer hope and reconnect people."
 
Personalizing the Issue
 Finding new ways to talk about crime could have benefits on other issues as well. Representative Charles E. Schumer, the Brooklyn Democrat who heads a House subcommittee on criminal justice, said, "Crime has been transformed from an issue that generally divides Democrats into one that unites them."
"It's a strong issue in the inner city," Mr. Schumer added. "It's a strong issue in Utah. And the solutions as to what to do about it are less ideological and more about resources and focus."
Mr. Clinton has seized on the universality of worries about crime, and he has personalized it as a way of signaling to Americans that he is as affected as they are by the headlines they see every day.
Mr. Clinton has also assigned a group of senior aides to devise a comprehensive list of suggestions about how the White House can speak to the issue. The group includes Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros; Peter B. Edelman, a Deputy Secretary at the Department of Health and Human Services; Carol Rasco and Bruce Reed of the White House Domestic Policy Council; Roy Neel, the deputy chief of staff, and Mark D. Gearan, the White House communications director.
But Mr. Clinton's advisers are quick to point out that the President is not planning to call for any huge new infusions of Federal spending to address the problems he sees. In his discussions on the subject, the President almost always doubles back to emphasize the need to depend on personal responsibility to resolve social ills.
"We're dealing with pervasive questions," said Mandy Grunwald, an adviser to the President. "You cannot look to the Federal Government alone for a solution. This is about everybody taking responsibility."

HEADLINE: Wage Proposal May Hurt Affordable Housing, Critics Say

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
A proposed amendment to a New York State labor law scheduled for a vote in the Assembly this week would deal a severe blow to the development of affordable housing throughout the state, housing advocates say.
The amendment seeks to broaden the definition of public works to include all private projects that benefit from public subsidies like grants, tax breaks or low-interest mortgages. The state's labor law already requires that workers on public projects be paid what is known as "prevailing wage," which usually amounts to the standard union wage. A similar bill has already passed in the Senate. 
 Critics of the proposal say housing production could drop by 35 percent or more.
"The changes would cripple New York City's affordable housing programs," said Joseph Rose, executive director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, a policy research and advocacy organization. "The Legislature would put unbearable cost and administrative burdens on a remarkably successful effort to address the critical housing shortage by leveraging private capital."
 
Two Key Subsidy Programs
 Virtually all privately built, low- and moderate-income housing is developed with some public subsidies. The state has been putting about $25 million each year into two key housing subsidy programs, the Affordable Home Ownership program and the Housing Trust Fund. Over the last four years New York City has invested about $2 billion in renovation and reconstruction of rental housing, mostly in partnership with private, nonprofit and for-profit development organizations. Developers are able to charge tenants less than the market rate because, in large part, because they pay wages below the union scale.
Housing advocates say these private-public partnerships have been responsible for the construction of tens of thousands of new and rehabilitated units over the last decade.
But union officials say the line between public and private projects has blurred over the years. Assemblyman Frank J. Barbaro, a Brooklyn Democrat who is one of the sponsors of the Assembly bill, said: "It is standard in public projects for contracts to go the lowest qualified bidder. But it is only prevailing-wage rules that keep the low bidder from paying unreasonably low wages."
 
Difference in Projects
 Alexander B. Grannis, a Manhattan Democratic Assemblyman, supports a clarification of labor law as it pertains to public projects, but not the existing version of the Assembly bill. "There is a difference between construction projects like schools, prisons and bridge and road repair work and privately built and privately owned affordable housing," he said.
Senator James J. Lack, the bill's Senate sponsor, a Republican from Suffolk County, has said he would agree to an exemption for affordable housing. Minority contractors maintain the bill would hurt them because it has been the community-based projects that have given them a toehold in the construction industry. They say they would loose their competitive edge if they had to pay union wages.
Kathryn Wylde, president of the New York City Housing Partnership, a nonprofit organization that has assisted in the development of some 9,000 homes sold to moderate-income buyers, says the trade unions are trying to force their way into a segment of the industry that, despite a languishing construction environment, remains active.
"For the past decade this level of residential construction work has been labeled cockroach work by the unionized trades," she said. "Now with high-rise development in recession, the union wants to take this work."
 
Not Aimed at Unions
 Edward J. Malloy, president of the New York State Building Trades Council, said the law was not designed to put more union workers on these jobs. "So many exceptions have been made to the prevailing-wage law," he said, "that it does not mean anything. We're not saying that all jobs have to use union workers, but that whoever works should be paid prevailing wages and benefits."
Typical of the privately built, publicly subsidized housing projects in New York City are those that take part in the city's Participating Loan Program. A building's owner gets about 70 percent of the construction financing for renovation from the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development. The current interest rate is 1 percent. The balance of the construction loan would comes from conventional financing. When the work is completed, the city places limits on the rents.
On such jobs, contractors now pay about $9 to $12 an hour for basic labor like demolition work, and up to $20 to $24 an hour for licensed skilled workers like plumbers and electricians. If union wages were required on these projects, developers say, the labor costs would more than double.
"Most development costs are fixed," said Sir James L. Robinson, an architect and developer who has used city subsidies to rebuild multifamily housing in neighborhoods like Harlem. "Whether you are talking a bout Park Avenue or elsewhere in the city, one of the mechanisms to control costs is to control the labor rate."
 
'Will Be Fewer Projects'
 Michael D. Lappin, president of the Community Preservation Corporation, a private, nonprofit lender for housing redevelopment in low-income neighborhoods, said, "Since public money is limited and tenants can't be expected to pay more, there will be fewer projects."
Proposals to amend the labor law never survived a vote in either house until July. In the closing hours of the legislative session the Senate gave its unanimous approval to a bill that mirrors the one now before the Assembly.

Critics say production of homes for low- and moderate-income residents will drop by 35 percent because of the higher wages. Non-union workers are building new homes for moderate-income buyers in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. (Nancy Siesel/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD;
Both Sides Emphasize High Stakes of Trade Vote

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Just three days before the decisive vote in Congress on the North American Free Trade Agreement, supporters and opponents today stressed the political, economic and diplomatic stakes riding on the outcome.
Vice President Al Gore maintained that "the consequences of a defeat for Nafta in the foreign policy arena would be really catastrophic." 
 Another proponent, Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, said, "To defeat Nafta endangers this Presidency."
But two Democratic leaders who oppose the trade agreement, Representatives Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and David E. Bonior of Michigan, said approval of the accord would represent a crushing blow to American workers.
 
Politically Important Vote
 "I believe this agreement will lower our wages for workers who have jobs in this country," Mr. Bonior said. He added that he expected 500,000 American jobs to move to Mexico under the accord because companies relished the lower pay and looser environmental regulations south of the border.
The House of Representatives is scheduled to vote on Wednesday on legislation that would put the trade agreement into effect. Politically, it is the most important vote remaining this year for President Clinton and Congress.
The President probably has the most to lose.
"He will be seen to have prevailed on a very tough vote, and it will help his Presidency if he does win," said Representative Vic Fazio, a California Democrat who supports the pact. "It will hurt his Presidency if he does not win because people are going to evaluate his ability to organize a majority."
Mr. Fazio, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, which raises money and otherwise supports Democratic candidates for Congress, was interviewed by telephone last week. On television interview shows today, both sides predicted victory.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," "I'm not going to predict how many, but we'll win."
On the same program, Mr. Bonior, the House Democratic whip, who has the responsibility for keeping track of how colleagues plan to vote, said the opponents had "about 222 votes going into this weekend."
There is one vacant seat in the 435-seat House. If all members vote, 218 votes will be needed to pass the measure.
 
Counts Unreliable
 Over a decade, the accord would abolish all tariffs and other trade barriers on 99 percent of the goods traded between the United States, Mexico and Canada, creating the largest free-trade zone in the world.
If the House, which votes first on tax and tariff issues, approves the legislation, the Senate is expected to follow quickly with its approval. If the House rejects the measure, the treaty will die, and there will be no need for a Senate vote.
The Associated Press reported today that its survey of all congressional offices found 204 Representatives opposed to the measure or leaning toward opposition, 176 in favor or leaning toward support and 54 with unannounced positions. A survey last week by The New York Times with the assistance of Washington Trade Daily, an independent newsletter, had similar findings.
But vote counts at this stage are unreliable. Many legislators clearly have made a commitment to vote for the agreement only if their votes become essential to the passage of the measure. Otherwise, they will vote against it.
The best bet is that Mr. Clinton will either prevail by a few votes , -- perhaps by only one or two, as was the case on the budget legislation last summer -- or lose by 30 or 40 votes after lawmakers are released from their commitment to support the White House.
Two previously undeclared Democrats came out in favor of the trade agreement today: Maria Cantwell of Washington and Karen Shepherd of Utah. Ms. Cantwell's announcement in her district in Seattle came just before Ross Perot led a rally there in opposition to the accord.
 
Calls to Lawmakers
 The outcome now seems to rest on the votes of about two dozen undecided representatives, divided about evenly between the two parties. The White House said Mr. Clinton spent much of today calling those lawmakers and asking for their votes.
Using a strategy that Presidents since Richard M. Nixon have employed, the White House arranged for the House vote to come just before Mr. Clinton leaves for an important international conference -- in this case, a meeting on economic matters next weekend in Seattle with the heads of the governments of 15 Asian nations. The meeting is under the auspices of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, known as APEC.
This strategy allows the White House to argue that defeating the free trade pact would weaken the President's hand in the eyes of foreign leaders. Mr. Gore made that case today on the CBS News program "Face the Nation," throwing out acronyms like a juggler tossing clubs.
"The President goes out to the APEC conference the day after the Nafta vote," Mr. Gore said. "The other countries in the world that are looking at this GATT negotiation are just waiting to see whether or not we have the courage of our convictions."
GATT stands for the the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the worldwide trade talks.
 
Side Agreements Assailed
 Mr. Bonior took issue with the view that approval of a trade pact with Canada and Mexico would strengthen Mr. Clinton's case in international negotiations.
He observed that to win votes, especially from the Florida congressional delegation, Mr. Clinton had approved special trade restrictions for imports of citrus fruits, vegetables, sugar and other commodities, just when the United States was trying to persuade European countries to stop protecting agricultural products.
And he complained that the Mexican Government had a weak record on human rights, while the United States was telling China and other nations that human rights should be a condition of open trade relations.
Debating Mr. Bradley head to head, Mr. Bonior (pronounced BON-yer) said: "This is supposed to be a free trade agreement? How are we going to deal with GATT when this is over with? What are we going to tell the French? We're just going to tell the French when this is over with, 'Well, you know, we just cut this deal on sugar. We cut it on wheat. We cut it on citrus.'
"How are we going to deal with the Chinese? When the President, the day after the vote, goes over and talks to the Asians, is he going to say, 'Well, we really didn't mean the democratization concerns we had with you and Singapore and other countries'?"
Unlike the debate last Tuesday night between Mr. Gore and Mr. Perot, which turned on personalities and one-liners, Mr. Bradley and Mr. Bonior stuck to substance and argued their cases in a tone of mutual respect.
Mr. Bradley called the vote "a historic moment" and continued: "This is not a vote that's going to come again next year or the year after. This is a one-time vote. I think you can parallel this to when Thomas Jefferson decided to buy Louisiana, when Seward and Johnson bought Alaska, when Harry Truman decided to reject isolationism and engage the world with greater trade and higher living standards around the world."

HEADLINE: Patents

BYLINE: By Teresa Riordan

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
PROCTER & GAMBLE may have been overly earnest in lobbying for patent extensions on Olestra, its long-languishing no-calorie fat substitute.
On Wednesdaythe Senate passed an authorization bill for the Patent and Trademark Office. Tacked on were provisions that would extend until Dec. 31, 1997, two Olestra patents due to expire in January and one that will expire in July. 
 The trouble is that Procter & Gamble lobbied not only Congress but also the Administration. Its two-pronged approach could backfire, giving the patents extensions two years shorter than those in the Senate bill.
In lobbying the executive, P. & G. called on Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld, a law firm whose partners include Vernon Jordan Jr., the former Clinton transition chief. Procter & Gamble said that this fall its chief executive, Edwin L. Artzt, met with Robert Rubin, the Presidential economic adviser and former Wall Street executive, and that its president, John E. Pepper, met with Commerce Secretary Ron Brown, whose department oversees the patent office.
 
'There to Share Information'
 "They were there to share information on Olestra," said Wendy Jacques, a P. & G. spokeswoman .
Procter & Gamble acknowledged that Mr. Jordan had met with company officials before but said that he had played no role in setting up the Olestra meetings with the Administration.
"Mr. Jordan does not lobby," said Joel Jankowsky, an Akin, Gump partner and spokesman.
Procter & Gamble says it spent $200 million developing Olestra, a fat-like substance that passes through the body without being absorbed, but that the long approval process has rendered its patents virtually worthless.
A report by the General Accounting Office two years ago agreed that Olestra faced extraordinary regulatory difficulties but also said that some of the delay had been of P. & G.'s own making.
The first Olestra patent, granted in 1971, expired in 1988. The three current ones were granted more than 17 years ago. P. &G. tried from 1975 to 1985 to get Food and Drug Administration approval for Olestra as a drug, which would have let it advertise its health benefits. After tests showed that it did not substantially lower cholesterol levels, the company sought its approval as a food additive. It is currently focusing on its use in snack foods like potato chips and corn chips.
 
Few Extensions Enacted
 In the last decade Congress has enacted at most a half-dozen extensions on patents, which normally have a life span of 17 years.
The Clinton Administration said it would not endorse patent extensions specific to Olestra. Instead, patent extension legislation drafted by the patent office would apply generically to companies in positions similar to P.& G.'s. According to someone familiar with the generic legislation who requested anonymity, Mr. Rubin's office initiated and monitored its formulation.
Michael K. Kirk, assistant commissioner of patents for external affairs, would not say whether Mr. Rubin's office had participated in drafting the legislation. He acknowledged that "Procter & Gamble did come in and talk to us," but said that "we have a long-standing aversion to what we refer to as private relief bills."
Late last month Representative William J. Hughes, Democrat of New Jersey and chairman of the Judiciary Committee's subcommittee on intellectual property, held hearings on new "generic fix" legislation that incorporated the patent office's draft legislation.
 
10-Year Extensions Sought
 The generic legislation would potentially give the Olestra patents a two-year extension rather than the three and a half and four years provided in the Senate measure. Neither is anything near the 10 years that Procter & Gamble originally sought.
The Senate measure has yet to be acted on by Mr. Hughes's subcommittee.
Mr. Hughes said that while he was sympathetic to Procter & Gamble's plight he was not sure whether he would approve the Senate measure as it stood.
"We may substitute the generic fix" for the specific Olestra provisions, he said. "Whatever we do, we're planning to resolve this" before Nov. 22, when Congress is supposed to recess.
Theoretically, Mr. Hughes also could do nothing, rolling the legislation into next year's session, which will not begin until late January. Such a turn of events could be disastrous for Procter & Gamble. If its patents expire before any extension legislation is enacted, relief will be highly unlikely, since Congress virtually never resurrects expired patents.
 
A Data Base For Living Wills
 Victor Alan Perry, an insurance defense lawyer in Reno, said he began thinking about a "system for administering a central depository for living wills" after reading in a newspaper article that more than $10 billion a year was spent for artificial life support of people who did not wish to be kept alive.
"That's an incredible amount of money, and it's probably a lot more when you consider that a lot more probably haven't committed their wishes to writing," he said.
Mr. Perry said that living wills and durable powers of attorney for health care often could not be found at the appropriate time or had not been properly notarized. Initially he envisions that the system would be accessible to doctors and hospitals through an "800" number. The service would immediately fax a copy of the appropriate document for a given patient, Mr. Perry said.
Ultimately, the system would take the form of an on-line service accessible by computer modem, he said..
Mr. Perry said he had written Hilary Rodham Clinton about the idea but had received no response.
Mr. Perry, Paul F. Oelsner, and Grant P. Anderson were granted patent 5,241,466.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Foreign Horizons Lure U.S. Broadcast Networks

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Before it was acquired by NBC in early October, Super Channel, a pan-European broadcaster, struck Patrick Cox as a bewildering mishmash of paid religious programming, rock videos, news and home shopping.
But Mr. Cox, the managing director of NBC's operations in Europe, also saw a great opportunity. So, along with NBC programming executives from the United States, he tossed much of the junk from the broadcaster's schedule. He began improving the more promising of the existing shows, especially those that focused on European culture, business and news. He is stirring in liberal quantities of NBC programming from the United States, including "The Tonight Show with Jay Leno," the "NBC Nightly News" and the "Today" show. 
 The result, NBC executives hope, is a broadcaster with a strong appeal to affluent, well-educated and internationally minded viewers across Western Europe, where Super Channel is seen in 30 million homes and most hotels via cable and satellite.
With the political changes, new technology and deregulation creating broadcasting opportunities all over the world, international markets have long drawn the interest of program producers from the United States, as well as cable networks like CNN.
 
 
Increased Attention
 But now, as NBC's deal for Super Channel suggests, foreign markets are also drawing increasing attention from the three big broadcast networks. CBS has largely limited its participation to stepping up sales of its news programming abroad. But NBC has started a 24-hour news service for Latin America, is discussing a 24-hour business news service in Asia and is looking for other deals in Europe and around the world.
Capital Cities/ABC Inc., the parent of ABC, owns stakes in broadcasters and program producers in Europe and in sports networks in Europe and Asia. Last month it created a new corporate division, the ABC Cable and International Broadcast Group, in recognition of the growing prospects for expansion abroad.
"We recognize that international development and investment will be a primary area of growth for the company as we capitalize on our current solid positioning in Europe, Latin America and the Pacific rim," Daniel B. Burke, the chief executive of the company, said in announcing the creation of the new division.
Broadcasting executives said Asia was perhaps the most promising market in the long run, given its huge population and rapid economic development. But for now, most of their investments are in Europe, where the dismantling of the traditional state broadcasting monopolies and rapid growth of cable and satellite television have set off a chase among domestic and foreign broadcasters for financing, programming, advertisers and viewers.
"The media markets of Europe are at the same points of development as the U.S. a decade ago," said Thomas S. Rogers, executive vice president of new business development at NBC. "There's all kinds of growth potential going forward that we can be major participants in."
Profits are not likely to come easily, or quickly. Television viewers across Europe, most of whom were accustomed to watching only two or three channels, have over the last several years been confronted with a rapid proliferation of choices.
National broadcasters, both state-owned and private, are beefing up program quality and becoming more responsive to popular tastes. Cable and satellite operators such as BSkyB, partly owned by Rupert Murdoch, have blanketed Europe with news, movies, sports and general entertainment channels. CNN, while struggling to attract advertising, has invested heavily in an international version of its news service.
To the extent they rely on their own news and entertainment programs for their operations in Europe, the networks also face a cultural and political backlash. Led by France, a number of countries are stepping up their complaints about "cultural imperialism" and seeking to restrict imported programming, especially from the United States.
France and Belgium, for example, earlier this fall barred the Turner Broadcasting System's TNT and Cartoon Network from cable networks in their countries, saying the network violated the European Community rules that require broadcasters to carry a majority of European-produced programming "where practical."
 
Indigenous Investments
 ABC has sought to sidestep some of the political issues by taking stakes in existing European television companies. It has bought a third of Hamster, a French program maker; a 25 percent stake in Tesauro, a Spanish producer; half of Molinare, a group of production companies based in London, and half of Tele-Munchen, a producer based in Munich.
Through Tele-Munchen, ABC owns a stake in RTL-2, a German broadcaster. And through its ESPN subsidiary, it owns a third of Eurosport, the largest sports network in Europe. It also recently took a small stake in a cable system operator in Britain.
"We think we will grow as the industry grows, first in Europe and then in South America and then in Asia," said Herbert A. Granath, the president of the new international division of Capital Cities/ABC.
 
A Hybrid Network
 With Super Channel, NBC has adopted a different strategy. By taking a majority stake in the broadcaster -- the remainder is owned by Credit Lyonnais, the French bank -- and assuming full management control, the company is the first to attempt a full-scale European-American hybrid network. NBC did not disclose the purchase price for its stake, but industry executives in Europe said the network was believed to have paid about $25 million.
NBC said the deal was attractive because there were no other opportunities to acquire a pan-European broadcaster with the kind of distribution enjoyed by Super Channel. Mr. Rogers said Super Channel was losing money, but it could be turned around in two or three years.
NBC's strategy is to mix European and American programming, with an emphasis on news, news magazines and programming with an appeal to sophisticated Europeans, primarily business executives. Super Channel, which will likely be renamed before NBC introduces its new program lineup in December, is broadcast simultaneously in English, German and Dutch, depending on where it is being shown. The NBC programming that is added will be dubbed or subtitled.
The challenge for NBC, industry executives here said, will be to provide viewers with programming they are interested in that is not available from their domestic broadcasters, and do so without having so much of an American flavor that European viewers are turned off.
"Getting the mix right is a question of good broadcasting, which we are pretty skillful at," said Mr. Cox, a Briton who grew up in France. "We'll spend a lot on research to make sure we are listening to the audience."

HEADLINE: Trade Center Mysteries Deepen;
Trial Raises Tantalizing Issues but Leaves Them Unresolved

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
The mysteries have begun to pile up: two shadowy figures who returned to Iraq after the World Trade Center was bombed; a Domino's pizza worker traveling long distance on first-class airline tickets; altered passports; fake I.D. papers; bomb-making manuals.
All are elements in the World Trade Center bombing trial, which finished its sixth week of testimony last week. But while the mysterious Iraqis and the forged passports have been mentioned in the Government's case against the four defendants, there has been very little clear explanation of their meaning, or how they tie together. 
 Bound by rules of evidence, limited to the specific criminal activities attributed to the four defendants, the trial has so far had the perverse effect of deepening, rather than resolving, some of the more persistent mysteries of the World Trade Center attack.
Who, if anyone, supplied the forged documents? Did the defendants act alone or were they supported by another group, or perhaps a foreign Government? And above all, what was their motive?
"In reading all the accounts of the trial, what strikes me is that something is missing," said Bruce Hoffman, a terrorism specialist at the Rand Corporation, a research institute. "An incomplete picture is emerging. It's harder than ever to put it in a wider context of why these particular guys on their own would have done this."
On trial are four men -- Mohammed A. Salameh, Nidal A. Ayyad, Mahmud Abouhalima, and Ahmad M. Ajaj -- accused of having conspired to make and transport the bomb that exploded in the World Trade Center on Feb. 26, killing six people and causing millions of dollars in damages. The case focuses on law enforcement, on the evidence against the defendants, which, since no one actually saw any of them plant the bomb, is largely circumstantial.
And that means that many questions will be raised and then left unanswered. For example, there are the various fake passports that have surfaced in the case. Mr. Ajaj, a Palestinian who worked at a pizza place in Houston, was found to be carrying four passports -- as well as six manuals on bomb-making and other elements of warfare -- when he came to the United States from Pakistan last Sept. 1. In addition to his real Jordanian passport, Mr. Ajaj was carrying Swedish, British and Saudi Arabian passports, under different names.
Where did a 26-year-old refugee get four passports? What did he intend to do with them? How did he have the money to be traveling on a $2,500 first-class ticket from Pakistan? Who gave him the military manuals? The questions suggest themselves, but because the prosecutors do not have to prove anything beyond that the defendants conspired to blow up the building, the trial does not promise to get into the answers.
But the trial has produced plenty of hints about the existence of a kind of penumbra of terrorism far larger than the four men accused of actually carrying out the blast. Indeed, some experts have concluded that the four men, if they were responsible for the attack at all, were likely only foot soldiers following the commands of higher-ranking plotters elsewhere.
Some specialists speculate, for example, that Iraq may have ultimately been behind the attack, though they say there is no clear proof.
Central to the theory is the role played by two Iraqis in the case, who have been indicted in the bombing but who fled the country after the explosion. One is Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, who arrived in the United States on Sept. 1 last year on the same plane as Mr. Ajaj. He was holding an Iraqi passport but no American visa. He was nonetheless allowed to enter the country when he applied for political asylum.
Six months later, right after the bombing, Mr. Yousef, whose fingerprints were on the military manuals in Mr. Ajaj's possession and who is believed by the authorities to have helped build the bomb, fled the country and is believed by investigators to have returned to Iraq, although his present whereabouts are unknown.
The other Iraqi is Abdul Rahman Yasin, who was questioned by the F.B.I. after the bombing, and then he, too, left the country, also going to Iraq, according to a family friend.
 
How Much Did Iraq Know?
 Terrorism experts are struck by the fact that two Iraqis came to the country a few months before the bombing and both then reportedly returned to Iraq after it. Given the tight control of Iraq by the regime of Saddam Hussein, it seems to some experts unlikely that Mr. Yousef and Mr. Yasin could have carried out their activities without the knowledge of the Iraqi authorities.
"It's almost inconceivable, given the nature of Iraqi society, that somebody could be involved in an act as dramatic as the W.T.C. bombing and then go back to Iraq, unless it were done under Iraqi direction," said Laurie Mylroie, a scholar at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy. "It's a totalitarian state."
And if the Iraqi authorities did know of their activities, could the attack on the trade center have been, at least in part, an officially approved act of vengeance against the United States for the bombing of Baghdad during the Gulf war?
 
No Clear Conclusions
 But other clues make it impossible to draw clear conclusions. There is, for one thing, the upcoming trial of 15 Muslim men, grouped around a blind Egyptian-born cleric, Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, who are accused of plotting to bomb several targets in New York, including the United Nations and the Hudson River tunnels. The indictment indicates that the plots were thwarted before they could be carried out.
Transcripts of tapes of conversations between F.B.I. agents and an informer, Emad Salem, who infiltrated the group around Mr. Abdel Rahman, show further intriguing international connections and ambitions.
Mr. Salem, for example, told one of his F.B.I. handlers that Mr. Abdel Rahman had contacts with representatives of Hamas, the extreme Palestinian organization, in Pakistan, and even seemed able to give orders to Hamas members playing some undisclosed role in the Afghanistan war.
Mr. Salem also says that Mr. Abdel Rahman gave orders to his followers to assassinate the Egyptian President, Hosni Mubarak, during an official visit to the United States last year, though the plot was dropped when Mr. Mubarak failed to make an expected visit to New York.
Perhaps, some experts say, Iraqi agents used the group around Mr. Abdel Rahman to enable them to carry out their purposes, at the same time supplying the men for whom Mr. Abdel Rahman was a spiritual guide with the means to carry out objectives of their own.
But while Mr. Abdel Rahman and some of the other defendants in the two terror cases are deeply religious Muslims with a religiously inspired hatred of Mr. Mubarak, they are, at the same time, not believed to be friendly to the regime of Mr. Hussein, who is one of the most secular of the major Arab leaders.
 
Tantalizing Hints
 The trial itself, which is to continue today in spite of what apparently were suicide attempts last week by Mr. Ajaj and by a defendant in the upcoming case, has focused on the clues gathered from the trade center rubble and the movements of figures like Mr. Ajaj and Mr. Yousef. As it does so, it throws off tantalizing hints of other matters and then drops them before coming up with answers.
Among the biggest question is why people like the four defendants, newly established in the United States and working hard to build better lives for themselves and their families, would have become involved in terrorism against their new country.
Here, too, various specialists have offered various explanations: that they were motivated by religious fervor, that they were manipulated, or perhaps paid, by foreign intelligence agents. But, because few if any of the defendants are expected to take the stand, it is not likely that those questions will be put directly to them in the courtroom.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's financings this week are confined to short maturities beginning with today's auction of new three- and six-month bills, and the auction of a new 52-week bill tomorrow.
Traders said that at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 3.09 percent, and the rate on the six-month issue was 3.22 percent. The rate on the one-year maturity was 3.37 percent.

HEADLINE: Weapon-Sale Loans Keep Americans Working;
Risky Business

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"No Loans to Boost Arms Sales (editorial, Nov. 3) deserves all support. As you point out, it is neither in the long-term security interests of the United States, nor is it morally justified, to encourage defense contractors with United States tax dollars (that is, with loan guarantees) to export weapons to countries that could then turn those same weapons against United States troops. 
 Further, with the United States already the largest arms exporter to the third world, the provision of loan guarantees to importing countries will further undermine any prospects for international control.
Rather than support policies that would lead to an arms trade free for all, the Senate needs to demonstrate its support for a more principled approach to this serious problem.
Given that the United States and European Community are now responsible for some 86 percent of arms-transfer agreements to the third world (1992 figures), effective control of this trade can only come about through coordinated action on both sides of the Atlantic. Such action will require the United States and European Community governments to agree on clearly defined criteria governing arms exports, supported by mandatory consultation before exports take place.
An important tool to insure effective coordination between the United States and European Community would be adoption of an international code of conduct on arms exports. Besides defining clear criteria, a code would allow parliaments, the news media and nongovernmental organizations to monitor governmental actions against objective standards.
Thus, the code would increase government accountability in this field and insure that regional security and human rights considerations are assessed alongside short-term economic benefits.
Support for a code of conduct on arms exports has been expressed by the European Parliament, the German Bundesrat and the Irish Government. Moreover, legislative bills based on a code are to be presented before both United States houses this month.
 
RAJ THAMOTHERAM
Bristol, England, Nov. 5, 1993
 
The writer directs Saferworld, a think tank concerned with international conflict.

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD;
San Antonio's Wild About Free Trade

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN ANTONIO, Nov. 12

 BODY:
More than half of all the goods exported from anywhere in the United States to Mexico pass through San Antonio. Two hundred companies based here, with 65,000 workers, have major business in Mexico. About 1.2 million Mexican visitors come here each year, spending $500 million.
And, as Mayor Nelson Wolff puts it, "I have only one picture of a president in my office, and it's President Salinas." 
 So if there is any major city in America that has reason to watch with anxiety over the possibility that Congress may reject the North American Free Trade Agreement, it is San Antonio, a city that has staked much of its future on the trade accord and that city leaders like to portray as a kind of Hong Kong to Mexico's China -- a city poised to take off as a banking, trading and shipping hub in a new world of trade without barriers.
The enthusiasm here for the trade agreement is palpable, not just among political and commercial leaders but also among many workers, whose jobs are already tied to Mexican trade. As the House of Representatives prepares to vote on the trade pact on Wednesday, a city delegation led by Mayor Wolff will be in Washington for the last few days of the debate, its fifth pro-agreement lobbying trip this year.
Even the chief A.F.L.-C.I.O. official here says he agrees that the pact, which would gradually eliminate tariffs and other trade barriers between Canada, Mexico and the United States, would clearly benefit San Antonio. But he hastens to add that he still opposes it because he shares the view of the labor federation's national leadership that there would be a net loss of jobs in the country as a whole.
Others who are wholeheartedly in favor of the agreement say they are struggling to understand how the pact became so controversial.
"I'm dumbfounded, to tell you the truth," said Al Silva, general manager of Labatt Food Service, a $120 million-a-year food-distribution company that recently began a venture in Mexico City with a warehouse that serves about 50 hotels and restaurants there.
"Three or four years ago, it wouldn't have occurred to me that Mexico would go this far to break down its barriers," Mr. Silva said. "Now they're ready to drop the last barrier, and we're rebuffing them."
"We're taught to believe in free enterprise and free markets," he said. Referring to the President of Mexico, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, Mr. Silva added: "I might have believed it if Salinas said, 'Only kidding, we're not going to do it.' But I never would have believed that we would be the ones to put our own wall up."
 
Transportation Hub
 San Antonio, now the 10th largest city in the United States with a population of about one million, finds itself so entwined with Mexico for both geographical and cultural reasons. It is a major juncture for both interstate highways and rail lines leading to Mexico's major cities. And it is as close to Monterrey, the major industrial city of northern Mexico, as it is to Dallas.
Founded in 1718 by Spanish settlers, San Antonio has a long history as a trade outpost for both colonial Spain and Mexico. With a distinct Old World feel and with 56 percent of its population of Mexican descent, it is a city in which Mexicans feel comfortable and prefer as a site for establishing business operations, said Humberto Hernandez Haddad, Mexico's Consul General here.
"The most important element is that you can find a mentality here that is really able to understand Mexico and the Mexicans," Mr. Hernandez Haddad said in an interview. Nearly 50 Mexican companies, ranging from a plastics recycling company to a securities brokerage, had established American headquarters here, more than in any other city in the United States, he said.
A companion view was echoed by executives at companies based here that do business in Mexico. The companies manufacture a broad array of goods, from bowling balls and golf clubs to sunglasses and biomedical equipment.
"People here have really made an effort to understand the Mexican culture, said Blair Labatt, the president of the Labatt company. "To a lot of us, it's second nature to go to Mexico. It's a lot of fun, as a matter of fact."
 
Slower Growth Feared
 While some people here fear that the defeat of the trade agreement could spell economic doom for San Antonio, a more common view among both American and Mexican executives is that it would slow the growth that the city and many businesses here are anticipating.
"The general feeling is that freer trade has been good to us, and free trade will be even better," said Al Martinez-Fonts, the president of Texas Commerce Bank-San Antonio and chairman of the local Chamber of Commerce.
Peter Holt, president of a local family-owned company that sells used construction equipment like bulldozers and backhoes to Mexicans and whose net revenue has climbed from $6 million to $30 million in the last four years, said, "If Nafta is defeated it would not stop us, but it would slow down that kind of phenomenal growth."
Mr. Holt said the number of welders, mechanics and other employees here in San Antonio had risen from 15 to 60 in the same period. "These are people who are benefiting from free trade. These are not elitist bankers sitting on Wall Street."
 
More Jobs for Region
 Even Jesse Bielefeld, the president of the local chapter of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, said the pact means jobs for the region.
"San Antonio will do well if it passes," he said. "I have never denied that it will. It's pretty much a foregone conclusion that San Antonio would be at the hub of everything that's going on." But he added that such growth would come at the expense of much of the rest of the country.
About 7 or 8 percent of the Texas work force is unionized, only half the national average, according to a spokesman for the labor federation in Austin. Nonetheless, the unions are still mounting a vigorous campaign against the pact.
Other pact opponents say they see no guarantee that benefits from the pact will extend to the entire population of the city. Despite the boom of recent years, a recent report by Partnership for Hope, a local community planning organization, found that a higher percentage of people here lived in crowded or deficient housing than in any other major American city. The organization based its conclusions on data from the Census Bureau.
Three of the four Representatives whose districts include San Antonio are strong supporters of the trade agreement, but the fourth, Henry B. Gonzalez, a Democrat who is chairman of the House Committee on Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs, is an outspoken opponent. If the agreement passes, he said, American banks could use foreign operations to evade United States banking laws and regulations.
Still, the dominant sentiment here is clearly in favor of the trade pact. "Most people understand what it is and they can see what it means for them," said Jorge Gonzalez, an economics professor at Trinity University here. "They are seeing free trade at work."
At the same time, there is considerable worry about what defeat of the pact would mean, especially if Mexico retaliated with a new round of its own tariffs or other punitive measures.
Professor Gonzalez noted that about 20 percent of all Christmas sales in San Antonio are to Mexican customers. If Congress rejects the accord, he added, it could mean a disastrous Christmas season for local merchants.
Rejection of the pact could lead to a sudden devaluation of the peso. It might also prompt the Mexican Government to begin strictly enforcing what is now a much-ignored requirement that Mexicans who cross the border carry no more than $50 worth of goods bought in the United States without paying steep tariffs on them.
But others say that no matter what happens, Mexicans will do anything they can to avoid punishing San Antonio. "The Mexicans know that of any city in the U.S., bar none, their friends are in San Antonio," said Mayor Wolff. "They'll remember that we stood with them through all this."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Wall Street rewards a tight strategic focus at La Quinta.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell

 BODY:
DID you hear the one about the traveling salesman? Well, this one can be told in mixed company.
After lackluster earnings almost precipitated a proxy fight for La Quinta Inns two years ago, La Quinta stock has been flexing its muscles in recent months. From trading mostly in the $10 to $11 range for much of last year (adjusted for a 3-for-2 split last month) the stock has about tripled, closing at $32.375 on Friday. 
 About those salesmen? Well, salesmen and saleswomen are the main customers of La Quinta (pronounced La KEEN-tah), which has 215 lodgings in 29 states, concentrated in the Sun Belt. While most hotel chains try to cast a wider net, the narrow focus of La Quinta, based in San Antonio, has clearly been paying off.
"We've been recommending purchase of La Quinta stock and we continue to recommend it," said Michael G. Mueller, an analyst with Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. "We believe its management is implementing a well-designed game plan for maximizing La Quinta's earnings and cash flow as industry supply and demand improve over the next few years."
The new management was installed in 1992 at the insistence of Sid R. Bass and Lee M. Bass, the Texas billionaires, and their adviser, Thomas M. Taylor, who own 32.5 percent of La Quinta stock. The next largest investor, Geo Capital, owns 11 percent. Shareholders of La Quinta averted a proxy fight in 1991 by electing four directors backed by the Bass brothers.
The appeal of the stock, Mr. Mueller of Montgomery Securities said, is its significant operating leverage in a recovering economy.
"Each 1 percent change of occupancy rates results in an 8 or 9 cents change in reported earnings per share," he said. "And each $1 change in average room rates is worth 17 cents a share."
Mr. Mueller is estimating earnings of $1.24 this year, compared with 98 cents last year, adjusted for the stock split, and $1.45 in the calendar year 1994. That could soar to $2.10 in 1994 if La Quinta increases its occupancy rate to 72 percent by then (from 66 percent now) and its average room rate to about $49 (from $47 now).
While that is a big "if," those are the rates achieved in 1992 by Marriott's Hampton Inns, one of La Quinta's largest direct rivals.
La Quinta Inns recently extended a cash tender offer, as part of a merger agreement with La Quinta Motor Inns L.P., to acquire all 3.5 million partnership units at $13 a unit.
La Quinta owns 11.4 percent of the partnership's units, and manages the 31 La Quinta Inns owned by the partnership. Mr. Mueller said the proposed acquisition price was reasonable and would benefit La Quinta.
Michael A. Depatie, the senior vice president of finance for La Quinta, said the tender was expected to close at the end of this month.
The chain wants to buy the units to help the limited partnership refinance $65 million in debt due in November 1994, and pay for renovations and logo changes at La Quinta properties. All 215 properties are expected to be revamped by next summer, at a total cost of $55 million.
"Before, we tried to be all things to all people, targeting business and leisure travel through mass advertising," said John Kaegi, the senior vice president of marketing for the chain. "Now we understand the proper role for a player our size is to target narrowly, rather than to diffuse our resources over too many targets."
La Quinta's customers are usually traveling a territory and working on commission, he said, adding, "They're the backbone of industrial America."
Founded in 1968, La Quinta is adding properties at the rate of one a month, primarily by converting existing properties. "The cost of conversion is probably 60 to 70 percent of building a new one," Mr. Kaegi said. "A frequent scenario is that we pay $2 million for a property and put in another $1 million, when it would have cost us $5 million to build a new one."

HEADLINE: NATION CONSIDERS MEANS TO DISPOSE OF ITS PLUTONIUM

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
In 16 unremarkable concrete bunkers built by the Army for a war with Hirohito and Hitler, the United States has begun assembling about 50 tons of plutonium, one of the most expensive materials ever produced and perhaps the most important to safeguard. The Energy Department says the bunkers, each about the size of a two-car garage, are going to be used for interim storage, meaning six or seven years.
 But plutonium, which was invented by the Energy Department's predecessor, the Manhattan Project, may turn out to be the hardest thing on earth to dispose of. And at the Energy Department, "interim" can have an elastic meaning. "Immediate" tends to mean several years. "Several years" can mean never. 
The Energy Department stopped making plutonium for bombs in the 1980's, but the stockpile of it is growing because the United States is now dismantling obsolete nuclear warheads.
 
No Easy Answers
 On Sept. 27 President Clinton announced the formation of an inter-agency task force to consider how much plutonium the nation needs in the post-Soviet era, and how to dispose of what is surplus.
 The Energy Department is also drawing up a plan for its far-flung weapons production complex for the next century and an environmental impact statement for the whole weapons program. The National Academy of Sciences is also studying the question. But officials are choosing among a short list of unattractive options.
 "I don't think people have a really good answer for what is going to happen to the plutonium," said Rich Loghry, general manager of the Texas plant where the nation's plutonium is being stockpiled.
One hurdle is psychological; the Energy Department cannot bring itself to think of its invention as waste.
 Developing a consensus may take years, and in the meantime there is "interim storage."
 
Comparisons With Gold
 Storage, in fact, may be the leading option, but even this is tricky. Plutonium loses half its radioactivity every 24,000 years, so it will reach background levels of radioactivity in 10 "half-lives," or 240,000 years; the American political system is focused largely on problems that can be solved in less than four.
 In the short term, storage at the Pantex plant near Amarillo, Tex., is affordable. Pantex's annual operating budget is only $210 million, much of it for security.
 Plutonium is more expensive than gold, though the cost of an ounce is difficult to calculate since the price includes the cost of production cleanup and that has not yet been paid. Tens of billions of dollars will be required to clean up messes in South Carolina and Washington State that were left behind by plutonium production.
 Plutonium is more important to safeguard than is gold; stolen gold cannot blow up a city. If the United States wanted to contrast the relative importance of these materials, it might put the plutonium at the center of Fort Knox, and leave the gold at the periphery, to distract thieves.
 But what is plutonium's value? Department officials say the material has tremendous energy value, and that is true. A recent study for Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory said that 50 tons of plutonium could be diluted to provide one-third of the fuel for seven large civilian reactors that now run on uranium, and that it would take 20 years to use up.
 
The Public's Perception
 That is almost too long, since most of the reactors now running are nearing the end of their economic lives and are likely to be retired in 20 years.
 But the nation's utility companies do not even want to discuss taking the plutonium. Executives complain that such discussions only reinforce the public's association of nuclear power with nuclear war. Besides, lightly enriched uranium, which they use now, is cheap.
 Also, using plutonium in a reactor licensed by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission would mean holding a public hearing, something the utilities view with distaste verging on phobia.
 But a reactor is the simplest way to actually destroy the plutonium, atom by atom, just the way it was produced.
 Thomas Cochran, a nuclear weapons expert at the Natural Resources Defense Council, noted that it took many years of many reactors running to make the current stockpile. Although heat energy for electricity production would be released, it would still take substantial engineering work to build or modify existing civilian reactors to use the plutonium, and then years of careful operation to consume it.
 "It takes you exactly the same effort to destroy it as it does to produce it," Dr. Cochran said. A Poor Track Record
 The Battelle Memorial Institute, an Ohio-based research and development concern, has proposed finishing two abandoned reactors, the Washington Public Power Supply System plants 1 and 3, with $3.5 billion in privately raised money and letting the Energy Department run them on plutonium; the money would be repaid with electricity sales.
 Such a plan would hold down the number of places where plutonium had to be stockpiled, but the costs and demand for power are uncertain.
 Also, the department has chalked up a poor track record lately on its management of complicated projects, from the Clinch River Breeder Reactor in Tennessee to the weapons plants to the Superconducting Supercollider in Texas. Congress does not seem likely to write a blank check for the project, especially to the Energy Department.
 Although reactors would not destroy all the plutonium loaded in them as fuel, they would greatly reduce the risk of proliferation, since the fission products created as the plutonium is split are intensely radioactive and thus would be too dangerous to steal.But at the moment, there is no permanent storage for spent fuel either, so the effect would be to solve the problem of the accumulating stockpile by vastly increasing the radioactivity of waste that must still remain in human custody until a repository is built. And no one knows where that will be.
 The plutonium could also be mixed into glass, , which is what the Energy Department plans to do with the tens of millions of gallons of toxic, radioactive liquid wastes left over from plutonium production at the Savannah River Site, near Aiken, S.C., and the Hanford reservation, near Richland, Wash. Mixed in glass with the wastes, the plutonium would be far too radioactive to be easily retrieved for weapons use by terrorists.
 Three years ago, the department dedicated a vitrification plant at Savannah River, but because of technical problems, it has yet to operate. Mr. Cochran, the expert at the Natural Resources Defense Council, said, "The complication is, since the Department of Energy can't get its act together on the vitrification to begin with, you're basically hanging this onto a problem that's not working very well already."
 
Birds and Barbed Wire
 Which brings the department back to storage -- the bunkers standing amid the milo and winter wheat of the Texas Panhandle, with sand hill cranes flying overhead and prairie dogs scampering beneath. Each bunker, built to store munitions in World War II, is now covered by dirt and scrubby weeds on three sides; the fourth side is obstructed by huge concrete blocks, called "access denial barriers," which are moved with heavy-duty forklifts. These protective measures are backed up by guards with M-60 machine guns and so much razor wire that a joke among plant employees is that if half the wire were removed, the place would look like a maximum-security prison.
 The department says fire, flood and explosion are not significant hazards, either to the bunkers or the disassembly of the nuclear weapons that proceeds them. But others are less sure.
 Opponents of storage say they do not want to stand in the way of dismantling the bombs and missiles that can cause millions of deaths almost instantaneously, but neither do they want all the remaining risk on their doorsteps.

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption on Monday about the search for ways to dispose of plutonium described the bunker shown at a plant near Amarillo, Tex., incorrectly. It is being used to test a storage system; no plutonium is stored in the bunker now.
An article on Nov. 15 about the retirement of nuclear weapons misstated the origin of plutonium. Physicists manufactured it in 1940 in early work on the atomic bomb, but they did not invent it; it was subsequently detected in nature.

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
Justices to Rule on Felon's Right to Own Gun

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether states may nullify the restrictions imposed by Federal law on a convicted felon's right to own a gun.
The question has divided Federal courts around the country, meaning that people with identical criminal histories can face opposite consequences from their gun ownership. That fact almost certainly led the Court to take up the question, although the Justice Department had told the Court there was no need to do so. 
 A Federal law, known as the felon-in-possession law, makes it a crime for those who have been convicted of serious offenses to own a firearm. The exceptions in the law are for convictions for antitrust and other business-related violations.
All states have laws or procedures that can restore a convict's civil rights, like the right to vote, serve as a juror or hold certain government jobs. The question dividing the courts is whether those state laws, which clearly prevent state convictions from being used to bar gun ownership, also act in the same way to insulate any Federal convictions the person may have had.
 
Conflicting Conclusions
 In two separate cases, which were combined for the Supreme Court appeal, men from Tennessee and West Virginia had their civil rights restored after serving sentences for felony convictions. Some years later, each man was charged with owning a gun in violation of the felon-in-possession law. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, rejected their arguments that the state laws had restored their rights to gun ownership despite the Federal law.
Federal appellate circuits covering parts of the West and the Midwest -- the Ninth Circuit, based in San Francisco, and the Eighth Circuit, in St. Louis -- had earlier reached the opposite conclusion. When the Fourth Circuit issued its ruling last May, the court said that it knew it was creating a conflict with the other courts but that it was not willing to infer that Congress intended to let state law override the Federal law.
Lenard Beecham, one of the men whose appeals the Justices agreed to hear, had his civil rights restored by Tennessee after serving a sentence for a Federal gun possession conviction in 1979. In 1990, while operating a used-car dealership in Raleigh, N.C., he began buying and selling guns. He answered "no" on a licensed firearms dealer's Federal form to the question of whether he had ever been convicted of a felony, and then sold a gun to an undercover Federal agent.
A Federal jury convicted him of making a false statement as well as being a felon in possession of a gun, but the judge set aside the conviction on the ground that the earlier restoration of his rights by Tennessee meant that the Federal law did not apply to him. The Fourth Circuit then reinstated the conviction. The case is Beecham v. United States, No. 93-445.
The Court's other activities today included these:
 
Abortion Case
 Without comment, the Court refused to hear a challenge to a provision of Mississippi's abortion law that requires teen-age girls to receive the permission of both parents, or of a judge, before getting an abortion.
The law was upheld in May by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans, which ruled that because the law had not yet taken effect, the three abortion clinics that brought the challenge were not entitled to present evidence showing that the law presented an undue burden to women seeking abortion.
The "undue burden" standard was set by the Supreme Court in its 1992 ruling on a Pennsylvania abortion law, and the Justices have yet to take a case to define the new standard further. Last year the Court turned down a challenge to another Mississippi abortion provision, which imposes a 24-hour waiting period.
Catherine Albisa, a lawyer representing the Mississippi clinics, said today that her organization, the Center for Reproductive Law and Policy, would probably file new challenges to the law now that both provisions were in effect. She called the law the most restrictive in the country to go into effect, and said the new lawsuit would seek to document that "young women and poor women in Mississippi have a harder time getting abortions than anywhere else."
The 24-hour waiting period has been in effect since August 1992, and Ms. Albisa said many women were going out of state for their abortions. The parental consent provision took effect this summer.
One issue the Supreme Court left unresolved in its 1992 Pennsylvania abortion decision, Planned Parenthood v. Casey, was under what circumstances plaintiffs would be able to challenge abortion restrictions before they took effect.
While the case today, Barnes v. Mississippi, No. 93-314, would have given the Justices a chance to discuss that question, there are other cases still in the lower courts that will also provide that opportunity when they reach the Supreme Court.
Last spring the Eighth Circuit blocked enforcement of a 24-hour waiting period in North Dakota after Justices Sandra Day O'Connor and David H. Souter indicated in a brief opinion in the case that those seeking to challenge abortion restrictions need not demonstrate, as the Eighth Circuit had earlier held, that the restriction would be unconstitutional in all circumstances.
 
Construction Wages
 Without comment, the Court turned down New York City's appeal of a ruling permitting a suit on behalf of construction workers who were not paid prevailing wages on a federally financed contract to renovate city-owned housing.
A Federal law, the Davis-Bacon Act, requires that work on federally financed construction projects be paid at the prevailing wages in the locality. In this case, the city was paying $90 to $95 per worker per day to the Chinese-American Planning Council, a community group that was the contractor on a job intended to provide work to recent immigrants, former drug addicts and others at high risk of unemployment.
The legal question in the case, New York City v. Chan, No. 93-534, is whether the Federal law can be enforced through private lawsuits of the sort brought against both the city and the planning council by the 35 workers, who are requesting back pay and damages. The Court probably turned down the case because the suit has not yet gone to trial.

HEADLINE: U.S. Threatens to Look Eastward for Trade Allies

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration threatened tonight that if the European allies did not show more flexibility in the stalemated global trade negotiations, Washington would move quickly to develop an alternative trading association with Asia.
In a briefing with reporters at the White House, a group of senior Administration diplomats and trade officials said they were treating this week's economic summit meeting in Seattle as an opportunity to lay the groundwork for a possible trading association, if the stalled negotiations with Europe over the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade are not completed. 
 The Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, which includes the United States and Canada as members, opens in Seattle on Wednesday and will be followed by a meeting of top leaders of member nations, including President Clinton. It is the largest meeting ever of American and Pacific leaders.
"The Europeans have to recognize that APEC can be a building block," a senior Administration official said. "If GATT is a failure, APEC stands out there as an alternative way to solve the problem" for the United States, the official said.
Asian leaders have been cool to the idea of transforming the forum into a trading bloc, and it is not at all clear that the Administration could entice them in that direction. Nevertheless, the Administration's blunt threat underscores Washington's broad disenchantment with seven years of global trade talks that have been stymied by squabbles with Europe, particularly France, over its refusal to cut farm subsidies.
 
APEC as Antidote
 "I think that our trading relationships in the Pacific will be enhanced by this APEC meeting," the senior official said. If the GATT talks fail, he added, "there is some risk that the world economic system will be in turmoil. APEC can be an antidote, particularly to European stubbornness. APEC will stand as a beacon toward which we can turn."
A successful meeting in Seattle, the official added, "will put some additional pressure on the Europeans." He said the pressure will be stronger if the North American Free Trade Agreement is approved.
"It will look a little lonely" for the European Community, the official added. "The antidote to that is a multilateral trade agreement called GATT. Hopefully APEC will be a stimulus for them" to make concessions.
The official noted that "we are just beginning to develop an integrated architecture for APEC. The very fact that APEC leaders are getting together takes it to another level of integration."
President Clinton's authority to negotiate a global trade deal effectively expires on Dec. 15, so if an agreement cannot be reached by then, the Administration will have to win Congressional approval of an extension, which could be difficult in light of the recent fight over the North American Free Trade Agreement. Hence the urgency with which the Administration is trying to pressure the Europeans with the Asia-Pacific forum.
 
Pressuring the French
 Explaining this tactic, the senior Administration official said that the French in particular would never make the necessary concessions unless they believed they were the only ones standing in the way of a successful GATT agreement. Passage of the North American pact and a successful Asia-Pacific meeting, the official said, would definitely enhance those prospects and put additional pressure on the French.
Many economists say that a GATT agreement, which sets trade rules and limits tariffs for commerce among 116 nations, would stimulate the global economy much more than the North American Free Trade Agreement, which applies only to the United States, Mexico and Canada.
Raising the prospect of a deal with nations in the forum, which includes some of the world's fastest growing economies, like Japan, China, Indonesia, Taiwan and Singapore, is a threat to European businesses that count on continued access to the United States market, the world's largest.
