HEADLINE: Argentine President Clears Hurdle to Second Term

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 15

 BODY:
A few months ago it seemed almost a political impossibility. President Carlos Saul Menem was saying he would change the Argentine Constitution to permit his immediate re-election in 1995, despite the fact that he would have to win a raft of votes in Congress from members of the opposition Radical Civic Union.
Few now doubt Mr. Menem's political deftness. In an agreement at the presidential residence on Sunday, Mr. Menem, the Peronist Party leader, signed an deal with Raul Alfonsin, leader of the Radicals and former President, in which the Radicals will support Mr. Menem in his desired constitutional changes. 
 In return, the Radicals got an agreement from Mr. Menem to transfer some executive powers to Congress.
The Menem-Alfonsin agreement, if ratified by the Radicals in early December, makes Mr. Menem the odds-on favorite to win re-election in 1995 and govern the country through 1999.
 
Most Astute Politician'
 "Without a doubt Menem has surprised everyone and pulled the rabbit out of the hat," said Steven Darch, president of Banco Mariva, a major commercial bank in Buenos Aires. "He is a rainmaker, the most astute politician in Argentina, possibly in Latin America."
Today, Mr. Menem signed a decree calling off a national plebiscite scheduled for Sunday in which the public was to have been asked to vote on whether the Constitution should be changed. It was a vote Mr. Menem was almost sure to win. The threat of losing the plebiscite, plus an embarrassing defeat in Congressional elections in October, plus the growing popularity of Mr. Menem, evidently forced the Radicals into the agreement.
"They knew they would lose in 1995 no matter which Peronist candidate they ran against, and that if Menem was not allowed to run, he would come back in the next election and they'd lose that as well," said Alberto Kohan, secretary general of the Peronist Party. "So the thinking was better to let Menem have his time in office now and start preparing a credible Radical candidate for 1999."
 
Influx of Investment
 Business executives and political analysts said the prospect of a second Menem term would boost international investor confidence in Argentina, adding to the billions of investment dollars that have poured in over the past three years, creating one of the most vibrant economies in Latin America.
Over the past four years, Mr. Menem has turned Argentina from an inflation-plagued country with an antiquated industrial base and a stridently anti-Washington, isolationist political bent, into one of the continent's models for economic and political reform.
He has sold off giant state industries, begun paying on Argentina's huge foreign debt and brought the inflation rate down from 5,000 percent in 1989 to 8 percent this year. Over the past two years, the country's economy has grown at almost 9 percent, and it is expected to grow 6 percent this year.
He has also made Argentina the closest ally in South America to the United States, scrapping the country's ballistic missile program and its nuclear weapons program and aiding the anti-Iraq coalition in the Persian Gulf War.
 
Discreet Support for Menem
 For business, the prospect that Mr. Menem would leave office in mid-1995, when he six-year term expires, created uncertainties. And though executives were fearful of openly supporting him for re-election, they repeatedly said they preferred another term for Mr. Menem so that his economic reforms could be made more permanent.
Under the preliminary agreement with Mr. Alfonsin, Mr. Menem will be able to stand for re-election for a four-year second term. The constitutional provision for one six-year presidential term will be changed to two consecutive four-year terms, similar to the United States system.
But Mr. Menem would have to step down in mid-1999.
The agreement also removes a requirement that the President be a Roman Catholic, creates the office of Coordinating Minister of the Cabinet, akin to that of a Prime Minister, who must answer to Congress, and gives the Congress the ultimate authority to intervene in the provinces in times of fiscal crisis, a decision that is now in the hands of the executive.
"The Radicals, who are in a very weak position, see this as an opportunity to get more checks and balances on the executive," said Felipe Noguera, a political analyst and a leading pollster.
 
Weakness of Opposition
 Many said the agreement underlined just how weak the Radical Party has become during the Menem years. Though Mr. Alfonsin, who was president between 1984 and 1989, is still the party's leader, the Argentine public vividly remembers his last months in office, a time of devastating hyperinflation and economic and social upheaval. The Radicals had hoped to recoup some power in mid-term elections last October, but were unable to use a string of corruption scandals in the Menem Government to weaken support for the Peronists.
But there are still risks for Mr. Menem. One is that the Radical delegation in Congress could revolt against the agreement and refuse to approve the constitutional changes.
Another is that before the 1995 elections, one of the many corruption scandals involving some of Mr. Menem's friends and former top aides might blow up in his face.

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: Ranchers;
Increased Trade in Mexican Cattle Brings a Rise in Disease to U.S. Dairies

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTA TERESA, N.M., Nov. 12

 BODY:
Before dawn, bawling calves from Mexico tumbled out of trailers and turned the sandy corrals of the inspection station here into a choking storm of dust. Hours later, the calves were examined, dunked in vats of pesticides to kill ticks and then herded into pens on the American side of the border, where they were sold to ranchers in New Mexico, Texas and other Western states.
More than 1.2 million Mexican calves passed through this and nine other smaller inspection stations along the border during the last year, four times the annual number a decade ago. Mexican cattle producers earn roughly $500 million a year selling young animals to Americans, who fatten them for sale to slaughterhouses. 
 The largely unrestricted trade in young cattle from Mexico is cited by ranchers as evidence of how free trade provides economic benefits in both countries. But as lobbying over the North American Free Trade Agreement reaches its final days, a darker side of this seemingly bright spot in Mexican-American trade is emerging.
Bovine tuberculosis has broken out in dairy herds near here and in two other Texas communities. And the Federal authorities say the most likely source is cattle imported into the United States from Mexico, where the disease is common.
 
Lowering Health Standards?
 The trade agreement does not address the disease directly, saying only that each country will be allowed to enforce its own animal health regulations. Under current procedures, cattle have to be certified free of the disease before coming into the United States from Mexico.
Opponents of the trade accord have seized on the outbreak of bovine tuberculosis to support their argument that free trade in other industries could lower American health and sanitary standards. They assert that the increase in trade in Mexican cattle, which has led to higher numbers of infected carcasses in American meat-packing plants, is a warning sign. They say that the infection was an unintended consequence of free trade and that freer trade will bring more of these kinds of problems.
But proponents of the trade agreement say that governments will adjust to new circumstances just as they have in this case. They point to Mexico's decision last month to institute new testing procedures intended to eradicate the disease in that country.
State and Federal veterinarians say that the spreading bacterial infection, which under rare circumstances can be transmitted to people, is among the worst outbreaks in years and that it comes nearly three decades after the United States had largely eradicated the disease in American cattle.
Word of the outbreak has stirred fear among ranchers across the Midwest and Rocky Mountain states, where most of the nation's cattle are raised and slaughtered. Infected cattle develop respiratory problems that affect their ability to gain weight or produce milk, and when the disease is detected, cattle are either quarantined or slaughtered.
In many ways, the political argument over bovine tuberculosis is a nearly perfect distillation of the larger debate over the trade accord and its effect on American public health and environmental standards: replete with conjecture, scary scenarios, emotion, and, occasionally, hard facts and solidly supported assumptions.
 
Are Problems Exaggerated?
 Jess Burner Jr., a cattle broker from Tornillo, Tex., 40 miles east of here, said in an interview that the problems associated with bovine tuberculosis, while worrisome, had been exaggerated by opponents of the free trade pact. Others, like Dr. Steve A. Marasovich, a retired doctor who operates a dairy east of here in Fabens, Tex., that is under Federal quarantine because of tuberculosis, said the situation was quickly developing into an emergency for the state's dairy industry.
Both men insist that the trade accord does not affect the issue one way or the other. "Whether or not Nafta passes, it will not affect trade in calves," Mr. Burner said. "We are going to see that our industry and our people are protected."
But the Institute for Agriculture and Trade Policy, a farm research organization based in Minneapolis that is opposed to the trade accord, published a study last month that raised the specter of infected cattle spilling into the United States across an open border, spreading disease to animals and people.
Steve Suppan, the author of the report, said in an interview that the sanitary requirements of the proposed trade accord were not strong enough to protect the $70 billion-a-year American beef and dairy industries, and that the Mexican Government was not well-prepared to eradicate tuberculosis in their cattle.
"Free trade makes it easier for Mexico to sell us cattle," Mr. Suppan said. "Mexico does not have in place the infrastructure to eradicate tuberculosis."
As the debate escalates before the House votes on Wednesday on the trade pact, which would eliminate most barriers to trade in North America over the next decade, several aspects of the bovine tuberculosis debate are not in dispute.
For one, bovine tuberculosis is fast becoming an important reason that carcasses are being condemned as unsafe in American beef packing plants. The number of carcasses at American slaughterhouses found to be infected reached 613 in 1992, 15 times higher than in 1986. Dr. Billy Johnson, an official with a division of the Agriculture Department that investigates animal diseases, said about 80 percent of the condemned carcasses were traced back to animals raised in Mexico.
Secondly, Federal and state veterinary officials are virtually unanimous in their opinion that bovine tuberculosis represents little threat to people. The bacterium that is responsible for the disease in Texas causes a chronic lung and lymph infection in cattle that rarely leads to death, Dr. Johnson said. The organism seldom spreads to people, he said. Pasteurization kills the tuberculosis bacteria in milk, and cooking destroys it in meat.
And third, Dr. Johnson and several state officials said that unless the infection in Texas was brought under control, bovine tuberculosis could cause millions of dollars in losses to ranchers, dairy farmers and feed lot operators across the nation's heartland.
 
Wiping Out Disease in U.S.
 The emergence of bovine tuberculosis as a threat to animal agriculture in the United States has surprised most veterinarians. In 1917, when the incidence of the disease in American cattle was about 5 percent, the United States began slaughtering hundreds of thousands of animals shown to be infected as a way to eradicate the disease. By the mid-1960's, said Dr. Mitchell Essey, a Federal veterinarian, the prevalence of bovine tuberculosis in cattle had dropped to less than 0.002 percent and was considered to be eradicated.
But starting in the early 1980's, the trade in imported cattle with Mexico began to climb sharply, with calves pouring through inspection stations like this one. In 1985, prompted by the discovery of tuberculosis in a carcass at a meat packing plant, the Federal authorities traced the infection back to a dairy herd near El Paso.
After more testing, the authorities quarantined 10 dairy herds in New Mexico and Texas that served the El Paso milk market. Quarantined dairies were allowed to sell milk because of pasteurization, but any animals culled from the herds and sold for slaughter were subjected to more testing and special sales and slaughter requirements.
Four herds are still quarantined around El Paso. On a grey afternoon in Fabens, 30 miles east of El Paso, Dr. Marasovich studied the animals in his quarantined herd and explained the exceptionally tight restrictions he has been under since 1990, when tuberculosis was discovered in a few of the 3,500 animals in the herd.
"I must follow all these rules to sell my animals even though the incidence of tuberculosis in this herd is tiny," he said. "But the Mexican animal, which is coming from a known area of exceptionally high rates of infection is allowed into this country without any restriction at all. All it needs is a certificate that says it has been tested for tuberculosis by a Mexican veterinarian. Whether it actually has been tested is not confirmed and documented."

HEADLINE: Administration Is Narrowing Its List for Fed Post

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
With one of the Federal Reserve Board's seven seats opening up in January, Administration officials are narrowing a list of candidates, saying they want someone who is respected by the financial community and is tough on inflation, but who will also support the Administration's goals for stronger growth.
The officials say they are being careful in preparing their list -- which includes several academics and several Administration economists -- because they recognize that their first nomination for a 14-year Federal Reserve seat will send a strong signal to financial markets, at a time when the Administration continues to count on low rates as an important source of growth for the economy.
 
 
Fear of Nervous Markets
 The last thing the White House wants is to push up long-term interest rates by making markets nervous that the Clinton Administration's nominees will be less tough on inflation than the current Federal Reserve Board. 
 The list of more than a dozen candidates includes three high-level officials: Alan Blinder, a Princeton University professor and a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers; Alice Rivlin, former director of the Congressional Budget Office and now deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget, and Alicia Munnell, former chief economist at the Federal Reserve Bank in Boston and currently Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Economic Policy.
Mr. Blinder, Ms. Rivlin and Ms. Munnell have all told acquaintances that they would prefer to stay in their current positions, which are more in the thick of economic policy action than a Federal Reserve post. Still, Administration officials speculated that if President Clinton took a candidate aside and said he or she was his ideal choice, that person might feel pressured to accept.
Administration officials said other candidates under consideration were Peter Kenen, a Princeton University economist; Benjamin Friedman, an economics professor at Harvard University; Sheila Tschinkel, director of research at the Federal Reserve Bank in Atlanta, and Roger Brinner, chief economist for DRI/McGraw-Hill, a consulting firm.
Also on the list is William H. Gray 3d, former chairman of the House Budget Committee and now president of the United Negro College Fund. Administration officials say he would be a strong candidate, but they doubt he would accept the post. Another black candidate is Franklin B. Raines, vice chairman of the Federal National Mortgage Association.
William C. Brainard, chairman of Yale University's economics department, and George L. Perry, an economist at the Brookings Institution, were also said to be under consideration.
Several officials called the Administration list-compiling an evolving process that like the search for Supreme Court nominees could undergo last-minute changes.
One official said the Administration had asked Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, for suggestions.
"This is the Administration's first appointment, so obviously you will look at it very closely," Darwin Beck, money market economist at First Boston, said. "The Administration has a good working relationship with chairman Greenspan, and they ought to maintain it by putting someone on who will have an independent opinion, but will nevertheless work well with the board members who are there."
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and the Council of Economic Advisers have a smooth working relationionship with chairman Greenspan, and they ought to maintain it by putting someone on who will have an independent opinion, but will nevertheless work well with the board members who are there."
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and the Council of Economic Advisers have a smooth working relationship with the Fed -- Mr. Bentsen and Mr. Greenspan have breakfast together once a week -- and the Administration wants to make sure this nomination does not undermine that. Even Federal Reserve officials acknowledge that the Administration's relationship with the Fed is better than the Bush Administration's.
Mr. Greenspan's term as chairman expires in March 1996, and many economists say that if he is not reappointed, there is a good chance he will step down then, even though his term as a Federal Reserve governor continues until 2006.
All of the board's current members have been appointed by Republican Presidents. President Clinton's opportunity to replace Wayne Angell, an inflation hawk whose term expires Jan 31., will be the first time a Democratic President has appointed a Federal Reserve member in more than a dozen years.
 
 
'Work in the Same Direction'
 An Administration official who insisted on anonymity said, "We're looking for someone who, within the framework of controlling inflation, will be willing to make sure that monetary policy and other elements of economic policy work in the same direction as the President's and not at cross purposes."
Several economists suggested that a Clinton appointee who was tough on inflation, yet wanted to promote the President's growth efforts, might be somewhat less inclined than other Fed members to raise short-term interest rates when growth is picking up, unless there were unmistakable signs of increased inflation. Similarly, if the economy starts to slow down at some point, a Clinton appointee might be more aggressive about wanting to cut rates.
Several officials also said they wanted to name a forceful candidate who would not be cowed by other board members and who could discuss monetary policy on the same plane as Mr. Greenspan, the chairman.
The officials overseeing the selection process are Mr. Bentsen; Bruce Lindsey, the White House personnel director; Robert E. Rubin, director of the National Economic Council, and Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers.

HEADLINE: Choosing Status Quo;
Puerto Rico Avoids Radical Change But Now May Be Ignored by Congress

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 15

 BODY:
With their ballots, Puerto Ricans on Sunday decided for the moment that they preferred just a few "enhancements" in their island's current status as an American commonwealth to the uncertainties of statehood. But with Congress in a belt-tightening and protectionist mood, Puerto Rico's obtaining even limited changes in its relationship with Washington is likely to prove difficult.
By choosing the safe course, in fact, Puerto Rico now runs the risk of being ignored on Capitol Hill. Although President Clinton repeatedly promised to support whatever decision the people reached in Sunday's nonbinding plebiscite, the issue of Puerto Rican status carries many of the same potential risks as the North American Free Trade Agreement, but with few of the potential gains. 
 "Now that it is over, I can say that had statehood or independence won, there would have been a confrontation with Congress," said Representative Jose E. Serrano, a Bronx Democrat who is chairman of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus and was neutral during the plebiscite campaign. "But the commonwealth victory may allow some people in Washington to say, 'They chose to remain the same, so let's go on to other issues.' "
The plebiscite, the first on Puerto Rico's status since 1967, drew nearly 1.7 million voters, or 73.6 percent of those eligible. A total of 823,258, or 48.4 percent, favored continuing as a commonwealth, while 785,859, or 46.2 percent favored statehood and 75,253, or 4.4 percent supported independence.
 
'Issue of Rice and Beans'
 Political analysts here said the outcome was an expression of the basic conservatism of Puerto Rican society. Rather than risk the drastic economic and social changes that they feared might come with statehood, the voters chose to remain with a system that has given Puerto Rico a per capita income of $6,200 a year, the highest in Latin America, while seeking some modifications to improve that situation.
"This vote should not be interpreted as a rejection of the United States or its people," Luis Davila Colon, a leading political columnist and television commentator, said of statehood's defeat. "This was an issue of rice and beans. This was about concerns you'd pay more taxes or lose your job."
Under the commonwealth arrangement, which began in 1952, the 3.7 million residents of Puerto Rico pay no Federal income taxes and enjoy some other tax benefits as well. But they are not allowed to vote in Federal elections, have been subject to the military draft and are represented in Congress by a single delegate, who has no vote. In addition, payments under several Federal welfare programs, including Medicaid, are limited at levels far below those for states.
The commonwealth option that won the support of the voters proposes to remedy some of what are seen here as inequalities. The package of enhancements of the current status that the pro-commonwealth Popular Democratic Party wants the government of Puerto Rico to submit to Congress consists of these four elements:
*Full restoration of Section 936 of the Internal Revenue Code, which until this year exempted local subsidiaries of mainland companies from Federal income taxes on profits earned here. That benefit, intended to help create manufacturing jobs here, is to be reduced by 60 percent over the next five years as part of Washington's efforts to reduce the Federal budget deficit.
*Extension of Supplemental Security Income, a Federal aid program for the elderly and the handicapped, to Puerto Rico. Statehood advocates, who have also lobbied for the program, estimate that such an expansion would cost the Federal Treasury $900 million a year.
*Removing the Federal cap on food stamps to Puerto Ricans so that they receive benefits equal to those distributed to the needy in the states. That change would result in a $700-million-a-year increase in the program, according to estimates by the commonwealth government.
*Special protection for Puerto Rico's main agricultural products through tariffs. Such a provision already exists for coffee, but officials here want similar barriers for other produce because they fear that Congressional approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement in particular would bring an influx of cheap Mexican goods.
 
Resistance to Change
 "There will be resistance to any increase in payments to Puerto Rico, no question about it," said Louis Nunez, head of the National Puerto Rican Coalition, a Washington-based advocacy group.
The voters' support for the enhanced commonwealth status faces other obstacles as well. Gov. Pedro Rossello, statehood's leading advocate, promised during the plebiscite campaign that he would fight for the winning option in Washington, no matter how the vote turned out. But on Sunday night he backed away from that pledge. Although he is obligated to present the enhanced-commonwealth package to Congress, the Governor made clear that he would not push it strenuously, saying of the commonwealth forces, "It is up to them to keep their word to the people of Puerto Rico."
Speaking from Washington in a telephone interview, Mr. Serrano, the head of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus, said of the pro-commonwealth party, "The Popular Democratic people have to come up here and push this thing hard themselves, or else it is going to end up on the back burner."
Nevertheless, Mr. Nunez said he was hopeful that Puerto Rico would obtain at least some of the package. He predicted that Congress, eager to avoid a decision on statehood for Puerto Rico, would eventually conclude that it was "a better tactic to enhance the current status so people will be more satisfied" and not agitate for statehood.
But it was Luis Munoz Marin, a commonwealth proponent, who announced after the 1967 plebiscite, when supporters of statehood accounted for only 39 percent of the vote, that "the interminable debate over the political status of Puerto Rico is over." He was wrong then, and nothing about the mood of Puerto Rico or Congress suggests that a similar evaluation would be correct now.

HEADLINE: Industrial Production Jumps 0.8%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
American industry posted its biggest gain in output in nearly a year during October, setting yet another record and further solidifying the view that the economy had picked up markedly in the last two months.
The rise in industrial production, of eight-tenths of a percent, was the fifth in a row. It was also accompanied by upward revisions for September and July, according to the Federal Reserve's monthly report issued today. 
 Although factories, utilities and mines account for less than a third of the overall economy, the performance of this component is regarded as one of the best current indicators of general conditions.
 
 
Vehicle Production Jumps
 "After languishing throughout most of the spring and summer months, the manufacturing sector is now rebounding sharply," commented Donald E. Maude, bond market strategist for Scotia McLeod in New York.
The October advance lifted the Fed's production index to a record 112.2 -- 12.2 percent above its 1987 average -- from 111.4 in September. Although the United States lost more than 250,000 factory jobs from February to September, industry has been setting repeated production records. Manufacturing accounts for about 85 percent of industrial output.
The October gain was paced by a 6.3 percent jump in the output of motor vehicles, partly reflecting a catch-up from output lost to production bottlenecks at the beginning of the new model year, but it extended broadly to other goods as well.
The result was even a bit stronger than analysts expected after digesting, among other things, the Labor Department's report earlier in the month of higher October factory employment and record-setting overtime.
 
'Pretty Good News'
 "It's pretty good news for the economy," James W. Coons, chief economist at the Huntington National Bank in Columbus, Ohio, said of today's report, adding that the economy as a whole could expand at a 4 percent annual pace in the fourth quarter, compared with 2.8 percent in the July-Septbmer period.
Yet he and others noted that growth has come in fits and starts since the official end of the 1990-91 recession, and they cautioned that growth might well settle back again in the new year.
"I think this is the high-water mark," contended Lacy H. Hunt, chief economist at Carroll McEntee & McGinley and a pessimistic analyst. He pointed to decelerating growth of various monetary gauges, the economic drag of higher taxes and what he sees as new economic "softening" abroad, especially in Japan and Germany, that could depress American exports.
Other analysts have questioned lately the ability of consumers to maintain their recent brisk spending pace, which has climbed faster than their incomes.
In a separate report today, the Commerce Department said business sales climbed eight-tenths of a percent in September, well above the rise in inventories of three-tenths of a percent. This suggested that continued demand would promptly be reflected in new orders.
 
 
Homes Are More Affordable
 Still another report, by the National Association of Realtors, found the typical family was better able to buy a home in the third quarter than in almost 20 years. The association's Housing Affordability Index was 134.5 in the quarter, the best level since the final quarter of 1973.
The Fed's report today showed not only that output hit another record, but that industry operated at 82.4 percent of capacity last month, up a half point from September and the highest rate since August 1990.
Donald H. Straszheim of Merrill Lynch said that while the rise in utilization in the last two months might "raise some eyebrows" about the possibility of supply constraints leading to inflation, he remained skeptical.
He noted that operating rates remained well below the levels at which inflation becomes an issue, beyond the mid-80 percent range, and that the Federal Reserve was probably underestimating the amount of new capacity brought on stream in the last two years.
Moreover, Mr. Straszheim said, the labor market is still slack, and capacity, viewed on a worldwide basis, "is immense."
Output from factories advanced nine-tenths of a percent last month, with production of durable goods up 1.3 percent and nondurables up four-tenths of a percent. Utilities showed a rise of one-tenth of a percent, but mining fell five-tenths after leaping 1.7 percent in September.
Excluding motor vehicles and parts -- assemblies equaled an 11 million unit annual pace, up from 10.1 million in September -- industrial output was up four-tenths of a percent last month, the Fed's report also showed.
 Over all, September's gain, originally put at two-tenths of a percent, was raised to four-tenths of a percent; July's gain was raised to three-tenths of a percent from two-tenths of a percent.
 
 
Furniture and Appliances
 Apart from the automotive sector, production of furniture and appliances was one of the strongest areas. Among nondurables, rising output of food and tobacco, consumer chemicals and fuels more than offset a decline in clothing of eight-tenths of a percent.
Business equipment was strong as well, with information-processing equipment up nine-tenths of a percent. Space and military equipment, however, continued downward, falling nine-tenths of a percent.
The operating rate for factories, up six-tenths of a point, to 81.7 percent, lifted it to one-half point above its 1967-92 average, the Fed noted. Among primary processing industries, the utilization rate reached 85 percent, nearly three points above its longer-run average.

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: Mexico;
On Border, Mexicans Are Fearful Too

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MATAMOROS, Mexico, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Just two miles from "the other side," in a dusty border slum called Hope, Maria Isabel Vazquez and Gilberto Lozano are trying to plan their future.
He works in an American-owned auto parts factory here, making dashboards for Cadillacs he never sees because they aren't sold in Mexico. Every Monday and Friday she goes to a hiring hall to see if one of the 76 assembly plants in Matamoros has accepted her application for work. Together, they make about $5,000 a year. 
 Their dreams remain simple: to marry, to have children and to stay close to their families, possibly as close as a house in Colonia Esperanza, which in Spanish means Neighborhood of Hope.
 
The Focus of Attention
 As a key vote on a free trade agreement with the United States and Canada has drawn near, attention has been focused on the way Mexicans live. In his debate with Vice President Al Gore last week, Ross Perot explained his opposition to the pact in part by challenging the Administration's assumptions that Mexicans will buy more goods from the United States if tariffs are removed.
"People who don't make any money can't buy anything," he said. But as Miss Vazquez pointed out, they do have some money, and they already spend some of it on American products.
"Like everybody else, we'd like to have something more," Miss Vazquez, 22, said. "But I don't think that we are living in poverty. We have food every day, we have the clothes we need, we have lights and water. We may not have everything, but I think we live well."
People here, one of the most American of Mexican cities just across the Rio Grande from Brownsville, Tex., have already seen one economic invasion from "the other side," as they call the United States. In the early 1970's American manufacturers started building big plants called maquiladoras along the border because new laws allowed them to assemble parts here and ship them back to the United States without paying taxes.
 
Factories Employ 36,000
 Now more than 36,000 people in Matamoros work in those factories, and whole communities, like Esperanza, have sprung up along a network of rutted streets that surround the industrial parks. They have come from Veracruz and Monterrey and many other parts of Mexico, lured by work.
What they found were jobs like Mr. Lozano's, which even after nine years working at the same plant pays around $100 a week. Esperanza is a place where pigs roam filthy streets, houses rarely have glass windows and an ammonia smell from two nearby chemical factories sours the air.
Mr. Perot and others who oppose the agreement say the factories here dump toxic wastes that poison the water and cause birth defects. They say low wages in Mexico will cost Americans jobs because factories will relocate here. But fear clearly crosses the border. Mr. Lozano said the rumor around his factory and others here is that if the pact is passed, on Jan. 1 -- the day it is supposed to take effect -- salaries at the plant will be cut almost in half and people will have to work a sixth day a week.
"That's what worries me," he said.
On Sunday morning, Miss Vazquez put on a flowered dress and walked two blocks to Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church for the 8:30 children's Mass. There the Rev. Cayetano Rosas, a rumpled, chain-smoking priest, told the children that they must have dreams, in spite of the grimness of where and how they live. "Even if the ground is bad," he said, "if the seed is good you can have a good harvest."
 
The Future Is Worrisome
 But in the sacristy after Mass, he confided that he was truly concerned about the future, with or without a trade agreement. "The treaty will affect those with money on this level," he said, reaching high into the air. "Those on the bottom, the people around here, don't even realize what it means."
The church, a circular modern building of whitewashed concrete, was built 10 years ago by the men of the colonia. During the Mass, roosters could be heard crowing outside. A train rumbled past. An old man sitting in a horse-drawn wagon shouted that he had good oranges for sale.
As elsewhere in Mexico, Sunday is a day of family and friends in Hope. After Mass, Miss Vazquez went to her grandmother's tiny house, with just a hint of paint on its often-patched walls. Soon it was filled with people, including her cousin, Cristian David Barajas, who five months ago came from Veracruz, about 700 miles away on the Gulf Coast, to look for work.
Last week he finally found a job in a plastics factory called Nova/Link making toy cars and dolls. He earns $7.80 a day working from 7 A.M. to 5 P.M. Saturdays are obligatory and nobody gets paid overtime.
 
Where It's Worse
 "It's hard here but it's worse, much worse, in Veracruz," said Mr. Barajas, also 22. He can survive on that for now because he lives with his grandmother, saving even the $65 a month he might expect to pay in rent here.
While most of the debate on the trade pact has taken place in the United States, Mexicans too are uncertain about what it means. A family friend who had stopped by said he thought a pact would make Mexico, and especially the industrialized northern border region, a beacon for people looking for work, a prospect that makes him worry for his own job.
"People from all over Central America will be coming here," Ramon Lopez Munoz, 31, said. "And you watch. Because there is so much unemployment in the United States, things are going to turn around and it's the Americans who will become wetbacks trying to come here."
Inside the homely cottage at 46 Gomez Palacio, mention of the United States is enough to fire up a debate on culture and values. None of the participants has ever lived on "the other side" or intends to, even though they could walk there and sometimes do, to go shopping.
"Sure, we go to buy Levis, or to look at what clothes they have, but to live? No," Miss Vazquez said. "I don't like it there. The style of life is so closed. People have their air-conditioning and their cars. There's never anybody on the street.
"Besides, if something happened to me here, I know I could go to my mother's house, or my friends'. On the other side, if something happens, you're all alone."
 
Relatives Are at Hand
 Esperanza is her whole world right now. Her mother, her grandmother and her great-grandmother live within a few blocks. The tortilla shop is half a block away. Her mother owns a 12-inch Hitachi television that can pick up channels from Mexico and the United States. They have a radio, two portable fans and a papaya tree in the front yard that yields luscious fruit.
Miss Vazquez said she crossed the border about once a week to shop: things like chicken and eggs tend to be cheaper in Texas, she said. The Gigante supermarket in the center of Matamoros has good prices on some things. For daily shopping, the streets of Esperanza have dozens of small stores attached to the front of houses.
One, on Calle de las Leyes de la Reforma, is run by Julian Rubio Regalado, a melancholy 62-year-old. He opens at 5:30 and doesn't close till well after dark. On a good day, he said, he can clear about $30. Soft drinks, eggs, a small can of prepared food that chases away hunger till the next payday are the regular transactions.
Living within sight of the maquiladoras, Mr. Rubio has never worked inside one. He steered away his six children too, telling them such work was at best only temporary. Today, his children have become teachers and journalists. One makes violins. Three live in Matamoros; three have moved away. All are still in Mexico.
 
The Reality of Life
 Mr. Rubio says he is not sure how getting closer to the United States might help Mexico; he has seen too much to believe that trust between the two countries can just materialize with the signing of an agreement. But for the sake of his children he hopes it will bring more jobs.
For himself, he said, there no longer is much hope. His only plan is to continue working in the store, for as long as he can.
"There's no such thing as a pension here, so that's just the reality of life," he said. But he has his children, and they, not the Government or any complicated trade agreement, will take care of him. That, he said, is the way it has always been in Mexico.
"To have a family is the greatest capital you can have," he said, "and for that I consider myself lucky."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Father Cayetano Rosas of Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Matamoros, Mexico, said he is truly concerned about Mexico's future, with or without a trade agreement. HEADLINE: Reshaping Mexico's Auto Future

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Of all the Mexican businesses that would be reshaped by a North American Free Trade Agreement, none is more likely to undergo a transformation than the automotive industry. In that sector, a trade accord may well alter the way cars are made and sold on both sides of the border.
For Mexico, the stakes are high. Cars are its biggest export business after oil, employing 60,000 people directly and more than 300,000 indirectly in parts manufacturing and distribution. Together, the Chrysler Corporation, the Ford Motor Company, the General Motors Corporation, Nissan and Volkswagen built more than a million cars in Mexico last year, making it one of just a few developing countries in the world to reach that mark. 
 Exports grew an average of 142 percent a year from 1985 to 1989, and continue to grow, but at a slower pace. Manufacturing efficiency and quality at some plants rival the best Japanese factories.
 
A Young and Growing Market
 For the United States' car industry, Mexico represents a young and growing market to which it would have privileged access, because the market would still be closed to companies not situated in North America. Although Vice President Al Gore may have overstated the case when he said last week in his debate with Ross Perot that Mexicans would soon be buying a million cars a year, the Mexican car market is growing much faster than the markets in either the United States or Canada.
Moreover, the Big Three already make and sell cars here, and have billions of dollars invested in assembly lines and parts plants. If the trade pact wiped away most of the protectionist restrictions that have hamstrung the way Detroit operates in Mexico, then big changes would follow; possibly including a shift of small-car production to Mexico from South Korea and other Asian countries. Big-car production might then be concentrated in the United States and Canada.
If that happened, the economic analysts said, car prices in Mexico and the United States could drop, each country would become the most efficient producer of the type of car favored by its market, and free trade would give the buyers on both sides of the border wider choices. It should also create more jobs.
The United Automobile Workers union in the United States disagrees and remains actively opposed. Auto workers in Mexico tend to fear the coming competition, but have quietly endorsed the pact.
"This deal is incredibly important to the Mexicans, but it's even more important to the Americans," said James P. Womack, a researcher at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who advised Mexico during the trade agreement negotiations. "The big loser on this deal basically is Japan, which has been left out in the cold."
The pact would make it difficult for most Japanese manufacturers to set up shop in Mexico, although they are expected to try. Things would be different for Nissan, which has been building cars here since the 1960's. It would share the Big Three's privileged position, with easy access to the American market because its Mexican-made cars would be considered North American in origin, not imports.
The other big car maker in Mexico is Volkswagen, which makes the Beetle, Jetta III and Golf III models in a huge assembly plant in Puebla, about 80 miles southeast of Mexico City. Unlike the others, Volkswagen has no operations in the United States, having closed its assembly plant in Westmoreland, Pa., in the mid-1980's.
Volkswagen has just come through what was probably its worst year since the first hump-backed Beetle was sold here in Mexico in 1954. The year was marked by a bitter strike, a wrenching labor transformation in which VW adopted Japanese-style production methods, and a production and sales debacle in the United States where the company's Jetta III and Golf cars were not available because of labor and production problems.
 
Manufacturing Requirement
 The five foreign auto makers are here because Mexico has long required that if a manufacturer wanted to sell cars here it must make them here. The Big Three were already here, but Nissan opened its plant south of Mexico City in the 1960's. It recently built a $1 billion assembly plant in the central state of Aguascalientes, from which it has started exporting 1,600 station wagons a month to Japan.
In the 1960's, Toyota decided the Mexican market was too small to justify its own plant, but now is one of several companies that have met with officials to discuss their options if a trade pact is signed.
The Mexican Government also restricts the total number of vehicles a manufacturer can import. Today, for example, imports from Chrysler or the other American companies cannot exceed 20 percent of the vehicles they sell in the Mexican market.
A free trade agreement would sweep away most of those rules, at least for companies already here, and would also do away with the current ban on the imports of used cars, which is considered a potentially huge market in Mexico.
 
Better Use of Plants
 A trade deal would allow the Big Three to make better use of their operations in Mexico. Ford, for example, has several plants, including an assembly plant that makes the Ford Escort in Hermosillo, near the border, that is among the most efficient in the world.
Ford also has a plant in Cuautitlan, just outside Mexico City, that is among the least efficient. Unlike most modern plants where just one or two models are produced, Cuautitlan builds all the Cougar, Thunderbird and Grand Marquis models and several lines of trucks sold in Mexico.
Victor M. Barreiro, the president of Ford in Mexico, said if the trade agreement was approved, the Cuautitlan plant would very quickly be redesigned to produced two lines at the most, instead of the current six or seven.
The plan "is to retain for the Mexican market what the Mexican market takes and export the balance," Mr. Barreiro said. "Some are going to say, 'There they go exporting,' but what would I do with the other niches of the market?" in Mexico, he asked. "Import, from the U.S."
 
More Exports Desired
 All the auto companies in Mexico said they wanted to increase exports to the United States, while the Big Three also said they planned to export more cars to Mexico from the United States if a trade agreement was signed.
A study by the United States Department of Commerce projected that with an agreement, the exports to Mexico would increase to more than 60,000 cars, from 1,000, in the first year of the agreement, which would be worth about $1 billion to American auto makers.
Steve Beckman, an international economist with the United Automobile Workers union, called the Commerce Department's projection "possible, but unbelievably unlikely," especially considering that the imports could be matched by Mexican exports.
The union contends that thousands of jobs making radios, wiring and other parts have already been shifted to factories in Mexico from the United States. Mr. Beckman said the constant enticement of Mexico's lower wages -- $1.55 an hour for assemblers in Mexico, compared with $17.38 in the United States -- has already had a dampening effect on salaries in the United States.
 
Worries About Wages
 "Lowering wages is not the way to compete internationally," Mr. Beckman said, "but that's the way Nafta sets the foundation for increasing the profitability of American companies."
Efrain Maldonado is also worried about wages and competition. He has worked at the VW plant in Puebla for 20 years, starting with a job on an assembly line that made vans. Now he is a supervisor, and earns about $1,580 a month. To make ends meet, he and his wife run a curtain shop in Puebla.
He said he thought there were advantages in a free trade agreement that auto workers in Mexico, Canada and the United States would share, but perhaps not at the same time.
"Many of the American companies are going to come here, and there will be more competition," he said. "On the level of technology, we Mexicans can't really compete now, but we've got the advantage of our labor. But the technology will come, and we'll buy more, and in the end there will be jobs all around."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Municipal Advisers Reject Gift Ban

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The National Association of Independent Public Finance Advisers has rejected a ban on political contributions to local officeholders and candidates who could hire them.
Instead, the association adopted a policy that "discourages" its member firms and their employees from making such contributions. In adopting this policy, the association rejected the ban on political contributions that was voluntarily accepted by 17 large Wall Street municipal bond underwriters last month. 
 The association represents independent firms that advise state and local governments and authorities on the underwriting of municipal bonds, working on the other side from the Wall Street and regional firms that underwrite them. While the association rejected the ban, if the firms themselves now decide to stop making political contributions, it would be another step in curbing the role of political contributions in the municipal bond business.
According to the association's president, Robert C. Bendzinski, the association voted over the weekend to stick with a policy initially adopted in September that "discourages its members either as individuals or firms" from making contributions to the state and local officials with whom they do business.
Mr. Bendzinski said the association stuck with this policy because it would apply to all members of these firms. He acknowledged that the association policy was something less than advocating a ban but argued that the association itself could not enforce such a ban.
"I agree that the discouragement does not have the force of an outright ban," said Mr. Bendzinski, who is the president of the Detroit firm of Bendzinski & Company. "But the discouragement does tell that firm and the employees that the association does not want them to do it."
The voluntary ban adopted in October by the 17 Wall Street underwriters will be applied to those who work directly in the municipal bond business and the upper management of the firms. Other members of the firms who are not involved in municipal bonds would be allowed to make contributions under the policies now being drawn up.
The Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board, the self-regulatory board for municipal bond dealers, adopted a final rule last week that prevents firms from doing business with issuers of municipal bonds for two years if the firm or an individual makes a political contribution. But this rule, as it applies to individuals, only covers top management and those in the municipal bond or public finance departments.
The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Arthur Levitt Jr., asked the major associations representing people involved in the municipal bond business recently to adopt the principles and ban accepted by the 17 Wall Street firms.
 
Treasury Market
 Prices and yields of Treasury bonds and notes ended yesterday with little change, as many traders and investors began to wonder what the impact of tomorrow's vote on the North American Free Trade Agreement would be on the bond market.
Trading was sluggish. The price of the 30-year bond wound up down just 1/32 as the yield remained unchanged at 6.15 percent. Earlier in the day, the price had been off more than 20/32 as the yield jumped to 6.20 percent.
The most interesting development may have been the fact that Treasury prices did not end the day down in response to positive economic news.
The concern that the economy appears to be picking up its pace has led to a lot of selling recently and pushed the yield on the 30-year bond back up as high as 6.25 percent. The stronger growth has increased worries about a rebound in inflation, although a lot of analysts argue that the economic pickup expected in the fourth quarter will not carry into the first half of next year.
Among yesterday's strong economic reports was a jump of eight-tenths of 1 percent in industrial production, powered by a 6.3 percent rise in motor-vehicle production. The monthly gain was the fifth in a row.
In addition, sales of cars built in North America for the first 10 days of November were at an annual rate of seven million, giving more support to the view that the economy could grow at a pace of 4 percent or higher in the last three months of the year.
In trading yesterday, the prices of shorter-term Treasury securities moved a little higher. The two-year note was up 2/32 as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped to 4.06 percent, from 4.09 percent on Friday. The price of the three-year note was up 3/32 as the yield fell to 4.41 percent from 4.44 percent.
William V. Sullivan Jr., the director of money market research at Dean Witter Reynolds, said that the move of some investors and traders into shorter-term maturities yesterday probably was a defensive move ahead of the vote on the trade pact.
Mr. Sullivan said that it appeared to him that the "prevailing opinion" in the market is that the trade pact, known as Nafta, could be defeated. "I don't think anybody knows how the bond market will react to an anti-Nafta vote," he said.
Mr. Sulivan added that there were some who thought the rejection of the trade accord would hurt the bond market. These analysts argue that approval of the trade agreement would open markets and increase competition, which could reduce inflationary pressures.
A defeat of the trade accord, thus, would be a negative for the bond market because it could lead, over the long term, to a rise in inflation.
But others argue that a defeat of the accord might lead to problems with the broader global trade negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. This, in turn, could hamper trade and curb global economic activity, which would lead to slower growth in the United States. If that were the case, a sluggish economy might temper inflationary fears in the short-term and give the bond market a lift.

HEADLINE: At 105 Colleges, a Cheaper Federal Student Loan

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Under a pilot program that the Federal Government says will save students and taxpayers money, students at 105 colleges will not have to fill out as much paperwork to get loans next year.
The project, the Federal Direct Student Loan Program, eliminates the middleman -- lenders and guarantor agencies. That means the Department of Education can offer students the lower interest rates available to the Government without the fees that banks now add. 
 And students will have a repayment schedule negotiated to fit their incomes, a plan the Government says will reduce defaults.
It is "one-stop shopping," Education Secretary Richard W. Riley said today. "We are on track to make good on our pledge to save taxpayers $4.3 billion in the course of the next five years."
 
'Going to Help Us All'
 Mr. Riley named 105 colleges and universities that will offer direct loans to almost 300,000 students next year, accounting for 5 percent of the nation's new student loans. The following year, nearly half of the institutions providing Federal student aid will offer direct loans. By 1998, these loans will make up 60 percent of all student lending.
"This is going to help us all," said Kassahun Tefera, a junior at the University of the District of Columbia. "Now it's so confusing with all the papers to fill out."
Under the current Federal Family Education Loan Program, students apply for loans through colleges. Banks provide the money and the Government pays the loan's interest until the student leaves school. If a student defaults, one of 47 guarantor agencies repays the lender and then tries to collect the debt.
 
Reduction in Fees
 The Clinton Administration estimates that direct loans can save $4.3 billion in five years, counting the fees it now pays lenders and fewer defaults. In the 1993 fiscal year, for example, the Government issued 6.1 million loans worth $18 billion; default costs totaled $2.5 billion that year.
The most immediate impact of the plan would be a sharp reduction in the fees that students are charged when they borrow. Under the pilot program, origination and insurance fees, which can now reach 8 percent of a loan, cannot exceed 4 percent.
About 1,100 educational institutions applied for the direct-loan program. About 900 were eligible: They participate in the current loan program, have a default rate lower than 25 percent and can electronically process loan applications or are installing the equipment to do so.
 
72-Hour Decision
 When a student applies for a direct loan, the college will electronically send the application to the Education Department, which will decide within 72 hours whether the student is eligible and send a check.
Despite the Government's enthusiasm, not everyone believes that direct lending is the way to go.
"The current public-private partnership is the best way to serve the interests of students, schools and taxpayers," said Daniel Cheever, president of American Student Assistance, the nation's oldest student loan guarantor. He said the industry was reforming itself, to make applying for and repaying loans simpler.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Strong as Traders Await Vote on Trade Accord

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most major currencies in jittery trading yesterday as traders awaited tomorrow's vote by the House of Representatives on the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Dealers said some positive American economic reports also supported the dollar. But the focus was clearly on the trade pact. 
 "People caught this up move initially on the thought that Nafta will pass," said Paul Alley, foreign exchange dealer at the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan. The dollar later wavered because "the stories all day had the vote close one way and then the other," he said.
In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 106.74 Japanese yen, from 105.65 yen on Friday. It also moved up to 1.6918 German marks, from 1.6845 marks Friday.
Gold prices rose as well, with the December futures contract gaining $2.10, to $375.70 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
Most dealers believe a "yes" vote for the trade agreement will help the dollar by improving the Clinton Administration's credibility and paving a smoother path for world trade negotiations.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said he believed the White House was close to having enough votes to pass the trade agreement and House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, predicted that lawmakers would approve the treaty by a slim margin.
But David E. Bonior, the Michigan Democrat who is House majority whip, contended that 223 members of the 435-seat House were solidly against the pact.
Nervous traders sold dollars aggressively last week but they were quick to buy them back when the dollar started to firm.
"The market was short dollars and all of the Nafta talk encouraged people to cover positions," said Christopher Wilson, foreign exchange dealer at the Union Bank in Los Angeles.
Reports indicating that " said Christopher Wilson, foreign exchange dealer at the Union Bank in Los Angeles.
Reports indicating that recovery was on track also helped the dollar, dealers said. Industrial production rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in October, and industry operated at 82.4 percent of capacity, the highest rate since August 1990.
The British pound closed in New York at $1.4885, down from $1.4937 late Friday.
Other late dollar rates, compared with Friday's quotes, included: 1.4930 Swiss francs, up from 1.4870; 5.8790 French francs, up from 5.8650; 1,665 Italian lire, up from 1,652, and $1.3197 (Canadian), up from $1.3133 (Canadian).

HEADLINE: Study Says Shelter Turnover Hides Scope of Homelessness

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
The number of New Yorkers who have been homeless in recent years is far greater than experts and advocates previously estimated, according to a new study that for the first time used city records to identify and count individuals in the city's shelter system.
On any given night, there are about 24,000 people in New York City's shelters. But the new study, released yesterday, found that 86,000 different individuals passed through the city's shelter system in 1992 alone. 
 The study, by Dennis P. Culhane, a senior fellow at the Leonard Davis Institute for Health Economics at the University of Pennsylvania, found that 239,425 people, or 3.3 percent of the city's population, had spent some time in the shelters over the last five years. The study also examined city records in Philadelphia and found that nearly 3 percent of its population had endured bouts of homelessness in the same period.
In the past, researchers have generally based their estimates of the homeless population on a snapshot of shelter systems during a certain day or week, missing the turnover.
 
Hints of a Larger Problem
 Such studies have tended to emphasize the needs and problems of the long-term homeless, such as those who are mentally ill or addicted to drugs or alcohol, because on any given night they make up a large proportion of the shelter population.
The new study, however identified a large pool of people who have an episode of homelessness, but then leave a shelter on their own.
Although the researchers did not study the characteristics of this group, Mr. Culhane said the sheer volume of people who became homeless and the similar rates of homelessness in New York and Philadelphia suggest that regional economic problems, not just the behavior of individuals, are a factor. Falling wages and welfare benefits, coupled with rising housing costs, have contributed to homelessness, he said.
Advocates have long contended that government has always dramatically undercounted the number of homeless, but Mary Brosnahan, executive director of the Coalition for the Homeless, said even she was surprised at how many people Mr. Culhane counted. She had estimated that half that number were sheltered in a year.
"I was truly astounded by those numbers," she said. "The Culhane findings underscore the need for affordable housing, income supports and jobs that pay enough to keep a roof over one's head."
Several experts said yesterday that the new study, together with a growing body of research from other cities, states and surveys, shows that homelessness is a far more common experience than previously believed. More than 2 million Americans may become homeless in the course of a year, they said.
Last month, Bruce Link, an associate professor at Columbia University, released the results of a random nationwide telephone survey of 1,507 people that he and his colleagues conducted in 1990. More than 7 percent said they had been homeless at some point in their lives, and 3 percent said they had been homeless in the previous five years -- a finding that was consistent with Mr. Culhane's. Mr. Link said he did not know the margin of error for the survey.
Martha Burt, an expert on homelessness at the Urban Institute in Washington, said Columbus, Ohio; Louisville, Ky., and Massachusetts have also experienced high turnover among the homeless, similar to that of New York and Philadelphia.
Mr. Culhane, an assistant professor of psychiatry at the University of Pennsylvania, was able to track the number of people in the shelter systems of New York City and Philadelphia through the cities' computerized records. The new study, done in collaboration with researchers from the city's Human Resources Administration, used Social Security numbers and dates of birth in city shelter records to identify individuals.
 
Children on the Edge
 Besides finding that more people than expected have periods of homelessness, Mr. Culhane also learned that the problem disproportionately affects blacks. From 1988 to 1992, blacks in New York were 16 times more likely to become homeless than whites. And black children were the most likely to become homeless, with 1 in 12 of them spending time in a city shelter.
The children belong to the growing number of families in the city who are living extremely close to the edge financially and periodically slip into homelessness, he said. Mr. Culhane said that the value of the monthly rental subsidy to families on welfare has declined by 42 percent since 1972, while the real cost of housing has risen. There are now close to 300,000 families on welfare in the city.
"There aren't many people who could afford to stay in their homes if you cut their pay in half," he said.
Mr. Culhane also found that homelessness has been worsening among families in New York City, but declining among single individuals. The total number of single people using the system dropped 31 percent from 1988 to 1992, while the number of families rose 32 percent.
The report itself offers no explanation for the diverging trends. Mr. Culhane speculated that some of the individuals may have been jailed or placed in programs for the mentally ill or for people with AIDS. They may also have died of AIDS, he said. City officials have said that more families are entering the system in part because the city has many new shelters that are nicer places to stay, and in part because shelter residents are given priority for subsidized, permanent housing.
In both Philadelphia and New York, Mr. Culhane found that turnover was generally high among the homeless, with many people moving in and out of the shelter system. In New York, 65 percent of families resorted to shelter more than once.
"Where are these people going?" he asked. "That is the big question. It's reasonable to assume many go back to the dangerous or difficult situations from which they came. But we don't really know."
In the report, Mr. Culhane said that the similarity in the proportion of people in Philadelphia and New York to become homeless suggests that homelessness itself "may in fact be reflective of broader regional and national trends, including the declining availability of affordable housing, the decline of wages and welfare benefits against inflation, persistent unemployment and underemployment among young urban adults and the underfunding of community health and mental health programs."
Mr. Culhane and Ms. Burt said the city and the nation should combat homelessness on two levels: by providing social services and special housing help to the smaller number of long-term, mentally ill or addicted homeless people, and by tackling the broader social and economic problems that are fueling the decade-old crisis.
Andrew Cuomo, who designed the city's approach to homelessness under Mayor David N. Dinkins -- an approach embraced warmly by Mr. Giuliani -- agreed with the experts' analysis, but said that government had to focus its limited resources on the neediest of the homeless, those who languish for long, expensive periods in shelters. Millions of poor people need help, he said, but the shelter systems have become a way of helping those who are most desperate.
"Shouldn't we provide services and housing to all 35 million people in poverty? Theoretically, yes," said Mr. Cuomo, who now oversees federal policies on homelessness at the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development. "But this is a budget climate where we're spending less money, not more."

HEADLINE: Stocks Retreat as Trade Vote Is Awaited

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks fell somewhat yesterday, as investor concern over the coming trade pact vote this week, the economy, and interest rates slammed the lid shut on any serious rally in the market.
The declining market hit both blue-chip issues and small stocks alike. Investors anxious about the House vote on the North American Free Trade Agreement tomorrow were also taking their cue from the Treasury bond market where interest rates rose early, then recovered toward the end. 
 Bonds fell lower in early trading after United States industrial production data for October and factory-use data showed that interest rates are not likely to fall soon.
 
Investors on the Sidelines
 Concern that a defeat of the trade agreement could mean another blow to a recovering economy moved many investors to the sidelines. Trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday totaled 251 million shares, a bit below average.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 6.99 points to finish at 3,677.52, while the Nasadaq composite index fell more sharply on a percentage basis, 6.87 points, to 772.45. On the Big Board, the number of losing stocks led gainers by 1,256 to 827.
Hugh A. Johnson, chief investment strategist for the First Albany Corporation, thought the market was adrift. "It's searching for direction and not finding it," he said. "The reason is that not many investors want to take a negative, or for that matter, a positive stand before the Nafta vote on Wednesday. There are worries that either way the vote goes, stocks will go down." He added, "Don't look much for direction from the markets for the first three days of this week."
Some market analysts, who looked to gold as a hedge if the trade accord loses, saw Newmont Mining close at 56 3/4, up 1.
However, a closer look at the the stock market suggets the real damage was in the over-the-counter market and probably more specifically in the technology sector.
Mr. Johnson said technology, computer peripherals and software were weak, showing signs of slowing from the breakneck pace of the last 10 quarters.
For the technology stocks, telecommunications stocks may be overvalued so when investors are faced with a market-sensitive event like the trade vote, it is natural to see investors back away, Mr. Johnson.
Analysts see the United States steel industry a winner if the trade accord passes, according to some industry experts. They believe that with domestic overcapacity, the nation's steel companies should benefit from an expanding steel market in Mexico, with little risk to United States workers worried about jobs moving to Mexico.
Companies with plants closest to the Mexican border would benefit even more, including Texas concerns like Chaparral Steel and the Nucor Corporation, with operations in Arkansas.
Shares of CBS, General Electric, and Capital Cities/ABC were all up sharply on news that a Federal judge has granted permission for the nation's three broadcast television networks to own financial interests in programs.

HEADLINE: Mexican Stocks Reach a High

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Mexican stocks soared to a record high today as investors snapped up shares two days before the United States Congress is set to cast its vote on the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The IPC index of 37 leading shares climbed 14.89 points, or almost three-quarters of a percent, to close at 2,123.33, breaking the high of 2,108.44 set on Nov. 12. 
 "The market continues to be optimistic with regard to the approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement," an analyst said. "But today it looked more erratic, perhaps because of the caution of some investors."
Early in the trading session, shares rose to 2,132.20, before falling back as some traders took profits.
Analysts said an announcement of the 1994 Mexican budget and economic targets, generally viewed favorably by the market, also helped the rally. The Government is forecasting a growth rate of 3 percent, after an expected 1.1 percent this year. It also said it expected an inflation rate of 5 percent next year.
