HEADLINE: The Free Trade Accord: The Mood;
Americans Split on Free Trade Pact, Survey Finds

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL

 BODY:
Americans are evenly split over the North American Free Trade Agreement and are uncertain about whether it would create jobs or cost them, a stance that closely mirrors the predicament facing Congress as it prepares to vote on the pact this week, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
The telephone poll, conducted Nov. 11-14 among 1,334 adults nationwide, showed 41 percent opposed and 37 percent in favor of the pact, which would gradually erase trade barriers between the United States, Canada and Mexico. The difference fell within the poll's margin of sampling error, which was plus or minus three percentage points. 
 The national ambivalence is illustrated by the lack of strong opinions about the agreement and evidence that most people shifted their position depending on the information provided by either side in the debate.
If the agreement is described as one that would create jobs in the United States, most of those who opposed it or had no opinion said they would support it, bring the overall support to 85 percent. If the agreement was said to result in a loss of American jobs, an equivalent number of supporters and undecided respondents changed their minds, resulting in overall opposition of 85 percent. .
As a result, the field of battle is fluid and has been left to those with a vested interest in the outcome.
 
Debate Was a Boost
 Public awareness of the debate over the pact has grown, the survey showed. Seventy-two percent of those polled said they had heard something about the trade agreement, and nearly one-third of that group said they had heard a "great deal." But 26 percent said they had heard "not much" about the pact.
The Administration's cause was helped by last week's face-off between Vice President Al Gore and Ross Perot, who debated the agreement in a live television broadcast that 46 percent of the poll respondents said they had watched, at least in part. This could have included subsequent television news coverage.
More than two-thirds of those who watched the broadcast declared Mr. Gore the victor in a sparring match in which the two men seemed to spend almost as much time attacking each other as discussing the merits of the trade agreement.
The Vice President was also viewed favorably by 48 percent of registered voters over all. That is the highest Mr. Gore has been rated since he was chosen to be Bill Clinton's running mate in July 1992.
In addition, the Clinton Administration's decision to take on Mr. Perot appeared to have worked in the short run. Mr. Perot, one of the trade agreement's most vocal opponents, dropped significantly in popularity, with nearly twice as many registered voters saying they view him unfavorably as favorably -- 47 percent to 24 percent. In September, a roughly equal number of respondents viewed him favorably as unfavorably.
Mr. Gore was considered the winner of the debate, by 2 to 1, even among those who opposed the trade pact.
On balance, the national ambivalence over the trade agreement could help the White House, which is engaged in a campaign to convince members of Congress that they will not suffer politically if they vote for the agreement. The White House can argue that the less strongly Americans view the agreement, the less lawmakers need fear retaliation at the ballot box next November if they vote for it.
 
Concept Is Favored
 The largest share of those polled said they generally favored expanding trade with Mexico and thought that establishing a "North American free trade zone" would be "mostly good" for the United States.
And 67 percent said that buying and selling products through trade with other countries "is good for the U.S. economy," suggesting strong support for the President's arguments against economic isolationism.
The White House has emphasized the Nobel Prize winners, economists and former Presidents who support the trade agreement, while opponents have denounced it as a plan that would endanger the livelihood of workers.
As a result, support for the accord has broken down along lines of social class rather than on the traditional party divisions that typically define policy debates. College graduates, people with annual household incomes above of $75,000 and those who were optimistic about the economy typically support the agreement.
But those with a high school diploma or less, adults under 30, blue-collar workers and those with union members in their households as well as those who were pessimistic about the economy typically oppose it.
And although many black members of Congress and black leaders like the Rev. Jesse Jackson oppose the trade agreement, the poll found no clear division along racial lines.
 
Confusion on the Impact
 More than two-thirds of Americans now know that Mr. Clinton, who has appeared in advertisements and delivered speeches on behalf of the agreement, supports the trade agreement. But more than two-thirds also said they did not know whether the lawmaker who represents them in Congress was for or against it. And there was no evidence of partisan division on the accord. Democrats and Republicans split evenly in their support.
Unlike other issues like health care, the economy and taxes, opinions about the trade agreement are not rooted in personal interest for most Americans, the poll found, and the merits of the pact stir little emotion. Only 1 person in 6 said his or her household would be economically affected by the agreement. Fewer still said they would cast a vote for or against an elected representative solely because of the lawmaker's vote on the accord.
These findings suggest that opponents and proponents of the pact may find it hard to deliver on threats to defeat legislators who defy them.
 
No Strong Sentiments Absent
 The absence of strong public sentiment also confirms Mr. Clinton's strategy to sway votes by appealing directlyto individual legislators rather than to their constituents. In addition, it may give an advantage to organized groups that support and raise money for members of Congress.
Many legislators are also being guided by the pulse-taking they have been conducting in their home districts rather than by the results of national polls that fail to account for regional concerns. Lawmakers from the industrial Midwest, for example, are more opposed to the trade agreement than are those who represent states that border Mexico and could therefore gain an immediate economic benefit from an increased international flow of goods.
The results of the poll indicate that neither side in the trade-agreement debate has been fully successful in making a clear case to the public.
The most significant evidence of this was the shift in public opinion that occurred when respondents were asked whether the pact would "increase or decrease the number of jobs available in the United States."
Although the largest share of those polled, 34 percent, said the accord would probably cost jobs, that tally was a decline from the 49 percent who felt the same way in September. Instead, 30 percent of the respondents volunteered the opinion that the number of jobs would probably stay the same; only 4 percent offered that view in September.
This represents a significant blow to organized labor, which has argued that the agreement would cost jobs and has devoted much of its advertising effort to driving home that point. In addition, the poll indicates that Americans may now be more sympathetic to the claims of business interests than to the concerns of organized labor.
There are also other underlying signs of uncertainty for opponents of the trade accord, who have spent millions of dollars to try to convince the public that the agreement presents a fundamental threat to the economic security of American workers.
When asked whether they would "side with business" or with labor in a dispute between the two, 44 percent said that without knowing any of the details of the dispute their first instinct would be to side with business. Thirty-four percent said they would side with the unions.

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: The Overview;
SUPPORTERS ASSERT MAJORITY IN HOUSE BACKS TRADE PACT

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
After a day of deal-cutting, arm-twisting and speech-making, supporters of the North American Free Trade Agreement said today that they had won commitments from enough representatives to give them a victory when the House votes on Wednesday.
Although neither side had a majority publicly committed to its cause, and the balance hung with about two dozen representatives whose positions were not announced, a senior White House official said that a narrow victory was at hand because enough uncommitted legislators had agreed to support the President if their votes were essential.
 
Feeling More Confident
 "It's just a question of who're going to be the ones to vote the hard votes," said the White House official. "I feel more confident than I've felt in a long time." 
 President Clinton, dropping in unexpectedly as Administration officials were briefing journalists at the end of the day, predicted a narrow victory.
"We're going to get it," he said. Then, joking about the razor-thin margins by which he won budget votes last summer, he added, "It's going to be another landslide in paradise."
As each side's nose-counters toiled in the background, Mr. Clinton continued his dispute with the labor unions that make up his party's bedrock. Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said Mr. Clinton "clearly abdicated his role as leader of the Democratic Party," by assuring Republicans last week that he would try to prevent Democrats from using pro-agreement votes against them. [Page B10.]
 
White House Promises
 Several of the undecided lawmakers said today that they were now leaning toward voting for the trade pact after Administration trade officials pledged to protect their rural constituents from foreign farm competition. Administration officials told the lawmakers they would limit Canadian shipments of wheat and peanut butter that compete with American products.
Two undecided Democrats whose constituents grow wheat and peanuts, Representative Glenn English of Oklahoma and Representative Bill Sarpalius of Texas, said they were leaning toward support for the pact because of the two arrangements.
Representative Romano L. Mazzoli, a Kentucky Democrat who announced his support for the agreement today, said that the arm-twisting had been remarkable and had included calls from Mr. Clinton, Vice President Al Gore, a dozen other top Administration officials and various labor leaders. "I've been around for 23 years, and I'll be honest with you, there've been some legislative full court presses I've seen, but I don't remember anything like this," he said.
Opponents continued to insist today, as they have for weeks, that they had enough votes to defeat the trade measure. In fact, several representatives announced for the first time that they would vote against it.
Among them was Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the New Jersey Democrat who heads the Foreign Affairs Committee's panel on Western Hemisphere affairs. Citing Mexico's shortcomings as a democracy, Mr. Torricelli became the first prominent member of Congress to say he would vote against the pact for foreign policy reasons.
 
9 Meetings for Clinton
 The President held nine meetings today with undecided House members, and told a group of small-business owners here that labor's central argument -- that the pact would cost Americans jobs -- was wrong. The accord, Mr. Clinton said, would instead create jobs by eliminating tariffs. "There is no way any wealthy country in this world can increase jobs and incomes without increasing the number of people who buy that nation's products and services," he said.
His opponents in the House Democratic leadership, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, and David E. Bonior of Michigan, the majority whip, countered by telling 40 busloads of union members on the steps of the Capitol this afternoon that the pact would result in lower wages and fewer jobs here as free trade lured American factories to Mexico.
Both sides have raised the political stakes in the vote, with Mr. Clinton asserting a defeat would damage his ability to conduct international affairs while opponents have warned of economic catastrophe if the agreement is approved. The debate over the deal has reduced a 15-pound package of detailed rules governing millions of commercial transactions into a competition of rallies and slogans.
Opponents held rallies today in Tennessee and Indiana, and fewer than 100 auto workers demonstrated near the General Motors factory in Linden, N.J. The auto industry strongly supports the agreement because it opens the Mexican market to American cars and because Detroit increasingly relies on Mexico for auto parts. But auto workers fear that more factories would be moved south.
Ross Perot, who has campaigned against the pact, showed up outside the Capitol and called for a Federal investigation of "billions of dollars" in projects that he said Mr. Clinton had offered lawmakers Sunday for their votes. He would not provide examples.
 
Pivotal Delegation
 Supporters also continued to plead their case, in television commercials and speeches by Administration officials. The White House released a list this evening of 54 representatives it said had committed themselves to vote for the pact since the debate last Tuesday between Mr. Perot and Mr. Gore.
Administration officials stepped up their lobbying of the pivotal Florida delegation, which is scheduled to meet on Tuesday morning to reconsider its opposition to the pact. The Administration has quietly promised to protect Florida crops against European, Asian and Latin American competition in trade talks now underway among 116 nations, reversing a commitment to keep the pact separate from the world talks. The concession to the Florida growers is certain to anger other nations in the talks.
Representative Thomas H. Andrews, a Maine Democrat and long-time ally of organized labor, announced that he would vote against the pact but also said that he would no longer accept political contributions from the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Mr. Andrews said he was concerned about the appearance of improper influence and angry at some Maine union officials who he said had threatened to withhold money if he voted for the pact.
"I will not be bought, I don't take well to being threatened and this cheapens the entire process," he said. According to Common Cause, a Washington research group, Mr. Andrews has been a major recipient of labor money in recent elections.
Tensions are high, and tempers are beginning to flare. Representative Michael J. Kopetski, an Oregon Democrat who plans to vote for the agreement, complained that unions in his district were circulating literature saying that his vote had been bought.
"I don't mind criticism," Mr. Kopetski said in an interview. "But when they say I'm for sale, I think they're crossing the line, and I resent it."
One of the leading vote-counters in the group of supporters, Jim Kolbe, a Republican from Arizona, said he thought the trade vote would follow the pattern of the one on the budget in August. Then, Mr. Kolbe recalled, neither side knew who would win when the voting began, but the Administration had enough votes in reserve to prevail by a one-vote margin.

HEADLINE: Japanese Tax Policy Enmeshed in Foreign Policy

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 15

 BODY:
When Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa meets President Clinton in Seattle later this week, he will bring an array of "omiyage," or gifts, including a vague plan for deregulating Japan's coddled economy and a proposal for opening the public works business to foreign construction companies.
But it appears unlikely that he will bring the one thing the United States and some private economists have said would do the most to reduce Japan's soaring trade surplus now -- a package of tax cuts to persuade recession-battered Japanese consumers to begin spending again. 
 The United States has been working to reduce Japan's surpluses -- expected to come to a record $150 billion this year -- for more than a decade, so no one believes there is a cure-all. But many experts agree one of the surest means of commencing a sustained reduction and easing some of the political strains between Tokyo and Washington would be to jump- start the stalled Japanese economy. That would attract more imports and make manufacturers less eager to export their way to profitability.
The last two years, successive Governments have announced huge increases in public works amounting to more than $280 billion to pump a fresh flow of money into the becalmed business sector. Official interest rates have also been squeezed down to the lowest levels since World War II. Neither step has produced much improvement, however, with the economy actually expected to shrink this year. Thus, many economists in both countries say a big tax cut is essential. It would put money directly in the hands of taxpayers and improve stubbornly morose consumer sentiment, the economists say.
On Friday, hours before Mr. Hosokawa boards a jet for Seattle, he is to receive the results of a study by a tax commission that will address this critical issue.
While hopes have been high in Washington, leaks to newspapers and comments by some Government officials suggest the commission is unlikely to give the Clinton Administration what it wants -- unless Mr. Hosokawa, a conservative reformer, makes an uncharacteristically bold political decision at the last minute.
And that seems unlikely because the diverse coalition Government Mr. Hosokawa heads is badly split over a tax cut, with the Prime Minister's conservative supporters staunchly opposed on the ground that such a step would burden the country with big deficits.
The report is expected to provide broad policy proposals, not specific figures. The numbers will be filled in by the Government.
But there is speculation that the Government will eventually reduce certain income taxes by about 5 trillion yen, or $47 billion, but then take most of that away by raising a year or so later the consumption tax, a kind of national sales tax. The two, in other words, would just about wash each other out.
"The sort of tax cut they are discussing is not sufficient to stimulate a business recovery," said Hirohiko Okumura, chief economist for the Nomura Research Institute. "The situation would be really miserable if there is no tax cut at all. But if they reduce income taxes and announce in advance that they will be increasing the consumption tax after a year or two, people will just discount this and the economy will continue to decline."
Bolstering those who advocate a tax cut is the fact that the income tax burden borne by working Japanese has been rising sharply in recent years, eating into consumption.
Jesper Koll, the economist here with S. G. Warburg Securities, said income taxes paid by individuals have increased an average 5.4 percent a year since 1989, as taxpayers edged into higher brackets. That has outstripped the 4.3 percent average annual increase in household incomes.
 
Letter From Clinton
 The sensitivity to the tax issue here was apparent last week when a newspaper reported that President Clinton had written a letter to Mr. Hosokawa demanding a tax cut of more than 6 trillion yen and a delay of any increase in the 3 percent consumption tax until the economy is growing by at least 2 percent.
Mr. Hosokawa acknowledged he had received a letter and that the two leaders would discuss taxes at a gathering of the leaders of Asia-Pacific countries. But Mr. Hosokawa denied the letter had contained any specific demands, which American officials confirm. Other American officials have laid out, however, the sort of stimulus they think Japan needs to deliver.
Resistance to a big tax reduction appears strong, however. Hiroshi Miyajima, an economist at Tokyo University and member of the tax commission, laid out the group's thinking in a recent newspaper interview.
"I believe there is little ground for carrying out drastic income tax cuts," he said.
He explained that with the "graying" of Japan's population, as the baby-boom generation ages and retires, increases in the consumption tax rate were "inevitable" to cover the growing demand for social security payments.
Indeed, Finance Ministry bureaucrats cling to the view that a straight income tax cut would be reckless. They argue that with the budget already in deficit and the Government's total debt burden relatively high, Japan will be unable to provide the Government pensions and social security payments of the growing numbers of elderly Japanese if some taxes are not raised.
 
Disputed by Washington
 Washington takes a different view. Japan's outstanding Government debt is about the same as that of the United States relative to the size of their economies. But, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the great majority of Japan's debt is owned by Government-controlled institutions. Thus Japan's net debt, or the amount held by non-Government investors, is about one-tenth that of the United States.
That, American economists argue, gives the Japanese more than enough room to cut taxes and produce a temporary budget deficit to generate fresh growth. That tactic was first articulated by the British economist John Maynard Keynes.
"The Government's agenda has been set by the Ministry of Finance, and they are not interested in a Keynesian stimulus, just some restructuring of the tax system," Mr. Koll said. "The Ministry of Finance still believes that at all costs deficit spending should be avoided as an evil. And that's that."

HEADLINE: Strange Oases In Sea Depths Offer Map To Riches

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
HUGE rock chimneys that spew hot water into the ocean abyss and nourish a riot of bizarre creatures are also fostering a wide range of economic spinoffs, leading some experts to call them the next great prize in the global race for natural resources.
These oases of heat and life in the frigid depths of the ocean were first discovered 15 years ago and have since been found along many of the volcanic gashes that gird the earth. Up to 15 stories high, the chimneys form as cold waters trickle through sea-floor fractures, soak up heat, leach out minerals, percolate upward and shed the minerals in solid deposits as the now superheated fluid mixes back into icy sea water. 
 Profits are already accruing from the exotic microbes that dwell in and around the rocky monoliths. These heat-loving bacteria are extraordinary in that some of them can survive water as hot as 700 degrees Fahrenheit. Such stamina makes them a gold mine for biotechnology companies, which are isolating, cloning and selling their extremely heat-stable enzymes for use in genetic engineering.
Scientists say such tools are likely to give biotechnology and other industries a major lift.
"We're like kids in a candy shop," said Dr. John A. Baross, a microbiologist at the University of Washington in Seattle who collects and studies the heat-loving microbes, which are known as hyperthermophiles.
"With biotechnology, we're just scratching the surface," he said. "The food and pharmaceutical industries are also starting to get into it, particularly with enzymes that modify sugars. These organisms have the potential to do lots of remarkable things, such as degrading toxic wastes. All sorts of breakthroughs are possible."
A different spinoff is mineral wealth. The chimneys and their environs turn out to be laced with rare metals like zinc, copper, silver and gold, which together are worth untold billions of dollars. Although commercial mining is far in the future, given the cold, darkness and crushing pressure of the deep, these deposits are now being carefully assayed by countries like Japan, Germany, Canada and the United States.
Even more important, the new understanding of the process by which metals are concentrated in the deep has become an analytical map to mineral wealth on land, with prospectors around the globe now hunting for slices of what ages ago was sea floor.
Experts say the abyss turns out to be riddled with mineral, biological and intellectual riches and will probably divulge more surprises in the decades ahead.
"The deep ocean has important resource implications that we're only beginning to understand," said Dr. Peter A. Rona, a senior scientist at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration who has written widely on the subject.
The alien world of deep-sea hot springs and their odd forms of life was first uncovered in 1977 by American scientists diving in the ocean depths off the Galapagos Islands. The site was part of a 40,000-mile-long chain of volcanic fissures that gird the earth like seams on a baseball, actively creating new crust in periodic outbursts. The scientists discovered a subtle byproduct of that process -- the hot springs.
The otherworldly animals found in this environment included giant tube worms and clams. When brought to the surface, the creatures smelled of rotten eggs, a sign of sulfur. It turned out that their primary source of energy was not sunlight, the basis of photosynthesis, but sulfur compounds emitted by the hot vents, in particular hydrogen sulfide. The new animals thrived on substances that most others found poisonous.
The mining potential of such sites emerged quickly. In 1979, American scientists exploring the ocean off the west coast of Mexico found towering rock chimneys spewing extraordinarily hot water that was black with minerals, dubbed black smokers. The chimneys turned out to be made of a mix of metals known as polymetallic sulfides.
Such blends are one of the most common types of mineral deposits on land, typically including iron, copper, zinc and sometimes commercially significant amounts of silver and gold. These deposits have been mined by humans for centuries.
In the sea floor, the process at work is thought to be fairly straightforward. Volcanic heat acts as a furnace to concentrate metals found in small amounts throughout the crust and the sea water itself. For instance, every cubic mile of sea water is estimated to hold 38 pounds of gold. As the hot water flows through the subsurface cracks, it becomes very acid and leaches rare minerals out of the crust as it flows upward.
Some of the minerals can precipitate out beneath the sea floor as they encounter cool water in porous rock, forming diffuse deposits of expanding mineralization, while others precipitate at the surface in icy sea water to form well-defined chimneys.
In 1981, scientists from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration exploring near the Galapagos found chimneys atop an ore body they estimated to hold 25 million tons of sulfides, according to "Fire Under the Sea" (William Morrow & Company), a book on undersea hot springs by Joseph Cone. The value of the copper alone in this deposit was estimated at $2 billion.
Such figures caught the eye of the Reagan Administration, which was told the Gorda sea-floor spreading center just off the coast of California and Oregon was probably laced with similar kinds of riches.
On March 10, 1983, in a terse, 532-word proclamation that received little public notice, President Ronald Reagan more than doubled the size of the United States, claiming sovereignty over waters extending 200 nautical miles (or 230 statute miles) from the nation's territories and possessions. This expansion of sovereign rights, he said, would "advance the development of ocean resources."
A bevy of Federal agencies soon embarked on mapping and exploration. Samples of polymetallic sulfides recovered from the Gorda ridge were found to contain copper, zinc, lead, cobalt and silver, but in amounts ultimately judged unattractive for mining in this century.
Gold was later discovered just outside American territorial waters on the Juan de Fuca ridge off Oregon, and along the volcanic spreading center that runs down the middle of the North Atlantic. At 23 parts per million, the concentrations there are 2,000 times greater than the average in the earth's crust and many times higher than what is routinely mined on land.
The Federal Government is continuing to assess the potential of such deposits through submarine dives, robot reconnaissance and deep-ocean drilling from ships.
Dr. Rona of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration cautioned that the possibility of mining deep-sea gold raised difficult issues that pushed its likely accomplishment well into the future.
"It's not just the cold and depth and darkness," he said in an interview. "The challenges are also economic, environmental and legal."
For instance, the United Nations is moving to regulate mining on the high seas, and if such a venture is ever undertaken, the costs could be very high. "We're talking hundreds of millions to billions of dollars to get operations like this going," Dr. Rona said.
The biggest payoff to date, mining experts agree, is that the discovery of deep-sea gold and polymetallic sulfides has become a guide to prospecting on land. The hunt is now on for ancient sea floors once thick with smoking chimneys that over the ages were pushed up onto land to become part of the continents. Some of these deposits have already been mined over the ages, though in ignorance of their origins.
"The lessons we learn from the modern sea floor can be applied to the same geological situation back through time," said Dr. Ian R. Jonasson, an economic geologist with the Geological Survey of Canada, in Ottawa. "It's a way of stripping away the rust of time to see the primary ore-forming processes."
Such insights, Dr. Jonasson added, were already paying off handsomely enough on land to help postpone the day when the sea floor itself might be mined. He also noted that some terrestrial mines were starting to yield fossils of creatures similar to those now found around active chimneys on the sea floor.
Any delays in the onset of mining are a good thing in the eyes of deep-sea ecologists and biologists, who prize the rich diversity of hot-spring creatures and fear that deep dredging could cause their extinction.
As early as 1987, life scientists were calling for some of these abysses to be declared biological preserves so the strange organisms could be studied for such things as biotechnology. In particular, scientists were intrigued by legions of bacteria that dwelled not only inside the creatures surrounding the chimneys but in the hot fluids themselves, some of them feasting off the sulfur compounds.
In 1988, a microbe of the Pyrococcus genus was isolated from a hot vent more than a mile deep in the Gulf of California. Unlike terrestrial bacteria, it could be grown, and its body chemistry could operate, at temperatures above the boiling point, which at sea level is 212 degrees. Instead, the microbe grew at temperatures of up to 220 degrees, and could withstand much higher ones.
New England Biolabs Inc., of Beverly, Mass., took the microbe, isolated from it an important enzyme that manipulates tiny bits of genetic material known as DNA, cloned that enzyme in large amounts and then sold it, beginning in December 1991. It was apparently the first time part of a deep-sea bacterium had been brought to market. The enzyme is DNA polymerase and its trade name is Deep Vent.
The enzyme can speed the polymerase chain reaction, or P.C.R., which has spawned a branch of biotechnology that allows scientists to rapidly make trillions of copies of vanishingly small amounts of DNA, including the DNA in fingerprints left at crime scenes. In the popular film "Jurassic Park," researchers used the technique to recreate dinosaurs.
The advantages of the new enzymes are many. They are extremely stable at the high temperatures of biochemistry, unlike many conventional enzymes that break down relatively quickly and have to be replaced. Perhaps most importantly, they allow genetic chemistry to be conducted in boiling fluids, a step that automatically kills off most terrestrial bacteria and helps insure that batches of genetic chemicals are pure. Contamination by foreign DNA is a major problem and source of error in P.C.R. work.
Other companies are racing to dissect such microbes and bring their unique enzymes to market. Stratagene, with offices in La Jolla, Calif., has cloned deep bacteria from the Juan de Fuca ridge and is searching for others.
"It's a growing area with lots of potential," said Dr. Eric J. Mathur, director of the company's high-temperature laboratory.
The United States Biochemical. Corporation, in Cleveland, is working with the University of Maryland's Center of Marine Biotechnology, in Baltimore, to gather new organisms from the deep. It just won a Federal grant from the Commerce Department to speed its enzyme work.
"The field is untapped," said Vincent Kazmer, a senior vice president at United States Biochemical. "The annual enzyme market might be $600 million. Just think about replacing chemical catalysts with these kinds of enzymes. There you start talking billions."
He added: "Let's be realistic. This is science today and it's future depends on what we find, and how well some things can be cloned and what their activities are like."
Dr. Holger W. Jannasch, a microbiologist at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution on Cape Cod, Mass., which plays a central role in locating new bacteria with its deep-diving submarine Alvin, said that perhaps 10 percent of the existing hyperthermophiles had been found.
"Every time we go to sea, we isolate new ones," he said. "We get surprises all the time. The biology and biophysics of these organisms is completely different, which is very exciting."
Commercially, Dr. Jannasch added, the hyperthermophile field is "already a big deal." He said it was a big source of income for biotechnology companies. He estimated that more than a dozen companies around the world were scrutinizing or exploiting the new area.
An Alvin voyage last month to a previously unstudied part of the Juan de Fuca ridge found more than a dozen different types of microbes in hot vents more than a mile deep, all of which appear to be new to science.
"Historically, every time we've isolated a hyperthermophile, it's been a new species," said James F. Holden, a biological oceanographer at the University of Washington who was on the voyage and is identifying the new bacteria. "This field is explosive."

Diagram: "Engine of creation on a volcanic rift"
Rocky chimneys up to 15 stories high form when cold waters trickle through sea-floor fractures, soak up heat, leach out minerals, percolate upward and shed the minerals in solid deposits as the superheated fluid mixes with icy seawater. Large mineral deposits can be built over thousand of years as old chimneys die and new ones form. Minerals can also precipitate more widely beneath chimneys as hot rising fluids meet cold water in the porous rock. (Sources: 'Understanding Earth,' (W. H. Freeman); National Geographic.) (pg. C1)

HEADLINE: New Test of Broadway Alliance Arrives With 'Any Given Day'

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
The advertising for "Any Given Day," the Frank D. Gilroy play that is to open on Broadway tonight, does not hesitate to trumpet that its star, Sada Thompson, has won a Tony Award, that Mr. Gilroy won the Pulitzer Prize for his long-running hit "The Subject Was Roses" and that the production is a world premiere that, unlike most Broadway shows these days, did not originate in London or Dublin or Los Angeles.
Nowhere does the advertising mention that "Any Given Day" is being produced at the Longacre Theater under the provisions of the Broadway Alliance, the three-year-old coalition of Broadway producers, theater owners, craft guilds and unions that was created to encourage more serious plays, fill darkened theaters and lure new audiences by reducing theater costs and ticket prices. 
 Small wonder. Of the four alliance plays previously produced, not one has made a penny. The first three -- "The Speed of Darkness," "Our Country's Good" and "Crazy He Calls Me" -- were flops. The fourth, "Mixed Emotions," a comedy by Richard Baer now playing at the Golden Theater, received unenthusiastic reviews but, because of low weekly costs, has stayed open with grosses that are a third of the theater's earning potential.
"I'm afraid that the name of the alliance leads to the perception that this is bargain-basement theater, even though that's not true," said Edgar Lansbury, the producer of "Any Given Day." "We decided that ballyhooing the alliance connection was not a very good idea."
 
'Boneheaded Idea'
 Frederick Zollo, who was one of the producers of "Our Country's Good," offered an even stronger assessment of the alliance, calling it "a boneheaded idea that will never be a success."
"The low ticket price gave the public the idea that they were getting damaged goods and all the alliance limitations were killing us," said Mr. Zollo, who is currently a producer of "Angels in America."
The ground rules for alliance plays have changed since Mr. Zollo's experience with "Our Country's Good" in 1991, however, and partisans of the agreement say they still believe it can work. Under the alliance's original terms, plays had to be produced for no more than $400,000. Royalties, many salaries and other costs for Broadway Alliance plays were to be cut by an average of at least 25 percent (actors, for example, could earn no more than $2,500 a week and no less than $713 a week), and the maximum ticket price was to be $24. The provisions were originally restricted to three of Broadway's often unoccupied theaters, the Belasco, the Nederlander and the Walter Kerr.
Last January, after complaints that the alliance rules were limiting the enthusiasm of producers, the number of participating theaters was expanded to 11, the limit on capitalization was raised to $650,000 and the top ticket price was increased to $35. (The most expensive ticket for a single straight play on Broadway now is $60, for "Angels in America.")
 
The Sam Shepard Card

 
 After making the changes, the alliance prepared for a deluge of projects from producers, which never came. Nevertheless, the alliance's advocates are buoyed not only by "Any Given Day," but also by "Simpatico," a new Sam Shepard work that is to be produced at the Cort Theater in late January, most likely under the alliance's provisions, with a cast that is to include Ed Harris, Jennifer Jason Leigh, Frederick Forrest and James Gammon.
"Producers can make a lot of money under the alliance," said Rocco Landesman, the president of Jujamcyn Theaters. "The advantage to a producer is that the cost structure is kept down, yet your gross potential is great, almost as good as it would be for a Broadway play not produced under the alliance."
This was what attracted Mr. Lansbury for "Any Given Day," a tragicomic drama about a family living in the Bronx during the 1940's. He ruled out a Broadway production under conventional contracts "because it would have cost in excess of $1 million, and it's hard to raise that much money for a straight play in the current theater environment."
With its large nine-character cast, he said, the play needed a 500-seat theater to be economically viable. "We knew the show would cost a half-million Off Broadway," Mr. Lansbury said. "The alliance production will cost $650,000. I don't think there is much difference between the Broadway and Off Broadway audience for a play by Frank Gilroy. If people want to come, they'll go anywhere to see it."
 
Larger House's Attractions

 
 Ultimately he and Mr. Gilroy decided on an alliance production because "Broadway offered the prospect of a larger house, so the possibility of recoupment and potential profit were much greater," Mr. Lansbury explained. The Longacre has 1,096 seats, more than twice as many as most Off Broadway houses.
More important, under the alliance the show could run more cheaply from week to week. "We can break even at slightly more than 40 percent of capacity," he said, alluding to a weekly nut of $85,000 to $95,000. The break-even point, he said, would be 25 percent to 35 percent higher under a standard Broadway contract.
"Off Broadway, the capitalization would be less, true," he said. "But also the potential for profit would be less." In addition, a Broadway location "would bring in some of the out-of-towners that you might not get in an Off Broadway venue."
The promise of low initial and operating costs was also the reason for plans to bring in the new Shepard play under the auspices of the alliance, because a production of "Simpatico" would cost $1 million under conventional Broadway rules and $650,000 under the alliance would be a lot easier to raise.
"Some of the cast is available for only a limited time," said Lewis Allen, the lead producer for "Simpatico," "and the possibilities for profit are limited Off Broadway if you have a restricted time." For this reason, he said, an alliance production in the 1,084-seat Cort might be preferable to one in an Off Broadway house.
He added, referring to Mr. Shepard: "Sam is not the darling of the traditional Broadway audience, so we're hoping to get an Off Broadway audience on Broadway. We can charge $20 or less for the balcony seats."
 
Disappointment in Audiences

 
 Other theater people are surprised that audiences have not responded to the opportunity to see live theater at a low price. "You can argue that the plays aren't as good as they should have been, but I think the audiences have let us down," said Alan Eisenberg, the executive director of Actors' Equity, who was the Broadway Alliance's first chairman. "I'm disappointed that audiences haven't given more support to these shows."
Some theater people have suggested that the alliance must exert more quality control. "But many people don't realize that the alliance doesn't make any artistic judgments," said David S. Rosenak, the executive director of the Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers, who was the chairman of the alliance last year. "We facilitate. We judge the budget and make sure it conforms to the alliance guidelines."
The alliance is administered by a 24-person committee composed of producers, theater owners, officials of theatrical unions and representatives from the League of American Theaters and Producers, which picks up the alliance's administrative expenses.
But Bob McDonald, the business manager of Local 1, the stagehands' union, who is now the chairman of the alliance, said he did not favor a committee that would make esthetic judgments about potential alliance shows. "Who are we to exercise criticism, or try to control the content of these plays?" he asked. "No one knows what will, or will not be, a success. It's a roll of the dice."
 
Lack of Good Plays?

 
 Mr. Lansbury said he believed that the alliance hadn't received more good plays because "there aren't that many plays on the open market." The most eagerly sought playwrights have connections with institutional theaters, he said, "and producers have just become a bunch of movers, moving institutional productions to commercial theaters."
Others favor modifying the alliance rules to give producers more incentives to bring in new works. Gerald Schoenfeld, the chairman of the Shubert Organization, said that the producers of an alliance play that becomes a hit should be allowed to switch it to a potentially more lucrative full Broadway contract, raising ticket prices to standard Broadway levels.
"The idea," Mr. Schoenfeld said, "is to get shows into theaters, and if they are successful, then standard contract terms should be invoked. I don't think the present alliance terms offer enough of an inducement to the producers, the actors, to everybody."
Mr. McDonald opposes this suggestion as well. "How can you tell the public you're charging them a maximum of $35 per ticket and then increase the price?" he asked. "I don't think changing that is in the cards."
Mr. Eisenberg added that such a move would give alliance shows an unfair competitive advantage against other shows that had to assume higher weekly operating costs from the beginning of their run, when a show is trying to build an audience.
 
Work and Awards

 
 Despite the alliance's sad track record, its defenders point to the fact that since 1991, the productions have provided about 40 weeks' worth of employment to actors and backstage crews, and have won eight Tony nominations. These accomplishments were achieved, however, at a total loss to the shows' backers.
"The time to applaud the alliance," Mr. Lansbury said, "is when it has a show that runs two years and returns its capitalization: when it has a real hit."

HEADLINE: Battle Looms Over U.S. Policy On Species

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
A NASTY fight is shaping up over the future of the Endangered Species Act, and it pits two cherished American values, private property rights and the preservation of nature, against each other.
Flashes of lightning from the approaching political storm have been abundant of late, even though action to reauthorize the expiring law is unlikely to come before well into next year at the earliest. The property-rights advocates, who see efforts to conserve endangered species as a restriction on free use of land and a brake on economic development, have found allies in Congress. Late last month, they served clear notice of the campaign they are preparing to wage. 
 "I hope we have laid the gauntlet down," Representative Billy Tauzin, a Louisiana Democrat who defends property rights, told the House then. Although he and others had just lost a round in Congress, Mr. Tauzin vowed that it was merely a skirmish in "what will be a real war in this chamber over what kind of balance we want to strike between environmental protection and the protection of human beings on their property."
Last month's defeated proposal would have required financial compensation for landowners whose economic use of property is restricted as a result of whatever imperiled species might be found on it by a newly organized National Biological Survey.
Mr. Tauzin is also the chief sponsor of a proposed revision of the Endangered Species Act, which would require the Government to compensate any landowner whose property drops substantially in value as a result of the act's provisions. Environmentalists and their Federal supporters say Mr. Tauzin's true purpose in backing the proposal is to seriously weaken the law by discouraging the Government from enforcing it aggressively.
Environmentalists contend that the property-rights advocates have exaggerated the extent to which property values are harmed because of the Endangered Species Act. "Undoubtedly, some landowners in some places have experienced diminished value," said Michael Bean of the Environmental Defense Fund. "I don't think it's widespread."
In any event, conservationists and their political allies say, the principle of restricting property rights on behalf of the public good is deeply enshrined in American law, and they argue that complaints should be adjudicated by the courts, where few if any claims have so far been filed.
 
Call to Strengthen Law
 Rather than being weakened, some environmentalists say, the Endangered Species act needs to be strengthened. The case for a stronger effort gained some support last week with the publication of a study thatfound that recovery plans drawn up under the act for some endangered species had set goals at or below existing populations of the species. These inadequate goals "risk extinction rather than insure survival," the authors wrote in the journal Science, and they suggested that political, social and economic pressures were responsible.
"Our conclusion is that the Endangered Species Act is an extremely valuable tool, but that it's simply being overwhelmed," said Dr. J. Michael Scott, a research biologist with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service at the University of Idaho. He was an author of the study, along with Timothy J. Tear and Patricia Hayward of the University of Idaho and Dr. Brad Griffith of the Fish and Wildlife Service.
Advances in the theory and practice of conservation may offer a means of strengthening the nation's efforts while at the same time coming to a compromise with property rights. Conservation strategies and tactics have moved well beyond what they were when the Endangered Species Act was passed 20 years ago.
Then conservationists focused on single endangered species, one at a time. Today, conservationists say, although the species-by-species approach has probably prevented the extinction of many species, it amounts to last-resort emergency-room care. What is called for now, according to the emerging conventional wisdom, is preventive medicine: seeing to it that large enough slices of ecosystems, containing multiple species, are protected before species populations become so small as to become imperiled.
"What you need," Dr. Scott said, "is a way to cut off the pipeline to the Endangered Species Act; that is, save species while they're still common. A lot of the species now on the endangered list were common 25 or 30 years ago. It would have been easier to sit down then with all parties and make decisions on a rational basis. You'd not be dealing with the last 1,000 hectares of habitat. At that point it's a motherhood issue for people on both sides, and with those types of issues there's very little give. The number of options is severely limited."
The new view among experts is that earlier intervention provides more leeway to work out compromises between conservationists and landowners, which preserve both wild species and the value of private property while avoiding confrontations like the one over the endangered northern spotted owl in the Pacific Northwest.
 
Basis of Concept
 The idea is that by focusing on whole ecosystems while habitat is plentiful, it is not necessary to preserve every single patch of it, and there is consequently more flexibility in negotiating tradeoffs between landholders and conservation interests. Humans are considered part of the ecosystem, too, according to this approach, and their interests are factored into the recovery plan. A number of tests of this idea are under way around the country, including in southern California, Texas and Florida.
The Secretary of Interior, Bruce Babbitt, who is responsible for enforcing the Endangered Species Act, eagerly embraced this concept soon after he took office and promoted it as a way to avoid what he called "train wrecks" like the spotted owl dispute. He proposed the establishment of a National Biological Survey, which would provide an inventory of the nation's biological riches. Without such an inventory, he said, it would be impossible to carry out a preventive-medicine plan based on an ecosystem approach.
The ecosystem-wide, multispecies approach would be assigned highest priority under a bill to revise the Endangered Species Act introduced by Representative Gerry E. Studds, Democrat of Massachusetts, in competition with the pending Tauzin bill. But the Studds bill does not provide for preventive measures to save species before they become candidates for listing as threatened or endangered. How all of this might be resolved is unclear, especially since Mr. Babbitt takes the position that the existing law contains all the authority needed to pursue the new approach.
All such considerations about improving the Federal effort to preserve biological diversity have now bumped smack up against the growing and vocal property-rights movement. At first, some members of the movement seemed receptive to the early-intervention, ecosystem-wide approach.
"I bought into that initially," said Chuck Cushman, executive director of the National Inholders Association, one of the most visible and active property-rights groups. "That made sense." The group, which is changing its name to the American Land Rights Association, is based in Battle Ground, Wash.
 
Suspicions About Survey
 But as events unfolded, Mr. Cushman said, he became convinced that the National Biological Survey, which is essential to the new approach, would become an instrument through which property rights would be infringed.
Under a House bill to establish the survey, he said, nonprofessional volunteers would have been empowered to go onto private lands without the owners' knowledge or approval, and to write up biological assessments that the owners would have no opportunity to see or challenge. Mr. Cushman said these assessments could end up freezing the use and development of property if they delineated the land as a hot spot for the protection of species. At the same time, Mr. Babbitt's actions to raise grazing fees on public lands in the West made his motives suspect to property advocates.
"His true agenda becomes clear: to use this as a massive private-property control-taking measure," Mr. Cushman said of the biological survey. "He may be honest in what he said before, but the bureaucracy is going to use it that way."
Despite such objections, the biological survey has been established by administrative action, backed by $164 million approved as part of the Interior Department's appropriations bill, which was passed by Congress this month. The survey came into existence last Friday. A bill to establish it more formally and permanently, in law, has passed the House with a number of amendments, including restrictions on the use of volunteers and requirements that property owners be informed in writing before surveyors come onto their land. The requirement for compensating property owners was defeated on a point of procedure.
The Congressional experience with the National Biological Survey may be making proponents of the Endangered Species Act nervous about its future prospects.
"Everything I hear is that they're going to hold off as long as they can" in bringing the law's reauthorization to a vote, said an Interior Department official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "My guess is next year, with a big question mark."
Congress can delay the showdown by simply putting off reauthorization, and it has delayed it by one year already. With Congressional elections coming in 1994, another year's delay might be in the cards.
Whenever the showdown comes, the extent to which the combatants can reconcile the protection of nature with property rights is likely to influence the struggle to conserve the nation's shrinking store of wild plant, animal and microbial species for years afterward.

HEADLINE: Puerto Rico Chooses, for Now

 BODY:
The close vote in Puerto Rico favoring continued commonwealth status rather than statehood will be greeted with relief in Washington. It spares Congress from deciding how and whether to admit a Spanish-speaking island to the Union.
Gov. Pedro Rossello's New Progressive Party hoped that Sunday's nonbinding referendum would build momentum for Puerto Rico's admission as the 51st state. But this course was preferred by only 46 percent of the voters, compared with 48 percent for commonwealth status and 4 percent for independence. That effectively sidetracks the statehood campaign, at least for now. 
 Yet the plebiscite does not resolve a more fundamental question: Is Puerto Rico a colony? The honest answer is yes and no.
Puerto Rico is clearly a willing subordinate. President Clinton, and most mainlanders, agree that the islanders themselves should be free to choose their final status. And overwhelmingly, Puerto Ricans favor one of two forms of association with the United States; there is no clamor for independence. In 1952 Congress approved commonwealth status, and a year later Washington persuaded the United Nations to take Puerto Rico off its list of colonies.
Even so, in vital respects Puerto Rico remains a dependent ward. Under commonwealth status Puerto Ricans are U.S. citizens, to a point. They can settle anywhere on the mainland, and on the island they elect their Governor and legislature. But because islanders pay no Federal income taxes, they do not elect U.S. senators or representatives or vote for President.
This arrangement, sweetened by other tax breaks, has spurred investment from the mainland, created jobs and raised wages, a boon that doubtless caused many Puerto Ricans to prefer remaining in a familiar halfway house to the risks of economic pain with any change.
But Puerto Ricans are reminded of their diminished citizenship when Washington gives short shrift to their petitions. The Treasury Department barely consulted islanders this year in proposing elimination of Federal tax incentives that Puerto Ricans deem essential to their economy. Twice since 1953, Puerto Ricans petitioned Congress for changes to enhance commonwealth status; Congress did nothing. Nor could it agree two years ago on a plebiscite whose results would be binding.
Many who voted for continued commonwealth status did so to protect Puerto Rico's distinct culture from homogenization into the English-speaking mainland. This choice of cultural autonomy short of national independence deserves respect in a world groping with the dilemmas of self-determination. Now that Puerto Rico has voiced its preference, it is incumbent upon Washington to react more sensitively to Puerto Rican requests and to continued exploration of the island's status.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Running Scared From Nafta

 BODY:
Only one Democrat in the House from New York, New Jersey or Connecticut -- Nita Lowey, who represents parts of Westchester, Queens and the Bronx -- supports the North American Free Trade Agreement with Canada and Mexico. What accounts for the near-united opposition, even from such ardent free-traders as Robert Torricelli of New Jersey and Charles Schumer of Brooklyn?
Most opponents profess anxiety about Nafta's impact on the local economy. But in private, some admit that their opposition owes more to calculations of political survival than to judgments of economic merit. 
 Local Democrats fear the wrath of organized labor. And well they should. As the accompanying table shows, labor political action committees contribute handsomely to their election campaigns. Though it's impossible to say just how much the PAC money explains opposition to Nafta, there's an unsettling pattern.
Nafta would eliminate tariffs and other trade barriers among the three countries over 15 years. This would spur economic gains, but the primary benefit is political: Nafta would lock Mexico into market reforms that could weaken the ruling party's authoritarian grip. Rejection would undermine Mr. Clinton's Presidency and his ability to negotiate other free-trade agreements.
The impact of Nafta on parts of the local economy could be beneficial. Some low-wage manufacturing jobs in the garment industry, for example, will be lost. But for every job lost to Mexican imports there will be at least one job created in export industries.
New York State exported over $1 billion worth of goods -- scientific instruments, chemical products, electronic equipment -- to Mexico last year, and that number will rise rapidly under Nafta. Nafta would also open up Mexico to U.S. banks, securities and telecommunications companies and exporters of management and other services, areas in which New York City excels. And the agreement provides strong protection for copyrights, patents and other intellectual materials -- exports that are vital to the current and future health of the New York City economy.
So why, then, have almost all local Democrats turned their backs on Nafta? Besides the PAC money, labor's endorsement is often key to electoral victory in the New York metropolitan region. And labor hasn't been bashful about threatening to retaliate against representatives who stray on Nafta. In times of economic distress, Nafta's potential victims, no matter how few in number, will know who these politicians are and blame them for any job losses. Nafta's beneficiaries -- for example, the low-income families that would gain the most from low-cost imports of clothes and food -- are spread out all over the region, are less well organized and don't have anything as dramatic as their jobs at stake. And many workers have been convinced -- wrongly -- that their jobs are on the line, leaving politicians fearful that they will be blamed for every plant closing whatever the reason.
Some Democrats might have supported Nafta had they been backed early and hard by the White House. But Mr. Clinton started campaigning late. He didn't pressure Democrats to fall in line, so many declared themselves against Nafta and can't now easily reverse course. But perhaps one or two -- as well as the many undecided Democrats and Republicans outside New York -- will decide to stand up to pressure and vote yes tomorrow. If so, voters should give them credit for courage -- and doing what's in their own long-term interest.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Nafta Hits Intellectuals

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
No need to worry. Nafta will not cost the job of a single American factory or agricultural worker. No plant or farm will be put out of business.
However, because of various complicated Nafta tax and anti-subsidy provisions, some other Americans will experience inconvenience. 
 Jobs will be lost by several hundred thousand editorial writers, columnists and other journalists, plus publishing executives, university professors, Wall Street specialists and members of state and Federal legislative staffs. A few dozen think tanks will close down altogether.
But unemployment insurance will be available, often, for these newly unemployed intellectuals. And many may be retrained for jobs as newsroom receptionists, school custodians or clerks in automated warehouses.
Of course they must be flexible -- willing to sell their homes, pull their children out of school and hunt for new jobs in other cities around the country. Many will find employment above the minimum wage, probably, if they take care not to be too old to compete with high school dropouts.
But being educated people they will also understand that contrasted to the possibility of a better balance of trade with Mexico their problems are entirely minor and not whine about it.
Anyway, perhaps things will pick up for them toward the end of the 90's.
Ah -- all this has been my evil little fantasy these past couple of weeks. Ah -- how they would howl, those journalistic and academic supporters of Nafta who have shown so little care, compassion or understanding about the fears of working people who might lose their jobs, how they would howl if their own jobs were in danger.
I can hear them already, because I have heard them so often before. If a newspaper is in danger of closing, or Wall Street brokers have a bad year, or if professors face loss of tenure for anything but murder, we fill pages of print and hours of air time with sheer poignancy.
But we really do expect workers who lose their jobs after years at a craft or assembly line to be sweet and humble, because some day some other workers in some other factory may pick up jobs.
I was in favor of Nafta, though I never did think the Republic would collapse, America be driven from the company of decent nations and extraterrestrials take over if it did not pass. But now the Administration and the intelligentsia have converted me to opposition to the current version of Nafta.
The genuine fears of frightened workers are dismissed contemptuously by the Clinton Administration, press and academia. If that is true now, while workers are still fighting, what care will be shown them or their thoughts if they are defeated and find themselves out of work in the name of grander interest?
I am a company man; any union that threatens my paper, watch out. But that does not turn me into some kook union-hater, spilling over with rage at unions exercising their right to lobby.
The Administration's attack on the whole A.F.L.-C.I.O. and its leaders is not only unjust, but damaging to freedom movements everywhere.
When it was not at all fashionable, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and Lane Kirkland, its president, came to the quiet assistance of freedom fighters, dissidents and political prisoners throughout Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. The U.S. will need Kirklands again.
But Mr. Kirkland is suddenly painted Mussolini and his members a bunch of know-nothing boobs.
Workers fear that Nafta would preserve child labor, abysmal wages and government-police union-busting in Mexico. All of these are brutally unfair to Mexicans and to competing U.S. workers. And in case anybody cares about such niceties, Mr. Kirkland argues they also run counter to provisions in U.S. free-trade laws.
But if this version of Nafta is defeated, American business, labor and government still have a chance to try to negotiate a Nafta that would open Mexico not only to free trade but to free unions and halfway decent pay.
President Clinton says he needs Nafta as a message of support to the Asian summit meeting in Seattle. If he loses, maybe the message will be even stronger: In Asia as in the U.S. and Mexico, Americans are against slave wages, forced labor, child labor and government union-smashing.
Aren't we supposed to be?

HEADLINE: Haitians Suffer With and Without Sanctions

 BODY:

To the Editor:
We appreciate the prominence and timeliness of "Study Says Sanctions Kill Up to 1,000 Children a Month" (front page, Nov. 9), describing our study titled "Sanctions in Haiti: Crisis in Humanitarian Action." You correctly convey our findings, except for the following two points. 
 (1) The headline is misleading. Our report attributed the excess child deaths and malnutrition to a "multidimensional political crisis," which included "political sanctions and an economic embargo . . . superimposed upon a crisis of governance, a military coup d'etat, the de facto government's mismanagement, an atmosphere of political violence and repression, and evasive and black-market activities by the private business community." We do not attribute all human damage to sanctions, but noted that sanctions have exacerbated a complex crisis.
(2) You do not include our primary conclusions that "The September 1991 coup was the triggering event of the crisis" and that "the long-term health and nutrition of the people of Haiti depend upon democracy, good governance and the protection of human rights."
Unfortunately, by emphasizing the embargo over other complex issues affecting the health of children and families, your article could be misused by the Haitian military and others who oppose sanctions in Haiti.
Our report does not address whether sanctions should now be tightened, extended or withdrawn. Our major recommendation is that whatever sanctions may be imposed, the United States and the international community should at the same time accept responsibility to mitigate the suffering and to protect the lives of innocent civilians.
 
LINCOLN C. CHEN
WINIFRED M. FITZGERALD
Cambridge, Mass., Nov. 9, 1993
 
The writers are with the Harvard Center for Population and Development Studies.

HEADLINE: Clinton Takes Political Risk in Talking to Chinese

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
In meeting China's President in Seattle on Friday, President Clinton is gambling that the strategy of tentatively embracing Beijing's leaders rather than castigating them will work better for him than it did for President George Bush.
The one-hour meeting, the highest-level contact since China suppressed pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square in 1989, comes after a formal policy review in September that led to a decision to shift away from threats and finger-pointing and substitute what a top Administration specialist called "enhanced engagement." 
 Mr. Clinton was so determined to turn the deteriorating relationship around that in September he opened high-level exchanges with Beijing and sent President Jiang Zemin a letter announcing that the United States would help promote a "strong, stable and prosperous China."
It did not seem to matter that Mr. Jiang's most important title is General Secretary of the Communist Party, or that in last year's campaign Mr. Clinton had accused Mr. Bush of "coddling" China's leadership.
There are some differences in both the policy and the risks for the two Administrations. President Clinton started off in office as a far tougher critic of the Chinese and, unlike Mr. Bush, he is willing to link trade benefits to Beijing's human rights performance, at least in the abstract.
Because of Mr. Bush's close association to China, dating from the 1970's when he was the American envoy, he was excoriated in Congress and in the press for meeting with Prime Minister Li Peng at the United Nations in January 1992. By contrast, there has been virtually no criticism of Mr. Clinton's planned meeting with Mr. Jiang. Administration officials maintain that this is due to a tougher track record that they hope will now make the switch to a softer line more effective.
On the lofty political level, the American goal is to convince China that it is in its national interest to liberalize its political process. Mr. Clinton will tell his Chinese counterpart that if China wants to continue to export its goods to the United States under the same low tariffs enjoyed by most other nations, it must make broad changes in its human rights policies now, rather than wait until the benefits face renewal in June.
 
What China Must Do
 The concern is that China may do too little too late in meeting the requirements of a May 1993 executive order linking extension of the trade benefits to China's progress on releasing of political prisoners, ceasing the jamming of international broadcasts, implementing the Universal Declaration on Human Rights, protecting Tibet's cultural and religious heritage and allowing visits by international humanitarian organizations.
On a more mundane level, the Administration's policy is driven by Mr. Clinton's determination that the United States get a larger chunk of the world's fastest-growing market. China's trade surplus with the United States could exceed that of Japan's by the end of the decade.
That means a renewal of China's trade benefits, because China has threatened to retaliate against American companies if the privileges are withdrawn. And all of the Administration's economic agencies have begun to weigh in heavily on China policy, arguing that the interests of commerce should prevail over other policy considerations.
 
Criticism From Christopher
 Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who has not acted on Foreign Minister Qian Qichen's invitation to visit China, is the Administration's most vocal advocate of Beijing's need to do much more if it wants to keep its preferential trade status.
At a briefing Monday, Mr. Christopher characterized as helpful but inadequate such isolated gestures as China's announcement last week that it will give "positive consideration" to allowing the Red Cross to visit prisoners.
The latest indication of China's attitude toward human rights came on Monday, when two dissidents were apparently seized by police and disappeared after attending a meeting to promote nonviolent political reform.
In a speech to a business group in Hong Kong today, Mr. Bush could not resist criticizing his successor's attempts to impose democratic values abroad. Saying China's economic leap forward had made its society much freer than when he was the envoy, he warned that to revoke China's trading privileges would isolate China and narrow Washington's influence.
 
Questions of Missiles
 But kind gestures and sweet talk in Washington do not necessarily produce results in Beijing, as evidenced by China's determination to sell ballistic missiles in violation of an international accord.
During a visit to Beijing in 1988, Secretary of State George P. Shultz was unable to dissuade the Chinese from going forward with contracts to sell such missiles; three years later, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d ended talks in China under the erroneous impression that the Chinese would adhere to their pledges not to export missiles or technology that violated the accord.
The Clinton Administration is fighting the same battle and, thus far, the Chinese are winning.
The Administration imposed sanctions on an estimated $1 billion in high-technology trade with China last August, as required under United States law, after intelligence agencies reported that China had shipped technology and components for M-11 missiles to Pakistan.
China has refused to pledge adherence to the accord. In a meeting with senior State Department officials in Washington early this month, the Deputy Foreign Minister, Liu Huaqiu, said Beijing would be willing to open a formal dialogue with the United States only after Washington lifted the sanctions.
 
Gesture of Good Will
 As a gesture of good will to the Chinese, Mr. Clinton's senior advisers are recommending that he accept a broad interpretation of the law requiring sanctions. That would enable him to announce to Mr. Jiang that he was allowing the export of two of the seven satellites affected by the sanctions.
Mr. Clinton's advisers are also urging that he approve the sale of a supercomputer for meteorological purposes that some nonproliferation experts in the Administration fear could be put to military uses.
The Clinton-Jiang meeting will certainly be Mr. Clinton's most important encounter during an economic summit meeting that will bring together leaders of the 15-member Asia-Pacific Economic Conference.
But a subdrama of another sort may also play out in Seattle: Mr. Christopher's search for a deputy after the forced resignation of Clifton R. Wharton Jr. last week.
 
Post Turned Down
 Senior Administration officials said Mr. Christopher's first choice was Michael H. Armacost, who served as Ambassador to Japan and was the third-ranking official in Mr. Baker's State Department. But Mr. Armacost, now a visiting professor at the Asia-Pacific Research Center, turned it down.
While senior officials said Mr. Christopher may try to change Mr. Armacost's mind, he is also focusing on several other candidates, including two officials who will be demonstrating their diplomatic mettle in Seattle this week: J. Stapleton Roy, the Ambassador to China, and Winston Lord, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs.
The front-runner -- at least on the lists of some officials among State Department executives -- remains Thomas R. Pickering, the Ambassador to Russia; unlike Mr. Armacost, he is said to be very interested in serving as Mr. Christopher's No. 2.
