HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: The Overview;
Scramble in the Capital for Today's Trade Pact Vote

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
On the eve of a crucial vote in the House of Representatives, the White House today won pledges of support for the North American Free Trade Agreement from legislators who had publicly opposed it.
For the first time, the number of representatives who have declared their support for the agreement surged ahead of its opponents. Together with private assurances made to the White House, that appeared to leave President Clinton and his allies poised to claim the narrowest of victories. 
 While opinion polls show that voters are not inclined to hold a vote for the agreement against their elected representative, lawmakers and the White House alike think it could be a source of vulnerability. And the White House today concocted one last blend of deal making, inspiration and flattery to convince reluctant representatives that the accord was worth the risk to their political futures.
 
Heavyweight Endorsements
 To widen support for the accord from Florida representatives, for instance, the Administration was relying on an agreement to protect producers of citrus fruit, sugar and winter vegetables. To prick others' consciences, all five surviving former Presidents joined for the first time in a formal letter appealing to lawmakers not to let a historic opportunity pass.
And to embolden the wavering, Mr. Clinton also invoked endorsements from 40 governors and heaped praise in advance on the final converts, asserting that voting for the accord was an act of political courage.
"Many members of Congress are literally willing to put their political careers on the line tomorrow night to do what they think is right even though they're not quite sure their voters agree with them yet," the President said at the White House this morning.
Flanked by 15 governors, including Gov. Pedro J. Rossello of Puerto Rico, at what amounted to one last campaign event, Mr. Clinton described the growth of support on Capitol Hill as "quite moving."
 
Tariffs Live Again
 Still, it became apparent today that one price the Administration had paid in seeking support for the trade accord had been to undermine the agreement's central objective. To win passage of a pact that eliminates taxes on imports from Mexico and Canada, the White House has agreed to reimpose some trade barriers, not just for orange juice but for a grocery list of commodities. [Page A21.]
This week alone, the White House made arrangements to limit shipments of Canadian peanut butter and wheat to the United States, to prevent Australian and New Zealand beef from entering the United States through Mexico, and to raise tariffs temporarily on Mexican tomatoes and other winter vegetables.
White House officials insisted today that those changes had simply made the trade agreement fairer for American producers.
After weeks of portraying their fight for Congressional approval of the accord as an uphill struggle, and some unease this morning after news accounts described their new confidence, White House officials said privately tonight that the shifting tide on Capitol Hill had given them great optimism that the vote would go their way.
 
'We're Going to Win'
 A senior official who briefed reporters at the White House said Mr. Clinton was "within single digits" of winning the 218 votes needed for passage in the House. Another Presidential aide said flatly tonight, "We're going to win."
Approval in the Senate has been regarded as more or less certain, and if the House approves the pact, Senate action is expected before Congress adjourns next week for the year.
Eight hours has been allotted for Wednesday's debate in the House. No amendments will be allowed. A vote is expected between 8 P.M. and 10 P.M.
At least 15 representatives announced their support for the agreement today, and few if any declared their opposition to it.
Among governors, Mario M. Cuomo of New York has come out against the pact, and Jim Florio of New Jersey has told the White House he is undecided. Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut did not respond to a White House request for his position.
 
'I Feel Abandoned'
 Today, for the first time, leaders of organized labor began speaking with a tinge of foreboding after accounts of more legislators shifting into the President's camp. A day after the head of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. strongly criticized Mr. Clinton for supporting the accord, labor leaders spoke bitterly about what they see as the White House's willingness to make any deal necessary to win approval of the agreement.
"I feel abandoned by Clinton," said Robert M. McGlotten, chief lobbyist for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. "Why can't we have a deal for workers if deals can be struck for citrus, sugar and plate glass?"
Among legislators who had publicly opposed the trade pact but said today that they would vote for it were Representative Bart Gordon, Democrat of Tennessee; Representative Sam Farr, Democrat of California, and Representative Tom Lewis, Republican of Florida. Among those who had been undecided but announced their support today was Representative Floyd H. Flake, Democrat of Queens.
Almost all of the 23-member Florida delegation formally opposed the accord a week ago. But after a meeting of the delegation this morning, it appeared possible that a majority of members would vote for the pact, and Mr. Lewis made clear he had been swayed by the assurances of protection for the state's citrus industry.
"I have long been opposed to passage of the Nafta based on its potential damage on Florida's $6 billion agriculture industry," the North Palm Beach Congressman said. "However, solutions have been successfully negotiated and completed to insure that Florida farmers will be treated fairly under the Nafta."
Most, if not all, of the 11th-hour converts had met privately at the White House with the President, who continued his lobbying today. Mr. Clinton took time out to bask in the governors' support but spent most of the day wooing legislators by phone or in person.
 
'Loneliness' of Decisions
 In addition to the more than 210 House members who have declared their support for the trade agreement, an unspecified number have told the President they will side with him if their vote is needed, aides to Mr. Clinton have said. The aides said today that they still expected to have to call upon those people.
Mr. Clinton got a strong dose of support today from his predecessors. Their endorsement of a trade-accord appeal was sent by express mail to every House member and represented the first time the signatures of Richard M. Nixon, Gerald R. Ford, Jimmy Carter, Ronald Reagan and George Bush appeared on the same document.
The letter, drafted by aides to Mr. Carter, expressed a shared familiarity with "the loneliness of making difficult decisions" but told the lawmakers that they had the opportunity "to sign your name on the right side of America's history."
"Nafta represents a turning point for America," the former Presidents said. "If you vote against it, the role of the United States as a world leader will be severely damaged, and the prosperity of the United States and the international economy will be endangered."
The 15 governors who traveled to Washington today to appear with Mr. Clinton were divided almost equally between Republicans and Democrats, reflecting the bipartisan alliance the White House has sought to forge in Congress for the treaty.
There was some confusion today over how many governors had declined to go on record in favor of the agreement, either by declaring against it, saying they were undecided or declining to respond to a survey.
The survey was conducted in the summer by Policy Review, the journal of the Heritage Foundation, and cited today by the White House, which said that 10 Governors had declined to go on record in favor.
According to Policy Review, and taking into account changes in positions since the survey was conducted, just eight Governors have declined to favor it. In addition to Mr. Cuomo, Mr. Florio and Mr. Weicker, they are L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, who has declared his opposition; Brereton Jones of Kentucky, who says he is undecided; and Jim Folson of Alabama, Zell Miller of Georgia and
Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania, who did not reply, the journal said.
All are Democrats except Mr. Weicker, who is an independent.

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: A Hard-Won Vote;
Voting Yes on Trade Accord Is Folly in Rust Belt. Or Is It?

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Representative Tom Sawyer of Akron, Ohio, a Democrat from the burliest of American factory towns now fallen on the toughest of times, swallowed hard today and pledged his vote to a North American Free Trade Agreement that factory men everywhere despise. Political instinct and Roy Hodoh say this makes him a political short-timer.
"I'm going to tell you right now: he's out of the 14th Congressional District," Mr. Hodoh, the president of United Auto Workers Local 856, said angrily in an interview today. The workers of Local 856 counted on Mr. Sawyer to oppose the agreement, Mr. Hodoh said, adding that they would not forget his "very disrespectful, deceitful" action next November. 
 But the truth is that Mr. Sawyer's vote, and his fate, are beholden to a force stronger than either instinct or Mr. Hodoh's influence: demographics. There are not that many factory workers left in Akron. The vast tire plants and aircraft factories that once blanketed the city with soot are going or gone. Akron's growth and its apparent future lie in polymer research laboratories and small nonunion makers of specialized plastics they fostered.
Mr. Sawyer cited one Akron company that produces a special polymer whose exports to Mexico have grown more than thirtyfold despite high tariffs. Lowering those tariffs, as the trade agreement would do, would cause the exports to grow even more.
 
Far-Reaching Changes
 Mr. Hodoh's own local is an example of the transformation. Just four years ago, it carried 1,800 workers on its rolls. Today it has 600.
The same sort of tectonic shifts are remaking both the political and economic fault lines in dozens of big and small factory towns across the nation's manufacturing heartland known in its decline as the Rust Belt. They are a major reason why a decision to support the hotly debated trade agreement with Mexico and Canada by Mr. Sawyer and lawmakers in similar districts may not be as perilous as it seems at first blush.
Not that it is risk free. A five-term Congressman from an eternally Democratic district that includes Akron and its rural environs, Mr. Sawyer agonized publicly for weeks before deciding, after a heart-to-heart talk with President Clinton on Monday, to join the treaty's supporters.
"It was, by a considerable margin, perhaps the toughest decision I've ever had to make in public life," he said in an interview today. "Probably this vote is more easily misunderstood than any vote I've ever cast."
 
Pain and Opportunity
 "He wins the award for most tortured," said one White House official who watched as Mr. Clinton wooed Mr. Sawyer in two White House meetings and at least four telephone calls. That official described Mr. Sawyer as looking "awfully pale" after the final session.
The agony is easy to understand. Mr. Sawyer describes his decision as a vote for the new Akron that is emerging from the industrial collapse of the 1970's and 1980's. The rebuilding of the city has peppered it with hundreds of speciality manufacturers that conduct thriving export businesses.
"The kind of visceral response in opposition is understandable," he said. But outweighing it, he said, is the fact that Akron "is so well positioned on the other hand to take advantage of the opportunity before us."
In political terms, it is hard to see Mr. Sawyer's decision as anything other than a departure from the traditional Democratic alliance with organized labor, with its demands to be insulated from foreign competition in industries like steel and autos, and a step toward a new and broader constituency.
 
Change of Mentality
 As recently as 1989, Mr. Sawyer drew a 100 rating, the best possible, from the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Last year his rating was 83, his lowest ever. Today, one senior Administration official who would speak only on the condition of not being named said Mr. Sawyer's "real dilemma was between being a person from the past and a new Democrat."
"This whole turn from protectionism toward international markets is tough," the official said. "Breaking that old Rust Belt mentality is a hard thing to do."
That is true not just of Mr. Sawyer, but of Akron and other Middle American cities as well. Those who rode the booms of the two coasts during the last 30 years have little notion of the devastation wreaked in Midwestern cities during that same time or the scars it has left.
Akron made its name in rubber. At one time it was home to four of the world's largest tire companies. But the city closed its last automobile tire plant in the 1970's, and the last truck and aircraft tire plant in 1984. Today only one company in the tire industry still counts the city as its world headquarters, as foreign ownership has severed the industry's ties.
 
'They Left in Droves'
 The departure of the tire behemoths only illustrates a larger wasting of the city's industrial muscle. From 1960 to 1990, one study found, the number of workers claiming union membership withered to 12 percent from 60 percent and is doubtless smaller today.
"We've lost maybe 200,000 jobs in the last 15 years, mostly high-wage, low-education ones," said David G. Meyer, a professor of management at the University of Akron. "They left in droves." About two-thirds of those jobs, he said, have been replaced by low-skill and often part-time work in stores, hotels and other service businesses.
The remaining third, he said, has fueled the growth of the city's advanced technology plastics industry and related businesses.
"The voting populace is broken into basically two groups: the professional group and the lower-level, relatively low-education job group." Mr. Meyer said. The former largely back the trade agreement. As for the latter, Mr. Sawyer said: "For the most part their jobs can't be moved to Mexico, and they know it. You can't take a mall or fast-food joint and move it to Mexico."
Ten years ago, that backlash from Mr. Sawyer's decision to cross the city's factory constituency and support the agreement might have been big enough to toss him straight out of office. But perhaps not now.
"Akron has changed," said Joe Rice, an Ohio political consultant. "So has labor's role in it. This vote is probably going to hurt him some. But the city is changing so much that the vote is probably in the best interest of Akron."

HEADLINE: Japan's New Leader Wins a Crucial Vote On Political Reform

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 16

 BODY:
The Government of Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa won a key vote today on a package of bills that would reshape the corruption-tainted electoral system, setting Japan squarely on course for its most sweeping political change in decades.
The 21-to-19 vote by a committee of Parliament to redraw the parliamentary districts, reapportion seats and limit corporate political donations was a major coup for the reform-minded Mr. Hosokawa and, political experts said, a sign that Japan is finally casting off its old political order. It also broke a five-year deadlock during which the political system sank deeper and deeper into a series of corruption scandals. 
 The bitter battle over electoral reform brought down the last two Governments and ultimately ended 38 years of one-party rule by the conservative Liberal Democratic Party this summer. Mr. Hosokawa, a highly popular conservative politician, has staked the future of his frail seven-party coalition Government on enacting the legislation.
With today's vote, Mr. Hosokawa appears certain to gain approval for the election reform package from the full lower house of Parliament on Thursday. The upper house is expected to approve the bills before year's end.
The approval of the legislation is likely to shore up the unusual coalition of right- and left-wing parties that Mr. Hosokawa heads, strengthen his hand in talks scheduled for Friday with President Clinton in Seattle and, perhaps most important, give critical impetus to Mr. Hosokawa's goals of opening the economy and reining in the powerful Government bureaucracy.
"The face of Japanese politics is just beginning to change now for real," said Takeshi Sasaki, a political scientist at Tokyo University. "This shows that the Government now has the political will to move on to the other issues: reform of the administrative system, reform of the economy and even the trading system."
Kenzo Uchida, a popular political commentator, remarked, "When this passes and an election is held under the new system, the old political structure will be in chaos."
In the current system, the 511 members of the more powerful lower house of Parliament are elected in three- to six-seat districts, many of which were devised in the 1920's. That system often pits members of the same party against one another, encouraging them to compete not on the issues but by offering cash rewards or preferred access to Government licenses and contracts.
 
Gain for Urban Voters
 Under the new bills, the number of seats would be reduced to 500, with cities gaining representatives and rural areas, whose population has been slowly declining for years, losing some. For instance, Tokyo's representation would grow from 21 to 23 seats.
A total of 274 members of Parliament would be elected directly in single-seat constituencies. The remaining 226 seats would be filled on the basis of proportional representation by party affiliation. Voters would cast two votes, one for the representative from their district and one for a party.
Corporate contributions to individual politicians -- a recurrent source of scandals and indictments -- would be banned. Corporations would still be permitted to donate funds to political parties but would have to comply with stricter reporting requirements.
Taxpayer money would be used to subsidize campaigning as well. The bills would provide the equivalent of $290 million in public funds for elections.
The angriest opposition came from some members of the two parties that dominated Japanese politics during the cold-war years: the Liberal Democrats, who controlled the Government from 1955 until this year and are now in the opposition, and the Socialists, long the largest opposition party, who have uneasily assumed the position of the largest party in the governing coalition. Ultimately, the Liberal Democrats rejected the bills, while the Socialists backed them.
 
Big Change in Election Finances
 The changes would eliminate what have been safe seats for some members of the two parties, while completely overturning their traditional means of financing election campaigns. As a result, some Liberal Democrats and Socialists threatened to quit their parties if there was too much compromise on the election reform package.
"The Socialist Party will perish after these continual compromises," complained Sukio Iwatare, a Socialist member of Parliament. "Why do we have to choke ourselves?"
Other Liberal Democrats and Socialists warned that the public, which is solidly behind the reforms, would never forgive the parties if they refused to compromise. The intraparty strains were evident in the fact that the Liberal Democrats hastily had to replace five members of the parliamentary committee that voted today and the Socialists changed two members after it became clear that the original members were planning to vote against their party lines.
Hard-line Liberal Democratic opponents of the bills said their party should have boycotted the session to embarrass the governing coalition. But Mr. Hosokawa and his coalition partners -- most of whom defected from the Liberal Democratic Party earlier this year -- appear to have executed a carefully calculated maneuver to show the opposition as intransigent and the Government as flexible and pragmatic.
After the vote, a buoyant Mr. Hosokawa cruised the crowd of broadly smiling legislators, shaking hands and basking in the glow of the first occasion on which he has moved beyond oratory to actually produce some of the changes he has promised.

HEADLINE: Clinton Signs Law Protecting Religious Practices

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
President Clinton today signed into law legislation requiring the Government to meet stringent standards before instituting measures that might interfere with religious practices.
The new law, the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, overturns a 1990 Supreme Court ruling that set a looser standard for laws that restrict religious practices. 
 That ruling, Employment Division v. Smith, abandoned a long accepted principle of constitutional interpretation that required the Government to demonstrate a "compelling state interest" to justify any measure restricting religious practices. Under the ruling, restrictions were acceptable as long as they were not aimed at religious groups alone.
The new law restores the old standard, and even in cases where Government concerns like health or safety do justify infringements of religious practices, the new law requires the use of whatever means would be least restrictive to religion.
After the 1990 decision, religious groups could not claim exemptions from routine legislation or regulations on the basis of the First Amendment's guarantee of religious freedom.
 
Gore Hails New Law
 Speaking at the White House signing ceremony today, Vice President Al Gore illustrated the kind of cases that have been affected.
"Those whose religion forbids autopsies have been subjected to mandatory autopsies," he said. "Those who want churches close to where they live have seen churches zoned out of residential areas. Those who want the freedom to design their churches have seen local governments dictate the configuration of their building."
Supporters of the law say that 50 to 60 cases of government infringements on religious practices have been justified in the courts on the basis of the 1990 ruling.
President Clinton hailed the new law at the signing ceremony, saying that it held government "to a very high level of proof before it interferes with someone's free exercise of religion."
J. Brent Walker, general counsel of the Baptist Joint Committee on Public Affairs called the new law "the most significant piece of legislation dealing with our religious liberty in a generation."
His sentiments were echoed by many other members of an unusual coalition of liberal, conservative and religious groups that had pressed for the new law. The coalition included the National Association of Evangelicals, the Southern Baptist Convention, the National Council of Churches, the American Jewish Congress, the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, the Mormon Church, the Traditional Values Coalition and the American Civil Liberties Union.
In the Senate, where the bill was approved 97 to 3 on Oct. 27, it was sponsored by Senators Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah. In the House, which passed the bill last May by a voice vote without objection, it was sponsored by Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, and Representative Christopher C. Cox, Republican of California.
President Clinton voiced wonder today at this alliance of forces that are often at odds across religious or ideological lines. "The power of God is such that even in the legislative process miracles can happen," he said.
 
Case in Oregon
 The 1990 case upheld the denial of unemployment benefits by the State of Oregon to an American Indian who was dismissed from a job in a drug rehabilitation program for using the hallucinogenic drug peyote as part of a ritual of the Native American Church. Oregon has a general law banning peyote use, which at that time did not exempt its use for religious purposes.
The Court's majority decision, written by Justice Antonin Scalia, held that the First Amendment did not oblige Oregon to show a "compelling state interest" for refusing such an exemption. If such exemptions were to be established, it had to be done by legislation, not the courts, Justice Scalia said.
Although supporters of the Religious Freedom Restoration Act saw that ruling as having wide implications, especially for small religious groups without political muscle, they said they at first found it hard to rouse public concern about a case involving hallucinogenic drugs.

HEADLINE: Albany Accord Supports Clinics For Mentally Ill

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
The New York State Legislature and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo reached agreement yesterday on a landmark mental health bill that would dedicate money saved by closing psychiatric hospitals to caring for mentally ill people living in communities throughout the state.
After months of haggling, the Governor and the chairmen of the Senate and Assembly committees that oversee mental health issues agreed to close five state mental hospitals and to reduce the number of beds in other hospitals by 2,400. 
 Of the $210 million in projected savings during five years, $180 million would be spent on clinical care, rehabilitation and vocational training for mentally ill people who are no longer hospitalized.
 
Help for the Homeless
 Another $30 million in savings would be set aside to aid the homeless mentally ill and mentally ill people addicted to drugs or alcohol.
At least half the $210 million would go to New York City, where the sometimes menacing presence of the homeless mentally ill on the streets has become a sensitive political issue in many neighborhoods.
Backers said they expected the mental-health bill to be passed by both houses when the Legislature reconvenes next month.
As agreement was being reached on the mental health bill, the Assembly convened to deal with some other lingering pieces of legislation. It gave final approval to a bill that is intended to end years of fraud and misconduct on the part of New York City's school custodians by delegating to principals and the city's Board of Education a degree of control over custodians' work, for the first time. [Page B1.]
 
20 to 25 Percent Increase
 The money in the mental health legislation would mean an increase of 20 to 25 percent in the state's spending on community mental health services, said State Senator Steven Sanders, a Democrat from the East Side of Manhattan who is chairman of the Assembly's Mental Health Committee.
"This is unquestionably the most dramatic reform of mental health policy in New York State in many years," he said. "For the first time, we are recognizing that people discharged from hospitals still have needs that have to be addressed and that the state has neglected for many years."
Assemblyman Nicholas Spano said: "For the first time, we'll have a mechanism to capture the savings from closing psychiatric hospitals and reinvesting that savings into the communities." Mr. Spano is a Republican from Westchester County who is chairman of the Senate Mental Heath and Developmental Disabilities Committee.
Legislators and advocates for the mentally ill hailed the agreement between Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature yesterday as a historic achievement that begins to fulfill the state's promise to care for the tens of thousands of people released from psychiatric hospitals. Since the mid-1950's, the number of people in state mental hospitals has declined from a peak of 95,000 in the mid-1950's to 10,000 today.
"This is the first legislation in 30 years that begins to stop the unchecked deinstitutionalization of the mentally ill by providing funding to follow the patients," said Cynthia Dames, executive director of the Coalition of Voluntary Mental Health Agencies.
This summer, the Legislature adopted a bill to reinvest savings from the shrinking numbers of people in state mental hospitals into community services, but Mr. Cuomo objected because the legislation made no specific provisions to close entire hospitals, many of which are important to the economies of the small communities where they are situated. Historically, the elected officials from those communities have fought the closing of the hospitals and the loss of jobs for constituents.
 
5 Hospitals to Close
 But under the terms of the agreement reached yesterday, five hospitals would close: Harlem Valley, near Poughkeepsie in the Hudson Valley, on Feb. 1, 1994; Gowanda, south of Buffalo, on April 1, 1994; Central Islip in Suffolk County on Oct. 1, 1995, and Kings Park in Suffolk County on Oct. 1, 1997. The fifth hospital, Willard, in the Finger Lakes area, does not have a specific closing date. The bill says it would be shut when officials find an alternative use for the facility.
Mr. Cuomo had also insisted that some of the money be earmarked for the homeless mentally ill and mentally ill people with drug and alcohol problems. The Legislature agreed to his terms.
"We now have a much stronger bill," Mr. Cuomo said in a statement released last night. "It specifically links reinvestment of funds in community mental health resources with state psychiatric center closings."
 
Politically Risky
 The Governor's threat to veto the bill adopted by the Legislature in July was politically risky for Mr. Cuomo because he risked being blamed if no legislation passed at all. But yesterday some of the advocates who had worried about the Governor's strategy said the new bill is better for the changes he obtained. "The Governor really improved the bill by putting on the table the closing of the five psychiatric hospitals," Ms. Dames said.
The negotiations were long and tortured. Legislators had agreed to most of the major policy changes to the bill, including the hospital closings, seven weeks ago. But until yesterday, the agreement was held up by a dispute over the local political concerns of legislators whose districts include two of the hospitals: Republican State Senators James J. Lack of East Northport, L.I., and Michael F. Nozzolio of Seneca Falls. Mr. Lack's district includes Kings Park Psychiatric Center. Mr. Nozzolio's includes Willard Psychiatric Center.
Mr. Lack insisted on local advice in deciding the future of the Kings Park site. The bill would originally have allowed the Governor to appoint the heads of all the advisory task forces that would make recommendations to the state about the future uses of the five psychiatric centers to be closed.
 
Local Advice
 But Mr. Lack won a promise yesterday that the head of the task force for Kings Park would be appointed by the task force itself, rather than by the Governor. Six of the 11 members of each task force would be appointed by local officials.
Mr. Nozzolio is concerned about providing jobs for those who would be laid off from Willard. He demanded and won state assurances that the center would not be closed before an alternative use for the site is found.
Legislative leaders said yesterday that they were confident the legislation would pass, but Mr. Sanders cautioned, "It's never done until you actually pass the bill. There's always the possibility something could go wrong."

The Free Trade Pact
The White House won pledges of support for the North American Free Trade Agreement from legislators who had opposed it. HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: Mexico;
U.S. Vote Crucial for Mexico's Chief and His Party

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 16

 BODY:
After nearly five years of an administration that has changed Mexico more deeply than any other in the last half-century, the success of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's presidency and the fortunes of his party may hang on the outcome of a United States Congressional vote on the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Contrary to the claims of many who support the accord, few economists here believe the future of free-market economic policies in Mexico will be at stake when the House of Representatives takes up the pact on Wednesday. But a vote against the agreement might well bring a chill to relations between Mexico and the United States, officials of the two countries say. Mexican officials have also warned that it could bring a backlash of anti-American sentiment here. 
 What appears most certain, though, is that Mr. Salinas's greatest gamble will either assure him a lofty place in Mexican history or begin a harsh stripping of his prestige that could bolster his leftist opposition as the country turns to the presidential elections scheduled for next August.
"Salinas is Nafta; his whole administration is Nafta," said Carlos Monsivais, a leading Mexican writer. "He has bet so loudly, so heavily. It's like political theology: we will all go to heaven or we will go to hell."
 
Stocks Set Records
 The tentative lines of Mr. Salinas's path have been drawn on separate graphs.
Over the last week, as foreign investors have bet bullishly on Congressional approval, values on the Mexican stock exchange have climbed to record heights day after day.
Yet as slow growth, tight credit and rising unemployment have darkened the economic outlook, one independent survey has shown support for Mr. Salinas dropping from 66 percent in early September to 45 percent in mid-October, the lowest level registered almost since he took office.
To those versed in the rhythms of Mexican politics, the idea of impending tragedy is more familiar.
Before Mr. Salinas faced his party's first serious electoral challenge in nearly 60 years, Mexican presidents had taken power with scant opposition and an almost absolute sense of power. Yet with presidents barred from re-election, the country's six-year political cycle weighed on the last four like a curse: one after another, successful administrations turned disastrous in their final two years.
 
A Flurry of Changes
 Jose Lopez Portillo, who governed from 1976 to 1982, was the strongest of the four before world prices for oil, Mexico's chief export, began to fall near the end of his term, and he led the country into its foreign debt crisis. Mexicans still sometimes bark when they see the former President on the street; just before he devalued the peso, ushering in 400 percent inflation, he had promised to defend the currency "like a dog."
Until this year, the term of Mr. Salinas had played out quite differently.
After an election that many Mexicans thought his Institutional Revolutionary Party stole from Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, who led a coalition of leftist parties, Mr. Salinas embarked on a flurry of major economic changes. He held down wages, began closing or selling off nearly 1,000 state companies, privatized the banks and continued the dismantling of trade barriers begun when Mexico joined the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in 1986.
While renegotiating the country's $92 billion debt in 1989, Mr. Salinas began slashing annual inflation from 51.7 percent the year he took office to 9.1 percent now. Sensitive laws on land tenure, religion and education were overhauled.
 
A Pledge to His Country
 Sweeping as Mr. Salinas's initiatives have often been, none has seized the imagination of his country's 85 million people like the agreement that would join Mexico to the powerful neighbor that has often been its enemy. And until it became apparent that the accord was in trouble, Mr. Salinas sold the deal relentlessly, promising skeptical Mexicans that the pact would make them "part of the first, not the third world."
Although Mr. Salinas promoted the agreement abroad as an international guarantee of permanence for his economic reforms, economic analysts believe many of those measures have taken on lives of their own.
In May, the Government granted the central bank autonomy to set monetary policy. By next year, Mexico hopes to become the first Latin American country to join the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development, a group of industrialized nations that sets standard economic goals for its members. The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum is to consider Mexico's request for admission at a meeting in Seattle this week.
Increasingly, politicians have criticized the failure of the Government to improve living standards and business executives have attacked the speed or scope of its opening to foreign competition. Yet among Mexican business people a remarkable consensus remains on the basic tenets of the new economic ideology.
"Everybody in the private sector here is convinced of the road the country has taken," said Jonathan Heath, an economic consultant in Mexico City. "You might see some things accelerate or slow down, but not a basic change in direction."
 
'The Failure of Salinas'
 Reflecting the strength of that consensus, Mr. Cardenas, the only serious challenger to the governing party who advocates a significant change in course, has for months been promising business people that he opposes only the existing trade accord, not a market economy or free trade in principle.
In an interview, Mr. Cardenas said that if the trade accord was defeated, he would direct his attack not against the United States but against "the failure of Salinas." Many political analysts believe that would give enough of a lift to Mr. Cardenas's sagging popularity to turn next year's campaign into a real race.
Their reasoning reflects the widespread belief that the essential political value of the trade agreement has been to uphold the hopes for change of millions of Mexicans who have yet to see significant personal benefits from the country's economic reforms.
Economists have predicted that over the next decade Mexico could receive as much as $15 billion in additional foreign investment if the free trade agreement is approved. A vote against the agreement would turn skittish investors away from Mexico, they say, raising pressure on the peso and possibly forcing the Government to devalue to cover the gaping $22 billion deficit in its trade of goods and services.
Yet even if the economic consequences prove severe, the political effects of a negative Congressional vote might have less to do with any real impact on people's standards of living than with their likely perception that the first world's endorsement of Mr. Salinas's policies had been withdrawn.
"The most pro-American President of the century will have been humiliated," said Federico Estevez, a political scientist here.

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: Dealing;
Clinton's Shopping List for Votes Has Ring of Grocery Buyer's List

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
To pass the trade deal that would eliminate taxes on imports from Mexico and Canada, the Clinton Administration has been forced to go this far: it has agreed to impose taxes on imports from Mexico and Canada.
The deal-making on the eve of the House vote Wednesday sounds a lot like a shopping list: beef, peanut butter, bread, sugar, orange juice, cucumbers, lettuce and celery. 
 To win the votes of legislators from farm states, the Clinton Administration has promised that if Mexican exports seriously cut into the American market, it will raise import taxes, as technically allowed by clauses drafted by the Bush Administration, which negotiated the North American Free Trade Agreement last year.
But the Clinton White House is apparently going far beyond what the Bush team envisioned, and has even reached two side deals with Mexico to reinterpret the language of the original pact to restrict trade in sugar and orange juice.
 
Controls on Peanut Butter
 Just this week the White House arranged to limit Canadian peanut butter and wheat shipments to the United States early next year. It also agreed to prevent Australian and New Zealand beef from entering the United States duty-free through Mexico by imposing stringent regulations requiring shippers to show that the cattle was raised in North America. And it pledged a swift procedure to raise tariffs temporarily on Mexican tomatoes and other winter vegetabables if Mexican imports capture what Washington considers too large a market share.
The deals appear to have been effective, since up to a dozen House members from agricultural districts in Oklahoma and Florida have agreed to support the President by voting for the trade pact.
As the White House struggled to round up enough votes for passage of the pact, it found rural Democratic lawmakers more amenable to making deals than legislators from the Northern and Rust Belt states, who tend to be linked to big labor and generally oppose the pact.
Farm groups' reservations about the effects of the agreement on specific crops can be addressed, as the White House has amply demonstrated this week, by tinkering with the regulations that would put the agreement into effect. The demands of urban workers are much harder to satisfy, on the other hand, because their concerns tend to more general -- that the agreement will make Mexico a more stable, profitable place to do business and encourage companies to move there.
 
Farmers Are Easier
 "The ag problems are more fixable than the labor problems," said a House member who insisted on anonymity.
Wheat growers, particularly near the Canadian border, have been among the agreement's strongest critics for many months. But the Administration won them over today by agreeing to open talks with Ottawa on ending Canadian subsidies for the transporation and marketing of the wheat, and to begin in 60 days a legal process leading quickly to import limits if the talks are unsuccessful.
The National Association of Wheat Growers responded by endorsing the pact this afternoon, as did Representatives Glenn English and Bill K. Brewster, Oklahoma Democrats from wheat-growing districts. Even the North Dakota Wheat Commission, a hard-line faction within the national wheat association, endorsed the pact today, although Representative Earl Pomeroy, a Democrat who is North Dakota's entire House delegation, said he remained opposed because the arrangement for curbing wheat imports would not take effect soon enough.
 
Farm Lobby's Influence

 The current deals may add a penny or two to the cost of a consumer's groceries by preventing tariffs on foreign competition from falling as quickly as might have been expected under the trade agreement. For example, the free-trade pact allows for the temporary raising of farm tariffs to their pre-agreement levels if imports prove damaging. The Administration has reassured lawmakers from rural areas of Florida by establishing swift procedures to put these provisions into effect for crops ranging from cucumbers and lettuce to bell peppers and tomatoes.
Representative Tom Lewis, Republican of Florida, agreed today to support the pact after the Administration included imported tomatoes on the list of vegetables subject to tariffs if they begin flooding the market. Still, Mr. Lewis said he was not pleased that the Administration had waited until the last minute to make a deal with him.
"I look with disdain on the way this whole thing has been done," Mr. Lewis said. "It almost looks like you're selling your soul."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "What the President Has Promised So Far"
 
PRODUCT: Beef
 STATUS QUO: Only North American beef will qualify for duty-free treatment, but ranchers worry that Australian and New Zealand beef will enter through Mexico.
 DEAL: Tight rules will require beef and cattle shippers to show where animals were raised.
 U.S. PRODUCTION: $37.9 billion
 
PRODUCT: Peanut Butter
 STATUS QUO: Canada imports peanuts for peanut butter, which it exports to the United States as a result of the 1989 U.S.-Canada Free Trade Agreement. Consequently, Canada is exempted from America's virtual ban on peanut imports.
 DEAL: The United States will move to impose limits on Canadian shipments of peanut butter in 60 days unless Canada cuts back on the amount of shipments.
 U.S. PRODUCTION: $1.3 billion.
 
PRODUCT: Wheat
 STATUS QUO: Canadian wheat exporters have captured 25 percent of the American market and 70 percent of of the Mexican market.
 DEAL: The United States, which suspects that the Canadian government subsidizes transportation and marketing of wheat, will move to impose limits on Canadian shipments in 60 days unless Canada reduces these subsidies.
 U.S. PRODUCTION: $7.6 billion
 
PRODUCT: Frozen concentrated orange juice
 STATUS QUO: American tariffs of 9.25 cents per kilogram on orange juice imported from Mexico will be phased out over 15 years.
 DEAL: If Mexican shipments increase and American prices fall, the United States would impose steep tariffs on the additional Mexican shipments. Also, in world trade talks, the United States would not accept a cut of more than 15 percent in its tariff on Brazilian orange juice.
 U.S. PRODUCTION: $3.2 billion
 
PRODUCT: Cucumbers
 STATUS QUO: American tariffs that range from 3.3 cents to 6.6 cents per kilogram, depending on the season, will be phased out over 15 years.
 DEAL: The United States would set up an expedited system to reimpose tariffs temporarily if Mexican shipments drive down the price American goods. Also, the United States would not accept more than a 15 percent cut in tariffs in world trade talks.
 U.S. PRODUCTION: $274.9 million

HEADLINE: SHELL DELIVERING GASOLINE IN HAITI

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Four weeks after the United Nations imposed an oil embargo in an attempt to force Haiti's military rulers to return the nation to democracy, the Shell Oil Company resumed gasoline deliveries today. Diplomats said the move could prolong the country's political crisis by up to six weeks.
After hearing an announcement Monday night on radio that Shell would resume sales of its gasoline reserves in Haiti, some drivers spent the night parked in front of stations to guarantee they would be among the first served when the pumps opened. 
 The streets of the capital were clogged with traffic this morning as motorists jockeyed for position at the pumps. At one station drivers formed a line more than a mile long.
The United Nations halted all oil sales to Haiti on Oct. 18 after the country's military leaders refused to resign to allow the return of Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. The embargo has been backed by United States Navy ships, which have turned around ships trying to deliver banned goods to Haiti.
An earlier embargo against Haiti was lifted after a United Nations-mediated accord was signed in New York by Father Aristide and Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, who overthrew him in a coup in September 1991. Under the terms of the accord, the military leadership was supposed to step down in exchange for an amnesty and Father Aristide was scheduled to return on Oct. 30.
 
Prices Haves Soared
 When the second embargo was imposed, foreign oil companies halted all deliveries to their stations although they were estimated to have about six weeks of reserves already in the country. Since then, prices have skyrocketed, and many businesses have closed. Gasoline has been selling for $10 a gallon on the black market.
Shell's surprise decision to begin selling its gasoline reserves came after lawyers for Haiti's petroleum distributors threatened to ask the army's help in forcing the three foreign oil companies in Haiti -- Shell, Texaco and Exxon -- to distribute their reserves.
The three companies had refused to release the stocks, saying that to do so would breach the embargo. But renewed threats that company employees would be arrested if the gasoline was not released appear to have persuaded Shell to resume deliveries.
Diplomats say Tuesday's move will drag out the country's political crisis by giving Father Aristide's opponents, especially the military, more time.
Officials of Haiti's civilian Government, which was appointed in anticipation of Father Aristide's return, were also dismayed by Shell's decision. "This will just prolong the crisis," an aide to Prime Minister Robert Malval said.
Oil company executives refused to say how long the reserves will last, but analysts estimate that there could be enough gasoline to last six weeks. Texaco and Exxon are expected to follow Shell's example and release their reserves later this week.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Clinton California Conundrum for '96

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
For President Clinton, California's beleaguered economy presents two riddles, with heavy political implications for 1996.
First, how can his Administration help pull California, with its 54 electoral votes, out of the economic abyss as Pentagon cutbacks continue to drag that state down? And how can the Administration mount a plan to rescue California without having other states accuse it of favoritism? 
 For months the Administration has wrestled with these conundrums, facing complaints from California that it is not doing enough, while New York and other states suggest it is doing too much.
 
Danger Signs for '96
 If President Clinton does not find a solution that will satisfy both California and the rest of the country, it could spell big trouble for him in a 1996 re-election race.
"There's no question that if California's recession goes on to 1996, it's going to be very difficult for Clinton," said Mervyn Field, a veteran California pollster. "It would be death to him if he didn't try to help California. It could make or break his chances in 1996."
Trying to please all sides, the Administration has tentatively settled on a strategy: it will move heaven and earth to help California's economy while staying within budget limitations but not play favorites.
In other words, the Administration is giving California heaps of money to convert military complexes to civilian uses, is gearing up to expand small business loans for the state and is making sure California gets a steady flow of Federal projects.
 
Balancing Act
 But Clinton Administration officials insist they are not favoring California, noting that Connecticut, New York and other states are also benefiting from such programs.
Rather, they say the Administration is treating California like a laboratory, where it will test programs for hard-hit areas that might then be used in other states.
At the moment, the Administration's evolving strategy is not pleasing anyone entirely.
"The Administration isn't doing enough," said Senator Dianne Feinstein, a California Democrat. "The Administration can't be afraid of what the other states think. California's unemployment rate is 9.8 percent, 3 percent over the nation's. We're the state hit hardest by defense downsizing. We've had every problem: the fires, the riots, the earthquake."
 
Rail Project Urged
 Reminding the White House of California's political influence, Senator Feinstein has been urging the President to spend 50 percent of the planned $19.5 billion in military conversion funds on her state, up from the current 20 percent. She also wants the Administration to finance a high-speed railroad through California and to favor it over other states in awarding Federal projects.
But Representative Marcy Kaptur, an Ohio Democrat who is co-chairman of a coalition of 92 Northeast and Midwest House members, has warned the President that there will be a political price to pay if he lavishes goodies on California at the expense of other states.
Ms. Kaptur sees no reason why the Government should do somersaults to help California. She contends that Washington ignored the Midwest when it was down and out in the 1980's and glamorous California was living high on the hog.
 
Say No to Favoritism
 "It's wrong to favor one region over another," she said. "We have lots of people who lost their jobs in the private sector, and we don't see why, just because they don't come from the defense sector, they deserve less attention."
For the Administration, the question is not favoring one region over another but figuring out what should be done for the nation's most depressed state. They say Mr. Clinton's help for California is consistent with American tradition, like President Lyndon B. Johnson's War on Poverty, which largely aimed to help backward Appalachia. Besides, Administration officials reason, for a state that grew fat by building missiles and jet fighters, it is only fair for Washington to lend a hand when Pentagon spending cuts are the main force pulling that state down.
"The economic situation in California didn't happen overnight. There has been a downward spiral that's been frightening, particularly in Southern California," said Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, who was named by President Clinton to oversee efforts to help California. "One-eighth of the nation's people live there, it represents one-seventh of the gross domestic product. It was the judgment of the President that California needed some concentrated attention."
 
Frequent Traveler
 It has got attention galore. Mr. Brown has been to California 11 times since March. The President's order to remove export controls on $37 billion in high-tech goods is a boon to Silicon Valley. California firms and schools won 22 percent of the $140 million that the Government awarded last month for projects to adapt military technologies to civilian use. The Government has given California two of the nation's four centers aimed at promoting high-tech exports, and it plans to open a special center in Los Angeles to help minority business.
Last month, the Government picked Stanford University over Cornell for a $36 million high-energy physics laboratory, a decision that caused New York's two most powerful Democrats -- Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan -- to complain to the White House.
"We want fair federalism for both states," Mr. Cuomo said at the time. (Some White House officials admit that whenever they are about to take a pro-California action, they first ask themselves how New York's Governor will react.)
 
And Santa Isn't Finished
 But Mr. Clinton has more in his Christmas stocking for California. It is due to receive a disproportionate share of money from new programs to retrain workers and finance environmental technologies.
To ward off charges that all these efforts amount to favoritism, Administration officials assert that the California aid is in many ways a Federally sponsored experiment that can show other states how to convert from military to civilian production. The idea, officials say, is to form a public-private partnership to lift California, especially by spurring defense conversion and small business.
"What we do successfully we hope will be replicated around the country," said Lawrence Parks, a special policy adviser to Secretary Brown.

HEADLINE: Giuliani and 4 County Chiefs Form a Regional Alliance

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani and the executives of four counties around New York City announced yesterday that they would forge an alliance to work together on regional issues from economic development to transportation and, for the first time in memory, prepare a common agenda to take to Albany and Washington.
Mr. Giuliani and the top officeholders of Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Counties -- all of them Republicans -- portrayed the alliance as a potential boon for the entire region's economy. Its purpose, they said, would be to rise above the local interests that have created deep rifts and, on occasion, open hostilities between the city and its suburbs. 
 "There are differences between and among us," Mr. Giuliani said yesterday after meeting with the four county executives for more than an hour at his transition headquarters on Madison Avenue. "But they are overshadowed and overwhelmed by the agreements that exist and the things we need for our counties."
It remains to be seen, however, whether yesterday's spirit of collaboration can overcome the divisions, particularly on such issues as the formula for state aid to schools, which the city has long argued favors suburban school districts.
 
Competition for Jobs
 And whatever the public platitudes and the common goals, the alliance will inevitably find itself strained when, say, a major corporation threatens to move its headquarters and 500 or so jobs from Manhattan to Westchester.
"There's no question that there will be some areas of disagreement," Mr. Giuliani said, "but even then, our remaining together and working together makes the most sense."
The five executives -- Mr. Giuliani, Thomas S. Gulotta of Nassau, Robert J. Gaffney of Suffolk, Andrew J. O'Rourke of Westchester and C. Scott Vanderhoef of Rockland -- will meet quarterly.
Representing 62 percent of the state's population, the alliance could have considerable sway in Albany, if the disparate governments can agree on a common agenda. It could also become a political challenge to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the State Legislature.
 
Political Move Denied
 At a news conference after yesterday's meeting, the executives maintained their alliance was not a political one -- even though their elections mean that come Jan. 1, for the first time in a generation, the chiefs of New York's downstate counties will all be Republicans.
Mr. Cuomo, who was traveling to Buffalo yesterday, was not available to comment, but a spokesman, Charles Porcari, said the Governor hoped the alliance would force action on issues long stalled in the divided Legislature, primarily his proposal to take over local Medicaid costs in return for a percentage of local sales tax.
Some of the common interests mentioned at yesterday's news conference included reducing the state's hotel tax and persuading the State Legislature to help pay for the programs it mandates for local governments.
The executives also said they would join together in planning policies that affect them all, including transportation, the environment and economic development, though they did not offer details of how they would do so.
 
Transition Presses On
 Meanwhile, Mr. Giuliani's transition team continued to prepare lists of candidates for police commissioner and budget director, two positions the Mayor-elect has described as his top priorities.
Among the candidates who reportedly have emerged for budget director are Dall W. Forsythe, the former state budget director under Governor Cuomo; Mark V. Shaw, who is the City Council's budget director; Abe Lackman, a budget analyst for the State Senate, and Elinor B. Bachrach, deputy state comptroller for New York City.
But when Mr. Forsythe, now a lecturer at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, was contacted by members of the transition team yesterday, he took himself out of contention.
The transition also announced that Mr. Giuliani's public inauguration will take place on Jan. 2 on the steps of City Hall. Inaugurations have traditionally been held on Jan. 1, but this year the inauguration would have fallen on a Saturday, meaning Orthodox Jews could not attend.
Mr. Giuliani, who received strong support from conservative Jewish voters, has said he wanted to schedule the inauguration so that Jewish supporters could attend.

HEADLINE: Poll Says People Expect Delay on the Health Plan

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

 BODY:
The American public doubts that Congress can pass health care legislation, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows. But, at least for now, the public blames the issue's complexities, not the lawmakers.
The poll showed that 57 percent of the public expected Congress to fail to pass a health care plan by the end of next year as President Clinton hopes, while 36 percent said they thought it would succeed. 
 But these views are unusually tolerant of Congress. Of those who expect Congress to fail, two-thirds said the reason was that the issue is too complicated. They numbered three times as many as those who said it was an inherent inability of Congress to solve important problems.
And among those who expected some plan to emerge from Congress on the White House schedule, about two-fifths said the lawmakers would improve on the Clinton plan; about one-third said they would make it worse.
Those signs of public amiability toward Capitol Hill may be short-lived, however. Fifteen percent of the public -- more than for any other issue with a specific legislative solution -- regards health care as the nation's most important problem, and only one-fourth of the public said it approved of how Congress was generally handling its job.
 
Congressional Motivations
 And the public, by an overwhelming 78 to 14 percent, said it believed that generally when Congress fails to pass legislation, the cause is selfish political reasons, not honest disagreement about policy.
The poll also made clear that President Clinton's advocacy of a plan for universal health insurance remains a prime political asset for him. His overall approval rating in the latest poll, conducted by telephone with 1,334 adults from Thursday through Sunday, improved to 46 percent, the best recorded in these polls since June. Forty-one percent disapproved of his performance. The margin of sampling error in all three polls was plus or minus three percentage points.
Mr. Clinton's handling of health care was approved by 49 percent of the public in the latest poll, and disapproved by 37 percent. That was distinctly better than the 38 percent who said they liked his handling of the economy or the 38 percent who approved of his performance in foreign policy. Because of its promise of universal coverage that could not be lost, his health care plan was favored by the poll's respondents despite fears that it would raise their own taxes and despite doubts that it would improve their own health care.
A similar plurality, 45 percent, said his plan would make health care in the United States better, while 27 percent said care would be made worse. Opposition has risen slightly from that shown in a poll taken just before he announced the program to a joint session of Congress on Sept. 22. In that survey, 46 percent said the plan would make health care better and 20 percent said it would make it worse.
One major political attack against Mr. Clinton's plan has been the contention that it would promote managed health care in a way that would deny Americans the right to choose their own doctors.
 
Divergence of Views
 The poll suggested that this argument was not widely accepted. While the survey indicated that 73 percent of Americans have their own doctor, only 15 percent of the public said they believed they would be unable to keep seeing that doctor if the President's plan was enacted. That 15 percent, mostly Republican, also felt that the plan was not fair to them personally and would be bad for health care generally.
Health care clearly remains an advantage not only for the President but also for the Democratic Party. Forty-eight percent of the public said Democrats were more likely than Republicans to improve the health care system. Republicans were the only significant group of respondents to disagree, by 50 percent to 22 percent.
Sixty-five percent said yes when asked, "Do you think Bill Clinton cares about the needs and problems of people like yourself?" Thirty percent said he did not.
Besides the traditionally supportive demographic groups, like blacks, union members and the poor, majorities of several groups generally dubious about the Clinton Presidency, like Republicans, conservatives and white men, felt that Mr. Clinton cared about people like them.
The public is also impressed with the health care plan's chief public advocate, Hillary Rodham Clinton. Forty-five percent said they had a favorable view of her, while 21 percent had an unfavorable opinion. That is as high a favorable rating as these Times/CBS News Polls have recorded for her, although far less than the 81 percent with a favorable view of Barbara Bush in March 1992.

HEADLINE: Chicken Shop Selling Guns, Officials Say

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

 BODY:
Roberto Pennyfeather didn't know about guns or drugs being sold at Mama's Fried Chicken in the Bronx. But then, like most of his neighbors, he didn't want to know.
"You just knew from who was around at night that it was a dangerous place," said Mr. Pennyfeather, who lives around the corner from Mama's, in East Tremont. "I don't ask too many questions." 
 The true business of Mama's, law-enforcement officials charged yesterday, was that of a supermarket in New York City's vast subterranean economy of destruction, operating virtually in the shadow of a junior high school. On Monday the chicken stand's owner, Fareedullah Nawabi, was arrested and charged with selling 59 unregistered firearms, 234 rounds of ammunition, a pound of cocaine and some heroin to undercover officers over a three-month period. When he was arrested, the police said, five more guns were confiscated at the store.
Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, said at a news conference that Mama's was a "a guns-for-order business with takeout service," specializing in the most popular weapons of the street -- 9-millimeter and .380-caliber semiautomatic pistols and .357 Magnum and .38-caliber revolvers. More exotic hardware, like a Calico pistol with a 50-round drum magazine, was also for sale, he said.
 
Received First Tips
 The investigation into Mama's was done by the police and the Manhattan District Attorney's office, which received the first tips of the gun sales in 1991, and the city's Office of Special Narcotics and the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms.
Mr. Nawabi, who lives in Flushing, Queens, with his father and sister, faces an array of charges that could net him a sentence of 25 years to life in prison if convicted. He pleaded not guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, and Acting Justice Leslie C. Synder ordered him held without bail.
"I'm confident that when all the facts are in, Mr. Nawabi will be exonerated," said his lawyer, Paul S. Brenner.
 
Political Asylum
 Mr. Brenner said that before coming to the United States in 1989, Mr. Nawabi, 23, was one of the Mujahadeen, the rebels who battled Soviet troops and the Soviet-backed Government of Afghanistan for more than a decade. "I understand he and his family were given political asylum here," Mr. Brenner said.
A second suspect, Russel Thompson of the Bronx, was arrested in Ohio, where investigators said many of the guns were first sold, but officials would not say what he was being charged with.
Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said Mr. Nawabi, an Afghan national known as Mohammed, bragged to an undercover investigator that he had sold a million guns from Mama's. "Obviously, we have to give him a little leeway for braggadocio," Mr. Kelly said, "but this is a significant case, a major case, as far as gun dealing in the Bronx and the city of New York."
Officials said Mr. Nawabi's clientele were criminals willing to pay a premium for hard-to-trace weapons. A police lieutenant, Kenneth McCann, said undercover officers paid a total of $26,000 for guns with a retail value of $11,000.
Mama's, on Boston Road at Seabury Place, sits at the southern end of a busy strip of delicatessens and groceries, within 100 yards of two churches, in an area dominated by five- and six-story apartment houses.
The residents, mostly black and Hispanic, say the neighborhood has rebounded from its nadir in the late -1970's. They point to a few dozen neat single-family homes with well-kept yards, where 10 years ago there were abandoned and fire-gutted buildings, and to Public School 98 across the street from Mama's, which, after being shuttered for a couple of years, reopened as the Foreign Language and Global Studies magnet school.
Still the fear that pervades so many of the city's neighborhoods has not entirely abated, nor has the sense that too much inquiry is a dangerous thing. Many people who live and work nearby say they knew that something was wrong at Mama's, which was open around the clock, but were not quite sure what.
Kosa, a teen-age girl who refused to give her last name, said, "There was always drug dealers sitting in there, and everybody knew it."
 
'Don't Want to Know'
 Angelo Sanchez, who works at a carburetor repair shop half a block away, said he had often wondered why Mama's was bustling at 3 A.M. But when pressed about what he might have seen, he said, "Sometimes you don't want to know."
Lieutenant McCann said investigators spent nearly two years trying to arrange an introduction to meet Mr. Nawabi and win his confidence. The first purchase of two handguns by an undercover investigator was made last August through the restaurant's drive-up window, he said.
The fast-food business served as little more than a front for the illegal trade, the lieutenant said. In the 11 weeks that law-enforcement officials had the restaurant under surveillance, he said, "I don't think they sold $50 worth of chicken."

HEADLINE: U.S. Survey Underestimated The Jobless Rate for Women

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
The Government has been substantially underestimating unemployment for at least a decade or more, particularly among women, the Labor Department reported today.
As part of the biggest revamping in the 53-year history of the Government survey that determines the nation's official jobless rate, researchers at the Labor Department have discovered a bias in the survey under which many women who were seeking jobs were erroneously described as homemakers, and therefore not counted as being in the work force. 
 Under the redesigned survey, which tries to wipe out any bias, the nation's average unemployment rate in the 12 months through August was 7.6 percent, a half-point above the 7.1 percent that the department had reported. The rate for women was 6.8 percent, rather than 6.0 percent; for men, the figure went to 6.9 percent from 6.7.
 
 
Discouraged Workers
 The Labor Department also discovered that besides undercounting jobless women, it was also miscounting laid off and so-called discouraged workers.
The redesigned questionnaire, which was tested in parallel with the present system for 12 months ending in August, will be used officially by the Labor Department beginning in January. If the higher jobless rates persist when the new survey takes effect, they could affect benefit programs like state unemployment compensation systems that are tied to joblessness figures.
Officials at the Labor Department said they had suspected for some time that the survey, whose last major revision was in 1967, was failing to reflect changes in American society, such as the greater participation of women in the work force. But it took years to design the revision and begin to put it into effect.
The effort, begun in 1986 and costing $40 million, includes the collection of new data, rewording of questions, changes in definitions and computerization of the entire process, beginning with laptop computers that will soon be carried into households by interviewers.
The first results using the new system will be published in early February; the old survey will be calculated, but with sharply reduced samples.
Marvin Kosters, a labor specialist at the American Enterprise Institute and its director of economic policy studies, said, "It's essential to move toward the use of new technology even if it means we have a little discontinuity" in the statistics.
But he also said that the figures published today acted as a reminder of the "subjective" element in even the most sophisticated data, and he reserved judgment about specific changes.
Labor Department officials also cautioned against making too much of the experimental comparisons published today, since the monthly variations were great in the year they ran their test, the samples relatively small and interviewers were still becoming acquainted with the refined questions and their new technology.
Nonetheless, the differences pointed up in the experimental results are considered important both inside and outside the Labor Department. Private analysts who have followed the redesign process generally applauded the effort, and some expressed little surprise at the results.
"The academic work that preceded this was careful, thoughtful and completely nonpolitical," said H. Erich Heinemann, an economist and student of the figures who works at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company, a securities house.
The redesign of the survey began with well-grounded suspicions that it was not capturing various shifts in American society and even, as in the case with the word "layoff," shifts in word usage.
Since the updating in 1967, the department said today, "there have been many societal changes, such as the continuing growth in service-sector employment; the more prominent role of women, particularly mothers, in the labor force, and shifts in the nature of employment, including more part-time work and less permanent attachment of employees to their employers."
One of the main deficiencies in the present survey, department officials said, was the first question interviewers asked householders, whether by visit or by telephone.
If a man responded, the interviewer typically asked whether he was "working or something else" during the period under survey while a woman was more likely to be asked whether she was "keeping house or something else."
 
 
'Tailoring' of Questions
 This bias due to wording and the "tailoring" of early questions "has caused some unemployed women to be misclassified as not in the labor force," the department found in its studies. This held the unemployment rate down since one must be actively seeking work to be considered unemployed.
Similarly, the word layoff had traditionally been used by respondents to describe a temporary period of not working when they expected to be called back to a job. But the Labor Department in recent years has increasingly found people using it even when they had no expectation of going back.
Thus the revamped survey abandons what the department called its probably "most notoriously complex" question: "Did you have a job or business from which you were temporarily absent or on layoff last week?" Replacing it are simpler, more straightforward questions, including whether the worker has been given a date to return.
The redesign of the survey, initiated when Janet L. Norwood was Commissioner of Labor Statistics, was inspired by a Presidential commission headed by Sar Levitan, a labor economist at George Washington University. In 1979, the commission recommended changes in the measurement of discouraged workers.
Such workers are those who have dropped out of the labor force because they believe a job search would be in vain, and so they are no longer counted as unemployed.
 
 
New Calculations
 Under the redesign, less than half as many workers will be classified as discouraged because of a new requirement that they have searched for work within the last year and are available to take a job. The change would tend to raise the unemployment rate because these workers would be listed as part of the work force, but unemployed.
This figure, which has been calculated quarterly, will now come out every month.
Among the other improvements produced by the redesigned survey will be better tracking of people over time to get data on movements between jobs, and more specific questioning of part-time workers about their desire for full-time work and their availability to take it if offered.
The parallel, or experimental, survey found a larger proportion of people working part time by choice than did the existing survey.
Respondents will now be permitted to disclose their pay by month or annually or in some other way, rather than having to specify, perhaps roughly, in weekly terms. And the inquiry into time worked has been sharpened to obtain actual hours on the job, avoiding a generality that might have been based on someone's usual schedule.
 
 
Improving Accuracy
 Spells of joblessness can be given in either weeks or months, improving accuracy and, according to the experimental figures, raising both the median and mean durations.
Full computerization of the process, the Department also said, permits more contingent questioning, the retrieval and verification of data from a preceding month's interview. This reduces repetitive questions and provides checks for consistency.
The department conducts its survey of households -- called the Current Population Survey -- to cover the week containing the 12th of each month. About 60,000 respondents are included, with households interviewed for four straight months after which they are out of the survey for eight months before coming back in for a final four months. Interviews are conducted at the respondent's home in the first and fifth months of their total of eight in the survey.
The department's other employment survey, which measures the number of payroll jobs, is unaffected by the changes in the Current Population Survey.
