HEADLINE: Cold War Over, Foreign Affairs Schools Refocus

BYLINE: By KEN BROWN

 BODY:
With the end of the cold war eliminating the superpower tensions that guided two generations of diplomats, graduate schools of foreign affairs are shifting their focus to the complexities of world trade, new technologies and the environment.
"The foreign policy after the cold war is going to be more concerned with economics and technology, and it's going to be more driven by the private sector than Government," said Stephen F. Szabo, associate dean for academic affairs at Johns Hopkins University's Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies. 
 "There is a sense that security and traditional concerns that were associated with the cold war have diminished in importance," said Professor Szabo, who led a curriculum review that included the creation of a program in energy, environmental science and technology.
The changes have been felt most deeply in courses on international security and on the former Soviet Union, which had been mainstays of curriculums at the major universities around the country that offer two-year master's degrees in international affairs.
But as such programs rush to meet the needs of a new generation of foreign affairs specialists, they are also struggling to preserve a focus that distinguishes them from business and other schools that are paying more attention to international issues, once the province of foreign affairs programs.
 
Tossing Old Lecture Notes
 At the same time, the push for new curriculums is offering international affairs schools an opportunity to breath new life into old courses.
Jeswald W. Salacuse, dean of the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University, said: "We're looking at new issues. We're looking at old issues in new ways. And so I don't think anybody is teaching his or her material in exactly the same way it was taught before."
Among the examples of new directions cited by Dean Salacuse are courses on conflict resolution and peacekeeping. The school is also bringing in anthropologists to teach a course on the cultural and ethnic roots of conflict.
At Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government, Philip D. Zelikow, an assistant professor of public policy, has shifted the main international relations course from a bipolar view of world relations to an emphasis on combining economics and political science to develop policy choices.
"For Americans during the cold war, some of the dominant interests were already mapped out, and people defined their positions by reference to that map, even if they didn't agree with it," Professor Zelikow said. "Now people are having to chart new intellectual maps of how they perceive the world. It's a harder challenge, both intellectually and politically, as President Clinton has discovered."
 
Demand for Programs Grows
 Professors are now dwelling more on power relations that lie outside the classical east-west military balance that defined cold war diplomacy. Today's security programs focus on small regional and ethnic conflicts and peacekeeping, while programs on Soviet studies concentrate on the building of democracy and free markets in the former republics and the new nations being carved from the old empire.
"There was wide recognition that old courses had fallen into this pattern of political and military on one side and economics on the other side," said Professor Zelikow, who was a foreign service officer and served in the Bush White House before going to Harvard in 1991.
Despite the rapidly changing international scene, or perhaps because of it, interest in foreign affairs programs has continued to grow. According to a study by 12 of the 15 members of the Association of Professional Schools of International Affairs, applications rose 63 percent between 1988 and 1992. Of the 12,000 students who applied to the two-year master's degree programs at the top 15 schools in 1992, about 39 percent were admitted, the group said.
The schools, which charge $7,500 to more than $19,000 a year in tuition and fees, are all trying to remain competitive by responding to student demands.
 
Working to Stay Competitive

For example, the School of International and Public Affairs at Columbia has attracted students by offering media courses in conjunction with the university's Graduate School of Journalism. But when in-coming students in the fall of 1990 found they were being shut out of media courses, including the broadcasting class, they organized and protested, demanding more classes, better access to the journalism school and fewer guest professors.
"People felt that the program was oversold," said Claudia Kalb, who as a graduate student in international affairs helped organize the protest. "It was advertised as a journalism program, and it really wasn't.
The school responded by adding classes and paying the journalism school to admit international affairs students to its broadcasting course.
Nowhere is the blurring of the schools' purpose more evident than in the international business programs that many of them now offer. Students are keenly aware that they are entering a tough job market in which they will be competing with M.B.A. graduates who are getting more international training than ever before.
 
Confusion in Job Market
 Professor Szabo of Johns Hopkins, said: "The business schools already are beginning to come in the direction of international relations training because they understand their students are going to be working in a global economy. We have to move, to some degree, toward the M.B.A. program and provide some of the more technical skills to help them at the entry level."
Johns Hopkins, for example, has added an accounting course to its international relations program, he said.
Several school officials say that their students now have all the skills of someone with an M.B.A., plus knowledge of politics, economic development and languages, but that recruiters reflexively hire business school graduates.
"It is clear with the internationalization of business schools the marketplace has become confused over how we are different," said John G. Ruggie, the Dean of Columbia's international affairs program.
Aggravating the problem is the fact that the top 15 schools offer an alphabet soup of 22 degrees with different names and derived from different curriculums, said Allan E. Goodman, associate dean of the School of Foreign Service at Georgetown University.
"There is tremendous confusion in the marketplace about what we do," he said, "and it's going to take a while for people to realize these degrees are roughly the same and they prepare people for public and private service."
Such confusion in the job market has also engendered some resentment among unemployed and deeply indebted graduates. Several said they regretted not having chosen business school instead of international affairs, where, in the words of Kaushik Shridharani, an unemployed graduate of Columbia's program, "the degree becomes so diluted" as to be almost useless.

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: The Overview;
HOUSE BACKS FREE TRADE PACT IN MAJOR VICTORY FOR CLINTON AFTER A LONG HUNT FOR VOTES

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
President Clinton scored one of the biggest triumphs of his Presidency tonight when the House of Representatives voted to expand trade with Mexico and turn North America into the world's largest free trade zone.
Legislation to put the North American Free Trade Agreement into effect starting Jan. 1 and to gradually abolish nearly all trade barriers between the United States, Mexico and Canada was adopted by a vote of 234 to 200, with three-fifths of the Democrats voting against the President and most Republicans supporting him. 
 The surprisingly large margin of victory, 16 votes more than needed to approve the legislation, could not have been imagined as recently as last weekend. As late as this afternoon, the Administration's head-counters, while expressing confidence, said victory was not a certainty.
 
'We Chose to Compete'
 Senate approval in the next week is certain, leaders of both parties said.
In the tally tonight, 102 of the 258 Democrats voted for the measure and to support their President. They were joined by 132 Republicans. On the other side, 156 Democrats, 43 Republicans and one independent voted against the bill. [Roll-call, page A20.]
Other than the budget votes in August, when Mr. Clinton prevailed by two votes in the House and one vote in the Senate, tonight's vote was the most important politically for the President and for Congress.
At the White House tonight, Mr. Clinton proclaimed the victory "a defining moment for our nation."
"At a time when many of our people are hurting from the strains of this tough global economy," he said, "we chose to compete, not retreat. Tonight I am proud to say, we have not flinched."
In an odd reversal, Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the Republican leader, gave a spirited defense of the President and the trade agreement in the final moments of the daylong debate. And Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the Democratic whip and usually a Clinton loyalist, gave an emotional closing speech against the measure.
With almost every representative on the floor and every seat in the visitors' gallery filled as the vote neared, Mr. Michel declared that the opponents of expanded trade with Mexico wanted "to define our time as the age of anxiety, in which our only response to the challenges of global competition is to retreat, whine and whimper."
He implored his colleagues, "Do not sacrifice the jobs of tomorrow to the fears of today."
 
A Standing Ovation
 Mr. Bonior brought the Democratic side of the chamber to its feet with a standing ovation, and some legislators appeared to be in tears.
"The working people who stand against this treaty don't have degrees from Harvard," he declared. "They don't study economic models. And most of them have never heard of Adam Smith. But they know when the deck is stacked against them. They know it's not fair to ask American workers to compete gainst Mexican workers who earn $1 an hour.
"The work of America is still done by people who pack a lunch, punch a clock and pour their heart and soul into every paycheck. And we can't afford to leave them behind."
In the debate, Republicans made a point of the fact that they were supporting Mr. Clinton as he prepares to go to Seattle for a meeting with leaders from Asian countries. Democrats did not appeal for loyalty to their party's President, a recognition that the heart of the party lay elsewhere.
 
Thank You to Republicans
 Appearing before television cameras in the Grand Foyer of the White House, just after 11 P.M., Mr. Clinton reached out to the fellow Democrats and labor leaders with whom he had fiercely battled. He portrayed them as "passionate defenders of the working people."
But even before his public remarks, Mr. Clinton telephoned Mr. Michel and Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip, to thank them for the Republican assistance that proved decisive in winning passage of the trade accord.
Vice President Al Gore is likely to travel to Mexico next week to discuss implementation of the accord with President Carlos Salinas Gortari, White House officials said tonight.
Mr. Clinton depicted the vote as a decisive moment in his Presidency, and spent the bulk of the last several weeks rounding up support. In Congress, some members saw the occasion as a rare vote on which their political futures could hang.
 
Symbol of Change
 The agreement, negotiated by the Bush Administration, creates a free trade zone from the Yukon to Yucatan. Since the United States and Canada are already bound by a free trade agreement, and since commerce between Canada and Mexico is relatively meager, the main question involved trade expansion between the United States and Mexico, its third-largest trading partner.
The substantive arguments seemed almost mundane, not worthy of the high political stakes riding on the outcome. Proponents said the agreement would generate a few hundred thousand additional jobs in the United States; opponents said it would cost a few hundred thousand. In an economy where about 120 million people go to work every day, the difference is no more than a statistical asterisk.
But the accord had become a symbol of the economic changes in the United States, of the promise for those who stand to benefit from an economy dominated by high technology and an educated work force, and of the anxiety for those who see a future in which there are ever-fewer high-paying assembly-line jobs for Americans without a college education or a skilled craft.
Labor unions ferociously opposed the agreement. Businesses generally supported it. Economists and foreign policy experts were almost unanimously in favor of it. So was every living past President, from Richard M. Nixon through George Bush.
Many political strategists advised their clients to vote against the agreement. In part, the reason was that opponents seemed to feel so much more strongly about the accord than those who favored it. In part, it was that legislators who voted for the agreement could expect to be blamed for every factory that closes in their districts, regardless of the real reason for the shutdown.
 
Equally Divided Time
 Partisan loyalties went by the boards, in striking contrast to the budget battle, which was decided on party-line votes. Within the Democratic and Republican parties, the divisions on trade were sharper than they had been over any other issue since the Vietnam War. Representatives mostly voted on the basis of what they saw as the interest of their own districts.
Usually, the debate time in the House is divided equally between proponents of an issue and opponents. This time, the eight hours of debate were allotted in fourths. Democratic supporters and opponents and Republican supporters and opponents each got two hours. No amendments were allowed.
The opposition outside the Capitol had strange bedfellows: Ross Perot and Ralph Nader, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Patrick J. Buchanan.
Both sides presented the vote as one on which America's future was in the balance.
Representative Dan Rostenkowski, a Chicago Democrat who heads the Ways and Means Committee and backed the agreement, put the matter this way:
"Our vote today will help determine what kind of American economy our children will inherit. We are debating whether America is a confident country, eager to face the future, ready to take on all competitors, or a nation in decline clinging to memories of our past.
"In this debate, we are telling the world how we view ourselves, whether we welcome change and challenge or whether we fear it."
But the agreement's opponents were equally passionate.
"This agreement before us is deficient and flawed," declared Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader.
Mr. Gephardt complained that the accord did too little to raise wages in Mexico to a point where American companies would not be induced to close their plants here and move south of the border.
"This country's greatness," he shouted, "was not built on cheap labor."
 
A Novel Experience
 Occasionally during the Reagan and Bush years, when Democrats controlled the House, as they have since the early 1950's, significant tax and budget measures strongly supported by the White House were approved with Democratic support over the opposition of a majority of House Republicans. That was the case in 1985 on legislation overhauling the income tax system and in 1990 on a deficit-reduction package.
But students of Congress said they could not recall an occasion when the White House and the House of Representatives were controlled by the same party and major legislation was approved with the majority party in the House voting against it.
The House was not literally voting on the trade agreement itself tonight. Rather, it was considering legislation that would make the necessary changes in American law so the agreement could go into effect.
As recently as last weekend, Mr. Bonior and others on his side said they had the votes locked up to defeat the pact. But that underestimated the hole cards in the White House's hand.
Alone and in groups, representatives were called to the White House to be worked over by the President. Those on the fence received 10, 20, 30 calls a day from Cabinet members and influential constituents rounded up by proponents of the accord. Mr. Clinton himself was still on the phone most of today.
To win support from particular lawmakers, deals were struck to restrain imports of orange juice, winter vegetables, sugar, peanut butter and wheat. A development bank was promised, to provide seed money for environmental development projects in the United States and Mexico.
As far as could be learned, all the deals involved trade and border projects. If bridges, judgeships or other more tangible prizes were offered in return for votes, the arrangements remained secret.
Opponents of the accord complained that votes were being bought and sold. But Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said today that the late arrangements represented "a strengthening of the agreement" and were "very important from the American point of view."

HEADLINE: U.S. Bishops Urge Men to Share in Work at Home

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
The nation's Roman Catholic bishops today unanimously voted to urge husbands and wives to treat one another as equals and men to share fully in child rearing and household duties.
The bishops also voted to ask the Vatican to make it easier to dismiss priests who sexually molest minors and passed a lengthy document on the moral responsibilities of the United States in the post-cold-war world. 
 The bishops said they sympathized with families in their struggles to cope with economic pressures and the unforeseen traumas of divorce, illness, alcoholism, neighborhood violence and AIDS, as well as the daily frictions of "different temperaments and opposing points of views."
The letter to families, titled "Follow the Way of Love," was approved by a unanimous vote. Its wording is practical and direct, avoiding the often difficult style of church documents that address questions of doctrine.
Aware of their status as celibate clergy, the bishops said that, nonetheless, "We have known the commitment and sacrifices of a mother and father, the warmth of a family's care, the happiness and pain that are part of loving." And they noted that they, too, "are sons and brothers and uncles."
Addressing their words primarily to Catholic families but adding that they might be useful to others, the bishops said, "The story of family life is a story about love -- shared, nurtured, and sometimes rejected or lost."
The bishops asked men and women to look beyond the familiar sexual roles. For many men, they said, "sharing feelings and a willingness to be vulnerable can be difficult, especially for those of us raised in the 'strong and silent' tradition."
The bishops urged men to view "their traditional role as 'provider' for a family in more than an economic sense. "Physical care of children, discipline, training in religious values and practices, helping with school work and other activities, all these and more can be provided by fathers as well as mothers," they said.
The message recognized that rapid social change and the hectic pace of American life were taking a toll on families.
"We urge you to take time to be together: making shared meals a priority (even if you gather at a fast-food restaurant), praying and worshiping together, especially at the Sunday Eucharist," the bishops said, and "building family traditions and rituals."
The message also develops the concept of the family as a "domestic church" that carries out a religious mission through spouses' love for each other and the care and teaching provided children.
The message will be widely distributed in the church.
 
Some Criticism of Text
 Some conservative Catholics criticized the message, which was written as the bishops' contribution to the "International Year of the Family" announced by the United Nations for 1994. In the newsletter of Women for Faith and Family, Helen Hull Hitchcock, the group's executive director, called the message "a retrogressive rehash of the secular sociological nostrums of the recent past -- with a heavy layer of multiculturalism and a thin Catholic glaze."
But none of that sentiment was expressed at the bishops' meeting. Four of the nation's active cardinals praised the document. Roger Cardinal Mahony of Los Angeles called it "so readable that it is hardly believable it is one of our documents."
Anthony Cardinal Bevilacqua of Philadelphia expressed gratitude for the message's reference to the fact that bishops, too, are members of families and experience the joys and tragedies of family life. "Sometimes people think we are products of spontaneous generation," he said.
The document on the United States and international affairs said the bishops recognized that the collapse of Communism had revealed the "new importance" of nonviolence. But the bishops turned down the pleas of Detroit's Auxiliary Bishop, Thomas J. Gumbleton, a representative of the pacifist wing of the American bishops, to condemn all warfare as immoral and to demand the immediate abandonment of the nation's remaining nuclear weapons.
 
On Sex-Abuse Cases
 Although the bishops were overwhelming in their support for changes in church law to deal with priests found guilty of sexual abuse, Cardinal Bevil acqua said that the changes would not directly affect a great number of cases.
But the modifications would provide a "last resort," he said, strengthening the hand of a bishop when a priest found guilty of sexual abuse refuses to give up his duties voluntarily or resists effective treatment.
Bishops currently have the administrative power to remove priests from parishes or even suspend them from priestly functions. But to make such a suspension permanent against a priest's will requires a decision by a church tribunal.
The bishops asked the Vatican to raise the age defining minors in church law to 17 from 15. They also requested that the five-year statute of limitations on dismissals in church law be extended so that an under-age victim of sexual abuse could press charges for five years after reaching the age of 18, no matter when the abuse occurred.
A bishop could also press for dismissal of a priest up two years after receiving a new, well-substantiated allegation of abuse, regardless of when the abuse was said to have occurred.

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: Reporter's Notebook;
After Marathon of a Debate, A 6-Minute Dash to Settle It

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 --
By the 11th hour of debate, with lawmakers growing ever more emotional, with the vote described in ever more apocalyptic terms and with longtime allies and enemies strangely scrambled, the people's house seemed exhausted with the North American Free Trade Agreement.
They were ready to vote and they did it fast: The agreement went over the top in just 6 minutes and 11 seconds, a sharp contrast to the long cliffhanger of the President's budget vote in August.
 
Throngs in the Capitol
 Throughout the day and into the night the halls of the Capitol were filled with men and women for and against the pact, waiting in long, hot and often contentious lines for a chance to see and hear the debate. They heard Representative David Bonior, the Democratic whip from Macomb County, Mich., plead for a "no" vote on behalf of working people, while Representative Marcy Kaptur, a staunch opponent of the agreement from Ohio, quietly wept. 
 They heard Representative Robert H. Michel, the Republican leader and advocate of the pact, surprise his grim colleagues with a joke. "Think," he said, "of the three most famous nonelected opponents of Nafta: Ross Perot, Pat Buchanan and Ralph Nader -- the Groucho, Chico and Harpo of Nafta opposition." The House seemed grateful for the chance to laugh.
It was an exhausting struggle, perhaps especially for the Democrats, whose leaders seemed eager to nudge their divided party toward reconciliation. Representative Vic Fazio, the California Democrat who supported the agreement, tried for a healing coda: "None of us are owned by labor. None of us are coerced by business. And none of us are afraid of Ross Perot."
 
An Oscar Performance
 President Clinton and his Congressional supporters played the Oscar-quality underdog during the week leading up to tonight's vote on the North American Free Trade Agreement. But anyone who looked inside the offices of the lobbyists for and against the accord walked away with a different view of the fight.
The lobbyists supporting the agreement -- Chamber of Commerce types, accountants, trade consultants -- occupied a stately conference room on the first floor of the Capitol, barely an elevator ride away from the action in the House chamber. Murals plastered the ceilings outside. Weighty quotations ("We Defend and We Build a Way of Life Not for America Alone, but for All Mankind") were inscribed above every door. A television was installed. Cellular telephones were everywhere -- not clunky low-rent models, but the teeny ones that fold to the size of lemons. People carried about gift neckties with buttons attached, reading "Don't tie the economy in knots."
Celebrities, Washington-style, were in evidence. "It's going to be a blowout," said Anne Wexler, a former official in the Carter Administration who is now a lobbyist.
The boiler room for the forces opposed to the pact, by contrast, was more of, well, a boiler room. Set in the spectacularly ugly Rayburn House Office Building, in a barren hearing room of the Education and Labor Committee, it was two elevators, a subway and a long walk from the House debate. The dress was union-label, inexpensive suits and nylon jackets inscribed with numbers and insignias of various locals.
There was one telephone, decidedly not portable, and basic black. That fit the mood.
Asked whether the forces opposed to the pact had any neckties or other giveaways, Charles E. Stott, director of a four-state A.F.L.-C.I.O. region in the Midwest, was caustic. "We feel like there's been enough given away already," he said.
 
A Demolition Derby
 The first grand debate over the trade agreement was a confetti blizzard of assertions that the accord would strengthen industry or decimate it, create jobs or destroy them. Only one fact is indisputable: this country still produces the highest-quality sound bites, non sequiturs, cliches and malaprops on earth.
All day and most of the night, distinguished members of the House of Representatives took the floor to thumb their noses, direct raspberries and practically throw cats at each other, oratorically speaking. It is highly unlikely that they changed anyone's mind; barely two dozen lawmakers were officially undecided when the arguing began, and the number of genuine fence-sitters probably was much smaller.
The argument nevertheless riveted the gallery in the same way that stock-car 500's rivet throngs at Daytona: after a while, nobody cared much who won or lost. The thrill lay in waiting for someone to spin out of control and careen in flames into the barriers.
"You and I are both members of the Marine Corps," Representative Pat Roberts, a Republican of Dodge City, Kan., who supported the accord, admonished another lawmaker who had attacked it in rabid terms. "In the Marine Corps they teach you to shoot straight. You, sir, have fired the shotgun of fear at me, and I resent it."
Representative James M. Inhofe, an Oklahoma Republican, cushioned his opposition with an assertion that xenophobia had nothing to do with it. "I used to work with a Mexican," he said.
"We all stand on the shoulders of giants today," said Representative Jim Moran, who backed the accord.
"I find it interesting how we get carried away by the dogma a la mode," said Representative Lincoln Diaz-Ballart of Florida, an opponent.
He apparently meant du jour, or of-the-day, not a la mode, which would imply that the pact was covered with ice cream.
 
Nasty and Nastier
 This was Mr. Clinton's third great House test of Presidential influence -- the first being his losing fight for $19 billion in deficit spending to stimulate the economy, and the second the hair's-breadth passage last August of his $500 billion package of tax and spending cuts. The previous two battles were waged by happy warriors, pumped with political adrenaline that left both winners and losers feeling good.
The fight over the trade accord was a nastier and more divisive battle, a class-lines split that cleaved both parties and left everyone feeling sullen.
The fracas reached its low point about 7 P.M., when four members of the environmental group Greenpeace rose from the gallery and, shouting "Not this Nafta," threw handsful of mock $50 bills onto the House floor below. According to a press release distributed by the group minutes later, the protesters were making the point that Mr. Clinton had bought support for the agreement through political favors to polluters and agricultural interests.
"The only thing free about Nafta is the amount of money passed around Washington to pass it," said Representative James Traficant of suburban Cleveland, repeating that charge.
Not so, said E. (Kika) de la Garza, the Texas Democrat who heads the Agriculture Committee. "We have taken care of ourselves," he said of the promises. "That's why we helped the American sugar industry, one that is providing these jobs that all the lawmakers are screaming about. That's what we're doing, and I'm proud of it."

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: Perot;
Perot Looks at Loss on Pact and Says the Battle Has Just Begun

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Ross Perot said tonight that even though he was on the losing side in the trade agreement struggle and was also slumping in the polls, he was nevertheless just beginning to fight.
Starting Thursday morning, he announced, his political organization, United We Stand America, will step up its efforts to recruit new members nationwide, with the central goal of influencing the 1994 Congressional and 1996 Presidential elections. 
 Mr. Perot indicated, as he has a number of times, that his organization would attempt to punish legislators who supported the agreement. He also implied that he might become involved in other major national issues, like health care and unemployment. And he has left open the possibility that he might again seek the Presidency.
"Tomorrow will be the start of a new day," he said in an interview, looking fresh and primed despite spending 10 months campaigning coast to coast in his unsuccessful struggle to defeat the trade accord.
"Think of all of this as three votes," he said. "There's Nafta tonight. And then there's 1994 and 1996. You get my point?"
 
'No Personal Goals'
 If the two major political parties do not change direction in coming months and become more responsive to average voters, he warned, as he has before, United We Stand America could evolve into a third party, and he could again become a Presidential candidate.
"But that's up to the membership to decide, not me," he added. "I have no personal goals. I would prefer a strong, responsive two-party system. That's my dream. The thing that drives me is that I intend to leave this country in better shape than I found it because I've been so lucky myself."
Mr. Perot again refused to disclose how many members have already been signed up by United We Stand America, which was formed when he ran in the 1992 Presidential race, finishing with 20 percent of the vote. Nor would he disclose how much money his organization has raised or how much of his own personal fortune he has contributed to it.
By some estimates, he spent upward of $2 million of his $1 billion-plus personal fortune on the effort to beat the trade agreement.
"When the time is right, I'll release the figures," he said.
Because United We Stand America is registered as a nonprofit, nonpartisan organization, it is not required by Federal and state laws to make public such figures.
 
Complaints From the Ranks
 Since last fall's election, and in particular since the trade agreement debate with Vice President Al Gore, Mr. Perot has slipped in the polls. Once viewed favorably by one of every two voters, he is now viewed favorably by one of every three.
Within his own political organization, some leaders of state and local chapters have accused him of autocratic rule. He denies the accusations.
Pollsters say voters tend to like many of Mr. Perot's ideas and to find his blunt espousal of them entertaining. But fewer and fewer voters view him as "Presidential," the pollsters report.
Specifically, the pollsters have found that voters agree with Mr. Perot about the need to run the Government more efficiently and about the need to reform Congress. But he loses much voter support when he focuses on matters like health care and, more to the point, foreign trade.
Two of every three voters polled shortly before tonight's vote said his stand on the agreement had not influenced them much, one way or the other.
 
'Voters Feel Bypassed'
 Whatever the case, in tonight's interview, Mr. Perot contended that the trade fight had left American voters more uneasy than ever about their Government and "beyond anger" at President Clinton and much of Congress. And he left no doubt that he and United We Stand America planned to exploit that unease and anger.
"Voters still feel bypassed and ignored and not understood," he said. "When was the last time ordinary people got involved in a foreign trade debate? Their anger is going to produce political change that will be something to see. People need good jobs and the treaty threatens them.
Mr. Perot called for a Justice Department investigation into President Clinton's effort to win votes for the trade agreement by promising to funnel Federal contracts and projects into the districts of House members who would commit to the proposal.
"They opened up the Treasury vault," he said. "That ought to be looked into."
Mr. Perot may have a difficult time making his vote-buying accusation stick. Throughout the nation's history, the White House and members of Congress have been striking such deals.
Mr. Perot also said that the White House had violated the Constitution by presenting to Congress an agreement that did not include everything that had been negotiated. "There were quite a few side agreements that were never put in what went to Capitol Hill," he asserted. "That's unconstitutional and something we also see as grounds for court action."
Because of a long and tangled history of White House treaty negotiations, Mr. Perot may also find this a difficult accusation to prove.

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: Reaction;
After Vote, Labor Is Bitter But Big Business Is Elated

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
The House approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement drew a bitter reaction tonight from the labor unions that as recently as last weekend had seen victory within their grasp, and elation from the agreement's supporters in business and academia.
Members filed out of the House of Representatives angry or relieved depending on where they stood. Representative Cleo Fields, Democrat of Louisiana, seethed as he left the chamber a few minutes after he voted against the pact. "I hope the same folks who voted here and talked about job retraining will come back and vote for job retraining for the people dislocated by this agreement," he said, echoing the criticism of labor unions that believe the pact will cost hundreds of thousands of jobs. 
 Then, Representative Newt Gingrich, usually the most partisan of Republican leaders, proclaimed that the vote would usher in a new era of cooperation with the President.
 
Difficult Experience
 Inside the House chamber, the Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, lingered, talking mostly to his allies, clapping members on the shoulder. When he left the chamber, he told reporters, in a hoarse voice, "I think it's the right decision." But, he said, it was "a difficult experience for many of our members. This has been very divisive."
Even before the vote was over, some preprinted interpretation began to flow as aides to Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, and Lloyd Bentsen, the Secretary of the Treasury, passed out statements that were at once congratulatory and self-congratulatory.
Much of the comment talked about the rift the issue has created between the Administration and organized labor. Mr. Foley told reporters it been hard for him, and others, to break with labor.
For their part, union leaders seemed to have few thoughts of mending fences with their Democratic President, whom they criticized for what they called vote-buying and warned of political retribution.
 
Objections to Deals
 "The flurry of horse-trading surrounding the final push to enact this agreement has demonstrated what Nafta is really about," said Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
Ron Carey, president of the 1.3-million-member International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s biggest union, echoed Mr. Kirkland's criticism. "The American people will be paying a price for all the perks," he said, referring to deals the White House struck with citrus fruits, wheat and other interests.
Mr. Carey made it clear that his union intended to follow through on the warnings it had given to House members favoring the pact. "Politicians who put the corporate special interests ahead of the public interest must be held accountable," he said. "We will develop political alternatives for 1994 and 1996 so that working people do not just have to choose between the lesser of two evils."
Moe Biller, president of the 249,000-member American Postal Workers Union, said of the House vote, "This is a good smack in the face." He, too, hinted of ballot-box retribution.
 
Quote From Tom Paine
 "I'll quote Tom Paine,' Mr. Biller said. "He said, 'The summer soldiers will shrink from their tasks, but those who stand it now will forever be honored.' We will honor those who stood fast."
But he equivocated a little, too. "It's hard to make a commitment for all time," Mr. Biller said. "Things change."
Away from the fax machines, some of the rank and file said they were disheartened by a vote they followed closely. As the second shift filed out of two General Motors parts plants in Detroit tonight, workers worried that highly paid manufacturing jobs like theirs were already vanishing and that the agreement would help their bosses ship the remainder abroad.
"It's going to make it easier for the companies, cheaper for them," said Curtis McGough, 40. "I got a 5-year-old son, he'll never see this place. I got nephews, they're in high school, they won't get in here."
 
What Mexicans Can Afford
 As he walked to his car, Michael Washington, a tool-and-die welder, said American exports would not rise because of the agreement because Mexicans simply could not afford the cars Detroit makes. Pointing at a battered Ford Crown Victoria, he asked: "Can they buy that car?" He answered his own question: "No."
Environmental groups were split in their reaction to the vote, as they had been by the pact itself. Barbara Dudley, the executive director of Greenpeace, an environmental group which strongly opposes the pact, attributed the agreement's approval to the Administration's deal-making. "The President went into high gear and auctioned off the country in the last couple days," she said tonight.
But officials at the National Wildlife Federation, which supported the agreement, took the opposite view. "Tonight, I am euphoric at the victory we've achieved for the economy and the environment," said Stewart Hudson, the federation's trade expert. "Without the environmental provisions, Nafta would not have survived."
The reaction from business was as pleased as that of the unions was bitter. Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, hailed the vote as "a great victory for American industry, American workers and the American political process."
The chairman of General Motors, John Smith, said "By saying yes to Nafta, the U.S. House of Representatives has made good on a great window of opportunity for America. For the first time, American-made products will be able to compete fairly in Mexico without the burden of tariffs and other barriers."
Several executives and economists stressed what they saw as the positive effect of the vote on other trade issues. William Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, who had made television advertisements in favor of the pact, said passage of Nafta "demonstrated our country's commitment to expanded trade."
Jeffrey Schott, an economist at the Institute for International Economics here who supports the free trade pact, said the real significance of the 34-vote margin was in the likelihood that it would bring about an even larger free trade agreement in 116-nation talks under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
 
Signs of Consensus
 "I'm pleased with the vote, but I think it really holds good promise for other trade agreements, particularly the GATT," he said. "It shows a strong bipartisan consensus."
On many minds was the effect of the Nafta fight on another issue, health care. With that in mind, Mr. Bentsen sounded a conciliatory note after the vote. "With Nafta behind us, we look forward to working with our friends on other issues on the American agenda, such as comprehensive health care reform."
But Mr. Carey predicted tougher going for the President's health care plan. The Teamsters originally sought a single-payer universal plan, with the Government providing care for all, not the President's managed competition approach. "We shifted to accommodate the President," Mr. Carey said. "But he has turned his back on us."
Without being specific, the president of the 143,000-member Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, Jack Sheinkman, also warned that the vote tonight "is going to impact the kind of health plan we have."

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: The Partners' Reaction
Mexico Seems Jubilant but the Government in Canada Has Many Questions;
A 'Real Revolution Stirs Celebration

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 17

 BODY:
After the long Congressional debate ended and the final vote was taken on Mexico's economic union with the United States, many Mexicans celebrated the approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
"It's a major step for Mexico, absolutely enormous," said Juan de la Cruz, a 39-year-old banker who watched the vote on television at the Yuppies Sports Bar in downtown Mexico City. "It's like there were two walls between the countries and now they're gone." 
 "It's a real feeling of accomplishment," said Raul Munoz Leos, president of Dupont de Mexico, who was attending the Tchaikovsky Festival here. "This is the real revolution for Mexico, not the one in 1910. This has much more potential because it provides a real life model for what the world will be coming to."
The vote ended an often-frustrating period during which Mexicans were left to sit on their hands while their future was haggled over in Washington.
 
Divided Opinion in Mexico
 "I don't like to see decisions being made in the U.S. Congress alone," said Gabriel Szekely, a corporate consultant in Mexico City. "But its reality for most of the countries in the world." Still, he said he felt the agreement will mark an important point in North American history. "This gives us an opportunity that we can really have a close partnership with the United States, and gain from it. It's not certain that it's going to happen, but if there had been no Nafta that would not even be an opportunity."
At Los Pinos, the Mexican White House, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari gave a short, low-key speech in which he again downplayed expectations by calling the agreement just one step in Mexico's economic evolution.
Mr. Salinas called President Clinton's efforts to get the agreement approved "decisive," and said that Mr. Clinton had achieved "what only weeks ago was considered impossible."
Mr. Salinas said the Mexican Senate would vote on the agreement "in the coming days."
Even as it was being approved in Washington, the controversial agreement was dividing opinion in Mexico.
"We don't trust any agreement that President Salinas negotiated," said Jesus Guadelupe Peralta, an unemployed 32-year-old sugar worker from Heroico Cardenas in the state of Tabasco who has been camping in Mexico City's main square for a week to protest what he considers to be the Government's lack of social support. "It would be fine if the agreement brought U.S. salaries here, but it won't."
In many ways, the vote was seen by Mexican businessmen as a confirmation of Mr. Salinas's economic policies. During the day, Mexico's stock market dropped 10 points, as many investors decided to sell their holdings in the last pre-agreement session of the Bolsa Mexicana de Valores. The Bolsa index dropped .5 percent on heavy trading.
The number of people in Mexico who watched the debate is believed to be comparatively small because it was only carried by certain cable companies and the majority of Mexicans do not have cable television. Blanca and Hugo Cano, both 30, were strolling through downtown Mexico City when the vote was taken. The results didn't surprise them. "The rich people are going to benefit most, but I think that after the transition, my salary is going to go up by as much as a quarter," Mr. Cano said.

HEADLINE: Beijing May Seek a U.S. Trade Deal

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 17

 BODY:
President Jiang Zemin of China left for the United States today, having begun what Chinese and Western officials say is the boldest set of economic changes since China's opening to market forces began 15 years ago.
And some Chinese officials say they believe that Mr. Jiang, emerging from a highly successful meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee last weekend, may try to capitalize on his political momentum by asking the United States to separate China's trade status from its human rights record. He will meet with President Clinton in Seattle on Friday at a summit meeting of Pacific rim countries. 
 To strike such a deal, Mr. Jiang would have to make concessions that go further than China's commitment, restated today, to give "positive consideration" to permit the Red Cross to visit its 3,000 political detainees.
In a news conference at his departure today, Mr. Jiang said Chinese-American relations were at a "crucial juncture," and he appealed to Mr. Clinton to take a "long-term perspective" on the relationship and drop conditions on China's trade status. But he offered no clue as to how he might broach a new understanding.
 
A Sense of Urgency
 Some Western human rights workers say they believe China has been preparing a number of steps to improve its human rights record, including releases of political prisoners and new legal procedures under which prisoners can contest their treatment.
One element of urgency underlying Mr. Jiang's first trip to meet an American President is that the health of China's paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping, is rapidly deteriorating. A Western official who recently spoke with a senior Communist Party leader said he was told that the progressive nature of Mr. Deng's decline will make it impossible for his physicians to sustain him past February or March.
Mr. Jiang, 67, is the handpicked successor of the 89-year-old Chinese patriarch. "His political position at home is very strong right now," said one Chinese who was an adviser at last week's Central Committee debate. But Western officials fear that Mr. Jiang, an uncharismatic former Mayor of Shanghai, will not be able to assure political stability after Mr. Deng dies or insure that China's market remains open.
A foreign policy victory in Seattle would strengthen Mr. Jiang's position and solidify the reform trend.
 
One Step at a Time
 As the Chinese President left, details about the new economic program emerged. The package, a product of months of negotiation by the leadership, would overhaul China's banking and taxation systems.
But most important, it would allow some of China's state-owned industries to accept private investments. It would guarantee the protection of profits and the right of investors to take part in managing of companies, much like a corporation in the West.
A 25-page document issued by the Central Committee on Tuesday does not say when or on what scale this transformation will begin, but there are references to "step-by-step" approaches. "It should be adopted in a gradual manner after experiments," the Central Committee report states. "It must not be done for show, or rashly on a mass scale."
The document, drafted under Mr. Jiang's supervision, has charted a course that one Western diplomat called one of the boldest initiatives undertaken by the leadership since 1978. That was the year in which Mr. Deng, arguing before an earlier Central Committee, won support for the first steps of the economic program that China has pursued for 15 years.
The diplomat said these new steps are just as "fraught with the risks of social unrest" as the earlier ones, perhaps more so, as the new reforms will "break the iron rice bowls" in China's state-owned industries, where Communism, for 45 years, has guaranteed jobs and lifetime security without demanding performance.
 
Investing in Stability
 Social unrest poses the greatest threat to the Communist Party's monolithic control in China. The death of Mr. Deng will only deepen the regime's insecurity because in four decades of Communist rule, there has never been a planned handover of power that has succeeded.
Concern about political stability explains in part the speed with which China and the United States have been rushing this fall to repair relations frayed by disputes over human rights, trade and China's exports of high technology, including missiles.
American officials would seek to support and nurture any Chinese leadership that carries on Mr. Deng's reforms, and if the leader dies, that would be likely to delay or defer decisions to impose sanctions on China for human rights abuses, Western diplomats here believe.
For Mr. Jiang, his patron's illness also explains the frenetic pace with which he is using Mr. Deng's final days to endorse the new economic reforms. Before the party meeting, Mr. Deng issued a few sentences from his sickbed backing rapid development and high-speed growth.
These utterances effectively put an end to China's four-month-old austerity program under the management of Vice Premier Zhu Rongji, whose political star, for the moment, has crashed.
The Central Committee's blueprint reads more like Milton Friedman than Karl Marx: the "socialist market economic structure" now "aims at enabling the market to play the fundamental role" in how resources are allocated, it says.
For China's economy to keep growing at rates approaching this year's phenomenal 13 percent, the Chinese want political stability, and that will be part of Mr. Jiang's message in Seattle.
 
More Trust, Less Trouble
 In a speech on Monday to the World Affairs Council in Los Angeles, Foreign Minister Qian Qichen, who will also be in Seattle, said, "China's desire is to have more trust, less trouble, increased cooperation and no confrontation with the United States."
A key element of political stability in Mr. Jiang's vocabulary is avoiding the train wreck he faces when Mr. Clinton links China's preferential trade status with China's record on human rights, which has gotten worse in some respects. Losing the preferential tariffs would stunt a third of China exports and wreak havoc in the economies of Hong Kong and Taiwan, both Washington's allies.
Access to the American market, where China may rack up a $20 billion trade surplus this year, is a key factor in guaranteeing China's future prosperity. And in China, as Mr. Deng has said, prosperity is the only thing that keeps the masses from rebellion against the Communist system.

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: Dealings;
New York Region 'Nays' Translate Into 'No Deals'

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
So while the deals were being struck on sugar and orange juice and peanut butter to round up last-minute Democratic votes for the free trade pact, how did the New York region do?
To begin with, most Democrats from the metropolitan area were out of the running. All but two Democrats from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut -- Nita M. Lowey and Floyd H. Flake -- opposed the pact, according to preliminary vote counts. 
 Ms. Lowey decided after much soul-searching to support the agreement, but she was proudly declaring, "No deals, no dams, no bridges." Meaning, her press secretary said, that she decided solely on the merits of the issue. "Nita made it very clear that she was not interested in getting anything for her vote," the aide, Howard Wolfson, said, "and she didn't solicit anything."
Ms. Lowey, who represents parts of Westchester, the Bronx and Queens, said that the pact adopted by the House tonight was "a good deal" for the metropolitan area and that if she did not believe it would create jobs and improve the New York economy, she would not have supported it.
Mr. Flake, of the Sixth District in Queens, met with President Clinton for 30 minutes on Tuesday and afterward said he would vote for the agreement.
The Congressman got "a philosophical commitment from the President to go forward with some community development initiatives," said Marshall Mitchell, Mr. Flake's spokesman. That includes more seed money for small businesses in distressed areas, Mr. Mitchell said.
Perhaps most important, Mr. Mitchell said, the President expressed his interest "in using the Sixth Congressional District as a crucible for experiments in economic empowerment."
Another longtime holdout like Mr. Flake was Representative Sherwood Boehlert, an upstate Republican who announced his support for the pact today.
"No deals," Mr. Boehlert said tonight.
But he added that he did tell the President that the Government was "the biggest disemployer in my district," citing cutbacks at Griffiss Air Force Base in Rome. Administration officials noted their past assistance to cushion that dislocation, Mr. Boehlert said, and promised continued cooperation.

HEADLINE: House Starts Surged 2.7% Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Responding to a revived housing market, builders broke ground on new homes in October at the fastest rate in more than three and a half years, causing analysts to raise projections for the economy at large.
The 2.7 percent rise in starts was the latest in what has become an almost unbroken streak of upbeat economic reports during the last two months, and it showed that housing, which showed little sign of life during the first half of the year despite tumbling interest rates, had resumed its traditional role as an economic pacesetter.
 
 
New Homeowners
 "Finally, we're getting pretty happy with these numbers," David Lereah, chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association, said. He and others said that many apartment dwellers, inspired by the most favorable combination of financing costs and home prices in decades, had decided to become homeowners. 
 At a White House briefing, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen called the comeback in housing, to a level 13 percent above that of three months ago, "a payoff with what we did on the budget and getting the cuts in that deficit and now getting the long-term low interest rates."
Over all, starts ran at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1,396,000 in October, 14 percent above the pace a year earlier, the Commerce Department report showed. For single-family houses the gain was 5.8 percent, to a rate of 1,224,000.
The rebound in housing has lifted single-family construction back to the levels enjoyed during the 1980's. The 1.1 million houses now expected to be built in 1993 would be the most since 1,146,000 in 1987 and would be not far under the decade's best performance, 1,180,000 in 1986.
Because of a collapse in multifamily activity, however, current levels are far short of the 2.4 million total units in 1972, the industry's best year. The slump resulted from overbuilding, changes in the tax law and lower Government subsidies.
"Building activity seems clearly to be driven by the demand," commented David F. Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, noting that there had been relatively little speculative construction or rise in unsold homes. He added that all three of his association's own surveys -- of customer traffic, current sales and builders' expectations for future sales -- stood at the highest levels since they were introduced in early 1985.
Today's Commerce Department report, which exceeded most expectations, also showed that permits for future construction rose 2.8 percent last month, the fourth straight advance.
The October groundbreaking was concentrated in the Midwest, part of which is rebuilding from summer floods, and in the South. But while the Northeast and West posted small declines, both regions had brisk activity in preceding months. The number of permits issued in the Northeast, moreover, rose to the highest level of the year for the second consecutive month.
Starts surged to their third consecutive gain last month despite a 20 percent drop for apartment buildings. That sector, buildings with five or more dwellings, had soared 35 percent in September after the Government restored a lapsed tax credit for low-income housing.
 
 
Raising Estimates
 Besides buoying people in real estate, today's report also prompted some economists to raise estimates of the nation's total economic output for the fourth quarter.
According to Kenneth T. Mayland, economist at the Society National Bank in Cleveland, the residential sector should add as much as a percentage point to the growth rate of the gross domestic product in the final three months of the year after acting as a drag during the first six months.
"Four percent almost looks like a slam dunk," Mr. Mayland said, bumping his own forecast up a quarter-point today. The automobile business is strong, capital spending continues brisk and fourth-quarter output will also benefit from flood recovery and absence of crop losses, he added.
 
 
Existing-Home Sales
 Mr. Mayland also pointed to very strong recent reports on sales of existing homes and the fact that they are often accompanied by fix-up spending and the purchase of new appliances and other household goods. "This may partly explain why consumer spending is so strong despite the low confidence held by consumers," he said.
Most economists believe that kind of increase in growth cannot be sustained, raising the likelihood of a repeat of last year, when a 5.7 percent boom in the fourth quarter of 1992 was followed by a bare eight-tenths of 1 percent increase in the first quarter of 1993.
By region, starts last month were up 13.3 percent in the Midwest, to a rate of 358,000; up 2.8 percent in the South, to 590,000; down 9.4 percent in the Northeast, to 125,000, and down 2.4 percent in the West, to 323,000.
The report also showed that manufacturers shipped mobile homes at a rate of 251,000 in September, 2.4 percent higher than in August and 15.7 percent above the September 1992 pace.
Actual housing starts last month -- without seasonal adjustment or annualization -- were 124,700. Of these, 50,700 were in the South, 35,300 in the Midwest, 26,700 in the West and 12,000 in the Northeast.

HEADLINE: When Crime Was Bit of All Right in East End

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Ricky Precord and his friends were children when Reg and Ron Kray, London's most notorious gangsters, were sentenced in 1969 to prison terms of at least 30 years for the murders of two fellow thugs.
But like other residents of the East End, where the Kray twins ran protection rackets and fought ruthlessly to defend their turf, Mr. Precord and his mates share a communal nostalgia for the men who are arguably the best-known criminals to operate in their neighborhood since Jack the Ripper. 
 "They looked after their own," said Mr. Precord, proudly displaying card No. 51 in the Kray Supporters Club, as four of his friends, all in their 20's and early 30's, nodded in agreement. "Back in those days you could walk the streets. Old ladies didn't get mugged. They did a better job of keeping the streets safe than the Bill."
The Bill -- the police -- might beg to differ. But there is little doubt that among some East Enders, the Krays, who remain imprisoned, have come to embody a time more imagined than real when their neighborhoods were not so full of crime, unemployment and racial tension, and when criminals acting under a strict code of conduct dispensed justice and favors, Don Corleonelike, to maintain order.
"There's no doubt that if they hadn't gotten nicked, the East End would be a different place," said Dick Bowman, who said he had been a friend of the Krays for 35 years.
Mr. Bowman led several hundred fellow supporters of the Krays to Downing Street in October to present the Government with a petition seeking parole for Reg Kray. Mr. Bowman said he had 18,000 signatures.
Ron Kray, who always had a reputation as the more violent of the two, has been diagnosed as paranoid schizophrenic; his chances for release from the Broadmoor psychiatric prison hospital rest with his doctors, and even the most fervid supporters of the twins said Ron may be better off under care.
In their heyday in the 1950's and 1960's, the Krays ran the closest thing to a crime empire that Britain had seen to that time. They built a fortune extorting "protection" money from business owners, demanding a cut from the proceeds of robberies committed by other criminals and other scams.
In the early 1960's they branched out into running legitimate nightclubs in the more stylish West End and took a page from the Mafia in the United States by developing and publicizing relationships with movie stars like George Raft and politicians like Lord Boothby, a minister in Winston Churchill's wartime Cabinet.
Neither their connections nor their flair for publicity helped in the courtroom. Ron Kray was convicted of murder in the slaying of a local hood who had insulted him because of his homosexuality. Reg Kray was convicted of murder in the death of Jack (The Hat) McVitie, another local criminal who owed them money.
But their penchant for the limelight has not let up since they entered prison. Both twins, now 60 years old, have written several autobiographies. They sold the rights to their story for $375,000 for the 1990 feature film, "The Krays." Through their supporters club, they sell T-shirts and "limited edition" family photo albums, and have spread tales of their good works, like providing money to poor and sick children. Celebrities like Roger Daltrey, the lead singer of The Who, have spoken out publicly in support of more lenient treatment.
The publicity has clearly helped promote the Krays' own view of themselves as victims of unduly harsh persecution by the police and the British establishment. Not that they deny the murders any longer. Rather, the Krays, and their supporters, feel that 25 years is an excessive amount of time.
But in a Britain where law and order issues have moved onto the center of the political stage, it is unlikely that the Government will be willing to release Reg Kray, much less his brother, under the glare of publicity and pressure, said John Pearson, author of "The Profession of Violence: The Rise and Fall of the Kray Twins."
"This isn't how these things are done in England," Mr. Pearson said. "They'd do better if they kept their heads down and did it quietly."

HEADLINE: 150 Windmills to Test Elusive Power Source

BYLINE: By WALTER SULLIVAN

 BODY:
Although the potential for using the wind to produce electricity has largely been untapped, a new initiative combining local and Federal resources could show that as much as 20 percent of the country's electrical power could be derived from this source by the year 2020, a leading proponent of wind power says.
The assessment was made by Dr. Edward DeMeo, who is in charge of wind and power energy at the Electric Power Research Institute, a national consortium of 700 utilities that is based in Palo Alto, Calif. 
 The institute recently joined with the Department of Energy to announce that three windy sites, in Texas, Vermont and Maine, had been chosen for a $40 million dollar program to test new wind turbines.
The plan is intended to help potential users of wind power judge if it can be economical.
The most ambitious of these wind farms will be on a ridge in northwest Maine, near the Canadian border. Dr. DeMeo said the initial plan called for 150 windmills.
The windmills will be built by Kenetech-U.S. Windpower to test its latest turbines, which produce maximum electricity even when winds are gusty. Their output will be sold to the Central Maine Power Company and other utilities. By 1995, they could produce 30 to 50 megawatts, with an ultimate goal of 250 megawatts, enough to supply a city of 100,000.
The second site, near Readsboro, in southern Vermont, will include at least 20 wind turbines, in a project sponsored by the Green Mountain Power Corporation. The utility will receive $3 million for construction and testing of an eight-megawatt plant. Since 1989, the company has been testing two turbines for performance in icy and harsh winters.
The third site, near Fort Davis in West Texas, where the weather is hot and dry, will consist of a six-megawatt plant with at least 20 windmills, run by the Central and South West Corporation, which operates utilities in Texas, Oklahoma, Louisiana and Arkansas. The design of the turbines to be tested at this and the Vermont sites has yet to be determined.
 
Experiment in Hawaii
 The diameter of the rotors on the windmills at the Texas site will be a little more than 100 feet. Each will generating more than 300 kilowatts.
Although these rotors are large, they are nowhere near the size of those on a giant windmill built under Federal auspices on the Hawaiian island of Oahu, which has blades longer than a football field. It has apparently not been successful enough for imitation.
In earlier turbines, Dr. DeMeo said, heavy gear boxes were used to adjust the speed of the generator, depending on wind velocity, to turn 1,800 times a minute. Now Kenetech-U.S. Windpower turbines can generate 60-hertz current from rotor blades spinning only 50 to 100 times a minute.
Meanwhile, a rival variable-wind turbine is being developed at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y. The speed of the fan varies with wind strength, generating alternating current with varying cycles, or frequency. This power is electronically converted to direct current, which is then transformed to the 60-hertz frequency for the American power grid. Ultimately, the use of many widely scattered windmills is expected to cancel out any variations in the cycles.
Dr. DeMeo said the future of the Rensselaer system depended in part on whether the cost of the electronics and low-speed generators was less than that saved by eliminating the gears. At present, most of the nation's 17,000 wind turbines provide electricity at seven cents to nine cents a kilowatt hour, which is in line with other sources.
 
Cost Expected to Fall
 The cost is expected to approach four cents for most of the country by the end of this decade. A new Federal energy act will provide a subsidy of 1.5 cents a kilowatt hour, starting next year. Of the $40 million to be spent, Dr. DeMeo said, $6 million will come from the Department of Energy, $6 million from the institute and the rest from the participating utilities.

HEADLINE: Fed Proposes a Compromise On Access to Its Transcripts

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, offered a compromise today to Henry B. Gonzalez, chairman of the House Banking committee, saying the central bank would grant public access to detailed transcripts of meetings it held between 1976 and 1988.
Mr. Gonzalez, a Texas Democrat, had sought transcripts through 1990. He said in a news release tonight that he was disappointed with the Fed's decision and that the Fed's members were "greatly mistaken" if they thought the Banking Committee would be satisfied with the release of only "certain transcripts." 
 In a letter to Mr. Gonzalez, who is trying to make the Fed's deliberations less secret, Mr. Greenspan said that before making the transcripts available the central bank would clean up the grammar and edit out confidential material about private individuals, commercial banks and foreign central banks.
Mr. Greenspan said the Fed would make public transcripts of meetings of its main policy-making committee with a five-year lag.
Mr. Gonzalez had called for the release of complete transcripts of all meetings held more than three years ago and for releasing edited transcripts of meetings more than 60 days old but less than three years old.
Transcripts of meetings up to 1976 are already public; they were released after a five-year lag. Since 1976, however, the central bank has kept unedited transcripts of its policy-making meetings on file without making them public. Instead, it releases a short summary of its policy-making meetings six weeks after they are held.
The transcripts are of meetings of the Federal Open Market Committee, which meets eight times a year and is instrumental in setting the central bank's interest-rate policies.
Opening them provides material for economists and historians about past economic and political controversies. For example, the transcripts are expected to show the debate that led to the Fed's decision to substantially raise interest rates in the early 1980's, shortly after President Jimmy Carter appointed Paul A. Volcker as Fed chairman.
In his letter, Mr. Greenspan argued against Mr. Gonzalez's suggestion that the central bank release transcripts with less than a five-year lag.
 
Free Discussion Called Vital
 He said that members of the committee believed "that early release of these documents would sharply curtail" the open market committee's "ability to discuss freely and frankly evolving economic and finanical market trends and alternative policy responses, which is essential to sound monetary policy."
Early release, Mr. Greenspan said, could stifle "originality, new ideas, and the give-and-take debate that so often open up new insights" at the committee's meetings.
Mr. Greenspan said that the Fed would make the slightly edited transcripts for 1988 available early next year and then release transcripts from previous years as the editing process proceeded.
 
Pressure Acknowledged
 The release of transcripts for all meetings and transcribed conference calls since 1976 should be complete within a few years, he said.
On Tuesday, Mr. Gonzalez released notes from participants in an Oct. 15 conference call organized by Mr. Greenspan with other Fed officials in preparation for a hearing on Oct. 19 of the House Banking Committee. In it the participants acknowledged that they felt pressures from a Department of Justice policy that created a presumption in favor of disclosing records that were more than five years old.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
A Rally in Treasury Bonds Fizzles

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
An early rally in the Treasury bond market fizzled yesterday after an expected Federal Reserve purchase of Government securities failed to materialize.
Adding to the selling of Treasury issues was a sharp rise in gold and oil prices. 
 After rising about half a point in early trading, the price of the Treasury's 30-year bond closed down 8/32 of a point. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, edged up to 6.18 percent, from 6.16 percent late Tuesday.
The bond market rose sharply in early trading on wide optimism that the House would approve the North American Free Trade Agreement. American financial markets are expected to benefit from the elimination of trade barriers among the United States, Mexico and Canada, which would stimulate more foreign investment.
 
 
Korea Electric Power
 Also strengthening bond prices was strong demand for a $1.35 billion bond sale by Korea Electric Power, a utility in South Korea, the latest in this week's flurry of sales by corporations. Analysts said the demand spread through the Treasury market.
But Treasury bond prices began tumbling after the Federal Reserve failed to buy securities as expected around 1 P.M. as a way to replenish banking system reserves during the holiday shopping season.
The Fed was expected to buy $3.5 billion to $4 billion worth of Treasury securities, said Joseph Liro, chief economist at S. G. Warburg & Company.
A surprising spike in gold prices also weighed on bond investors, who view bullishness in gold as an indicator that inflation may be heading higher. After falling about $3 an ounce in early trading, gold for December delivery closed up $2.60 an ounce, at $377.20, on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
Higher oil prices also contributed to inflation fears. Crude oil for December delivery jumped 27 cents, to $17.04 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Inflation can hurt the value of long-term fixed-income securities such as bonds.
Peter McTeague, market strategist at Technical Data in Boston, said some investors used the negative news as an excuse to take profits on the earlier rise in bond prices.
 
 
Short-Term Maturities
 Prices of short-term Treasury maturities were unchanged to 1/32 point lower, while intermediate maturities were unchanged to 1/16 point lower.
The Lehman Brothers daily Treasury bond index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, fell 0.13, to 1,312.93.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills were unchanged at 3.14 percent as the discount held steady at 3.08 percent. Six-month yields fell to 3.31 percent as the discount fell one-hundredth of a percentage point, to 3.22 percent. One-year yields dropped to 3.54 percent as the discount fell one-hundredth point, to 3.41 percent.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 10213/32 , up 4/32 from late Tuesday. The average yield to maturity was unchanged at 5.60 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Boeing Gets Order for 63 737-X Jets

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17

 BODY:
The Boeing Company said today that it had received an order from Southwest Airlines for 63 of its 737-X family of jetliners, the next generation of its best-selling Boeing 737.
The order, for delivery in 1997 through 2001, means the Seattle-based Boeing can now proceed with the introduction of the new aircraft. No price has been established for the 737-X, but the average $40 million price of current 737's would make the Southwest order worth about $2.5 billion. While the order will not have any near-term impact on earnings, it indicates that Boeing will remain competitive with Airbus Industrie in the crucial market for smaller jetliners, analysts said. 
 The order is recognition that Boeing is "the market leader in the one segment of the market which has long-term growth potential," said Wolfgang Demisch, an analyst with BT Securities in New York. "During this really dismal period for the industry, with orders being deferred and canceled, they're continuing to gain ground."
 
Shares Rise by $3.125
 The order announcement came after the close of the stock market, but Boeing shares gained $3.125, to $40.75, on the New York Stock Exchange today, as investors reacted to reports on news services that a pending announcement would be extremely positive.
The new order includes four 737-300X's for delivery in the fall of 1997, 16 in each of 1998 and 1999, 15 in 2000 and 12 in 2001. Of the 63 new orders, 32 result from the conversion of existing 737-300 options. Southwest's existing orders for 50 Boeing 737-300's for delivery in 1994-97 are unaffected by this order. Southwest's entire fleet of 157 aircraft consists of Boeing 737's.
Herb Kelleher, Southwest's chairman, president and chief executive, said in a statement: "We're delighted to once again be the launch customer for a Boeing aircraft. The current 737 models serve our high-frequency, short-haul operation very well. However, Boeing's business offer, combined with the additional attributes and operational flexibility of the 737-X, made the economics of this agreement superior."
Mr. Demisch said that Boeing's business offer to Southwest probably included "meaningful levels of support from General Electric," the sole engine supplier for the 737-X. These could include financing, special service arrangements or other considerations, he said.
The new 737 family is a derivative of the current 737, which features a modified wing with a larger span, and quieter, more powerful engines. Like today's 737-300/400/500 family, the next-generation 737 will be offered in three sizes. The 300X is the middle- size member of the new family, equivalent in capacity to the 737-300, which seats 128 passengers in mixed class and 137 in single-class configuration. The seating totals of the three models range from 108 to 160.
