HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Morgan Stanley Buying Red Roof

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
The Morgan Stanley Real Estate Fund said yesterday that it would buy Red Roof Inns, a private chain of 210 economy motels, for about $600 million.
Red Roof motels, all company owned and operated, are spread across 30 states but heavily concentrated in the Middle West. All but one are limited-service properties, offering only rooms, not restaurants, swimming pools or similar amenities, and they are aimed at the business traveler. 
 Such motels have generally weathered the recent recession in large part because business travelers, with their companies under pressure to cut costs, have been trading down from full-service to limited-service lodgings.
"The acquisition," said Paul D. Kazilionis, president of the Morgan Stanley Real Estate Fund, "fits with our strategy of identifying and acquiring attractive real estate opportunities along with their successful existing managements."
The price paid for the chain's 23,443 rooms works out to about $25,500 a room, compared with a cost to build them new of about $35,000. The acquisition is effective Dec. 17.
 
No West Coast Properties

 
 Mr. Kazilionis said that while Red Roof was successful in the Middle West and Northeast, it had few properties in the Southwest and none on the West Coast. "We expect to expand in those markets," he said, "and we would be looking at acquisitions of smaller chains and individual assets."
Red Roof headquarters will remain in Hilliard, Ohio, a suburb of Columbus.
"This means the logjam in hotel asset sales has been broken," said Margo Vignola, lodging analyst for Salomon Brothers. "Red Roof is a healthy chain, not some distressed property." There has a been a surplus of hotel properties for sale since the late 1980's.
Rooms at Red Roof properties average $38 a night and the chain's occupancy rate this year is 81 percent. By contrast, through August of this year room rates at economy hotels have averaged $43.67 and occupany has averaged 63 percent, according to Smith Travel Research.
Founded in 1972 by James R. Trueman, Red Roof Inns -- owned by a private trust created by Mr. Trueman shortly before his death in 1986 -- grew steadily until about three years ago, when it viewed the market as saturated. The company grew from 101 to 194 units between 1983 and 1988, and has added only 16 units since, the last one in 1991.
The Morgan Stanley Real Estate Fund, founded in 1991, is a $840 million equity fund managed by a subsidiary of Morgan Stanley Group Inc. Its investments include Carmel Valley Ranch, a California resort purchased from the Resolution Trust Corporation for $18.3 million, and the Doral Telluride, a Colorado ski resort and hotel spa, purchased from a private developer for about $30 million. Both purchases, which occurred last summer, were part of a joint venture with Westcor Partners of Phoenix.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Evidence contradicts common sense in the trade tug-of-war.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WHERE you stand on the free trade agreement, Bill Clinton told the country, is all about hope and fear -- hope that American industry can compete in world markets, fear that it can't. That struck many as good political oratory, good enough, perhaps, to tip the balance on the vote. What red-blooded member of Congress, after all, would suggest that Americans couldn't play in the big leagues?
But the idea of trade as the moral equivalent of football makes almost all economists uncomfortable. And it is downright dismaying to Paul Krugman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, whose own research, he readily acknowledges, has provided an intellectual rationale for those who portray international commerce as a competition in which their gain is our loss. "People who really know economics have lost control of the educated discourse," he glumly concludes. 
 In the catechism according to Adam Smith, individuals compete and businesses compete -- indeed, the core insight of free-market economics is that competition transforms selfish behavior into common good. But by the same token, competition between economies with different currencies has no real meaning.
Toyota, for example, may make sturdier, more reliable cars in Japan than Renault makes in France. And at current exchange rates between the yen and the franc, Toyota may be able to sell cars profitably in France for fewer francs than Renault can. But at the end of the day (well, year or decade) French exports must equal French imports, unless foreigners are willing to hold French i.o.u.'s indefinitely. And consumers in both Japan and France will be better off if they are given the choice of goods from either country.
That is not quite the whole story. If an economy is lucky enough to specialize in exports that the world particularly values, the foreign currency it earns will buy more imports. And what is loosely called the New Trade Theory suggests that smart countries may be able to make their own luck. If, for example, there is room in the world market for only one low-cost producer of computer microprocessors, being first in the market with a decent product may generate a financial windfall that will not be blown away by competition.
But theories that appeal to common sense (and serve special interests) have a way of thriving without much factual underpinning. Mr. Krugman calculates that changes in America's terms of trade -- how much our export earnings will buy abroad -- have accounted for a trivial percentage of the change in American living standards over the last half-century. Thus America's success (failure?) in trade "competition" is virtually irrelevant to the average American's income.
Averages, of course, are not everything. Doesn't international trade stir the pot, raising some people's incomes and lowering others'?
Yes, but so does domestic competition. If there is an intuitive truth to the populist suspicion about international trade, it must be that the burdens are systematically borne by people in no position to take the hit -- namely, unskilled workers. And, at least until the last few years, many economists assumed that the intuition was correct -- that the rapid opening of trade in manufactured goods had effectively forced blue-collar Americans to compete with their poorly paid counterparts in South Korea, Taiwan and -- dare we say it? -- Mexico.
The catch once more, though, is that the evidence does not support the self-evident truth. Lawrence Katz, the Labor Department's senior economist, estimates that competition with the bowl-of-rice-a-day crowd accounts for just a tenth of the change in the gap between the wages of America's skilled and unskilled workers in the 1980's.
If competition is virtually irrelevant to trade issues, why haven't economists who know better said so? "We used the word to get people's blood up," fudging the meaning in the name of advancing socially redeeming causes, Mr. Krugman said.
Van Doorn Ooms, the research director of the Committee for Economic Development, agrees. "I've used competitiveness as a synonym for productivity growth," said Mr. Ooms, who like many economists believes that Americans save too little and invest too little in human skills -- and need to be convinced to do better.
"Competitiveness means the ability to achieve trade equilibrium with a high level of wages," said William Baumol, the director of the C. V. Starr Center for Applied Economics at New York University. That may not be exactly what Joe Sixpack thought it meant, but it does lead to a virtuous policy prescription that sounds a lot like Mr. Ooms's.
"Paris is well worth a mass," the Duke of Sully is said to have counseled Henry of Navarre, a reluctant convert to Roman Catholicism. Mr. Krugman wonders whether economists, facing a similar problem, would not be better off sticking by their principles.
The doctrine of international competitiveness, he concludes, may spur politicians to do what ought to be done about domestic productivity. But to "win" a competition, America must, by definition, beat someone. "The obsession has led to trade conflict," Mr. Krugman says -- and it could lead to trade war.

HEADLINE: Soccer: Ins and Outs of '94 World Cup: Italy (In), England (Out);
France Beaten; Argentina and Ireland Qualify

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN

 BODY:
It was soccer's version of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament, a throng of games played simultaneously, eight European vacancies available in the 24-team World Cup field, at least one shocker guaranteed. In the end, Italy and Ireland erupted in sweeping celebration, while France and England sank into national heartache.
Italy qualified for its ninth consecutive World Cup by defeating Portugal, 1-0, on a late goal by Dino Baggio in Milan, and delighting American organizers, who are paying attention to ethnic enclaves in the United States for next summer's tournament and are almost certain to place the Italians in the New York-New Jersey area at Giants Stadium. 
 Ireland also qualified, barely, by tying Northern Ireland, 1-1, in Belfast, and edging out the European champion, Denmark, by the tie breaker of total goals scored in the two-year qualifying process. Ireland scored 19 goals and Denmark 15 (each team had the same goal differential). Yesterday, Denmark was shut out, 1-0, by Spain, which finished first in Europe's Group 3 despite playing all but 11 minutes of the game without goalie Andoni Zubizarreta, who was ejected for a foul outside the penalty area.
 
Australia Is Defeated
 The final qualifying berth went to 1986 champion Argentina, which defeated Australia, 1-0, on a second-half goal by Gabriel Batistuta in Buenos Aires last night and made Diego Maradona, the redeemed superstar, eligible for his fourth World Cup.
No side experienced the humiliation and suffering of France, which will miss its second consecutive World Cup after surrendering a crushing goal in the final 10 seconds and losing a stunner to Bulgaria, 2-1, in Paris. Emil Kostadinov scored both goals for Bulgaria. France, which has twice finished third in the World Cup, was one minute away from qualifying on Oct. 13, but allowed a similarly late goal to weak Israel and lost at home, 3-2. There is good news for the 1998 World Cup, at least, France is the host and gets an automatic bid.
Another big loser -- this one expected -- was England, the acknowledged birthplace of the sport, which needed a loss by the Netherlands in Poland and a seven-goal victory margin of its own against lowly San Marino. The English surrendered a goal in the first 10 seconds after at weak back pass by captain Stuart Pearce, then recovered with four goals by Ian Wright for a 7-1 victory in Bologna, Italy, but it was insufficient. No victory, no matter how large, would have been enough, with the visiting Netherlands defeating Poland, 3-1, at Poznan on two goals by Dennis Bergkamp.
World Cup organizers are sorry to lose the tradition of British soccer, but are elated at having the problem of English hooliganism disappear before it could cross the Atlantic.
"The attachment of thugs to English football would have caused serious security problems," Alan Rothenberg, president of World Cup USA '94, said in a conference call from Milan. "Fortunately, they didn't qualify, but it's a mixed situation."
With England, Northern Ireland, Wales and Scotland all eliminated, no British team will be represented at the finals for the first time since 1950.
Joining Italy, Spain, Ireland, the Netherlands and Bulgaria yesterday as the final European qualifiers were Switzerland, which clinched its first appearance since 1966 with yesterday's 4-0 victory over Estonia; Belgium, which will make its fourth-straight appearance after playing a man short for the final 50 minutes and getting a free-kick save by substitute goalkeeper Filip de Wilde in a scoreless tie against the Representation of Czechs and Slovaks in Brussels, and Romania, which sealed a back-to-back appearance with a 2-1 victory over Wales at Cardiff.
 
Welsh Fan Dies
 An elderly Welsh fan was struck and killed at Cardiff by a firecracker that shot across the field into the stands after the Romanian victory, The Associated Press reported.
On Dec. 19, at the World Cup draw in Las Vegas, Nev., the 24-team field will be seeded and divided into six four-team groups. The six No. 1-seeded teams are the defending champion, Germany; the host, the United States; the three-time winners Italy and Brazil; the two-time winner Argentina, and Belgium.
 
Luck of the Draw
 "The expression is, 'I'd rather be lucky than good,' and I think the field shows we're very lucky in the U.S.," Rothenberg said. "We're going to have a great mixture of most of the great soccer nations of the world, those that have tremendous fan following and appeal to a large ethnic population. At the same time, we have a smattering of Cinderella teams. Almost no country that I was really anxious to see here didn't make it."
The tournament will be played from June 17 to July 17 at stadiums in or near Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Detroit, Los Angeles, New York, Orlando, Fla., San Francisco and Washington.
The United States will be based in Detroit and Los Angeles, with the Germans in Chicago and Dallas. Ireland will most likely be placed in Boston.
Three nations will be making their first appearance in the cup final: Greece, Saudi Arabia and Nigeria. The absence of England, Japan and France, and the presence instead of such poorer Eastern European countries as Bulgaria and Romania, could have a negative financial impact on the World Cup in terms of merchandising and money spent by visitors. But Rothenberg stuck by the $4 billion estimate that the cup is expected to pump into the United States economy.
"Our overall economic status remains as valid as it ever was," he said.

HEADLINE: Nonproliferation Nonsense

BYLINE: By Jose Goldemberg; Jose Goldemberg, a visiting professor at Princeton University, is a former Secretary of Science and Technology in the Brazilian Government.

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's new nonproliferation policy reopens the Pandora's box of proliferation around the world at a time when it is slowly being closed.
The policy, unveiled in September, states that the U.S. will "not oppose" programs by Japan and Western Europe to keep producing plutonium, a weapons-grade material, for civilian use, while it will seek to discourage such activity in "regions of instability and high prospective risk." 
 Plutonium separated from spent Japanese fuel in European reprocessing plants will be sent back to Japan to be used to fuel a $5 billion prototype breeder reactor that burns and produces more plutonium. By the year 2000, Japan will have its own large reprocessing facility to separate plutonium from spent fuel; more importantly, it will have a large stockpile of plutonium ready for use in weapons.
Why should Japan be permitted to produce plutonium while developing countries like Brazil are considered suspect when they set up plutonium reprocessing or uranium enrichment facilities?
To imply that Japan is more trustworthy than they are rekindles deep concerns in developing countries about the discriminatory character of American policy.
That policy will strengthen the hand of those in developing countries who have urged their leaders to acquire nuclear weapons at a time when important progress has been achieved in gaining universal adherence to the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.
How can military establishments and their civilian allies be persuaded that while they are denied the right to enrich uranium and produce plutonium they are not giving up important technologies for production of energy in the future?
Tokyo is not prepared to forgo such technologies even though Japanese leaders and scientists know that reprocessing nuclear fuel to recover plutonium as an energy source makes no economic sense. It will only serve as a political justification for the heavy investment in nuclear facilities already made.
What if the mounting stockpile of plutonium is eventually converted to military use? Such suspicions are frequently cast on many "near-nuclear-threshold" developing countries. What differentiates Japan from them?
A more acceptable course of action for the Administration would be a nondiscriminatory nuclear policy in which all countries would indefinitely forgo reprocessing of spent fuel to produce plutonium.
This would not hurt the prospects of the nuclear industry and would insure that civilian programs do not feed military ambitions.

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: The New York Region;
Businesses Say Most Jobs Now Exist In Industries Trade Accord Will Help

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Though labor unions and many small manufacturers are braced for the worst, economists and business people generally predict that New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will benefit far more from the North American Free Trade Agreement than the region will be hurt by losing jobs to low-wage Mexican workers.
 Seldom has a region of America undergone a more profound economic transformation than these three states. Over a generation or so, they have moved from an economy fueled by factory production to one dominated by banking and finance, law and accounting, publishing and entertainment, telecommunications and advanced research in fields like pharmaceuticals and biotechnology. 
These are the cornerstones of what economists call the information economy, as vital today as were the steel mills, railroad yards and garment lofts of yesteryear.
 "On balance, the entire metropolitan region will benefit," said Representative Nita M. Lowey, a Democrat, whose district covers parts of Westchester, the Bronx and Queens. She said she expected the region's banking, telecommunications and service concerns to flourish under the trade pact.
 These are the industries, already adept at global business and eager for more, that even opponents of the agreement acknowledged would benefit most by exploiting new markets in Mexico.
 What's more, Mrs. Lowey said, whatever manufacturing jobs are drained from the region would be lost with or without the accord. "The defeat of Nafta would not prevent manufacturers' cutting jobs," she said before the vote.
 For many of the region's enterprises, the issues that have dominated the national debate over the trade agreement -- the impact of reduced Mexican tariffs on American goods and the threat that factories will move south of the Rio Grande -- are not the telling provisions of the accord. The crucial provisions will strengthen the protections for copyrights and other "intellectual property" and eliminate some restrictions that Mexico imposes on United States ownership of Mexican subsidiaries.
 Indeed, some publishers, pharmaceutical companies and computer makers -- all trying to cope with piracy of the copyrighted material and technology they export to Mexico -- say the new rules to protect intellectual property are paramount.
 Banks and Wall Street securities firms, which will probably draw more benefit from the pact than any other businesses, say they are itching to buy Mexican businesses or invest in them.
 To be sure, semi-skilled production workers across the region have reason for worry. Even if the pact does not create direct inducements for their employers to leave, the new competition from Mexico's expanding manufacturing base seems likely to worsen the financial troubles that have closed hundreds of plants.
 In the last five years, according to Federal data, the region has lost one million jobs, with the deepest cuts coming in the manufacturing industries that will remain most vulnerable to foreign competition. Those losses followed 25 years of decline.
 In New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, where 12.6 million people work, the shrunken assortment of manufacturers that still survive now employ fewer than 1.8 million workers.
 
Poor Industries to Get Poorer
 By contrast, the industries that can expect a boost from the trade agreement, including banks, insurance companies and other service companies, employ more than 4.8 million people.
 The accord is expected to worsen the problems of many communities already staggered by lost factory jobs and pockmarked with abandoned plants. Few will toast the pact in the once-vibrant brass and textile towns of central Connecticut, in the old steel and machinery-producing cities of western New York, or in the New Jersey cities of Edison, Trenton and Linden, where Detroit's auto assembly operations long paid the rent.
 "As an American, I am in favor of Nafta, but as a businessman, I know it's going to hurt," said Justin Israel, the owner of Knitwaves Inc. His Manhattan clothing company has manufactured in Brooklyn for 43 years and never made a stitch abroad.
 Mr. Israel said that he was certain that some New York competitors would set up production in Mexico, and that the region's garment makers would experience even more severe competition. "You don't need to employ brain surgeons to make apparel," he said.
 
Auto Losses Inevitable
 In basic manufacturing, auto executives say, production will move to Mexico, as it has before. For the region's auto makers, textile workers, metal fabricators, foundry workers and other production ranks, job losses are inescapable -- as they would be even without the agreement, industry executives say.
 The Linden General Motors plant has cut its work force in half, to 2,500 from 5,500, since 1985. But it has survived while the major auto companies are abandoning North Tarrytown, Syracuse and Trenton and have already shifted large-scale production to Mexico and other countries.
 According to job data, these days the region's two largest manufacturing industries are publishing, which stands to benefit from the trade agreement, and chemicals, based largely in New Jersey. Publishers employ 220,000 people in the region, and chemical companies, 189,000.
 Executives in chemicals say they expect few job losses, largely because the cost of moving the plants would far exceed savings from lower wages.
 "It costs $80 million to build a catalytic converter, and if you've got one in New Jersey you are not going to build a new plant in Mexico," said Hal Bozarth, executive director of the Chemical Industry Council of New Jersey, a trade group.
 But in textiles, "the people most at risk in this industry are predominantly women, blacks and Hispanics," said Herman Starobin, research director for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union in New York City, where 80,000 workers make clothing. "These are people who need the jobs most."
 But high technology is a different story.
 As president of Locknetics Inc., a company in Bristol, Conn., that makes the card-activated locks for computerized building security systems, James J. Scott said competition from companies paying low wages in Mexico would be nothing new.
 
'Control We Have Here'
 "We already have competitors in Taiwan," he said, adding that his company had just built a new plant in Bristol and had no plans to move. "The advantage we have is the control we have here and the quality we produce."
 Like most high-technology manufacturers in the region, Mr. Scott says the agreement will benefit his company: by stimulating the Mexican economy, it will increase demand for his products in Mexico's airports, universities, factories and office buildings.
 Another benefit for high-technology concerns like I.B.M., based in Armonk, and more than a dozen major pharmaceutical companies will be the requirements that the Mexican Government protect patents and intellectual property.
 Because it often takes more than 10 years to bring a drug to market, "protecting intellectual property is critical to us," said Kevin Cogan, a spokesman for Merck & Company, the nation's largest drug maker. If the agreement expands markets for its products in Mexico, he added, the company, based in Rahway, N.J., may well increase its investment and jobs in the state.
 
Securities Firms Interested
 Marc E. Lackritz, president of the Securities Industry Association said there would be other benefits, adding, "It will be terrific for New York employment, because so much of it is based in and around finance." .
 Longstanding Mexican prohibitions on American companies' having majority interests in Mexican companies, will be eliminated under the accord. Mr. Lackritz said several securities firms are considering acquiring or opening subsidiaries in Mexico.
 The only American bank that now has a wholly owned Mexican subsidiary is Citibank, with five branches in Mexico that it opened in 1929, before foreign ownership was restricted.
 Now, Citibank plans to open more. "And the overall growth in Mexican prosperity will help us more," said Jack Morris, a Citibank spokesman.The bank plans to expand its credit card business with Mexican customers, leading to an expansion of its United States credit processing operations.
 
Closer to Clients
 A vast assortment of professional service firms, from management consulting and public relations to law and marketing, are poised to seek new business in Mexico.
 Many law firms also have long experience with foreign clients and hope to lure more in Mexico. While they are likely to attract clients who need assistance in international business law, they will also seek lucrative new business in the enforcement of Mexican environment laws and in the revised intellectual property rights the pact calls for.
 Besides creating a larger market in Mexico, the trade accord will also provide critical copyright protection and help reduce recurrent piracy, including mass duplication of books and magazines and brisk sales of re-recorded records and home videos.
 "This is one of those industries that is not moving out of the New York area," said Donald D. Kummerfeld, president of the Magazine Publishers of America, representing 220 publishers, most of them in this region."Nafta is not a big thing for us, but it is a plus," he added.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1200 words

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: News Analysis;
A High-Stakes Gamble That Paid Off

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
In July, Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington confided to a diplomat that he thought the North American Free Trade Agreement was dead and that there was nothing he or President Clinton "or anyone on the planet" could do to revive it.
In August, a top Clinton aide said, the private judgment of most senior members of the White House staff was that the President should abandon the trade accord, doing the best he could "to cover his tracks." 
 But Bill Clinton pressed on, growing more rather than less committed as the days passed. Abandoned by two of the three top Democratic leaders in the House, opposed by usually reliable Democrats in the trade unions and by some important leaders of minority groups and environmental organizations, he kept shoving more and more chips into the pot on an issue that few Americans really understood.
 
Against the Odds
 It paid off handsomely. Mr. Clinton worked harder, Mr. Foley said, "than any President I've seen, on any issue, and I've been here 30 years." Against all the odds, with unlikely conservative allies, he forged a surprisingly comfortable majority -- a coalition with more Republicans than Democrats.
Politically, it was the most important achievement of his Presidency. He looked not like Jimmy Carter, tripping and slipping in his relations with Congress, but like the Lyndon B. Johnson of 1964 and 1965: relentless and resourceful, a fighter and not a fumbler.
Mr. Clinton retreated early on Bosnia, on Haiti, on homosexuals in the military, on important elements of his economic plan; he seemed ready to compromise on all but the most basic provisions of his health-care reforms. Critics started asking whether he had a bottom line on anything.
On the trade accord, he did, and that question won't be asked much for a while.
 
President as Deal Maker
 The President's smashing success this week sends him to Seattle on Thursday for the Pacific Rim summit conference with something quite substantial to back up his advocacy of free trade, and likewise gives him leverage in the stalled global trade talks.
In the end, Mr. Clinton won because he made deals, yes; that is what Presidents have always done, when they could. He collected votes because he twisted arms, yes; that, too, is a time-honored practice. (When Henry F. Ashurst of Arizona, a formidable Senate figure from 1912 to 1941, changed his vote on a fiercely disputed bill, a colleague congratulated him on having seen the light. "I didn't see the light," he replied. "I felt the heat.")
But Mr. Clinton also turned the House in his direction because he skillfully repackaged the issue.
"We learned something from Ronald Reagan, finally," said an Administration strategist. "You need to be right on more than the merits of the case; you need to be right on the presentation. We started to do better when we got off statistics and cast it more broadly -- shining city on the hill, you know -- as a choice between the future and the past, optimism and pessimism, hope and fear, embracing the modern world and trying to hide from it."
Mr. Clinton won support, too, because his much-maligned staff turned in a sterling performance that garnered praise from a tough jury on Capitol Hill. A Democrat who fell into line only this week commented tonight, "The gang that couldn't shoot straight must have been taking a lot of target practice over the summer."
Howard Paster, the chief White House liaison with Congress, used to lobby for organized labor, which was on the other side this time. But he was praised by his peers, as were Rahm Emanuel, another key White House staff member, and William Daley, the son and brother of Chicago mayors, who was brought in especially to help on this issue.
Finally, Mr. Clinton won because he dared to gamble, not only in campaigning for the pact when it seemed doomed but in sanctioning the debate between Vice President Al Gore and Ross Perot. It was not his idea to start with; it was cooked up in the Vice President's office, where any chance to speak for the Administration is welcome. But Mr. Clinton bought it, Mr. Gore delivered, and the impact seems to have been considerable.
No one can be certain, especially after the hyperbolic talk of the last 10 days, precisely what the economic impact of the agreement will be once it wins Senate approval. Opponents warned that it would cost a half-million jobs in the next five years; advocates boasted that it would create a quarter-million jobs. Economists tend to doubt both figures, and they point out that those numbers are relatively small, anyway, compared with the 4.9 million new jobs that the American economy is expected to create by 1998.
 
Seen as Economic Boost
 Still, the success of the trade measure, coming as it did a few months after the passage of the President's budget, is seen in the White House as further help for the current economic recovery. Administration economists and some of their academic colleagues think the economy is already doing better than any one statistic shows, and they hope the trade pact will help to keep the curve rising.
There were certain bills to be paid for the approval of the accord.
One was the bewildering series of side deals that were made to win votes this week, some of them unabashedly protectionist corollaries to a free-trade theorem. Tariff barriers were built to protect peanut growers and wheat farmers and orange-juice producers, among many others. They meant that free trade would not be quite so free as it might have been, but more walls came down this week than went up.
Another was the damage to the Democratic coalition. No doubt feelings were hurt and alliances strained. Some voters may have been permanently alienated, especially if their jobs go to Mexico; some will turn to Mr. Perot. But legislative politics is ultimately about interests, not emotions, and the unions, for example, will likely come back into the fold on the big issues that lie ahead, like health care.
That, of course, is the next legislative mountain to be climbed (although the Clinton Administration has already climbed more hillocks than generally noticed, including national service, student loans and family leave). If the trade accord required considerable statecraft in assembling a coalition bit by laborious bit, health care will require two or three times as much. But at least Mr. Clinton has gained credibility, through his tenacity on the trade pact, that will help him in the months ahead.
Can the White House sustain a legislative campaign for that long? Will the staff perform as it did on the accord or as it did in the travel office fiasco? And, above all, can Mr. Clinton avoid the kind of foreign-policy blunders that have recently plagued him and threatened to throw his Presidency permanently off course?
"This is a great victory," said Robert S. Strauss, the longtime Democratic power broker. "But if he's going to be re-elected, Clinton has to learn to focus on domestic and foreign policy at the same time. He can't be just a domestic-policy President any more than George Bush could be just a foreign-policy President. The country expects the President to handle both."

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1639 words

HEADLINE: After the Layoffs, Checks in the Mail

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
More than a year after the last red Chevrolet Camaro rolled off the assembly line at the General Motors plant northwest of downtown, about 1,200 workers laid off from the plant spend their days sleeping late, watching soap operas, taking classes, planting gardens, working out at the gym and, in one instance, learning to surf. Yet every week they continue to receive paychecks from G.M.
Under an unusual provision of the labor agreement between the company and the United Automobile Workers union, the plant's workers will continue to get those checks for up to three more years unless they agree to take a temporary job, move to another G.M. plant hundreds of miles away or opt to retire. 
 G.M. is now trying to figure out a way to stop the giveaway by putting the employees to work at temporary jobs or by offering them sweetened retirement packages, or in the case of younger workers, buyouts.
So far, the workers have had little incentive to retire. G.M.'s retirement benefits do not currently pay as well as the program that pays idle workers for doing nothing.
Three years ago, Robert C. Stempel, who was then G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, offered to pay people to stay home. The U.A.W. liked the provision, which made it "as uneconomical as possible for companies to lay off people," said Frank Joyce, a U.A.W. spokesman. The provision cost the world's largest auto maker more than $3 billion from 1990 to 1993 while it rang up a $17 billion loss in North America. Many experts think the provision was one reason Mr. Stempel lost his job last year.
This fall, G.M. dearly wanted to eliminate or at least limit the giveaway when it negotiated a new contract. But the U.A.W. shrewdly chose to bargain first with the Ford Motor Company, where it won increases in the company's contribution to long-term layoff funds. Ford cared little about the cost of the program, since it had already closed its unnecessary plants and would not be laying off workers permanently.
By the time it was G.M.'s turn to bargain, the Ford contract had set a pattern that G.M. could not break without a costly strike. In the end, G.M. wound up committing more money to the layoff funds than it had in 1990 -- nearly $4 billion more over three years -- even though its workforce had shrunk by tens of thousands of workers.
Besides the plant here, situated in the Van Nuys area of the San Fernando Valley, workers at G.M. plants in North Tarrytown, N.Y.; Wilmington, Del., and Ypsilanti, Mich., are also drawing pay for staying home, but Gerald A. Knechtel, G.M.'s vice president of North American operations, singles out the Van Nuys situation as "a particularly emotional situation among our plant closures."
That is because G.M. first moved car production to Canada and promised the workers that they would be given another model to build. Then, as G.M.'s market share declined, the company announced that it would close the 46-year-old plant. So now it has come up with a series of incentives -- and even some temporary work making seat covers -- to either get the remaining workers off the payroll or keep them productive.
 
 
'Going Crazy'
 At first glance, being paid to be laid off seemed like a dream come true for Terri Varela, 56, who worked for 18 years as a polisher at the Van Nuys plant. She now gets about $1,700 a month, compared with the $2,000 she was paid before being laid off.
But after a year of living leisurely, Ms. Varela and other laid-off workers are starting to have second thoughts. "I'm going crazy," she said. "It's getting to the point where I sit here for hours saying, 'What am I going to do today?'
"I have no sense of what I'll be doing six months from now. I guess I would rather be working full time."
Paying workers for not working is not new in the auto industry. As long ago as the mid-1950's, Detroit auto makers paid workers during temporary plant closings, for slowing production or retooling for new models. When the industry began closing plants and eliminating jobs in the 1980's, additional programs began offering workers payments that provided from 50 to 95 percent of workers' pay, when combined with Government unemployment benefits.
In recent interviews, many laid-off workers from the Van Nuys plant said that they had searched for new jobs in the last year but that they were unsuccessful mainly because of the weak Southern California economy. In addition, they said, many employers refused to hire them when they learned that they were former G.M. employees who were receiving nearly full pay.
 
 
Waiting for the Mail Carrier
 John Dominguez, 41, worked as an electrician at the Van Nuys plant for 22 years, but after a year of being laid-off and receiving G.M. checks, he says he now knows how it feels to be on welfare. "The money is great, but it's demeaning," Mr. Dominguez said. "Just sitting around waiting for the mailman is very frustrating, especially when you have some skills to offer but no job."
For four hours a day, Mr. Dominguez attends a trade school, paid for by a fund set up by the company and the union, where he is studying to become an air-conditioning technician. The rest of the day, he says, he looks in vain for a new job and worries about his future.
When the Van Nuys plant closed in August 1992, many of the 2,707 workers who were laid off began receiving 85 to 100 percent of their gross pay, which averaged about $700 a week here, because of the union-negotiated program. About 600 workers later retired and 300 accepted jobs at G.M. plants in 10 states.
The program enabled laid-off workers to receive all of their wages if they went to school full-time or did community service work, though there is no evidence that the workers were asked to do anything.
But at the end of February, the fund that was created in 1990 ran out of money and the workers were shifted to another program. Through a combination of company-paid benefits and state unemployment compensation, that program enables the workers to receive what they say is about 70 percent of their gross pay.
 
 
Vouchers for New Cars
 Now, after failing at the bargaining table, General Motors is going out of its way to get the workers off its payroll. As part of the new U.A.W. contract, G.M. is offering sweeteners for the Van Nuys workers -- and idle workers at North Tarrytown, Wilmington and Ypsilanti -- to elect early retirement or leave the company voluntarily.
Union officials say one retirement option of the new contract allows retirees to collect a full pension and still work full time at another job without having their G.M. benefits reduced. G.M. would also give these retirees a $10,000 voucher toward the purchase of a new G.M. car or truck and up to $4,000 for taxes and registration fees.
As an alternative, for those who agree not to earn more than $15,500 a year at another job, G.M. is offering a $15,000 voucher toward a new car, plus $6,000 for taxes and license fees.
Finally, for workers at the Van Nuys plant who do not qualify for retirement now, G.M. is offering up to $100,000 if they leave G.M. voluntarily.
 
More May Now Retire
 Ray Knudson, a trustee at the U.A.W.'s Local 645, said that at least half of the Van Nuys plant workers were eligible for retirement, but that many had delayed retiring to keep receiving the more generous weekly paychecks. Mr. Knudson said that while it was still too early to tell, he thought many workers eligible for retirement would now take advantage of the sweetened benefits.
After 31 years at the Van Nuys plant, Salvador Torres, a 50-year-old mechanic, said he planned to retire to receive the $10,000 voucher and $4,000 cash, which he will put toward either a Pontiac Grand Prix or a Chevrolet Astro van.
Mr. Torres, who currently attends automotive school from 8 A.M. to 3 P.M., where he learns to repair cars other than G.M.'s, said he hoped to find a part-time job to supplement his pension, which he estimates will be $1,830 a month.
When he is not in school, Mr. Torres says he spends his free time helping his wife with housework, fixing his children's cars, coaching Little League and running marathons. "Under the circumstances, I feel quite lucky," he said. "I've had an extended vacation this past year, and now I can get on with my life."
The Van Nuys plant, a 100-acre operation built in 1947, at various times churned out Chevrolet trucks, Monte Carlos, Chevelles and Novas, as well as Oldsmobile Omegas and Pontiac Venturas. G.M. moved the plant's last remaining vehicles, Camaros and Pontiac Firebirds, to a newer plant in St. Therese, Quebec, as part of a cost-cutting move.
 
Retraining Classes
 Currently, the Van Nuys plant sits idle most of the day, except between 6:30 A.M. and noon, when 80 laid-off employees show up for a retraining program jointly run by the company and union. Classes in reading, math, grammar and computer skills are taught by teachers from the Los Angeles schools.
Leaving a computer class at the G.M. plant last week, Ismael Barba, 55, said that after 37 years as a tool maker for G.M., he realized he could not compete for other jobs because he was not "computer literate."
Mr. Barba, who said he now received $600 of the $800 a week he made before being laid off, planned to spend the rest of the day as he usually did, visiting his parents and doing housework.
"Having free time is not all that people think it's cracked up to be," he said. "After going to school half the day, it's not easy going out and finding a job."
Even G.M. executives at the vacant plant seem to have plenty of time on their hands. A man who identified himself as a plant official was spotted last week tending to the rows of yellow, pink and red roses that line empty parking lots at the plant. He declined to answer any questions.

GRAPHIC: Photos: After 31 years at the General Motors plant in the Van Nuys area of Los Angeles, Salvador Torres is learning to repair cars other than G.M.'s so he can find a part-time job to supplement his pension; Ismael Barba, 55, is attending computer classes at the plant; Terri Varela, a laid-off G.M. worker, helping Stan Vrbanic, a retired auto worker, during a trip to his physical therapist. (Photographs by Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1200 words

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: News Analysis;
A High-Stakes Gamble That Paid Off

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
In July, Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington confided to a diplomat that he thought the North American Free Trade Agreement was dead and that there was nothing he or President Clinton "or anyone on the planet" could do to revive it.

 But Bill Clinton pressed on, growing more rather than less committed as the days passed. Abandoned by two of the three top Democratic leaders in the House, opposed by usually reliable Democrats in the trade unions and by some important leaders of minority groups and environmental organizations, he kept shoving more and more chips into the pot on an issue that few Americans really understood.

 It paid off handsomely. Mr. Clinton worked harder, Mr. Foley said, "than any President I've seen, on any issue, and I've been here 30 years." Against all the odds, with unlikely conservative allies, he forged a surprisingly comfortable majority -- a coalition with more Republicans than Democrats.
Politically, it was the most important achievement of his Presidency. He looked not like Jimmy Carter, tripping and slipping in his relations with Congress, but like the Lyndon B. Johnson of 1964 and 1965: relentless and resourceful, a fighter and not a fumbler.
Mr. Clinton retreated early on Bosnia, on Haiti, on homosexuals in the military, on important elements of his economic plan; he seemed ready to compromise on all but the most basic provisions of his health-care reforms. Critics started asking whether he had a bottom line on anything.
On the trade accord, he did, and that question won't be asked much for a while.
 
President as Deal Maker
 The President's smashing success this week sends him to Seattle on Thursday for the Pacific Rim summit conference with something quite substantial to back up his advocacy of free trade, and likewise gives him leverage in the stalled global trade talks.
In the end, Mr. Clinton won because he made deals, yes; that is what Presidents have always done, when they could. He collected votes because he twisted arms, yes; that, too, is a time-honored practice. (When Henry F. Ashurst of Arizona, a formidable Senate figure from 1912 to 1941, changed his vote on a fiercely disputed bill, a colleague congratulated him on having seen the light. "I didn't see the light," he replied. "I felt the heat.")
But Mr. Clinton also turned the House in his direction because he skillfully repackaged the issue.
"We learned something from Ronald Reagan, finally," said an Administration strategist. "You need to be right on more than the merits of the case; you need to be right on the presentation. We started to do better when we got off statistics and cast it more broadly -- shining city on the hill, you know -- as a choice between the future and the past, optimism and pessimism, hope and fear, embracing the modern world and trying to hide from it."
Mr. Clinton won support, too, because his much-maligned staff turned in a sterling performance that garnered praise from a tough jury on Capitol Hill. A Democrat who fell into line only this week commented tonight, "The gang that couldn't shoot straight must have been taking a lot of target practice over the summer."
Howard Paster, the chief White House liaison with Congress, used to lobby for organized labor, which was on the other side this time. But he was praised by his peers, as were Rahm Emanuel, another key White House staff member, and William Daley, the son and brother of Chicago mayors, who was brought in especially to help on this issue.
Finally, Mr. Clinton won because he dared to gamble, not only in campaigning for the pact when it seemed doomed but in sanctioning the debate between Vice President Al Gore and Ross Perot. It was not his idea to start with; it was cooked up in the Vice President's office, where any chance to speak for the Administration is welcome. But Mr. Clinton bought it, Mr. Gore delivered, and the impact seems to have been considerable.
No one can be certain, especially after the hyperbolic talk of the last 10 days, precisely what the economic impact of the agreement will be once it wins Senate approval. Opponents warned that it would cost a half-million jobs in the next five years; advocates boasted that it would create a quarter-million jobs. Economists tend to doubt both figures, and they point out that those numbers are relatively small, anyway, compared with the 4.9 million new jobs that the American economy is expected to create by 1998.
 
Seen as Economic Boost
 Still, the success of the trade measure, coming as it did a few months after the passage of the President's budget, is seen in the White House as further help for the current economic recovery. Administration economists and some of their academic colleagues think the economy is already doing better than any one statistic shows, and they hope the trade pact will help to keep the curve rising.
There were certain bills to be paid for the approval of the accord.
One was the bewildering series of side deals that were made to win votes this week, some of them unabashedly protectionist corollaries to a free-trade theorem. Tariff barriers were built to protect peanut growers and wheat farmers and orange-juice producers, among many others. They meant that free trade would not be quite so free as it might have been, but more walls came down this week than went up.
Another was the damage to the Democratic coalition. No doubt feelings were hurt and alliances strained. Some voters may have been permanently alienated, especially if their jobs go to Mexico; some will turn to Mr. Perot. But legislative politics is ultimately about interests, not emotions, and the unions, for example, will likely come back into the fold on the big issues that lie ahead, like health care.
That, of course, is the next legislative mountain to be climbed (although the Clinton Administration has already climbed more hillocks than generally noticed, including national service, student loans and family leave). If the trade accord required considerable statecraft in assembling a coalition bit by laborious bit, health care will require two or three times as much. But at least Mr. Clinton has gained credibility, through his tenacity on the trade pact, that will help him in the months ahead.
Can the White House sustain a legislative campaign for that long? Will the staff perform as it did on the accord or as it did in the travel office fiasco? And, above all, can Mr. Clinton avoid the kind of foreign-policy blunders that have recently plagued him and threatened to throw his Presidency permanently off course?
"This is a great victory," said Robert S. Strauss, the longtime Democratic power broker. "But if he's going to be re-elected, Clinton has to learn to focus on domestic and foreign policy at the same time. He can't be just a domestic-policy President any more than George Bush could be just a foreign-policy President. The country expects the President to handle both."

HEADLINE: U.S., in Stern Terms, Warns North Koreans on A-Arms

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher warned North Korea today to open its nuclear installations to international inspection or face punishment, probably in the form of economic sanctions.
Mr. Christopher made his remarks before meeting with Chinese officials to enlist their aid to get North Korea to comply with the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons. 
 In a speech at the University of Washington, Mr. Christopher said the United States preferred to deal with North Korea's refusal to allow inspection of its nuclear plants through diplomacy. But he added that if North Korea continued to refuse, the United States would recommend that the United Nations impose sanctions.
In order to avoid such action, Mr. Christopher said, North Korea must agree to inspections by the International Atomic Energy Agency and resume talks with South Korea on fulfilling an agreement between the two countries to keep the Korean peninsula free of nuclear weapons.
 
Words of Warning
 "If North Korea refuses the necessary inspections and refuses to resume a dialogue with South Korea on nuclear issues, then we are prepared to recommend that the United Nations Security Council consider options other than negotiation," he said.
The warning differs little in tone from President Clinton's nearly two weeks ago. But coming on the eve of a summit meeting by the 15 members of forum on Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, it underscores the importance of the issue to the Administration.
Mr. Christopher's warning also came a few hours before he is to meet with Qian Qichen, the Chinese Foreign Minister. In an interview this week, the Secretary of State said he intended to stress the need for cooperation in putting pressure on North Korea.
"It will be important to have Chinese understanding and support for what we're doing in this present diplomatic negotiation," Mr. Christopher said, "and it's important to have their understanding and support if it's neccessary -- which we hope it won't be -- if we go back to the United Nations Security Council."
 
Frustration in Washington
 China is one of the few countries that exert any influence on North Korea, one of the world's most isolated nations. Chinese cooperation will also be essential if an economic embargo is placed on North Korea, since the two countries share a long border.
Mr. Christopher's stern tone reflects a growing frustration in the Administration over North Korea's continued refusal to allow inspections of its nuclear research installation, about 60 miles north of Pyongyang.
In addition, North Korea has refused to allow inspection of a site near the reactor complex where officials from the atomic energy agency suspect nuclear wastes have been dumped. Inspection of the suspected dump site is critical to determining if North Korea has diverted plutonium from its reactor to use in nuclear weapons.
Rather than allow inspections, North Korea announced in March that it intended to withdraw from the non-proliferation treaty.
Mr. Christopher's tone contrasted sharply with a more concilatory message coming from South Korea. While warning of the dangers of a North Korea with nuclear weapons, senior South Korean officials have stressed the need for continued negotiations.
The South Korean officials, speaking on the condition that they nat be identified, say talks should continue unless the international agency determines that North Korea is no longer in compliance with the non-proliferation treaty. The South Korean President, Kim Young-sam, is to travel to Washington after the summit meeting here and is expected to confer with Administration officials on North Korea.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Secretary of State Warren Christopher at the University of Washington before meeting with Chinese officials to enlist their aid in getting North Korea to comply with the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: After the Layoffs, Checks in the Mail

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
More than a year after the last red Chevrolet Camaro rolled off the assembly line at the General Motors plant northwest of downtown, about 1,200 workers laid off from the plant spend their days sleeping late, watching soap operas, taking classes, planting gardens, working out at the gym and, in one instance, learning to surf. Yet every week they continue to receive paychecks from G.M.
Under an unusual provision of the labor agreement between the company and the United Automobile Workers union, the plant's workers will continue to get those checks for up to three more years unless they agree to take a temporary job, move to another G.M. plant hundreds of miles away or opt to retire. 
 G.M. is now trying to figure out a way to stop the giveaway by putting the employees to work at temporary jobs or by offering them sweetened retirement packages, or in the case of younger workers, buyouts.
So far, the workers have had little incentive to retire. G.M.'s retirement benefits do not currently pay as well as the program that pays idle workers for doing nothing.
Three years ago, Robert C. Stempel, who was then G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, offered to pay people to stay home. The U.A.W. liked the provision, which made it "as uneconomical as possible for companies to lay off people," said Frank Joyce, a U.A.W. spokesman. The provision cost the world's largest auto maker more than $3 billion from 1990 to 1993 while it rang up a $17 billion loss in North America. Many experts think the provision was one reason Mr. Stempel lost his job last year.
This fall, G.M. dearly wanted to eliminate or at least limit the giveaway when it negotiated a new contract. But the U.A.W. shrewdly chose to bargain first with the Ford Motor Company, where it won increases in the company's contribution to long-term layoff funds. Ford cared little about the cost of the program, since it had already closed its unnecessary plants and would not be laying off workers permanently.
By the time it was G.M.'s turn to bargain, the Ford contract had set a pattern that G.M. could not break without a costly strike. In the end, G.M. wound up committing more money to the layoff funds than it had in 1990 -- nearly $4 billion more over three years -- even though its workforce had shrunk by tens of thousands of workers.
Besides the plant here, situated in the Van Nuys area of the San Fernando Valley, workers at G.M. plants in North Tarrytown, N.Y.; Wilmington, Del., and Ypsilanti, Mich., are also drawing pay for staying home, but Gerald A. Knechtel, G.M.'s vice president of North American operations, singles out the Van Nuys situation as "a particularly emotional situation among our plant closures."
That is because G.M. first moved car production to Canada and promised the workers that they would be given another model to build. Then, as G.M.'s market share declined, the company announced that it would close the 46-year-old plant. So now it has come up with a series of incentives -- and even some temporary work making seat covers -- to either get the remaining workers off the payroll or keep them productive.
 
 
'Going Crazy'
 At first glance, being paid to be laid off seemed like a dream come true for Terri Varela, 56, who worked for 18 years as a polisher at the Van Nuys plant. She now gets about $1,700 a month, compared with the $2,000 she was paid before being laid off.
But after a year of living leisurely, Ms. Varela and other laid-off workers are starting to have second thoughts. "I'm going crazy," she said. "It's getting to the point where I sit here for hours saying, 'What am I going to do today?'
"I have no sense of what I'll be doing six months from now. I guess I would rather be working full time."
Paying workers for not working is not new in the auto industry. As long ago as the mid-1950's, Detroit auto makers paid workers during temporary plant closings, for slowing production or retooling for new models. When the industry began closing plants and eliminating jobs in the 1980's, additional programs began offering workers payments that provided from 50 to 95 percent of workers' pay, when combined with Government unemployment benefits.
In recent interviews, many laid-off workers from the Van Nuys plant said that they had searched for new jobs in the last year but that they were unsuccessful mainly because of the weak Southern California economy. In addition, they said, many employers refused to hire them when they learned that they were former G.M. employees who were receiving nearly full pay.
 
 
Waiting for the Mail Carrier
 John Dominguez, 41, worked as an electrician at the Van Nuys plant for 22 years, but after a year of being laid-off and receiving G.M. checks, he says he now knows how it feels to be on welfare. "The money is great, but it's demeaning," Mr. Dominguez said. "Just sitting around waiting for the mailman is very frustrating, especially when you have some skills to offer but no job."
For four hours a day, Mr. Dominguez attends a trade school, paid for by a fund set up by the company and the union, where he is studying to become an air-conditioning technician. The rest of the day, he says, he looks in vain for a new job and worries about his future.
When the Van Nuys plant closed in August 1992, many of the 2,707 workers who were laid off began receiving 85 to 100 percent of their gross pay, which averaged about $700 a week here, because of the union-negotiated program. About 600 workers later retired and 300 accepted jobs at G.M. plants in 10 states.
The program enabled laid-off workers to receive all of their wages if they went to school full-time or did community service work, though there is no evidence that the workers were asked to do anything.
But at the end of February, the fund that was created in 1990 ran out of money and the workers were shifted to another program. Through a combination of company-paid benefits and state unemployment compensation, that program enables the workers to receive what they say is about 70 percent of their gross pay.
 
 
Vouchers for New Cars
 Now, after failing at the bargaining table, General Motors is going out of its way to get the workers off its payroll. As part of the new U.A.W. contract, G.M. is offering sweeteners for the Van Nuys workers -- and idle workers at North Tarrytown, Wilmington and Ypsilanti -- to elect early retirement or leave the company voluntarily.
Union officials say one retirement option of the new contract allows retirees to collect a full pension and still work full time at another job without having their G.M. benefits reduced. G.M. would also give these retirees a $10,000 voucher toward the purchase of a new G.M. car or truck and up to $4,000 for taxes and registration fees.
As an alternative, for those who agree not to earn more than $15,500 a year at another job, G.M. is offering a $15,000 voucher toward a new car, plus $6,000 for taxes and license fees.
Finally, for workers at the Van Nuys plant who do not qualify for retirement now, G.M. is offering up to $100,000 if they leave G.M. voluntarily.
 
More May Now Retire
 Ray Knudson, a trustee at the U.A.W.'s Local 645, said that at least half of the Van Nuys plant workers were eligible for retirement, but that many had delayed retiring to keep receiving the more generous weekly paychecks. Mr. Knudson said that while it was still too early to tell, he thought many workers eligible for retirement would now take advantage of the sweetened benefits.
After 31 years at the Van Nuys plant, Salvador Torres, a 50-year-old mechanic, said he planned to retire to receive the $10,000 voucher and $4,000 cash, which he will put toward either a Pontiac Grand Prix or a Chevrolet Astro van.
Mr. Torres, who currently attends automotive school from 8 A.M. to 3 P.M., where he learns to repair cars other than G.M.'s, said he hoped to find a part-time job to supplement his pension, which he estimates will be $1,830 a month.
When he is not in school, Mr. Torres says he spends his free time helping his wife with housework, fixing his children's cars, coaching Little League and running marathons. "Under the circumstances, I feel quite lucky," he said. "I've had an extended vacation this past year, and now I can get on with my life."
The Van Nuys plant, a 100-acre operation built in 1947, at various times churned out Chevrolet trucks, Monte Carlos, Chevelles and Novas, as well as Oldsmobile Omegas and Pontiac Venturas. G.M. moved the plant's last remaining vehicles, Camaros and Pontiac Firebirds, to a newer plant in St. Therese, Quebec, as part of a cost-cutting move.
 
Retraining Classes
 Currently, the Van Nuys plant sits idle most of the day, except between 6:30 A.M. and noon, when 80 laid-off employees show up for a retraining program jointly run by the company and union. Classes in reading, math, grammar and computer skills are taught by teachers from the Los Angeles schools.
Leaving a computer class at the G.M. plant last week, Ismael Barba, 55, said that after 37 years as a tool maker for G.M., he realized he could not compete for other jobs because he was not "computer literate."
Mr. Barba, who said he now received $600 of the $800 a week he made before being laid off, planned to spend the rest of the day as he usually did, visiting his parents and doing housework.
"Having free time is not all that people think it's cracked up to be," he said. "After going to school half the day, it's not easy going out and finding a job."
Even G.M. executives at the vacant plant seem to have plenty of time on their hands. A man who identified himself as a plant official was spotted last week tending to the rows of yellow, pink and red roses that line empty parking lots at the plant. He declined to answer any questions.

GRAPHIC: Photos: After 31 years at the General Motors plant in the Van Nuys area of Los Angeles, Salvador Torres is learning to repair cars other than G.M.'s so he can find a part-time job to supplement his pension; Ismael Barba, 55, is attending computer classes at the plant; Terri Varela, a laid-off G.M. worker, helping Stan Vrbanic, a retired auto worker, during a trip to his physical therapist. (Photographs by Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Some see bargains among the stocks of close-out stores.

BYLINE: By Andrea Adelson

 BODY:
DURING the recession, penny-pinching shoppers learned to hunt for discounted brand-name goods at close-out stores. Although the economy now appears to be recovering, such stores continue to thrive, making up a $5 billion segment of the general retailing industry.
Some retail analysts say investors too can find a bargain among stocks of close-out retailers, which buy distressed goods when manufacturers produce too much or make mistakes with a product. Close-out stores sell the goods at steep markdowns compared with traditional retailers.
The Consolidated Stores Corporation, Mac Frugal's Bargains Close-Outs Inc., Value City Department Stores Inc., Tuesday Morning Inc. and Value Merchants Inc. are retailing's scavengers. Their bare-bones stores are stocked with goods in last year's colors, items labeled for test markets, unsold factory inventory, orders canceled by cash-short department stores, products in old wrappers and food whose shelf life is near its end. 
 Analysts who follow these deep-discount merchants recommend Consolidated Stores, by far the largest in the niche. The Columbus, Ohio, company had sales of $929 million last year from 381 stores operating under the Big Lots and Odd Lots names, as well as from 160 All for One stores.
Shares of Consolidated closed at $21 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The price is relatively expensive because it is about 17 times analysts' estimates of earnings for the year ending Feb. 1, 1995.
The close-out business is growing twice as fast as the 5 percent growth rate of retailing in general. Yet stocks in a broader retail index sell for 14 times expected earnings for fiscal 1995, Thomas H. Tashjian, an analyst for First Manhattan, said.
If Consolidated's stock price seems high, true bargain hunters can consider the shares of Mac Frugal's, the industry's pioneer. Its shares have been trading around $16 after hitting a peak of nearly $20 in June.
But Mac Frugal's sales and profit momentum stalled soon after a period of rapid growth in the late 1980's, when expenses got out of hand. A turnaround has been held back by a prolonged recession in Southern California, which seemingly would help sales but has not. Mac Frugal's, based in Dominguez, Calif., has 81 of its 205 stores in the region. Sales were $540 million in 1992.
But David H. Batchelder, a member of a dissident shareholder group that forced a restructuring of Mac Frugal's in 1990, says the stock of the company is undervalued compared with its primary competitor.
Mac Frugal's closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $16.625 -- a price to earnings multiple of 10 for the year ending Feb. 1, 1995.
"The market is betting that Consolidated can sustain its earnings growth in fiscal 1993 and into 1994," Mr. Batchelder said. This fiscal year, to meet analysts' estimates of 95 cents a share, Consolidated must outperform the previous year's results for the second half by 30 percent. "That's a very aggressive assumption," said Mr. Batchelder, who is a Mac Frugal's director and holds about 50,000 shares.
Mac Frugal's needs at least an 18 percent increase in second-half earnings to meet analysts' earnings forecasts. "Mac Frugal's has an opportunity to outperform the market's expectations," he said.
Mr. Tashjian of First Manhattan is skeptical of the prospects for such strong growth, noting that Mac Frugal's sales rates for stores open at least a year are not growing.
Dana Telsey, an analyst at C. J. Lawrence, said Consolidated, rather than Mac Frugal's, would benefit from current consumer preferences. Consolidated has a reputation for making shrewd buying sorties; for example, it swiftly acquired discontinued apparel from the Sears catalogue, lifting its sales for September by 8 percent.
Mac Frugal's is better known for its array of imports. "Consumers want to buy the same brands they did in the 80's but can't afford in the 90's," she said.
Although manufacturers have become more efficient in recent years, resulting in fewer overruns of products, buyers for close-out chains still find plenty of merchandise to scoop up. "Humans make mistakes," said Howard Snyder, co-owner of Odd Job Trading, a privately held close-out store.

HEADLINE: U.S. Will Allow Computer Sale To Court China

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
In a good-will gesture toward China, the Clinton Administration has agreed to sell it a sophisticated $8 million supercomputer, senior Administration officials said today.
The decision is part of the Administration's strategy to embrace rather than isolate China despite disagreements over human rights, weapons proliferation and trade. The Clinton Administration is determined to grab an ever-larger share of China's market, the fastest growing in the world, and reduce a trade deficit that could exceed the one with Japan by the end of the decade.
 
G.E. Stands to Profit
 Even more significant for American business, the Administration has also decided to lift the ban on important components for China's nuclear power plants, like generators, senior Commerce Department officials said. That could mean billions of dollars in sales for the General Electric Company, which has begun to break into China's burgeoning nuclear power market. 
 But the decision to go forward with the supercomputer sale is strategically more important because it signals the Administration's willingness to sell high-technology equipment to Beijing.
The Administration was also eager to give a lift to the financially troubled company that makes the computer, Cray Research Inc.
The decision was relayed to China's Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, by Secretary of State Warren Christopher in Seattle on Wednesday. Senior White House officials said today that it had not been decided whether Mr. Clinton would announce the supercomputer decision, as well as other parts of the economic package, after he met with China's President, Jiang Zemin, in Seattle on Friday.
The Administration decided to allow the sale despite clear evidence that China has broken its promises to Washington by exporting M-11 missile components and technology to Pakistan. Those exports violated an international missile control accord.
The computer is for use in weather prediction by China's State Meteorological Administration. Although there has never been a statutory ban on the supercomputer sale, the Bush Administration postponed the sale last December after intelligence reports showed that China had exported the M-11 technology. But in the final days of his Administration, Mr. Bush overruled the Defense Department and ordered the approval of a license pending necessary processing.
That put the decision on the desk of Mr. Clinton, who had accused Mr. Bush in the Presidential campaign of not doing enough to halt the spread of nuclear, chemical, biological and ballistic missile technology.
In informing Mr. Qian on Wednesday, Mr. Christopher did not ask for any concessions from Beijing.
"There was no linkage," a senior Administration official said. "The only thing we wanted to be sure of was that we weren't running up against any U.S. export restrictions."
 
China May Get Satellites
 Mr. Christopher also told Mr. Qian that the United States would be prepared to interpret an American law governing the export of high technology to China to allow the export of two of the seven sophisticated American-made satellites banned by sanctions imposed on China in August, senior Administration officials said.
But the Administration could offer such a gesture only if China opened formal talks on the sanctions and its missile sales, which thus far it has refused to do, arguing that the sanctions had to be lifted first.
Mr. Qian showed some flexibility, saying that the Chinese were willing to study entering into such consultations, the officials said.
In August, as required by American law, the Administration imposed sanctions on an estimated $1 billion in high-technology trade, including a ban on the export of the seven satellites, after American intelligence agencies produced conclusive proof that China was continuing to ship M-11 technology and equipment to Pakistan in violation of the accord known as the Missile Technology Control Regime. The law only covers sanctions against the Chinese companies involved in weapons transfers and therefore does not apply to the supercomputer.
 
Some Experts Are Opposed
 Some Administration experts, particularly in the Defense and Energy Departments, argued against sale of the supercomputer, saying it would give China important new technology that could help its nuclear and ballistic missile development.
Senior officials involved in the decision insist that the supercomputer will be sent under strict conditions, including substantial American monitoring, that will prevent its diversion for military uses.
But some Pentagon officials and key lawmakers disagree. When informed of the Administration's decision, Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, who has opposed the sale, said in a telephone interview: "It's a mistake. We have to be firmer with China, and that's what China will respect. We should not be sending that kind of high-tech equipment to any nation that continues nuclear explosions."
After China broke an informal nuclear-testing moratorium and exploded a nuclear weapon last month, Senator Simon sent a letter to President Clinton urging the Administration to withhold the supercomputer and other sensitive high-technology sales until Beijing guaranteed that it would not conduct more tests.
 
U.S. Appeals Disregarded
 A Pentagon official involved in proliferation issues said: "There are technical difficulties putting in safeguards. And if the Chinese manage to use the supercomputer in a weapons program, no one's going to go in there and pull the plug."
The official also questioned lifting of the ban that would make it easier for China to build nuclear power plants, since China has disregarded American appeals to end its nuclear cooperation with Iran.
Until now, the United States has not sold Beijing any computer with a speed of more than 70 million calculations per second. By contrast, the Cray supercomputer has a speed of 958 million calculations per second. Even with that capacity, China would have only about one-twentieth of the computing power of advanced nations.
