HEADLINE: CLINTON NOW TURNS TO WIDENING TRADE ACROSS THE PACIFIC

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Hoping to build on his triumph with the North American Free Trade Agreement, President Clinton arrived here today vowing to open new markets in the Pacific. He immediately ran into obstacles from Asian officials who say the world's most booming economies are not yet ready for free-trade zones of their own.
"We come here today hoping to drive down trade barriers, open up tradeopportunities and promote more growth," Mr. Clinton said after arriving at Boeing Field here. 
 Before leaving Washington, Mr. Clinton said Vice President Al Gore would travel to Mexico to meet with President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, probably next week, to discuss carrying out the trade accord. And the President and the Congressional Democrats who opposed him on the trade pact moved to find common cause on other issues, including health care. [Page A27.]
 
A Three-Day Meeting
 The President and his aides have hailed the three-day summit meeting, the first time that Asia's leaders have ever gathered in one place, as an historic moment to accomplish what past administrations have often talked about but never succeeded in carrying out: redirecting American foreign policy toward the Pacific. Mr. Clinton's focus is on a fledgling regional trade group called the Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum that embraces countries as diverse as Australia, Indonesia, Japan and Canada.
But Mr. Clinton and his aides have made it clear that they hoped to use the economic group as a vehicle to create a sense of political community that has never existed amid the rivalries and competing cultures of Asia, hoping it will clear trade barriers in the markets that Mr. Clinton views as the key to job growth in the United States.
"Make no mistake about it, ultimately this meeting is about the jobs and futures and incomes of the American people," the President said, talking to employees at Boeing Corporation, America's largest exporter and Seattle's biggest employer.
Mr. Clinton, speaking to a cheering crowd of Boeing workers, never mentioned the huge layoffs that the aircraft manufacturer has made in recent months or the accusations by some of workers that the company, by striking up relatiohships with manufacturers in China and Japan, is effectively exporting jobs in order to sell planes.
 
'Not Enough Growth'
 Mr. Clinton said the main problem in the American economy "is there's not enough growth in the world economy," and added, "We're going to change that, beginning at this meeting for the Pacific region."
But that same agenda is the source of concern among many of the Asian leaders Mr. Clinton is meeting, who say they fear the American President is trying to turn the group into a powerful trade weapon that will undercut their own economies.
Today, in the first concrete action since officials began meeting here earlier this week, foreign ministers from the 15 nations agreed to allow in three more members: Mexico, Papau New Guinea and Chile. President Salinas of Mexico does not plan to attend the meeting in Seattle, however, though Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada will be here.
But even the move for new admissions touched off controversy, with Australia and several of the Southeast Asian countries expressing fears that the economic corporation would lose its regional flavor by including Latin American nations. Officials said an agreement was reached to bar the entry of any new members for at least three years, while the group better defined its mission.
"You have to think of this a bit like being at a NATO meeting in 1950," a senior aide to Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today, as foreign ministers from the nations of the Asian-Pacific forum met here to develop what Mr. Christopher has termed a "vision statement" for an Asian community. "Only there is no common enemy, and uncertainty about what the common economic objective should be."
 
Indonesia Leads Objectors
 That became clear this morning, when several nations, led by Indonesia, whose labor costs and per capita income are among the lowest in Asia, expressed clear objections to several specific proposals to turn the consultative body into a formal trade organization, with free-trade areas, procedures for settling disputes among members and uniform criteria for accepting foreign investment.
"It's fair to say that there are a variety of concerns, especially among the developing nations, that we proceed with some caution," said Nobuo Matsunaga, a former Japanese Ambassador to the United States and Tokyo's special envoy to the Asian-Pacific froum. Japan has cast itself as something of a mediator between the Asian countries and the Western members of the organization, although many nations suspect that it, too, is not eager for free trade zones in a region Japanese companies have come to dominate.
In recent days Washington has backed away from its earlier efforts to use the meeting to declare the birth of an Asian-Pacific Community; so far is the group from such pronouncements that it still refers to its "member economies" for fear that terms like "nations"' would prevent China and Taiwan from joining the group.
 
Action on GATT Sought
 For now, American officials say, they will be satisfied if this week's meeting results in Asian pressure on Europe to clear the considerable obstacles to concluding years of negotiations over the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The deadline is Dec. 15, when Mr. Clinton's negotiating authority, granted by Congress, runs out. Part of the Administration's strategy is to use the specter of an Asian trading agreement as a spur -- some say a threat -- to the European Community, particularly France, to make the agricultural concessions needed to conclude the GATT negotiations, called the Uruguay Round.
A senior Administration official said today that a statement to be issued by the Asian-Pacific ministers on Friday would probably contain a specific reference to agricultural subsidies. It is unclear how Japan, whose continuing but crumbling ban on rice imports remains an obstacle to an agreement, might try to water down that statement.
"We want them to know that while we all want GATT, there are other options we have with Asia," an American official said here earlier this week.
Privately, both American and Asian officials say the bruising Nafta debate left them doubtful that broad trade agreements with Asia could ever survive the kind of scrutiny accorded the agreement with Canada and Mexico. The issues and questions of job security raised in the debate over the North American Free Trade Agreement pale in comparison with the challenges of Asia's economies, which include both high-tech trading powers like Japan and low-wage manufacturing giants like China.
 
Pressure for Plant Sites
 Already many of those countries have exerted strong political pressure to insure that countries like Japan and the United States build many of their products in the markets where they are sold -- which explains Malaysia's giant Mitsubishi car factory and the huge McDonnell Douglas aircraft assembly plant in Shanghai.
"If there was this much debate on Nafta, imagine the debate you would have in America over a free trade area with the whole Pacific," said Han Sung Joo, South Korea's Foreign Minister.
The United States is clearly also isolated within the group on another major tenet of American foreign policy -- human rights. So far, few of the other member economies have joined in American protests over the treatment of dissidents in China and Indonesia, the Pacific's two most populous countries.
State Department officials have made it clear that Mr. Clinton will be raising human rights concerns here when he meets on Friday with Jiang Zimen, China's President, in the first such meeting since the Beijing Government suppressed China's pro-democracy movement in the Tiananmen Square protests in 1989.

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: The Partners' Reaction;
Mexican Leader a Big Winner As the Trade Pact Advances

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Arduously as it may have come, many Mexicans today hailed the approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement as resounding confirmation of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's vision of a new economic future for their country.
"It's an enormous personal and political victory," the novelist Carlos Fuentes said of Wednesday night's vote. "Salinas has really clinched his whole economic revolution. Mexico's economic position in the world is assured." 
 Far more than Bill Clinton, it was Mr. Salinas who staked his Presidency on the trade agreement, often dragging a reluctant nation into partnership with a powerful neighbor it has always feared. And even more than Mr. Clinton, Mr. Salinas and his long-ruling party may reap decisive benefits.
 
There Is a Downside
 Yet while the approval of the agreement may mark the beginning of Mexico's emergence from the third world and its unchallenged leadership of Latin America in that process, the path is by no means clear.
Though the Mexican economy has been in the throes of profound change since the country began opening its borders to foreign competition in 1986, economists predict that several million Mexicans will probably lose their jobs in the first five years after the accord takes effect on Jan. 1.
How the Government will ease the impact while new jobs are created, what role it will take in guiding industrial integration with the United States and Canada and how it will respond to rising pressure for further democratization of an authoritarian political system are all questions that Mexican officials have yet to answer fully.
"Mexico must now prepare for a very difficult period," said Berta Lujan, a trade-union organizer who was a leader of the modest political opposition to the agreement. "There are going to be social costs to the economic restructuring, and I think that Mexico may not be prepared for either the restructuring or for the costs it will have to pay."
Lorenzo Zambrano, chief executive of the huge cement manufacturer Cementos Mexicanos and a strong supporter of the agreement, said the Government had oversold its benefits.
"It will not by itself make us into an Asian tiger," he said in a telephone interview from his office in Monterrey. But he added, "This makes it extraordinarily difficult for Mexico to ever turn back to the old closed economy, and it makes our comparative advantage of being the neighbor of the United States much more tangible."
 
A Subdued Leader
 As though sobered by the agreement's near-defeat, Mr. Salinas marked his triumph with striking restraint. And his office insisted again that he has no plans to go to Seattle for the meeting of leaders from Pacific Rim countries, despite rumors that he would.
While senior Salinas aides beamed and laughed and slapped one another on the back, their 45-year-old leader appeared almost poker-faced when he emerged from his offices about an hour after the vote.
"I reiterate that we should not expect immediate effects from the treaty," he said. "The principal effects of the treaty will be reflected in the medium term and because of that, overly high expectations would not be justified."
By its intense promotion of the deal both at home and abroad, the Salinas Government had helped to create a situation in which potential losses from a rejection of the accord would have been worse than anything Mexico might have suffered had Mr. Salinas never taken up the offer of a trade pact.
Though the Government was attacked by opponents of the agreement for having spent millions of dollars to lobby for it in the United States, many Mexican officials expressed a sense of powerlessness as the vote neared.
Key aides to Mr. Salinas who had expected to join the fight in Washington were told by United States officials to stay home because it was thought that their presence might be counterproductive. And before Mr. Clinton telephoned on Wednesday night to offer congratulations, Mr. Salinas had gone more than a month without hearing from him, two Mexican officials said.
Mexican officials also seem to have been somewhat chastened by the high price they were forced to pay to win Congressional support.
 
The Shadow of Deal-Making
 On Wednesday night the Trade Secretary, Jaime Serra Puche, continued to insist that Mexico had not renegotiated any aspect of the agreement in response to the demands of United States legislators. But as the vote neared, complaints rose from Mexican business executives who saw some Nafta benefits for exporters of sugar, citrus fruits, vegetables and other items dealt away.
Even so, the vote in Washington will bring an immediate and perhaps insurmountable boost to Mr. Salinas and the Institutional Revolutionary Party as Mexicans turn their attention to the election of his successor in August.
Under the Constitution, Mr. Salinas cannot run for re-election. But with neither the leftist nor rightist opposition yet able to rise above about 20 percent support, the President's coattails now seem long enough to carry forward whichever aide he chooses as the party's candidate. The President is to announce his candidate by January.
 
'It Was a Great Risk'
 "In many years there has been nothing so important for the country as this treaty," said Antonio Aguilar Gomez, 73, a retired hospital worker, as he sat this morning on a bench in the Alameda park in downtown Mexico City. "Salinas has shown great audacity. There were a lot of doubts about the treaty. It was a great risk, but he had a vision that others did not have."
For millions of Mexicans, especially poorer people who have yet to see gain from the economic changes that Mr. Salinas has carried out, the trade accord looms as a shining if vague promise of better jobs, higher wages and more of everything American, from breakfast cereals to banks.
In a neighborhood bar in Mexico City, a 31-year-old electrician, Geraldo Diaz, thought for a moment when asked late Wednesday night about the effects of the agreement, then said, "I think my salary is going to go up about 20 percent, more or less."
He could not explain exactly why that would happen, Mr. Diaz said; he just had a feeling.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Canadian Threat Fades
 TORONTO, Nov. 18 (Special to The New York Times) -- Canadian officials said today that a threat to delay the North American Free Trade Agreement would probably be withdrawn if the United States and Mexico resolved to negotiate codes covering unfair trade.
Part of Canada's unfinished business with the pact is an insistence on greater security against what Ottawa feels are often arbitrary curbs on exports on the ground of unfair pricing.
But because of the time needed to work out new standards in one of the most complex sectors of trade policy, officials here say it is unlikely the trade accord will be delayed.
The newly elected Prime Minister, Jean Chretien of the Liberal Party, said today that he remains convinced of the need for special adjustments covering some trade sectors, specifically a definition of unfair subsidies and the "dumping" of exports at unfairly low prices.
Both President Clinton and Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, have said they want to try to accommodate Canada's concerns.
Roy MacLaren, Minister of International Trade, said he did not see a need for Canada to delay implementation of the North American accord.
"I don't know if we need to approach it in that way," he said in Seattle. "I am quite confident we will be able to reach agreement in the near future on how we might best proceed."
The business community has declared its own firm resistance to any delay in carrying out the accord.

HEADLINE: FRANCE NOW FACES U.S. ON TRADE ISSUE

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 18

 BODY:
The progress of the North American Free Trade Agreement has given an important spur to attempts to conclude a world trade agreement by Dec. 15, but it has also placed Prime Minister Edouard Balladur in a tight corner.
"Last night, President Clinton won half the battle," Peter Sutherland, director general of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, said today, summing up a widespread European feeling that if the accord had failed, global talks known as the Uruguay Round would have had scant chance of approval. "I'm not here to tell you that the Uruguay Round is now in the bag," he said. "It isn't. But it's almost within our grasp." 
 For more than two years, the United States and France have sparred over a GATT accord, divided by issues like agricultural trade and French insistence that the trade forum subsidize its movies and its aircraft. Now Mr. Balladur faces a newly self-confident Mr. Clinton, a 27-day deadline, a restive ally in Germany and a surly domestic constituency ready to pounce if he does not get palpable concessions from Washington.
 
Great Pressure on France
 The pressure on France has never been greater. Setting a buoyant American tone, Secretary of State Warren Christopher declared in Seattle: "This vote sends a message to Geneva on GATT that the United States remains fully committed to opening markets and doing so on the time schedule envisaged by Congress, Dec. 15. There'll be no Dec. 16. That's the message I want to go from here to Europe."
Mr. Christopher mentioned Geneva, where the trade forum has its headquarters, but the message was clearly aimed at Paris. European governments know that an agreement under GATT could be a decisive stimulus for stagnant European economies. But difficulties remain in France.
A combination of recession, soaring unemployment and national disorientation after the cold war have helped turn GATT into a dirty word in France. It has become equated in the popular imagination with jobs lost to cheap labor in places like Singapore, the devastation of the French countryside through lost agricultural exports, and marauding American culture.
Politicians of all stripes, including President Francois Mitterrand, the Gaullist leader Jacques Chirac and Mr. Balladur, have insisted they will not yield on trade issues that they consider essential.
These issues include adjusting the Blair House accord concluded last year between the United States and the European Community calling for a 21 percent cut over six years in the volume of subsidized European grain exports and food; insuring that the French movie industry retains the right to be subsidized and French television the right to limit American programming, and improving access for French services, particularly banking, in the United States.
On all these questions, up to now, the United States has shown little or no inclination to budge.
 
Up to U.S., French Say
 But French officials said today that with gains for the North American accord, Mr. Clinton should have more room for maneuver. "It's now up to Washington to come up with new propositions, which alone will enable the GATT negotiation to be successfully concluded," Industry Minister Gerard Longuet said.
A senior Foreign Ministry official said concessions by the United States would not have to be large because Mr. Balladur, a free trader by instinct, wants to reach an accord. "But," the official said, "Mr. Balladur has to have something to show a skeptical public or the risks to his Government are enormous."

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: Labor;
Unions Vow to Punish Pact's Backers

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
Leaders of the nation's labor unions today swore to get even with the representatives who voted for the North American Free Trade Agreement, and they accused President Clinton of outright political bribery in his deals to win votes for the pact.
But amid the rancor, Mr. Clinton, on his way to Seattle for a Pacific Rim meeting, tried to mend fences, calling Lane Kirkland, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., from Air Force One. 
 No fight, not even its nastiest squabbles in the Reagan-Bush years, has so ignited labor, and no defeat has so stunned it. To stop the agreement, labor mobilized more money, troops and lobbying muscle than on any issue since the 1930's.
For the first time in more than a decade, it built a real political force, one irksome enough for the President to rebuke labor for using "roughshod" and "muscle-bound' tactics against the trade agreement's supporters.
 
Wide-Ranging Alliances
 With their own power base having dwindled with the decline of union membership to less than 16 percent of the work force, unions struck alliances against the trade agreement with Ross Perot, Jesse Jackson, Ralph Nader and the Sierra Club. Frightened for their jobs, rank-and-file members, often indifferent to their leaders' causes, and nonunion workers helped drive the campaign.
"We found our voice in this fight, as did the American public," said Jack Sheinkman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union.
Still, the unions lost. They tried to show a Democratic President that he could not rule without them, and the President called their bluff.
"They threw all their forces into this and made it a defining issue of labor's strength," Ted Van Dyk, a Democratic political consultant, said. "They got themselves painted as rear-guard oppositionists to modernism. They got themselves trapped as negativists."
Today, Mr. Kirkland called a news conference with 11 bristling union presidents flanking him. President Clinton had "stiffed" working people and bribed Congress for votes, Mr. Kirkland said.
 
'Rights of Workers'
 "Amid all the planes, trains and bridges and all the protections for citrus, peanuts, sugar and wheat," Mr. Kirkland said, "there was not one word about the rights of workers on both sides of the border to obtain decent wages and safe working conditions or to defend themselves from gross exploitation."
Several of the union presidents promised retribution against the legislators who supported the agreement.
"We will not forget those Congressmen," said William H. Bywater of the electronics workers union. "And I guarantee in November my union and many other unions that feel as I do, we're going to make sure we get even at the polls." He said later that he, the teamsters union, the operating engineers and other unions would meet to set a strategy for the elections.
 
Labor's Decision
 But most of the votes for the trade pact were cast by Republicans, who rarely count on labor support. And many of the 102 Democrats who voted for it represent rural and Southern districts where unions barely exist. Many other Democrats backing the pact support unions on other issues, so would labor dump them, too?
"Why in the world would labor go after those Democrats whom they need for upcoming votes?" said Robert D. Squier, a political adviser to Democratic candidates. For all the anger they feel now, Mr. Squier said, "there's not a suicidal bone in their body."
President Clinton's spokesman, Mark D. Gearan, said the White House was surprised by the intensity of labor leaders' comments, and a senior Administration official said that "he's already begun making calls" to union officers.
 
A 'Warm Visit'
 Mr. Clinton, on his way to a meeting of the forum on Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, called Mr. Kirkland, pool reporters said, quoting officials accompanying him. Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the President's chief of staff, said the two had a "warm visit." Officials said the President invited Mr. Kirkland to meet with him, probably in early December.
The Center for Responsive Politics, a nonpartisan research organization, found that 78 percent of the House Democrats who voted against the trade pact had received more campaign funds from unions than from business.
How much the vote will alter the politics driving the remainder of the unions' and the President's legislative goals is impossible to discern. Both want to overhaul health care, and the President cannot expect to marshal as many Republican votes for his plan -- 132 -- as he did for the trade agreement.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ticketmaster Near Deal With Potential Partner

BYLINE: By JOSHUA MILLS

 BODY:
The Ticketmaster Corporation, the upstart whose computers dominate the sales of sports and concert tickets, is likely to acquire a major partner shortly: Paul G. Allen, the co-founder of Microsoft who is now a major shareholder in America Online, the computer-based information service.
Ticketmaster sells more than 52 million tickets a year and has annual sales of more than $1.3 billion. The company, based in Los Angeles, is owned largely by the Pritzker family of Chicago, which owns the Hyatt hotel chain. 
 "We may have taken it as far as we can," Jay Pritzker said yesterday in a telephone interview, adding that the likelihood was that his family would add a partner rather than selling outright. There are people outside the family, he said, "who could bring more to the party, with interactivity coming in."
 
Action Expected Soon
 Spokesmen at some of Mr. Allen's companies did not return telephone calls or said he would not comment. But people familiar with the negotiations say the investment is likely to be about $275 million and the deal should be announced before the end of the year, perhaps within days.
What Mr. Allen, who retired a billionaire from Microsoft in 1983 at age 31, has in mind, people in the industry say, is probably some sort of link between Ticketmaster's computerized ticketing and the tens of millions of personal computers that can tap into it through America Online or a similar service.
Last month Ticketmaster, America Online and the Tribune Company, which owns the Chicago Cubs, announced a project that might serve as a model for a national, or even international, system: personal computer owners can link to the system by telephone modems, scan concert and sports schedules, buy tickets to events and order Cubs' merchandise. Mr. Allen, who earlier this year bought a 24.9 percent stake in America Online, already has ties to professional sports; he bought the Portland Trail Blazers basketball team in 1988.
 
Rise to Dominance
 Ticketmaster was founded in the early 1980's in Scottsdale, Ariz., when the computerized ticket business was dominated by Ticketron, which started in 1968.
After Fredric D. Rosen, a New York lawyer, became the chairman of Ticketmaster, it moved to Los Angeles and cashed in on the rock-concert business, which was increasingly dominated by the California-based record companies.
By 1985, Ticketmaster was profitable, while Ticketron, owned by the Control Data Corporation, languished. Ticket managers and concert promoters said Ticketron provided poor serviceand, in contrast to Ticketmaster, did not get involved in marketing the events for which it sold tickets.
The Carlyle Group bought Ticketron in 1989 for $19 million, but the service lost money steadily and was sold to Ticketmaster in 1991 for an undisclosed price.
Today, Ticketmaster has "a tremendous network, many outlets, huge phone rooms," said Joel Fisher, vice president for business and consumer sales at Madison Square Garden, which has done business with Ticketmaster since 1988.
 
An Exclusive Deal
 Ticketmaster's contract with Madison Square Garden is typical of its arrangements with coliseums and arenas. "We made them exclusive seller for all events at the Garden and the Paramount," a theater within the building, Mr. Fisher said. While much of Ticketmaster's business is done over the phone, most box offices including Madison Square Garden's are hooked into Ticketmaster's computers as well.
Ticketmaster pays face value for the tickets, Mr. Fisher said, and makes its money through handling and service fees, a percentage of which are returned to Madison Square Garden. Typically, he said, Ticketmaster handles about 20 percent of the more than three million tickets the Garden sells annually.
The fees can be hefty. Karen Sachs, a spokeswoman for the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs, said a 1992 survey of events handled by Ticketmaster found that fees added an average of 29 percent to ticket prices, based on a phone order for two tickets.
The fees -- from $2.75 to $7.10 a ticket and an additional $1.50 to $2.55 an order -- are not regulated. Rather, Ticketmaster negotiates its fees with the source of the tickets.
"We don't want the service charge to be huge over the face value of our tickets," said Mr. Fisher of Madison Square Garden.
Ticketmaster also makes money by marketing merchandise as ticket orders are phoned in.

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: How Clinton Won;
56 Long Days of Coordinated Persuasion

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
In the last eight weeks, Representative Anna G. Eshoo, a first-term Democrat from California, has been to the White House three times, dined at the Vice President's residence once and held dozens of conversations with members of the Cabinet. As she was leaving for Mexico on a fact-finding mission, President Clinton tracked her down by phone.
Representative Eshoo was on the receiving end of the White House strategy that amounted to a coordinated, computer-generated, all-hands-on-deck plan to pry votes loose for the North American Free Trade Agreement that consumed nearly all of the time of the President and his lieutenants for 56 critical days. 
 If Ms. Eshoo worried aloud about the environmental side effects of the trade pact, Carol M. Browner, the Administrator for the Environmental Protection Agency, or Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt would be dispatched to soothe her fears. If she doubted its economic impact, she would find Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen knocking on the door of her Longworth House Office Building suite.
And when the Administration wanted to close the deal, Mr. Clinton invited her to the Oval Office for a final private round of reassurance.
Representative Eshoo, who said she treated the members of the Cabinet like county department heads in her home district, said she saw nothing unusual in the attention she received and used her high-powered visitors to provide answers to questions she received from constituents in her Silicon Valley district south of San Francisco.
"For me this was not a Washington decision," she said.
 
Elements of Grand Plan
 But at the White House, the last two months have been all about how to win in Washington. Starting out far behind and lacking traditional party support, the Clinton White House won the free trade battle by alienating friends, embracing enemies and working members of Congress with all of the attention and care typically found in a small-town sheriff's race. At stake, White House officials said, was the stature of the President and his ability to win future battles.
For the Administration, every phone call, visit and hometown newspaper editorial was an element of a grand plan. And as the full magnitude of the victory began to make itself clear during the 48 hours leading up to Wednesday night's vote, the Administration officials who worked out a plan to first freeze lawmakers in their tracks and then woo them over to the President's side with sweet reason and sweet deals, exulted in their success.
"It was pretty at the end, but it wasn't very pretty along the way," Stanley Greenberg, the President's pollster, said today.
The path to victory was strewn, in fact, with elements of the lessons learned from the President's other legislative near-death experiences. The intensity came from the budget struggles; the focus came from the fallout over the gays-in-the-military policy and the politics of the head count came from the determination not to hang another supporter out to dry like the White House did when it forced Representative Marjorie Margolies-Mezvinksy, a Pennsylvania Democrat with a precarious hold on her job, to cast the decisive vote for the higher taxes in the budget bill.
The biggest problem all along was what the members of Mr. Clinton's own party would do with the trade accord, which was despised by many traditional Democrats, including union members. Many Democrats had also staked out their opposition last year when President George Bush first presented it. In looking-glass fashion, they knew they would have to rely on Republicans instead of Democrats for the bulk of any victory.
"Most members wanted cover," one White House official said. "They wanted to get labor off their backs. They wanted to get Perot off their backs. They wanted to make it politically possible to support it."
 
President Absent at Start
 But by Labor Day, the President was nowhere to be seen on the issue, and supporters of the accord began to worry when the White House made clear that the President intended to spend as much time as possible on his health care plan rather than on the trade agreement.
"In spring and summer, some of the members thought they could have a free ride on this; an easy no," said Representative Robert T. Matsui, a California Democrat who helped lead the House fight. "There was no countervailing force."
Without the President's personal commitment to the issue, they feared, they would all suffer defeat. These complaints leaked steadily and anonymously into news reports about the trade agreement, and finally snagged the attention of the President and his chief advisers.
Then White House officials were able to corral three former Presidents who came to Washington for the signing of the peace accord between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization to speak in favor of the trade agreement at a formal event in the East Room of the White House.
At the "East Room event," as it is now referred to in reverential terms in the Administration, Mr. Clinton delivered his first wholehearted speech on the agreement with enough verve to send sighs of relief through the ranks of business people and politicians who had seen their cause slipping away.
That was Sept. 22, and the hunt for votes began in earnest. "Our goal from the very beginning was just to hold people," said William Daley, the Chicago businessman who was recruited to run the White House effort on the accord. "Because if they were moving in September and October, they were pretty much moving against us."
The day after the President's speech, House supporters could count only 100 of the Democrats they needed in their column. Sixty-two said they were against it and 152 were undecided.
 
Vote-Chasing Marathon
 The President began an effort that came to include 18 public events, meetings with more than 150 wavering House members in October, selectively timed endorsements, telephoning marathons and the creation of an extensive lobbying system in which names of undecided House members were divided up among Cabinet members and senior officials for persuasion and head-counting.
And during the last week, the White House took to the airwaves to deliver what one official called a "one-two punch" and another called a "circuit breaker." Mr. Clinton chastised labor unions for playing hardball on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" and Mr. Gore bested Ross Perot on CNN's "Larry King Live."
"The dam broke after the debate," Mr. Matsui said.
Part of the reason the atmosphere changed, officials said, was because they had succeeded in changing the terms of the discussion about trade.
Instead of arguing back and forth over job losses and gains, Mr. Gore and Mr. Clinton were able to defuse the opposition and define the battle as one about the international stature of the United States.
"Back in their districts, members went home and suddenly their mail was turning even," said David R. Gergen, the counselor to the President. "It changed the politics of it. It made them more open to Presidential persuasion."
Susan Brophy, the legislative liaison, dreamed up the plan to use Cabinet members as a substitute for the organization that Representative David E. Bonior, a Democratic House leader, took with him when he announced he would oppose the agreement and do all he could to defeat it.
 
'Code Blue' Got Results
 When a likely supporter began to slip away, anyone who caught the first whiff of defection notified the White House and officials there issued what they called a "code blue," a signal that immediate attention was needed. In the beginning, the White House goal was just to stop lawmakers from making up their minds too soon.
Then there was the muscle. The bulk of the strategy came from the seasoned political operatives on the White House staff, Rahm Emanuel, a Chicago native who raised money during the Presidential campaign and once ran the White House political operation, and Mr. Daley, a banker, the son and brother of two Chicago mayors, and Ms. Brophy.
By the time the final debate began on the House floor on Wednesday afternoon, Mr. Emanuel was too nervous to sit still. At one point, his phone rang and Ms. Brophy was on the other end, telling him that Representative Charlie Rose, a North Carolina Democrat who had said he was opposed to the agreement, was changing his mind. Mr. Emanuel whooped.
"When we take one from a 'no' to a 'yes' without stopping at 'undecided,' we call it a three-pointer from the top of the key," he exulted, using the terminology of a man caught up in the last quarter of a basketball game.

She held a staff meeting at her office the day after the House of Representatives passed the agreement. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: Texas;
San Antonio Celebrates New Free Trade World

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN ANTONIO, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Welcome to the new crossroads of North America. Perhaps that is an embellishment of the situation here, one day after the House approved a continental free trade pact that many economists agree would benefit San Antonio more than any other major American city and Texas more than any other state.
But that was the exuberant boast from city officials, who threw a huge festival downtown this afternoon to celebrate the passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement, complete with mariachi bands and ritual shattering of cascarones, Mexican confetti-filled eggs. 
 Nor is it all that much of a stretch to say that at least for now, all roads to Mexico lead through San Antonio, the closest big American city to Mexico City, Monterrey and Guadalajara. About half of the Mexican imports and nearly 70 percent of the United States exports to Mexico pass through San Antonio by train or truck.
 
'We Are Ecstatic'
 If the current $80 billion in trade between the countries doubles by the turn of the century, as one state study projects, many people here have a definite idea about who stands to get a generous piece of an enlarged pie.
"We are ecstatic," said Al Martinez-Fonts, president of the Texas Commerce Bank in San Antonio and chairman of the local Chamber of Commerce. "We're at the center of the action."
Some members of a city delegation that went to Washington to lobby for the pact stayed there, hoping to press San Antonio's case as the site for a new North American Development Bank to be created under the pact.
Elsewhere in Texas, in communities along the state's 1,200-mile Rio Grande River border with Mexico and in big cities like Houston and Dallas, there was considerable enthusiasm as well.
"We are going to be transformed," said Pat Ahumada, the Mayor of Brownsville, a border city near the Gulf of Mexico that is one of the poorest cities in the United States.
Gov. Ann W. Richards of Texas, stepping off a plane on Wednesday night in Houston after a pro-trade-pact lobbying trip to Washington, said the Congressional vote "places Texas at the center of the world's largest trading zone" and would bring tens of thousands of jobs to the state.
 
'A Natural Advantage'
 And also in Houston, Mayor Bob Lanier predicted that passage of the trade agreement would provide a significant benefit for Texas's largest city. "Right now the oil business is flat, NASA is flat, the health business is reasonably flat," he said. "Foreign trade is an area where we have a chance to grow. We have a natural advantage due to proximity, our Hispanic population and our port."
Texas exports to Mexico amounted to $18.9 billion last year, according to the United States Commerce Department, three times the amount of the exports of California, the state with the second-highest volume of trade.
Here in San Antonio, the local Economic Development Foundation, which seeks to lure businesses to the area, wasted no time today in getting on the telephone to executives at 85 companies that are seriously considering putting operations in San Antonio. Many of them had said they would wait to see how the vote would come out before making decisions.
Still, Peggy McCray, a principal officer of McCray Research, a consulting concern based here that monitors trade with Mexico, warned that despite its fortunate geographic position, San Antonio's role as a free trade hub could ultimately be overtaken by larger cities like Houston or Dallas.
With a population of about one million, more than half of Hispanic descent, San Antonio is the country's 10th-largest city, but is still dwarfed by the other two Texas cities.


GRAPHIC: The Senate is tentatively scheduled to vote on the North American Freee Trade Agreement on Saturday. If the bill passes, it will be phased in according to this timetable. All dates are Jan. 1.
 
1994 -- The United States immediately cancels tariffs on 60 percent of Mexican goods now subject to import taxes; other tariffs are phased out over 5 to 15 years.
 
1998 -- United States-Canada Free Trade Agreement, which took effect on Jan. 1, 1989, and which the Nafta expands on, eliminates the reamining tariffs on each country's goods.
 
2000 -- American banks, virtually banned from Mexico now, will be allowed to have taken over 15 percent of the Mexican market by this date. In addition, American trucking companies will be allowed to begin taking majority stakes in Mexican trucking concerns, and truck drivers from both nations will be allowed to haul goods across the border and deliver them anywhere in either country.
 
2003 -- More American tariffs will be eliminated on Mexican goods, bringing to 92 percent the proportion of previously taxed Mexican goods entering the United States duty free.
 
2008 -- Remaining tariffs are eliminated on a handful of goods traded between Mexico and the United States as well as Canada. These goods include the cantaloupes and glassware imported by the United States and corn imported by Mexico.

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: Auto Workers;
Anger, Fear but Also Hope on the Assembly Line

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FLINT, Mich., Nov. 18

 BODY:
As the first shift poured out of the mammoth Buick assembly plant here this afternoon, Bill Ferguson, an Igloo cooler and newspaper in hand, gave his version of the resignation that many auto workers felt about the passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
"That sucking sound was there before Nafta," said the 53-year-year-old Mr. Ferguson, alluding to Ross Perot's prediction during last year's Presidential campaign. "I think our jobs -- they're gone." 
 With the pact making it even easier for companies to move their plants, he said, the agreement was also sure to strengthen management's hand in bargaining with his union, the United Automobile Workers. "It's just another chip to use to hold over our heads," he said.
 
Feeling Let Down
 Workers interviewed in this frayed factory town dominated by several huge General Motors plants said they remained suspicious of the trade agreement and its well-heeled corporate sponsors. Even if it did not hurt, they said, the pact would not help preserve jobs like theirs, which pay about $17 per hour with full benefits. And with President Clinton's complaints about big labor's tactics and his own expensive last-minute arm-twisting, they said, he badly let them down.
But many workers also said that with the agreement apparently headed for ratification in the Senate they hoped it would bring some of the benefits that its backers claimed.
"I voted for President Clinton, but I didn't vote for him to do this," said Ed Millington, who has spent 28 of his 46 years in the plants. Still, "I'm a fair person. I'll see how this works."
 
Some Benefits
 Indeed, some said they were optimistic about the agreement's possibilities for the United States, if not for auto workers. "I think it'll be good for the nation," said Ples McDuffie, polishing off a double cheeseburger in Angelo's restaurant and before going back to making steel slugs for spark plugs.
A bigger trade bloc will make the United States more competitive globally, said Mr. McDuffie, and will also break down suspicions among nations. "You look at Europe and everyone else -- seems like everyone is going with that structure," he said.
But what benefits the country as a whole may not benefit auto-parts workers like himself, said Mr. McDuffie, who was working a 2 A.M.-to-2 P.M. shift to fill in for colleagues who vanished with the start of deer-hunting season. Mr. McDuffie fears that he and his co-workers could lose their jobs. "I'm against it," he said of the pact. "I don't like seeing our jobs shipped out."
In some cases, workers' resignation about the accord seemed to be a product of despair. "I don't know," said Jim Gardella, when asked if jobs would vanish to Mexico. "Are there any left?" Given the drubbing the local economy has taken, he said, he hoped that in the long run the the pact would help promote growth. "I'll wait and see," said Mr. Gardella, who has worked in G.M.'s Buick City complex here for 31 years. In that time, he said, he has seen the work force at the complex shrink from 28,000 to 11,000.
 
A North American Union
 Dave Yettaw, the president of Local 599 here and the leader of a small dissident U.A.W. faction favoring a more aggressive stance toward management, said American labor unions should reach out aggressively to Mexican workers. "We need to have a labor union of North America," capable of calling general strikes, he said. "In the European economic community, that's what they do."
But like many of his union colleagues, Mr. Yettaw said that the first thing that labor needed was a more credible and effective spokesman. "It's a sad state of affairs when Ross Perot stands as the spokesman for organized labor and working people," he said.
Workers who took a longer view of the union's struggles and the American economy said the agreement would not matter much. "I don't think it's a good deal," said Al Federico, 85, a retiree who helped organize the Flint plants in the 1930's, when American auto workers were paid less than what the pact's opponents say Mexican ones are paid now. "But America is too strong, and it will survive this."

HEADLINE: Bright Sun of Trade Rising in the East

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Nov. 18

 BODY:
A prominent European ambassador was at the White House recently for a talk with members of President Clinton's national security team and to raise an unusual protest: the Administration, the ambassador complained, was spending too much time focused on Asia and the Pacific and not enough on Europe.
Officials say the ambassador was told politely that with Asia's emergence in world trade and with North Korea now the most dangerous threat to global stability, Washington was going to focus more of its post-cold-war foreign policy on Asia and the Pacific. 
 Secretary of State Warren Christopher recently declared that "Western Europe is no longer the dominant area of the world" and that Washington has to get over its Eurocentric view of diplomacy. President Clinton's arrival in Seattle today for a summit meeting of the 15-nation forum on Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation is the latest expression of this shift.
 
Consider the Numbers
 Administration officials have said the meeting here serves notice that "in both economic and security terms, Asia has been put on a front burner," in the words of Mr. Clinton's trade representative, Mickey Kantor.
Underpinning this shift are economic, security and generational changes.
The 14 other members of the forum account for 40 percent of all United States trade; the 12 nations in the European Community account for about 35 percent. The United States has an $80 billion trade deficit with the other members of the forum, while it has a surplus with Latin America and is roughly in balance with Europe.
The United States exports $128 billion in goods and services annually to the 14 other forum members, supporting about 5.3 million American jobs, compared with about $102 billion to Europe.
 
Clinton's 'No. 1 Priority'
 "President Clinton has made reviving the domestic economy his No. 1 priority," said Winston Lord, Assistant Secretary of State for Asian Affairs. "Asia and the Pacific are now the most lucrative terrain for American exports and American jobs, and therefore the most relevant region of the world for the President's domestic economic agenda."
James Auer, an Asia expert at Vanderbilt University, said the shift to a foreign policy better balanced between Asia and Europe began under President Ronald Reagan, who was primarily interested in containing Soviet influence in the Pacific.
But, he said, "that trend was halted under the Bush Administration, when there was backsliding toward Eurocentrism" as the Berlin wall came down. Mr. Bush's Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d, spent less than a week in Beijing and Tokyo in four years.
This week, Mr. Clinton will deliver his fourth major speech on Asian policy. He will not deliver his first address on Europe until January, at a NATO summit meeting.
But with the Communist threat having receded, Mr. Clinton is drawn to Asia by a very different notion of national security: promoting free trade and stemming missile proliferation.
 
The Domestic Constituency
 "The Bush generation grew up in the tradition of the Atlantic Community," said Lee Hong Koo, a former South Korean Ambassador to Britain and cabinet minister, "whereas Clinton seems free of the traditions that make it automatic to focus on Europe. I am sure he is not trying to replace Europe, but we believe he wants a more balanced view and feels free to do so."
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said another reason the United States had tended toward Eurocentrism "was because most immigrants in the 19th and 20th centuries came from there."
But in recent decades, there "has been a reorientation of the country away from our European roots," he added. "Our future," Mr. Reich said, "seems to lie more with Latin America and Asia, where more and more of our population is coming from."
Couple these population shifts with the fact that the end of the cold war "has presented an opportunity to rethink some very basic questions about how America should relate to the rest of the world," Mr. Reich said, and the new emphasis is "quite logical."
 
Fear of an 800-Pound Gorilla
 Asian leaders are ambivalent about this new focus: they want the United States to act as a balance between China and Japan but they are sensitive about being dominated by Washington or drawn into security or trading blocs that might harm their commercial relations elsewhere or among themselves.
This makes American leadership in Asia a much more subtle enterprise than with NATO in Europe.
"There is no legacy of communal fellowship in Asia-Pacific," said Mr. Lee, the former Korean envoy. "It is not like the European Community, where you faced a common enemy together. It is much more of a Wild West situation where you have to persuade each country to come along on each issue."
For some, the intensified United States interest in Asia is also a lever they can use against Washington.
"The Chinese, in particular, understand now that the United States needs their market," said Robert D. Hormats, a former Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs.
"Fifteen years ago our entire relationship with China was geo-strategic," he said. "They were a card to play against the Soviets. Now it is geo-economic. They know we need them as a market for exports, not a card to play. That gives them a lot more leverage when we make demands on them about human rights. Clinton will be meeting with a much more self-confident Chinese leadership than any President in the past."

HEADLINE: Japanese Premier Wins Approval of Vote Reform

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Parliament passed landmark electoral reform legislation today, handing Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa his first important victory and pushing the old party system toward a realignment.
The surprisingly strong 270-to-226 margin of victory in the powerful lower house broke a long deadlock on cleaning up Japan's scandal-tainted politics. The outcome also underscored how much the leadership of the world's second largest economy is in the embrace of a whirlwind transition after five years of corruption scandals. 
 Though beaming after the vote as he shook hands with members of his disparate coalition of conservatives and Socialists, Mr. Hosokawa sought to strike a cautious note. The legislative package of four bills still faces a vote in the upper house of Parliament, where the coalition has a solid majority.
"We have a saying that you must not believe you have walked halfway on a 100-mile journey until you reach the 99th mile," he said. "In that respect, we have covered only one-third of the road we have to walk."
Nonetheless, the idea of such legislation's passing -- and with nearly 20 lawmakers crossing party lines -- would have been unthinkable just six months ago. But because the political world has been so thoroughly shaken by the growing list of indicted politicians and rising public anger, the main questions were how much the new parties that assumed power three months ago would be strengthened and how damaged the once dominant Liberal Democratic Party would be.
Indeed, with 13 Liberal Democrats openly defying their leadership and voting in favor of the bills, while 4 abstained, the party that ran the Government for 38 years appeared to be heading toward its second serious split this year.
Several political analysts agreed that even when these bills become law, it is far from certain that the string of bribery scandals will end, so systemic is the graft.
In addition, getting through the struggle for cleaner politics just permits Mr. Hosokawa to focus on other difficult tasks, like stimulating the stalled economy, removing some of the layers of regulations that restrict commerce, reorienting the government bureaucracy toward serving consumers rather than manufacturers and reducing the soaring trade surplus.
Even with that heavy agenda, when Mr. Hosokawa flies to Seattle Friday for a meeting with President Clinton and the heads of government from other Pacific countries, he will be more firmly in control of policymaking than any other Japanese prime minister in years. Because he was seen as serious in his commitment to reform, he received the highest approval ratings of any prime minister in the postwar era -- more than 70 percent -- even before today's vote.
The legislation passed today will completely change the way members of the powerful lower house of Parliament are elected, redraw the election districts, reapportion seats by taking some away from rural districts and giving them to cities, and change the way campaigns are financed.
Corporations will be permitted to make contributions only to parties, not individuals, and the parties will receive public subsidies.
One goal of the legislation is to remove an incentive for graft by transforming the election districts from multi-seat to single-seat.
Under the current system, members of the same party often run against one another. They usually follow the party line on the issues and so do not compete on policies. Instead, the usually seek support through handing out "gifts" of money or by other types of lavish spending, which means they have voracious appetites for cash.
It is hoped that under the single-seat formula politicians will seek to distinguish themselves in terms of policies, a step that would mark radical change for Japan. It is also hoped that the new electoral formula -- under which the lower house will be reduced to 500 seats from 511 -- will in effect create a two-party system. The lower house will consist of 274 members from the new districts and 226 elected on the basis of proportional representation along party lines.

HEADLINE: Where the Mexico Gold Rush Begins

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAREDO, Tex., Nov. 18

 BODY:
From the red-tiled roofs of this fabled American gateway to Mexico to the executive suite of the nation's largest corporations, business began its race today to take advantage of the North American Free Trade Agreement. Some companies here plan to parlay their proximity into expanded markets, while those more distant were talking as if the border had just shifted 1,000 miles or so northward.
Banks, insurers and brokerages will be among the first to exploit new opportunities under the trade agreement, but so will manufacturers like the General Motors Corporation. While many tariff reductions will be phased in over several years, Mexico's virtual ban on foreign financial institutions will be eased on Jan. 1. 
 The American International Group, a diversified insurance company, has been limited to holding a small stake in a modest insurance venture in Mexico. Now it plans to buy a controlling interest, send in marketers and build from there.
It's the sort of virgin market that makes Ned Cloonan, the company's director of international and corporate affairs, swoon. "The average Mexican is consuming about $30 of insurance a year," he said. "In the U.S., about $1,900 a year. About 80 percent of the Mexican population is under 40. They need insurance, and with our global expertise . . ."
Among securities firms, Merrill Lynch & Company is gunning to be the first to open in Mexico after Jan. 1. The firm has six offices in other Latin American nations, but until now has not even been allowed to solicit Mexican corporate business from a hotel room.
Merrill Lynch executives were so anxious about the fate of the agreement that on Wednesday they dispatched employees to Washington armed with cellular phones to feed them news. Jerome P. Kenney, Merrill's chief corporate strategist in New York, woke up relieved. Then he began planning a Mexican debut that could include sales of American stocks and bonds to investors, and of American financial expertise to corporations. From Merrill, Mexican companies will hear about raising money in foreign markets, and American investors will hear about Mexican securities' advantages.
"Once that is set up," Mr. Kenney said, "then you would contemplate the degree to which we become a local firm," selling Mexican investments to Mexicans.
 In Laredo, meanwhile, power breakfasters at La Posada Hotel dealt in English and Spanish over their cellular phones. Although incomes remain far below the national average, they compared their rapidly growing town (population 140,000) with San Antonio, New York and Hong Kong.
"When people from San Antonio, Dallas and New York didn't want to spend three minutes speaking about Mexico, we did," said Gary Jacobs, president of Laredo National Bancshares. Told later that Citicorp, the world's largest issuer of credit cards, planned a plastic blizzard for the previously closed Mexican market, Mr. Jacobs shrugged, opened his wallet and whipped out a Visa card issued by Bancomer, a large Mexican bank.
He jumped up from his breakfast table to clap Jaime Loera, manager of a maquiladora plant across the border, on the shoulder in celebration of the House vote. Mr. Loera's plant, where Rheem Manufacturing produces water heaters for the United States, will now have greater latitude to sell its heaters in Mexico.
And Mr. Jacobs is set to finance such activities. "More business? Yes," Mr. Jacobs said. "Especially trade-related." Maquiladora plants, largely owned by American corporations, have to ship most of their goods back to the United States under current trade rules.
For more than a century, Laredo has been a railroad gateway to Mexico. Now, half of all freight shipments from the United States to Mexico chug across bridges that span the Rio Grande here. From his bank office, Mr. Jacobs pointed to a string of manufacturing plants on the south bank of the river, and to a string of warehouses on the north.
 With the trade accord's future in doubt, some plans were on hold here before the vote. Dennis Nixon, president of the International Bank of Commerce in Laredo, said he had grown more cautious about approving loans, "in case it didn't pass."
The sprawling Mall Del Norte here, drawing shoppers from Monterrey and even Mexico City, had planned to expand -- Nafta or no -- but some retailers fear the loss of business to American stores that will open in Mexico. Laredo has the nation's largest Wal-Mart store that doesn't sell groceries, but Mexico City's new Wal-Mart is larger.
Luis Lidsky, whose chain of 36 department stores spans the Texas border, now plans to close several. "With everybody going into Mexico, our business is going to shrink," he said, in an office above his El Mundo store in downtown Laredo. "Retailing on the border is in for a major, major transformation."
Mr. Lidsky doubts that Mexican shoppers will continue to believe that goods north of the border are better than the same goods back home. "That will certainly change," he said. "Because more and more of the products that we're buying here say 'Made in Mexico.' "
 The many American manufacturers that campaigned for the agreement remain eager to dramatize domestic, but not foreign, job gains. Gary Tapella, Rheem's chief executive, said he would serve the Mexican market as much from his plant in Montgomery, Ala., as from his Mexican factory.
General Motors has two Mexican assembly plants that already supply the Mexican market and 51 maquiladora plants. But Mexico has been virtually closed to cars not made there, and the two G.M. plants could not justify the expense of the tooling to make Cadillacs and Oldsmobiles.
As of today, General Motors planned to step up American production of these nameplates, as well as of the Oldsmobile Silhouette mini-van, through November and December. "We want to be ready to start shipping across the border on Jan. 1," said Mustafa Mohatarem, G.M.'s director of economics. "There's pent-up demand."
He was happy to point to the benefits for plants in North Tarrytown, N.Y., and Detroit, but not to provide figures on increased output or job gains. "That we can't talk about," he said, protecting his claim in the Mexican Klondike. "That has competitive significance."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Luis Lidsky, whose department stores span the Texas border from Brownsville to El Paso, now plans to close several. "With everybody going into Mexico, our business is going to shrink," he said at his El Mundo store in Laredo. "Retailing on the border is in for a major, major transformation." (J. Michael Short for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Salvagers Receive 90% of Treasure; Insurers, 10%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 18

 BODY:
Salvagers of a ship that sank in 1857 with three tons of gold aboard were awarded 90 percent of the treasure by a Federal judge today, with only 10 percent going to a group of insurance companies that claimed ownership.
Earlier estimates had put the value of the treasure at $1 billion, but the judge, Richard B. Kellam of Federal District Court, said it was worth far less. 
 The Columbus-America Discovery Group, an Ohio investment syndicate, has spent $30 million on the salvage effort so far and has recovered more than a ton of gold. But Judge Kellam said the recovered gold was worth only about $21 million.
The steamship Central America sank 136 years ago in a hurricane off the South Carolina coast. Of the paddlewheel steamer's 578 passengers, 153 survived.
Many of the passengers were California prospectors traveling to New York with gold to head off a banking crisis. Shortly after the vessel sank, the insurance companies paid off at least $1.2 million in claims for the lost gold.
In 1987, Columbus-America found the muddy wreck 8,000 feet under water. It has been using a remote-controlled robot to salvage the ship and has recovered a 62-pound gold brick and thousands of $20 Double Eagle gold pieces.
Columbus-America said the wreck was abandoned and claimed ownership. But the insurers of the voyage and their corporate heirs said they still owned the gold. The insurance companies in the case are the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company, based in New York City; the Insurance Company of North America, based in Philadelphia; Lloyd's of London, and five other British companies. The Superintendent of Insurance of New York represents eight defunct companies.
 
'Finders, Keepers' Rule
 In 1990, Judge Kellam awarded the entire treasure to Columbus-America under an ancient "finders, keepers" rule in maritime law. But the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, sent the case back to Judge Kellam to reconsider the insurance claims.
The judge, in his latest 80-page ruling, said he took into account the millions already spent by the salvage group.
He ordered both sides to come up with a sale plan and said the court would impose its own plan if no agreement was reached within 30 days.

HEADLINE: Call for a New Study Derails a Plan to Build Luxury Homes on Robins Island

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 18

 BODY:
A plan to let a developer buy Robins Island, a 445-acre uninhabited island in Peconic Bay, and build 22 luxury homes there has apparently collapsed, giving new hope to groups that want Suffolk County to buy the island and turn it into a nature preserve.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has already offered to finance half the cost of a county purchase, but County Executive Robert J. Gaffney has insisted that the state finance the entire deal. 
 The plan for private development was on the verge of approval but began to unravel on Wednesday when the Suffolk County Council on Environmental Review, an advisory panel to the County Legislature, ruled that an environmental study was required before the purchase could proceed.
The study could take up to two years and would make it impossible to meet a February deadline to complete the deal. The deadline was agreed to by the county; the seller, the Southold Development Corporation; and the developer, the Robis Corporation.
 
Impossible Deadline
 While the Legislature could overrule the council, a lawyer for Southold Development said the council's decision made it unlikely that the plan would survive.
"I don't see how the settlement can be concluded within the necessary period, and extending it is not a possibility," said the lawyer, Albert A. D'Agostino. "Even if the County Legislature doesn't go along with the council, there will be legal objections."
In 1989, the county agreed to buy the island for $9.2 million. But soon after, Southold Development filed for bankruptcy and sought court approval to sell instead to Robis for $12.2 million.
Mr. Gaffney and a majority of the 18-member Legislature had backed the plan for the county to abandon efforts to buy the island and allow Robis to buy it instead.
Robis would then have sought permission from the Town of Southold, where Robins Island is, to build the 22 homes on five-acre lots near the shoreline of the wooded isle. With its spectacular views and splendid isolation, the island has been promoted as the jewel of the Peconic. Proponents of the county purchase have called it Long Island's Yosemite.
 
A Change in Policy
 Under the plan, about 90 percent of the island would have been placed under a conservation easement to guard it from development.
But the environmental council said the proposal represented a change in policy and would thus trigger a requirement in the State Environmental Quality Review Act for a detailed study.
Paul Sabatino, the counsel to the County Legislature, said a vote on the plan would probably occur at a legislative meeting on Dec. 21. He said the plan would need the legislators' approval by then to meet the February deadline.
Mr. Sabatino said the Legislature had overruled the council in the past. But a Legislator who favors the county purchase, Nora Bredes, a Democrat from Stony Brook, said rejection of the council's recommendation would almost certainly be challenged in court by an environmental group.
"It would be very foolish to ignore the council," she said. "It would only guarantee further litigation."
In September, a task force created by Governor Cuomo to study the economic and environmental needs of eastern Long Island asked Mr. Cuomo to help the county buy the island. Mr. Cuomo announced several days later that the state would provide half the $9.2 million purchase price.
But in a letter dated Nov. 8, Mr. Gaffney told Mr. Cuomo the state would have to "commit no less than $9.2 million" toward purchase of the island by Dec. 14.
 
'A Gift Horse'
 Mr. Gaffney has argued that the plan to sell to Robis assures preservation of nearly all of the island at no cost to the county, and would also allow county residents to visit the part of the island within the conservation easement.
The chairman of Mr. Cuomo's task force, Thomas A. Twomey Jr., said Mr. Gaffney's rejection of Mr. Cuomo's offer for the state to pay half the purchase price was "a perfect example of looking a gift horse in the mouth."
Mr. Gaffney's proposal "would create a private, exclusive compound for a very few rich and famous individuals," Mr. Twomey said. He said that promises of public access were untrue because visits would be strictly limited and require approval of the island's property owners.

HEADLINE: A Poll Shows Cuomo Rating Sliding Lower

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 18

 BODY:
As he nears a decision about running for a fourth term, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's approval ratings continue to slide, according to an independent statewide poll released today. But the poll shows the Governor with a comfortable lead over the little-known Republicans who may challenge him in 1994.
Only 34 percent of the registered voters questioned by the Marist Institute for Public Opinion said they considered Mr. Cuomo's performance in office either excellent or good. That approval rating is the lowest registered by Marist in Mr. Cuomo's 11 years in office and is 6 percentage points lower than in the last Marist poll, taken in May.
 
Half Say No 4th Term
 Half of those surveyed said they did not want Mr. Cuomo to run for another four-year term, while 40 percent said he should seek re-election. Fifty-nine percent said they thought New York was going in the wrong direction, compared with 26 percent who approved of the state's direction. 
 The poll of 730 registered voters was conducted on Nov. 15-16 and has a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.
The Marist numbers are comparable to the results of a poll released nine days ago by the John Zogby Group of New Hartford, near Utica. It showed Mr. Cuomo with a 38 percent favorable rating among likely voters. Fifty-six percent said the Governor should not run.
Mr. Cuomo has said he will announce his decision by Jan. 1. A dozen Republicans, none with significant name recognition, are seeking support for the nomination.
In the Marist poll, none of four Republicans received more than 27 percent in a head-to-head contest against Mr. Cuomo.
Bill Green, a former Representative from Manhattan, received 27 percent to Mr. Cuomo's 46 percent; Herbert London, a former Conservative Party gubernatorial nominee, 26 percent to Mr. Cuomo's 48 percent; State Senator George E. Pataki of Peekskill, 24 percent to Mr. Cuomo's 48 percent; and Richard M. Rosenbaum, a former Republican state chairman, 25 percent to Mr. Cuomo's 48 percent.
The poll also showed that 57 percent thought Mr. Cuomo has "generally been a good governor" since taking office in 1983, while 35 percent thought he has not been.
Those figures tend to validate Mr. Cuomo's argument that recent polls reflect a frustration with the state's drowsy economy and its epidemic of crime. But elections, he says, are contests between individuals, not referendums on the incumbent.

HEADLINE: Stocks Continue Their Broad Fall

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
For the second day, stocks continued their across-the-board retreat, as a slumping bond market and rising fears of inflation led to an investor selloff in equities.
Traders said investors were using the approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement on Wednesday as a reason for cashing in on the run up in stocks before the vote. 
 Others said a weak bond market and movement out of groups including telecommunications equipment stocks were also weighing on the market.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 19.01 points, to 3,685.34, as volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy at 313.5 million shares, a little off the pace of Wednesday's 319.6 million shares. Decliners held a wide lead over gainers, 1,276 to 795.
Chevron a component stock in the Dow, fell by 4 points, to 89, and accounted for 8.94 points of the index's decline, according to Birinyi Associates. The stock fell after the sale of more than 8.1 million common shares of Chevron common held by Pennzoil, which rose 5/8, to 58 1/8. The big block trade totaled more than $731 million.
 
Other Large Block Trades
 Other large block trades included two multimillion-share blocks of FPL Group Inc. Investors tried to capture a regular quarterly dividend payout of 62 cents a share, with today being the last day investors can buy the stock and receive the dividend. About 18.7 million shares changed hands as the day's most actively traded stock slipped 3/8 to close at 37 1/8.
An early-morning rally was expected following the passage of the free trade agreement, but it did not materialize. The market instead was placed on the defensive by a sharp drop in Treasury bonds, which may have been reacting to a larger-than-expected drop in United States jobless claims.
Abraham J. Bronchtein, director of research for the Portfolio Group Inc., the investment subsidiary of Chemical Bank, said yesterday was probably an acceleration of fears rooted in the strengthening of the economy and its impact on interest rates.
"People are have been worrying about rates for several weeks and I think anybody watching the market has seen a lot of profit taking in all the winning groups," Mr. Bronchtein said. "It started in the financials, I think it's now spreading into all other high tech and telecommunication stocks that got pumped up because of the Bell Atlantic and Tele-Communications deal." Shares of telecommunications equipment makers dropped yesteray after two major companies failed to beat analysts' earnings estimates. American depository receipts of L.M. Ericsson Telephone fell 7 7/8, to 42 5/8, as Newbridge Networks fell 3 1/2, to 54 1/2. The fall in the two companies' shares helped drag down the shares of Motorola, which closed at 95 5/8, down 4 1/8.
Analysts at MMS International note the market remains concerned by the breakdown in the broader market, as the Nasdaq composite picked up where it left off on Wednesday. As the composite slipped below the 760 level, traders braced themselves for a retest of the 750-748 critical bottom support area. The Nasdaq composite closed down 8.02 points, to 754.34.
"I think the things that are making investors worry about interest rates should ultimately lead to better corporate profits," Mr. Bronchtein of Portfolio Group said. There is a gap between converting an improving economy into profits for a large number of companies. And until you get the higher earnings to support current market prices we'll continue to get this volatility."
Elsewhere, American Barrick fell 1 5/8, to 27 5/8, after the Horsham Corporation, its controling shareholder, announced a $550 million sale of convertible debt into Barrick stock.
As American Airlines flight attendants went out on strike, some investors headed for their brokers. The stock was down 7/8, to 69.
The Cholestech Corporation gained 1 7/8 to close at 27 5/8 after Kemper Securities upgraded its rating to a "strong buy" from a long-term buy. The company makes medical-diagnostic systems that measure blood cholesterol. It received clearance from the Food and Drug Administration to market two new diagnostic test panels.
