HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Notes and Bonds in Fall

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Good economic news is continuing to be bad news for the bond market.
More reports yesterday showing that the economy is picking up pace helped send the prices of Treasury notes and bonds down across the board while yields, which move in the opposite direction, rose. The yield on the 30-year bond jumped to 6.24 percent, its highest close since Aug. 18. 
 The Clinton Administration victory on the North American Free Trade Agreement seemed to provide no boost for the market, as the old adage of buy on the rumor and sell on the fact took hold once again. What lift there was for the market had come earlier in the week when it became evident that the House of Representatives would approve the treaty linking the markets of the United States, Canada and Mexico.
The two reports yesterday that added to the picture of a stronger economy were minor by typical market standards, but when added to the recent data showing increases in auto sales, retail sales, housing starts and industrial production, they may have provided traders with a reason to sell.
One report showed that initial jobless claims had dropped by 20,000 in the week ending Nov. 13. The other report was the second consecutive sharp jump in the manufacturing index of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia. Its index in November rose to 22.4 from 15.1.
"The economic statistics continue to show a pattern of increasing growth," said Skip Shaw, who becomes president of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company at the beginning of next year. "Our belief is that we have seen the low in rates and that we will now trade higher" in an irregular pattern.
Also weighing on the market yesterday were continued rumors that the Treasury might issue new 30-year bonds in an effort to ease the shortage of the bond in the market, which could be distorting market prices. The Treasury had no comment. But more and more market analysts are suggesting that the conditions for such a move exist.
 
Treasury Partly Responsible
 The Treasury itself has been partly responsible for the problem because it decided last May to reduce the annual sale of 30-year bonds by about 40 percent and to shift to two auctions instead of four auctions a year.
In late trading in the secondary market, the price of the 6.25 percent 30-year bond was down 29/32 as the yield moved to 6.24 percent, from 6.18 percent Wednesday. The price of the two-year note dropped 5/32 as its yield jumped to 4.13 percent from 4.06 percent the day before.
The leap in short-term interest rates appears to be in response to fears that the stronger growth in the economy will make the Federal Reserve worry more about inflation and, in turn, raise its target for the short-term interest rate, which has been 3 percent for more than a year.
While the victory on the North American Free Trade Agreement did not give a boost to the United States bond market, it did seem to help in Mexico. According to Robert J. O'Donnell, a managing director at Stires, O'Donnell & Company, the yield on six-month Mexican paper dropped about half a percentage point, to 12.25 percent. The Mexican peso also got a boost, jumping more than 2 percent in value against the American dollar.
The victory for the trade accord also helped Mexico with the credit-rating agencies. The Standard & Poor's Corporation said that it was changing its outlook on Mexico from stable to positive.
Referring to the approval of the trade accord, S.& P. said, "The agreement should boost economic growth over the medium term, trigger new overseas equity inflows, and reduce reliance on external borrowing to finance Mexico's subtantial current account deficit - estimated by S.& P. at $22 billion," or 6 percent of the country's gross domestic product in 1993.
The S.& P. rating for Mexico is BB+, which is below investment grade. Duff & Phelps, which raised its rating of Mexico to an investment grade triple-B in May, said that "Mexico's strong fundamental policies will be strengthened by Nafta's passage."

HEADLINE: O.E.C.D. Says Fed May Raise Rates

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development predicted today that the Federal Reserve would soon push up short-term interest rates because of concerns that the inflation rate had stopped falling.
The Paris-based organization, which promotes economic cooperation among its 24 member nations, said in a new study that "there is good reason to expect inflation to remain below 3 percent," but added that with short-term rates so low, unemployment edging down and factory utilization rising, monetary tightening could be justified to head off a resurgence of inflation. 
 In its annual grading of America's economic performance, the organization -- which normally takes a tough stance on inflation -- added that "tightening could also be justified if" inflationary "expectations need a jolt and the Federal Reserve's credibility is endangered."
 
'Real' Rates: Zero Percent
 Peter Jarrett, the economist who wrote the study, said in an interview that if the Fed decided to raise short-term rates, that should not in turn push up long-term interest rates, because the Fed would be showing its determination to keep inflation low.
The O.E.C.D. expressed concern that "real" short-term rates -- nominal rates minus the inflation rate -- were zero percent. Mr. Jarrett said rates at that level were highly stimulative and could reignite inflation.
Fed officials declined today to respond to the report.
In what was probably the most pointed section of its report, the organization criticized the Clinton Administration's efforts to pressure Japan to open its markets and agree to specific targets for reducing its trade surplus and increasing imports. The report said this approach ran the risk of creating managed trade, and might result in the "cartelization" of Japanese markets.
It also questioned the usefulness of Washington's pressure campaign, saying that even if the Clinton Administration succeeded in persuading Japan to reduce trade barriers, this was unlikely to do much to reduce the American trade deficit with Japan.
Mr. Jarrett said the Clinton Administration challenged this part of the report more than any other. The Administration has repeatedly argued that efforts to press Japan to import more promotes freer trade, rather than managed trade.
 
Sees More Growth
 Each year the O.E.C.D.'s secretariat issues a report that assesses the economic policies and problems of each member nation.
The study forecast a slight rise in American economic growth to a moderate 3 percent next year, with an increase in the trade deficit and another moderate drop in the unemployment rate, currently 6.8 percent.
"While this may appear to some as a disappointing picture, it is actually rather satisfactory," the report said. The organization was less sanguine about long-term growth prospects, saying the nation's potential growth rate was a lackluster 2.3 percent.
In another piece of bad news, the report said that because of slow productivity growth, the United States would lose its worldwide lead in productivity per worker within a decade.
 Probably the biggest long-term problem for the American economy, the O.E.C.D. said, is inadequate savings. This holds back the nation's ability to increase educational skills and expand plants and equipment, in turn inhibiting productivity growth.
After years of criticizing the United States for not tackling its budget deficit, the organization praised President Clinton's deficit-reduction efforts, but suggested that a new round of cuts might be required by 1998.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Fall in Week

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing first-time claims for jobless benefits fell by 20,000 last week, erasing the previous week's jump that had lifted claims to a 15-week high, the Government said today.
The Labor Department said new applications for unemployment insurance totaled 338,000, down from a revised 358,000 during the week that ended on Nov. 6. It was the largest decline since claims fell by 56,000 during the week that ended on July 31.
Last week included the Veterans Day holiday. Claims often fall during a holiday week because of the fewer number of days in which to file claims. 
 The Nov. 6 figure, originally estimated to be 354,000, was the highest since 395,000 claims were filed during the week that ended on July 24.
The less-volatile four-week moving average of jobless claims, which analysts prefer to track because it smooths out the weekly spikes, also fell. The average totaled 345,500, down from 348,750 during the period that ended on Nov. 6.
The report also said 5,116 applications were filed under a Federal emergency unemployment program during the week that ended on Nov. 6, up from 4,747 during the previous week.
That number reflected people still eligible to file under the emergency program before it expired on Oct. 2. The House and Senate have approved differing versions of legislation to extend the program, and those differences must be reconciled before final passage. President Clinton supports an extension.
States reporting the biggest increases in claims last week were California, Ohio and Pennsylvania; Texas led states with declines.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises, With Victory For Trade Accord a Factor

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar strengthened slightly yesterday, partly in reaction to House approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Traders said the dollar was also bolstered by positive economic signals in the United States and expectations of lower interest rates in Europe. 
 In late New York trading, the dollar jumped to 1.7125 German marks, from 1.7035 marks on Wednesday. The dollar also rose to 107.35 Japanese yen from 106.85 yen.
Gold prices were lower in the United States after rising in Europe. Gold for December delivery fell 50 cents, to $376.70 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
 
 
 
European Rate Cuts Expected
 Widespread expectations for another round of interest rate cuts in big European countries, including Germany and France, helped to buoy the dollar, analysts said.
"European interest rates are slated to come down against a background of strong economic data in the United States," said Benoit Jadoul, vice president for foreign exchange at Chase Manhattan Bank. He cited a decision by Belgium's central bank to cut interest rates sharply on Wednesday, along with a new Government austerity program.
The German Bundesbank is expected to reduce rates before the end of the year, said Curtis Perkins, a trader at Chemical Bank. The Bundesbank hinted at an easier monetary policy when its rate on repurchase agreements, a tool of short-term monetary policy, came in lower than expected on Thursday, he said.
Also aiding the dollar was new evidence of American economic growth. The Philadelphia Federal Reserve issued its November business outlook survey, a closely watched measure of East Coast manufacturing activity, which said manufacturing continued to improve. The Labor Department also reported that the number of newly laid-off workers filing claims for jobless benefits fell last week by 20,000, the biggest drop in nearly four months. Both reports supported the dollar.
Mr. Perkins said another factor helping the dollar was the decisive House vote Wednesday night to pass the North American Free Trade Agreement. The Clinton Administration said the pact, which liberalizes trade among the United States, Canada and Mexico, will help the United States become more competitive overseas.
The British pound, meanwhile, slipped to $1.4760 in New York trading, from $1.4805 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: After the Nafta Victory

 BODY:
A neophyte watching the House vote on the North American Free Trade Agreement could be excused for thinking President Clinton was the leader of the Republican Party, supported by a minority of the Democratic Party. But however odd the coalition -- 132 Republicans and only 102 Democrats -- Mr. Clinton won a small economic and huge political victory in pushing Nafta through the House.
Nafta will open Mexico's borders to more U.S. exports and investment, a worthwhile achievement. More important, the Nafta win empowers Mr. Clinton to complete the more important Uruguay Round of international trade talks. And the vote tells Congress that the White House knows how to play tough, which should make health care and welfare reform a bit easier to achieve. 
 Critics accuse Mr. Clinton of buying the Nafta vote at taxpayer expense. But he bought victory remarkably cheaply. For all the wheeling and dealing, Mr. Clinton did not -- based on what's been made public -- gut Nafta, undermine the Uruguay Round or saddle future taxpayers with a big bill.
For example, he promised wheat and peanut growers that he would investigate Canadian export policy; but this poses little danger to consumers or Canada because any action the U.S. might take could be appealed to an impartial panel. He promised vegetable and citrus growers that he would limit tariff cuts on their products under the Uruguay Round; but he can do that without violating the draft agreement under negotiation. And, the President did not, as environmentalists feared, ease restrictions on pesticides.
With Nafta won, President Clinton can now move on to the Uruguay Round, which must be negotiated by Dec. 15 to meet a Congressional deadline. Under the draft accord, tariffs and other trade barriers on food, services, foreign investment and copyright materials would come tumbling down -- each of which would help the U.S. economy.
The agreement promises to add hundreds of billions of dollars to the world economy. But finalizing the deal won't be easy. Mr. Clinton will have to overcome opposition from the domestic textile industry and the French Government, which threatens to undermine the entire agreement for the sake of a handful of farmers.
Next, Mr. Clinton has to make good on his promise to send Congress a bill early next year that would provide dislocated workers substantial training and education. With or without Nafta, millions of Americans will lose long-held jobs because of transformations within the U.S. economy. The compassionate answer is to provide opportunities to acquire new skills.
President Clinton has set out the right vision: an America that opens its borders to foreign goods in return for similar access abroad; an America that provides ample resources to train its workers so they achieve high productivity and, therefore, high wages. Nafta is only the first step.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Defining Bill Clinton

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Billions to buy Congressional votes and a fist in the face to American labor -- after less than a year in office, that is what Clinton idealism came down to in the Nafta debate.
Now the President is in Seattle to face a different problem of political morality: the human right of Chinese men and women to live, work and talk without fear of years in torture cells -- to fight for it or not. 
 The President can use the new strength he claims from his Nafta victory, one of two ways. He can push Beijing toward human decency for Chinese who do not bow their minds to Communism, and for the people of Tibet, captive and brutalized for almost a half-century.
Or he can do what appeals now to some politicians and journalists who once talked big about human rights in China -- give the issue a little pious attention but quickly get down to political and business deals. All right, maybe that will help the Communists and their army. But hey, it is a big-boys world and maybe the deals will help some American businesses with the bottom line.
At least show time in Seattle will not be as expensive for the taxpayer as voting time in Washington.
On both sides of Nafta were honest opinions in the House of Representatives. One was that Nafta would open a new era of open trade. The other was that the treaty as written would be like a small cat with tiger fangs -- -- interesting but nothing to have around the house.
Opponents saw Nafta as a perpetuation of Mexican conditions that no American worker could or should compete with -- child labor, peon wages, government union-busting.
Afraid to leave the decision to a clean ballot, the Administration bought votes with tariff breaks and other goodies: for members from citrusland, for sugar, for peanuts, bed frames, wine, wheat, manhole covers.
The money comes from the taxpayer. As for the bill -- who will ever add it up? The White House?
As bad as bribes was the campaign of distortion about the beliefs and emotions of American workers. They were not fighting against free trade, as the Nafta lobbyists said, but against a perversion of free trade that could send hundreds of thousands of them into the humiliating wasteland of unemployment -- them, not some other person.
Lane Kirkland, A.F.L.-C.I.O. president, says he asked the Administration, Mr. Clinton included, to insist on strict enforcement against built-in Mexican competition-killers. He said he wanted no more than the enforcement Nafta gives against violations of intellectual property -- patents, royalties and so on.
The Administration said yes, according to Mr. Kirkland. Only when it failed to come through, he says, did labor go into the field against Nafta.
Mr. Clinton's "victory" forced into opposition millions of working people who had voted for him. They (and I) would have supported Nafta, if they had been given the safeguards granted to Americans who produce "intellectual property."
Vice President Gore gave an overdue thrashing to Ross Perot. But the Administration's contempt for labor's opinions allows Mr. Perot to prance about as labor's savior -- early Christmas for that peculiar man.
If this political spectacle, this open government vote-buying and bone-breaking, had taken place in Japan, say, or India or Italy, American correspondents in those countries would have filed astonished stories about the strange ways of the natives.
But when it happened in Washington, American journalism, by and large, positively glowed with admiration. Man, see how tough Bill Clinton is, how at last he knows how to bait with money, like other Presidents.
American correspondents abroad get rotated every few years so they don't start to think widow-burning is normal, even admirable -- or vote-buying with public money.
President Clinton said Nafta was the "defining" moment for America. I doubt that, but after the moral debacle of the Nafta debate, Seattle certainly will help "define" the Clinton Administration. Is it recasting itself in the Bushbaker mold -- tough guy, power pol, cash register uber alles? Or does the Administration remember the title of that Clinton-Gore campaign book, "Putting People First"?
Chinese dissidents, Tibetan captives, Mexican children forced to labor, American union members, you could say they are all people.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Now, Be the President

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

 BODY:
The last week may have been the turning point for a flagging Presidency. It can be if Bill Clinton acts on the lessons of his two triumphs in that week.
The Nafta vote in the House was the second. President Clinton showed that he could work the political system to overcome the odds and win a tough one: win big. He trounced the strange collection of Yesterday's Men who thought they had him beat: Ross Perot, Lane Kirkland, Pat Buchanan, Ralph Nader et al. 
 Mr. Clinton's first triumph was a speech last Saturday at the Church of God in Christ, in Memphis. What he did there was in its way as surprising as the winning effort on Nafta.
From the pulpit where Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. spoke the night before he was assassinated in 1968, Mr. Clinton gave passionate voice to Americans' concerns about crime. He imagined what Dr. King would say if he could see his community today:
"I did not live and die to see the American family destroyed. . . . I fought to stop white people being so filled with hate that they would wreak violence on black people. I did not fight for the right of black people to murder other black people . . . ."
In Memphis Mr. Clinton broke out of the pattern of political speeches, of the expected and the calculated. He spoke as if from inside himself, responding in emotional terms to the appalling reality in this country today.
The response he got shows that one thing Americans want a President to do is to speak out about wrongs: not always to have a 10-point plan, a graph, but to speak. No one person can solve our problem of social decay, but the President can make us face it. That is Teddy Roosevelt's bully pulpit.
The Nafta saga has another lesson. To be effective, a President must focus on objectives crucial to him and the country. And then he must be resolute in pursuit of those objectives.
Mr. Clinton was slow to focus on Nafta. While he delayed, opponents got commitments from a lot of House Democrats who could have been won for the treaty. The opposition got so far ahead that many expected the President to back away from Nafta. Instead he went all-out and won.
Too often before now Mr. Clinton has backed away from declared positions. There was a widespread belief in Washington that if you made something difficult for him, he would cave. In politics that perception is disabling. Mr. Clinton will have dispelled it if he follows up his Nafta performance with resolve on other issues.
Not just Congress but the world is ready for resolute American Presidential leadership. Many issues await it:
GATT. Only a few weeks remain to conclude the Uruguay Round of world trade negotiations, far more important economically than Nafta. The negotiations will not succeed without a real push from the President.
Haiti. Mr. Clinton has allowed America to be pushed around by a few hundred goons. Does he mean it when he says he is committed to dislodging the coup leaders? If so, it is time to take more determined action, not excluding the use of military force.
It is past time to stop the C.I.A from undermining his Haitian policy. The agency has been pushing vicious descriptions of President Aristide based on interviews with the very men who overthrew him. Who does the C.I.A. think is the President, Bill Clinton or Jesse Helms?
Bosnia. Without going back over the question of stopping Serbian aggression, Mr. Clinton can do much to prevent the tragedy from becoming worse. Indeed, he may be the only person who can prevent human disaster from occurring in Bosnia this winter on a massive scale.
The first snow has fallen in Sarajevo. Supplies of food are inadequate, and the Serbs have again cut the flow of natural gas. They continue to block relief shipments, and they are shelling other Muslim enclaves that are supposedly safe havens.
Mr. Clinton can at least speak out about the need to get relief through, focusing the world's attention on the problem. He can launch an airlift to Sarajevo and Gorazde Airports -- parachute drops are inadequate, especially in winter. He can warn Serbia to stop blocking the gas supply or see its own cut off.
Mr. Clinton, in short, should be the President. He knows how.

HEADLINE: A Risky Victory

BYLINE: By Ted Van Dyk; Ted Van Dyk is a Democratic strategist and trade policy analyst.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The House's passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement was no triumph for enlightenment.
Nafta is likely to create modest economic growth in Mexico, the United States and Canada, even while creating near-term dislocations. But the victory could induce the Administration to make misjudgments that could sink the far more important global negotiations in the 116-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which face a Dec. 15 deadline for completion. 
 Nafta's most important immediate effect will be to rescue Presidents Clinton and Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico from personal political setbacks.
The idea of a free trade zone had been around for 40 years before George Bush's espousal of it midway through his term. He supported it not out of any measured political and economic assessment but for the same reason he had chosen Dan Quayle as his running mate: he wanted to reward and encourage a young man to whom he had taken a liking.
The young man was Mr. Salinas. Trying to modernize and open the corrupt, protected and state-dominated Mexican economy (and deflect charges that his Presidential election had been stolen), Mr. Salinas wanted Nafta as his centerpiece initiative.
Nafta had not been pursued earlier by the U.S., Mexico and Canada for valid and substantive reasons. First, Mexico was far less advanced and economically open than the other two. If this were the 1960's, Nafta would be akin to an embryonic European Community of Germany, France and Spain; Spain would need years of economic, financial, political and social adjustment to truly fit with the others.
Second, as a regional bloc Nafta will be at odds with the international trade and investment system represented in GATT. Countries not in Nafta will be on the outside looking in, and will face discrimination against their products. Caribbean chiefs of state already have protested.
By suggesting that Nafta should be expanded gradually southward into Latin America -- and implying that the U.S. should consider joining a new Pacific bloc -- Mr. Clinton, perhaps unknowingly, has undermined the global regime of economic and financial liberalization that has served the postwar world so well. Faced with Nafta and the European Community, Japan is considering forming a new regional group with itself at the center. Other countries are also looking for a regional club to join.
The White House portrayed Nafta as a way to gain an edge on Western Europe and Japan, both beset by economic stagnation. This was the wrong reason to argue for completion of a North American deal. Western Europe and Japan, our principal security and economic partners, are in trouble; their cooperation is indispensable for global progress. They are not mere commercial rivals.
Mr. Salinas and his Institutional Revolutionary Party will now face slightly less pressure to conduct genuinely honest elections next year. His economic liberalization will doubtless continue, and Mexico probably will not revert to hyper-nationalist policies. But the cost will be high: one-party, oligarchic domination for yet another six years by corrupt conquistadores posing as statesmen and national leaders.
Canada, always something of a bystander in the three-way negotiations, must decide what it will do about the trade sanctions Mr. Clinton imposed on its products as he sought farm-state votes for Nafta. The new Government of Prime Minister Jean Chretien, already forced to cope with Quebec separatism, may have little choice but to respond in kind to what Canadians consider bullying tactics.
Mr. Clinton's Nafta victory saves him from immediate damage to his Presidency. But the price he paid for victory will be steep. It includes billions in spending obligations to buy key House votes. And his trade actions against Canada and other partners will make it more difficult to complete the GATT deal on time.
Mr. Clinton's confrontation with the labor movement over Nafta may well poison his relationship with it, at least for the time being, and make it harder to advance his health care reforms.
His incredible promise to House Republicans that he would protect them next year if they were attacked for pro-Nafta votes cannot be kept. It has angered members of his party and core Democratic constituencies whose concerns go beyond Nafta.
The Administration would do well to curtail its recent boasting that "Nafta will send a message to Japan and Europe" and force them into high-noon concessions in the final stages of the GATT talks.
The Nafta victory will be hollow if Mr. Clinton uses it to try to bulldoze the rest of the world in the Pacific talks in Seattle -- and then at the GATT talks -- into accepting U.S. commercial ultimatums. America's choice about GATT, not Nafta, will provide real proof of whether we are optimistic and open or defeatist and closed.

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Lower Interest Rates Favor Treasury Funds

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
For the last three years, the story among the 46 Treasury bond funds has been interest rates.
Unlike the United States Government bond funds, Treasury funds do not buy agency or mortgage issues. And Treasuries carry virtually no credit risk. So shifts in interest rates create straightforward changes in their share prices. 
As rates fall, bond prices rise, and the longer a bond's duration (its maturity plus some other factors), the better the bond performs. Conversely, bond prices fall when rates rise.
The best performers among the Treasury funds have been long-term zero-coupon bonds. (For the purposes of this ranking, Benham's other target maturity funds, and the Scudder Zero Coupon 2000, also a target maturity fund, were eliminated.) Next in performance were long-term funds, and then intermediate funds.
No one can predict with certainty what direction interest rates will take, though the dominant view is that rates will rise only slightly over the next year. Conservative investors can hedge their bets by owning shares in intermediate-term Treasury funds, said John Rekenthaler, the editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds, in Chicago.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1867 words

HEADLINE: SENATE APPROVES BROAD CRIME BILL; SPLITS OVER GUNS

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
The Senate today overwhelmingly passed a broad and expensive anticrime package whose leading provisions would add 100,000 police officers to the nation's streets, build a network of high-security regional prisons and create more boot camps for young offenders.
But a related and more contentious piece of legislation, the Brady gun-control bill, stumbled badly when its supporters failed tonight to break a Republican-led filibuster against it. That development appeared to doom the bill's chances for two months at the very least, until after the Senate returns in late January from its winter recess. 
 Supporters of the Brady bill, which would require that every buyer of a handgun wait five business days before taking possession of it, had hoped to have the legislation on President Clinton's desk by Thanksgiving. But they failed twice today to shut off debate. The first vote, this afternoon, was 57 in favor of cloture -- 3 fewer than needed -- and 42 against. The second, late tonight, was 57 to 41.
 
$23 Billion Package
 The broader anticrime package that passed today, a product of lawmakers' new sense of urgency stemming from a public outcry over violence, would cost $23 billion over five years. That would amount to a sixfold increase in the annual subsidy that Washington now gives to state and local governments to fight crime.
It is unclear how big a part of this new assistance would flow to New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Even the smallest of the 50 states would receive millions of dollars, but the bulk of the package would be disbursed by the Justice Department on review of applications filed by the states and on the basis of crime rates and other barometers of need.
Still, New York State officials said they hoped to obtain $1 billion of the aid, and New York City has said it hopes to add 5,000 police officers over the next five years as a result of the bill.
The legislation's passage, by a vote of 95 to 4, followed years of gridlock that had killed less ambitious anticrime measures. Senate leaders were able to avoid an impasse this time by stitching together a variety of provisions that allowed conservatives and liberals alike to claim victory.
"This is the finest anticrime package in history," said Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, the ranking Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. "It has the right combination of tough-on-crime provisions and prevention."
On the Democratic side, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, the commmittee's chairman, said: "Conscience and convenience have crossed paths. We're finally beginning to listen to the American people. People are prisoners in their neighborhoods, prisoners in their houses."
 
Headed for Conference
 The bill was opposed by only two Democrats and two Republicans, and now heads with significant momentum for a conference early next year between the Senate and the House, which two weeks ago passed a series of far more modest anticrime measures. Congressional leaders expect that the compromise that emerges from the conference committee will be taken up by both houses promptly and be ready for President Clinton's signature by spring.
House Democratic leaders, who allowed the Senate to assume chief responsibility for drafting the crime package, hope that the final version will closely resemble the Senate bill.
But those same leaders doubt that it will include a Senate provision that would prohibit the further manufacture of 19 kinds of military-style firearms. Largely because of Western and Southern lawmakers from rural districts who are particularly sensitive to the demands of hunting interests, the House has repeatedly turned back similar curbs on long-barrel weapons.
 
Intense Lobbying on Brady Bill
 By contrast, the Brady bill cleared the House with relative ease last week. But today it ran headlong into the Republican filibuster in the Senate, where it had been killed twice in earlier years, and once again it came out the loser.
The bill's opponents were able to fend off cloture despite a daylong lobbying effort by the Clinton Administration. Attorney General Janet Reno visited lawmakers on Capitol Hill, Vice President Al Gore lobbied them by telephone, and Mr. Clinton, in Seattle for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation conference, issued a statement there that called on the Senate to break the filibuster and pass the bill.
But the National Rifle Association and its allies, who argued that the bill would pose no threat to criminals and instead inconvenience only the law-abiding, had also engaged in a furious lobbying campaign in recent days, and in the end they were the victors.
The Brady bill is named for one of its chief advocates, James S. Brady, the White House press secretary who was disabled by gunfire in the assassination attempt on President Ronald Reagan in 1981. Its waiting-period requirement is intended to give law-enforcement authorities time to check the background of every handgun buyer for evidence of a criminal or mentally unstable past.
Mr. Brady's wife, Sarah, who accompanied Attorney General Reno to lobby for the bill at the Capitol today, expressed anger that it could not be passed despite the clear majority support that it enjoyed in the Senate. "This isn't the way democracy should work," Mrs. Brady said of the filibuster.
The debate on the Brady bill was intense. Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, said that if it was not passed, "we will have blood on our hands." Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, countered by citing the Second Amendment's guarantee of citizens' right to bear arms. "An armed citizenry," he said, "is not going to become an oppressed citizenry."
 
Victory for Clinton
 Debate on the Brady bill began today immediately after approval of the broader anticrime legislation. Unlike the outcome on Brady, that measure's passage was a victory for Mr. Clinton, who campaigned for the Presidency last year on a promise of one of the bill's central provisions: pouring 100,000 new police officers over the next five years into state and local efforts against crime.
And it was an easy victory, at that. Given public pressure on lawmakers to do something about violence -- pressure that became all the more evident during a number of election campaigns this fall, when crime emerged as a defining issue -- Mr. Clinton did not have to engage in much lobbying on behalf of the bill. And he had virtually nothing to do with the compromises that made its passage possible.
It was those compromises that allowed lawmakers of every stripe to find at least something about the legislation that pleased them.
Liberals won the ban on an array of assault weapons, as well as programs that would provide treatment for drug-abusing prisoners and members of youth gangs. Conservatives won a provision that would broaden the death penalty so that it applied to a total of 52 Federal crimes, and they also achieved a mandate requiring states that accept Federal money for construction of the new regional prisons to insure that violent offenders serve at least 85 percent of the prison terms to which they are sentenced.
To be sure, some parts of the anticrime package are little more than symbolism, a result of political grandstanding at a time when voters are demanding action against street violence. There is, for instance, a provision that would apply the death penalty to cases of genocide, and another that would loosen rules of admissibility of evidence in cases of child molestation, an offense that is rarely adjudicated in the Federal courts.
Nonetheless, the bill would bring a remarkable surge in Federal resources earmarked to fight gang violence, prison overcrowding and such offenses as rape and hate crimes.
The $23 billion that the bill would authorize in spending over five years amounts, on an annual basis, to roughly six times the $756 million a year that the Government now provides for state and local law enforcement. In real terms -- that is, when inflation is taken into account -- that current level is only a third of what Washington provided in such help two decades ago.
The source of all the new billions in spending would be the Federal work-force reductions, so far unspecified, that have emerged as a central part of the Vice President's campaign to streamline the Government.
To make sure that the new money would be spent in the way that the bill envisions, the legislation specifies that state and local governments would not be permitted to use it to replace money that they divert from crime-fighting to other programs.
The crime bill takes a two-front approach.
The first, the one with the greatest emphasis, is law enforcement and punishment. About a third of the $23 billion, the biggest single chunk of the package, would pay for the training and hiring of the new police officers. In addition, the legislation would provide the states $3 billion to finance construction of the 10 new regional prisons, the aim being to ease prison overcrowding that frequently forces the release of violent offenders.
There are a variety of other enforcement provisions as well, one of which would provide $200 million in college scholarships to students who commit themselves to serve as police officers for four years after graduation.
 
 
 
MAJOR PROVISIONS OF THE CRIME BILL
 Bans the manufacture, sale and possession of 19 semiautomatic assault weapons and clips designed to feed more than 10 rounds of ammunition. Specifically exempts more than 650 hunting weapons, in addition to assault weapons that have been already manufactured.
 
Some Examples
A. Tech-9 -- 9-mm assault pistol manufactured by Intratec in the United States.
 
B. Uzi -- 9-mm assault pistol manufactured in Israel.
 
C. Ar-15 -- Assault rifle manufactured in the Unites States by Colt.
 
OTHER IMPORTANT PROVISIONS
 
Authorizes $8.9 billion to put 100,00 new police officers on the nation's streets over the next five years.
 
Authorizes $3 billion for construction of regional high-security prisons and another $3 billion for boot camps for young offenders and other innovative correctional programs.
 
Prohibits the sale or transfer of guns to minors.
 
Authorizes $1.8 billion to combat violence against women. Stregnthens Federal laws against battery and other abuse, sets up a special phone line to report domestic violence and toughens Federal sentences for sex crimes.
 
Makes certain gang activities Federal offenses, ranging from conspiring to join a criminal street gang to committing murder for that gang.
 
Expands the Federal death penalty to cover 52 offenses, including the slaying of Federal law-enforcement officers and drive by shootings.
 
Authorizes $1.2 billion for programs providing drug treatment, alternative punishments, job training and other preventive measures for nonviolent drug offenders who are sentenced to probation.
 
Authorizes $100 million in grants to schools for metal detectors and other security measures.
 
Authorizes $40 million to develop a national criminal background check on those who provide care to children, the elderly or the disabled.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%);

HEADLINE: THE PACIFIC SUMMIT;
'DIALOGUE' IS BEGUN AS CLINTON MEETS WITH CHINA'S CHIEF

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Nov. 19

 BODY:
Having promised this morning to tread "a more constructive path" in relations with China, President Clinton met this evening with President Jiang Zemin, leader of the Chinese Communist Party, in the most important contact between the two countries since the massacre in Tiananmen Square in 1989. But little tangible progress was reported.
"I thought we began a dialogue," Mr. Clinton said afterward when asked whether he had made any headway in persuading the Chinese Government to lower trade barriers, limit missile sales and ease up on dissidents. He appeared subdued, and made it clear that there had been no real meeting of the minds between the two. 
 Mark Gearan, the White House communications director, said that the Chinese leader had delivered a 15-minute monologue about the "importance of noninterference in the internal affairs of other nations."
 
In Praise of Honesty
 As if to counter those in Congress and elsewhere who disapprove of meetings with Mr. Jiang or other members of the Chinese leadership without first extracting some quid pro quo, Mr. Clinton said, "I don't think that you ever lose anything by talking to someone, as long as you are honest."
In a continuing effort to loosen the linkage between human rights and commercial relations, the President argued that when China and the United States "work together, we are powerful force for security and economic progress." In effect, he said that abuses of civil liberties in China must not be ignored but must not be permitted to dominate the relationship -- a formulation remarkably like that which guided the Bush Administration and which Mr. Clinton roundly criticized during the 1992 campaign.
 
No Chinese Concessions
 In June, Mr. Clinton renewed trade benefits for China, but said he would not do so again next June unless Beijing's record on human rights improved substantially. Privately, he has said such improvements could not come on the eve of the renewal but must be made to build credibility over 12 months. The President gave no sign that he had received any major commitments during his 90-minute conversation this evening, but he noted pointedly the historic Chinese aversion to discussing such matters in public.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher said that progress had been made because the two sides had talked about the tough issues without stonewalling. But he reported no Chinese concessions, large or small, and used the words "frank" and "candid" to describe the encounter, which are diplomatic code for discussions that produce no measurable result.
Mr. Clinton came to this first summit meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum on the wings of his success in winning House approval for the North American Free Trade Agreement, and he sought to use that victory to generate support for a similar free-trade zone in the Pacific and for the long-stalled negotiations among 108 nations on new world trade rules.
"We hope to complete a triple play," Mr. Christopher declared.
The 16 Asian and Pacific foreign ministers gathered here issued a pointed statement intended to prod the Europeans, particularly the French, into completing the trade talks by Dec. 15. The talks, aimed at updating the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, have dragged on for seven years.
Pledging themselves to support further tariff cuts on products traded heavily by Pacific countries, including electronic goods, wood pulp and scientific instruments, the ministers said "the time for pledges and commitments is long past."
 
'Lively Discussion' Reported
 But there was far less unanimity on the eventual establishment of a free-trade area in the Pacific. Drawn from nations with widely differing cultures and with economies ranging from the rudimentary to the sophisticated, the ministers rejected a recommendation by a group of private experts that a commitment to free trade be made and officially announced by 1996.
The proposal, Mr. Christopher said, "provoked a lively discussion" during the three-day ministers' meeting here that made it evident that the organization is "not ready to reach that kind of definitive decision."
In addition, the Secretary signaled that the leaders would stay away, as much as possible, from potentially divisive political issues in their discussions on Blake Island, eight miles from Seattle in Puget Sound. He said that "one of the geniuses of APEC is that it focuses on economic development rather than political issues."
Mr. Clinton held a number of meetings with other Asian leaders, including Morihiro Hosokawa, the new Japanese Prime Minister.
American negotiators said that the long-discussed easing of the Japanese prohibition on rice imports did not come up during the main meeting between the two, at which advisers were present. Mr. Christopher said, however, that it came up at a subsequent private meeting, though he gave no details. Several Japanese sources said they were certain that Mr. Hosokawa had decided to modify the ban once his political reform measures have been enacted.
The rice question is important not only in terms of American exports but also because it is a major stumbling block to a new GATT agreement.
 
Seattle Is in Knots
 Seattle was tied into knots by the plethora of meetings involving the leaders and their ministers. Unaccustomed to gatherings of this sort, the Seattle police not only closed off streets, as is always the case at summit conferences, but halted elevators at many hotels for long periods and sealed other guests into their hotels while officials came and went.
But the city nonetheless embraced the meeting as a symbol of its own bright economic future as one of the American cities best situated to benefit from enhanced trade across the Pacific. This is exemplified by the sales of the Boeing Company, the largest American exporter, which sells vast quantities of jets to China and Japan and as part of sales agreements has agreed to the manufacture of fuselages and other items in those two nations.
Mayor Norm Rice and Gov. Mike Lowry, both Democrats, effusively introduced the President today for his fourth speech about trade with Asia since taking office. Behind Mr. Clinton as he spoke were symbols of the considerable regional pride of the Pacific Northwest: four enormous clamshell-shaped glass sculptures by Dale Chihuly, who works in a village named Pilchuck north of here.
Mr. Clinton painted a bright vision of an Asia-Pacific region with "robust and open economic competition," with "Japan fast becoming a model of political reform as well as an economic colossus" and China "playing a constructive regional and global leadership role while moving toward greater internal liberalization."
He compared the meeting here to those at the end of World War II that helped to build such international institutions as NATO, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. He added: "It took them a few years to put this together, and it wasn't self-evident at the time that it had to be done. We now have to bring the same level of vision to this time of change."
"Such goals extend beyond tomorrow's agenda," the President conceded at the end of his speech, "but they must not lie beyond our vision."
 
Computer Sale Confirmed
 The Administration confirmed that it had approved the sale of a Cray supercomputer to China for use in meteorology but tried to play down the significance of the move.
"They could go down to Radio Shack and buy a couple of personal computers and do the same thing," said Bowman Cutter, the deputy assistant to the President for economic policy.
In essence, the Administration gave China the computing power that it desperately sought a few years ago, but which today has more symbolic than practical value, in the hope that it might prompt the Chinese to make concessions on some major points.

HEADLINE: THE PACIFIC SUMMIT;
Clinton Sees Asia Exports as Key to Jobs

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Nov. 19

 BODY:
President Clinton today summoned the nation to look eastward now that the cold war has ended, asserting that unemployment in the United States can only be dealt with by expanding foreign trade and that the most dynamic markets for American exports are in Asia and the Pacific, not in Europe.
"The fastest-growing region is the Asian Pacific, a region that has to be vital for our future," Mr. Clinton said in a speech to representatives of the nations taking part in the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation conference. 
 In the span of a few years, the President added, these Asian economies have gone from being thought of as "dominos" in the struggle between Communism and democracy to "dynamos" driving the world economy.
Mr. Clinton argued that the United States today faced one of those hinges of history that come along every few generations, and the direction in which it now swings will be critical in determining the country's economic health and security for the coming generation.
 
'Security Is Tied to Economics'
 In this new era, the President declared, "We cannot let our national worries blind us to our national interests. More than ever our security is tied to economics. Military threats remain, and they require our vigilance and resolve, but increasingly our place in the world will be determined as much by the skills of our workers as by the strength of our weapons, as much by our ability to pull down foreign trade barriers as our ability to breach distant ramparts."
The President argued that exports have now become the "lifeblood" of American economic growth.
"This trend will continue," he said. "All wealthy nations are having difficulty creating jobs and raising incomes, even when there is economic growth. Why is that? Because workers in advanced countries must become ever more productive to deal with competition from low-wage countries on the one hand and high-skilled, high-tech countries on the other.
"Being more productive simply means that fewer and fewer people can produce more and more goods. And in an environment like that, if you want to increase jobs and raise incomes, the only way to do it is find more customers for each country's products. There is no alternative. We must compete, not retreat."
 
Call to Update Social Programs
 That was what drove him to push for the North American Free Trade Agreement, Mr. Clinton said, and it is what impels him even more strongly to push for an expansion of American trade with Asia and the Pacific.
Mr. Clinton has told his aides that the purpose of this conference and the purpose of trying to develop this economic forum into something more concrete, is to insure that the United States and its businesses have a strong foothold in the Asian markets at a time when they are increasingly trading and investing with one another, and not the outside world.
The President noted that just as some of America's attitudes about foreign trade have been based on a world that no longer exists -- which was why the fight over the North American trade agreement was so difficult -- so America's unemployment system has been overtaken by global change and has to be revamped to keep the nation competitive.
He seemed to suggest that to get the free trade agreement passed he had had to dismantle the New Deal coalition of labor, minorities and big city Democrats, and replace it with a new coalition of high-tech workers from the Northwest and the South and big and small business. And now, to deal with unemployment, he indicated that he would have to dismantle the New Deal approach to that problem as well.
 
Retraining the Unemployed
 "The unemployment system," Mr. Clinton said, "was created at a time when the average length of unemployment was shorter than it is today and when the average unemployed person, when called back to work, went back to his or her former employer." So workers, he said, could draw money from unemployment insurance, their income would go down for a while and then they would be called back to the same job.
Today, most people are unemployed for much longer and rarely re-employed by the same company, so the current unemployment system is "now an unfair tax on employers and a rip-off for employees because it does not help them," Mr. Clinton said. That is why, the President said, his Administration wants to set up a new system where people who lose their jobs immediately begin retraining programs to learn new skills.
But putting America's domestic economy on a new track is not enough, the President said. While Europe remains at the core of American strategic alliances, Mr. Clinton said, "as our concern shifts to economic challenges we must look across the Pacific as well as the Atlantic."
While it is necessary for the Government to open markets that are being kept closed by Asian Pacific governments, American businessmen "have to do a better job of piercing those markets," Mr. Clinton said. "We cannot have customers where we are not there to make the sale."
To insure that the United States is not shut out, Mr. Clinton painted his vision of how the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum might be developed.
"We will propose a meeting of the APEC finance ministers to advance our dialogue on the broad issues affecting economic growth," Mr. Clinton said.
"We can't imagine now how we could have weathered the cold war without NATO. In the same way, future generations may look back and say they can't imagine how the Asian-Pacific region could have thrived in such a spirit of harmony without the existence of APEC."

HEADLINE: COALITION IN HOUSE MOVES ON DEFICIT

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
The same kind of pot-luck stew of House Democrats and Republicans that just swept President Clinton's free trade accord to victory suddenly is threatening to give the White House an embarrassing drubbing on the year's most persistent political issue: reducing the deficit.
Without much fanfare, Representatives Timothy J. Penny, Democrat of Minnesota, and John R. Kasich, Republican of Ohio, have pushed to a vote in the full House, probably on Monday, a proposal to cut an additional $90 billion from the Federal budget by 1998. They say Congress must approve the package, or something like it, if lawmakers are ever to convince voters that they have shed their spendthrift ways. 
 It is not clear whether they have the votes to do that. But the House leadership is fearful enough that it has already postponed the House vote, originally set for Saturday, to spend time twisting arms against it. And the White House is so anxious that it has dragooned Cabinet secretaries and top Clinton aides into a furious media campaign to paint the proposal as an assault on the nation's health and fiscal welfare.
 
'Immoral' Impact
 The White House budget director, Leon E. Panetta, summoned reporters to the White House today to call the plan's impact on Medicare recipients "immoral." Defense Secretary Les Aspin called its proposed cuts in military retirement benefits and other Pentagon spending "anti-family" and "a very, very severe blow" to the national security.
Meanwhile, Mr. Kasich, a young Republican who is seen as a comer on fiscal matters, and Mr. Penny, a fractious Democrat who says will retire after this term in disgust at Washington ways, claim at least 50 Democrats and the vast bulk of the House's 175 Republicans are on their side.
In an interview today, Mr. Penny guessed that another 50 Democrats are still up for grabs.
"We're not there yet," he said. "It's not going to be easy. But this vote, more than any in recent years, will define those legislators who are serious about solving the deficit problem and those who are part of the problem."
 
Whither the Center?
 In fact, defining the Congress's political center on Federal spending is really what the struggle is about, as no one seriously expects Mr. Penny's and Mr. Kasich's plan to become law. Even if it passed the House, it would not come before the Senate until Congress returned to session in January, when passions would have cooled. And even if it did pass the Senate, it probably would face a Presidential veto.
Rather, Mr. Penny and Mr. Kasich hope to show enough muscle to force Mr. Clinton into serious bargaining over deeper Federal spending cuts than the White House seems willing to make.
They have allies in Senators Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska, and Hank Brown, Republican of Colorado, who have a broadly similar plan for $109 billion in budget cuts ready to offer in the Senate.
And they have a wild card: House members may well feel they can vote for it, and score points back home, without worrying that the White House would actually accept the cuts it proposes.
 
Dramatic Cuts
 And some of the cuts -- in dozens of specific Federal programs -- would be dramatic. Among them are proposals to scale back the Superfund program that cleans up hazardous-waste sites; to end subsidies for public-housing construction in favor of vouchers that would let low-income residents choose their own housing, and to abolish the Energy and Commerce Departments and create in their place a Department of Science.
The plan is intended to cut the Medicare program by $35 billion, partly by raising the hospital deductible for affluent Medicare recipients, to $2,000 from $676, and by raising Medicare premiums for the same recipients. The proposal would also withhold cost-of-living increases on military pensions until retirees reach age 62, and it would raise the retirement age, to 65 from 62, for civilian Federal workers.
Besides arguing that the plan would disrupt the economic recovery and hurt the military, the Administration argues that the cuts would wreck Mr. Clinton's blueprint for health care. The health care proposal would be financed partly by $124 billion taken from the Medicare program that Mr. Penny and Mr. Kasich now seek to pare back.
 
Clinton's Plan
 On Monday, Mr. Penny and Mr. Kasich will offer their proposal as an amendment to Mr. Clinton's own budget-cutting plan, one he promised in August to win conservative Democrats over to his fiscal package.
That plan would cut existing Federal programs by $2 billion and save another $9 billion partly by putting into effect Vice President Al Gore's recommendations on streamlining Federal operations.
Mr. Clinton is in the politically difficult situation of arguing against large cuts in Federal spending. Moreover, his plan's savings look puny beside the Penny-Kasich proposal.
To bulk up his own plan and swing votes away from his rivals' Mr. Clinton said today that he would add another $600 million in spending cuts and try to get Congress to put into law Mr. Gore's plan to gradually reduce the Federal workforce by 252,000 workers. Those actions would boost the White House's total savings to about $30 billion, the Administration said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
President Clinton met with China's President, Jiang Zemin, hoping to persuade his Government to lower trade barriers, limit missile sales and ease up on dissidents. But he said there had been no real meeting of the minds between the two. [Page 1.]
Pacific Rim countries offered to reduce or eliminate many tariffs to spur stalled GATT world trade talks. [6.] Now that the three-nation North American Free Trade Agreement has been passed, attention is shifting to the 116-country GATT. [45.] 
 A widening trade gap with Japan and China and a rare shortfall with Mexico swelled the American trade deficit with the rest of the world by 8.3 percent in September. [37.]
 
Companies

HEADLINE: THE PACIFIC SUMMIT;
Mending Images With Pandas and Taking Home 747's

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Nov. 19

 BODY:
In another era of Asian diplomacy, American leaders visiting China would always stop in at the home of a Chinese worker, sip tea and painfully follow a scripted conversation about his life at home and work. This time it was President Jiang Zemin's turn, sitting in the loveseat in Cary Qualls split-level house in Marysville, a blue-collar suburb 25 miles north of Seattle.
China's leader came with a giant stuffed panda for the Qualls's 2-year-old son, Gregory, and a doll for Marinda, their 4-year-old daughter. There was Chinese silk for Mr. Qualls's wife, Melanie. And he had a lot of questions about the capitalist life of the 33-year-old mechanic at the Boeing Company, who makes mid-wing stub joints for 747's when he is not entertaining world leaders. 
 Mr. Jiang wanted to know if Boeing owned the house. No, said Mr. Qualls. That led to a discussion about the Qualls's monthly mortgage payments, a new concept in China, and his work schedule. "You have a nice home," Mr. Jiang concluded, surveying the three cars parked in the driveway before speeding off with his entourage of 50.
 
Different Agendas
 These have been days of disparate agendas for the leaders of Asia, each working furiously at image-building and deal-making on their way to meeting President Clinton for the first-ever summit meeting of Asian powers. Mr. Jiang was at the Qualls as part of a carefully orchestrated effort to reform China's image as a repressive regime. He even showed pictures of his grandchildren.
President Fidel V. Ramos of the Philippines stopped off for Texas barbecue and then dropped by to pick up a 747 for Philippine Airlines. Twirling one of his signature cigars in his suite at the Four Seasons Hotel this afternoon, Mr. Ramos described how he was flying his new toy back home.
"We may be the only ones going back from APEC with something really big," he said, referring to the otherwise dry-as-trade-figures talk that swirled around the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum.
 
No News Is Good News
 For Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa of Japan, the biggest challenge was to try to make no news at home, particularly news that would threaten his 70 percent approval ratings. Mr. Hosokawa, the Japanese press reported as he left for a 30-hour visit, was coming ready to give in on rice, telling Mr. Clinton that when push came to shove he would finally open a market that Japanese leaders have long feared to breach. No one doubts that agrees with Mr. Hosokawa's own feelings on the issue.
But today, sitting next to President Clinton, he chose his words with utmost precision, mixing English and Japanese to describe the whole question as a "serious no mondai" -- a "serious problem" -- that he could not afford to tackle until he was finished pushing a sweeping political reform bill through the Japanese Parliament.
So did he make his promise or not? Carefully preserving deniability for all in the room, Mr. Hosokawa and Mr. Clinton went off for a private chat, one that the American Ambassador to Japan, Walter F. Mondale, said with obvious relief that he did not witness and so could not discuss.
But Mr. Hosokawa will go home with the one thing he most desperately sought: some more time before he has to get serious about trade problems. "This is a different Government for a different time," Mr. Clinton said this afternoon, taking every chance he could to congratulate Mr. Hosokawa for finally moving to reform a political system whose corruption became a trade barrier in itself.
As soon as that is done, he said, "I believe Mr. Hososkawa will move seriously on the two great economic issues we face," restoring economic growth and moving toward greater opening for investment in Japan.
 
Not Too Casual, Please
 Japan's biggest concern about this week's meetings is that Mr. Clinton will make them too casual. He has already banned assistants and the usual legions of notetakers from his big meeting on Saturday on Blake Island, off the Seattle coast. More than a few ministry bureaucrats are worried their leaders may not be able to sustain hours of serious talk without someone to whisper in their ears.
"Asians don't really feel so comfortable with informal meetings," a senior Japanese diplomat lamented a few days ago. "They feel better if they have to keep their jackets on."
Probably the hardest public relations task of the whole meeting fell to Rafidah Aziz, the Minister of International Trade and Industry of Malaysia. Malaysia has made no secret of the fact it dislikes the whole idea of APEC, which competes with an Asians-and-Asians-only organization that Mohamad Mahathir, the Malaysian Prime Minister, has long advocated.
Mr. Mahathir was the one spoilsport of the event, refusing to take part and quietly urging other leaders in Southeast Asia to do the same. He failed, and at the last minute sent Mrs. Rafidah, who is known for a pithy tongue and a colorful wardrobe.

HEADLINE: Dow Makes Slight Gain In Broad Market Slump

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks were mostly lower yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average the only market indicator posting a gain on the day. The average rose 8.67 points to close at 3,694.01, up 9.50 points for the week. On Tuesday the Dow posted a record high of 3,710.77.
While some of the large capitalization stocks rose, the remainder of the market slumped. Investors, some traders said, were focused on rising interest rates and the state of the economy. 
 Joseph V. Battapaglia, the chief investment strategist for Gruntal & Company, said there were two things to watch in yesterday's market -- bonds, which continued to slip, and the Nasdaq composite, which also continued to weaken.
Also, he noted, "yesterday was an expiration day for options and futures, and the Dow and Standard & Poor's indices were skewed by those closing positions."
 
'A Sloppy Process'
 "Unfortunately, the fundamental change from sliding interest rates to an expanding economy is a sloppy process," Mr. Battapaglia said. "Investors are having trouble dealing with the fact that interest rates are not going any lower and are starting to second-guess if the economy has staying power. This has been the cause of the volatility in the stock market for the past few weeks."
Despite the volatility, Mr. Battapaglia said there were some positive fundamental factors in place. The Producer Price Index and Consumer Price Index numbers were strong recently. The North American Free Trade Agreement was approved despite contentious debate, and the economy is performing strongly as the fourth quarter progresses.
"So, if investors can hold their noses, and keep their eyes closed through this and maintain their positions," he said, "they should be able go into the new year being happy they did so."
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 303 million, down from 313.5 million on Thursday. The number of losing issues was far greater than stocks that showed gains for the day: 1,333 to 795.
 
Price 'Bounce' Expected
 In early trading, blue-chip issues recouped some losses as investors picked the market for buying opportunities based on lower prices.
Market strategists said that while the selloff was not finished, some kind of price "bounce" was due as prices fell, attracting buyers looking for cheaper stocks. And it was bargain hunting that may have kept the blue-chip issues resilient in the face of a sharp drop in bond prices, which caused interest rates to rise abruptly. Bonds had opened lower and then sold off after the United States merchandise trade deficit came in at an unexpectedly high $10.89 billion.
Elsewhere in the market, Talbots, the specialty retailer of women's apparel was up 16 percent from its initial public offering price during the first day of trading, closing at 22 5/8. The company sold 11 million shares and made the top of the most active list yesterday, as 6.8 million shares changed hands.
 
Airline Stocks Weak
 Airline stocks were weaker on news of the strike by flight attendants at American Airlines and the restructuring of United Airlines. AMR, the parent of American, was down 3/4, to 68 1/4, while UAL, the parent of United, was unchanged at 140.
The Pep Boys -- Manny Moe & Jack gained 1/2, to 24 1/8, as the auto parts retailer's third-quarter earnings reached 28 cents a share, compared with 24 cents for the comparable period a year ago. A consensus of 19 analysts surveyed by the Institutional Brokers Estimate System was for 27 cents a share.
On the first full trading session after the North American Free Trade agreement was approved, the expected excitement in trading on the Mexican stock exchange did not materialize. It closed only nine-tenth of a percent higher, or 19.48 points, to 2,185.66.
Stock prices ended lower in Tokyo yesterday, with the benchmark Nikkei index closing below 18,000 for the first time since March 16. The Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 225.13 points, or 1.24 percent, to 17,941.19.

HEADLINE: Ski Merger May Perk Up Aspen

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EVERGREEN, Colo., Nov. 19

 BODY:
For years, Aspen has been celebrated as much for celebrities like The Donald and The Ivana, as for, well, The Snow.
Now the area's two skiing companies plan to merge, which may again put snow at the forefront in Aspen at a time when the nation's $2.5 billion ski industry has finally recovered from a recession. 
 For skiers, the merger may mean better ski facilities and more skiing at four mountains, instead of three, with a single lift ticket. For Aspen residents, the merger may mean more jobs and a greater emphasis on being a resort for serious skiers. It also may mean more traffic congestion and even more high-priced housing.
 
 
A Tangled Tale
 But first a tangled tale must be at least partly resolved next week, which is the start of the ski season in Aspen. The tale involves a California billionaire, a Chicago billionaire, a mere millionaire from Texas, and Harvard University. It also involves the five commissioners of Pitkin County, which includes Aspen, whose approval is indirectly key to the merger.
If the two companies merge, the combination would control the $42 million ski business in Aspen, the nation's fifth-largest ski resort. Vail, Colo., is the largest.
The companies are the Aspen Skiing Company, owned by the Crown family of Chicago, and its far smaller unprofitable rival a few miles away, the Aspen Highlands Ski Area, owned by the trustees of Harvard University.
Gerald Hines, a soft-spoken real estate millionaire from Houston, now has an option to buy the Highlands, as it is known, from Harvard, reportedly for more than $20 million. The Indiana native is one of the most prolific developers of office buildings in the country and is known for showplaces like Pennzoil Place in downtown Houston.
 
 
County Approval
 Mr. Hines must first get approval from the Pitkin County commissioners for an ambitious redevelopment plan involving the construction of a shopping mall, ice rink, an amphitheater, and more than 50 condominiums and houses -- the largest such project in Aspen's history.
Mr. Hines's project, which would be at the base of the Highlands, will make little sense as a real estate development unless he also owns the Highlands. His option to buy the Highlands from Harvard expires Monday, and if he exercises it he will be gambling that he will get the county commission's approval in January for his plan.
The Highlands, combined with the redevelopment project, will be even more valuable when it is merged with the larger Aspen Skiing. Aspen Skiing officials say they are certain of the county commission's approval, but an earlier negative vote by an agency making recommendations to the commission indicates that approval is far from certain. Mr. Hines would only say he plans to "wait and find out."
However, it is highly unlikely the Highlands-Aspen Skiing merger would go through without Mr. Hines winning approval for his plan from the county commission.
The commissioners themselves would not comment, except to say they would meet in January on this issue. However, Jody Edwards, a county official who reviewed Mr. Hines's plan for the commissioners, said that Mr. Hines's project was so huge that it would block "the views of the mountains with second homes that are vacant most of the year."
Moreover, Michael Conviser, a member of the Maroon-Castle Creek Caucus, a neighborhood advocacy group, said Mr. Hines's plan would "destroy the Aspen Growth Management Plan," a 20-year-old government plan to restrain real estate development that might damage the environment.
 
 
A 'Sweetheart'
 Still, Mr. Conviser describes Mr. Hines as 'a sweetheart" whose developments are quality projects and who might yet develop a plan that would satisfy the county's objections.
By far, the king of the mountain in Aspen is Aspen Skiing, founded in 1946. It controls three of the valley's four skiing mountains -- Aspen Mountain, Snowmass and Buttermilk -- and two hotels, Little Nell and Snowmass Club. It is the community's largest employer, with 2,250 workers during peak season. More than half of the town's revenues are generated during the five-month ski season.
Aspen Skiing has annual revenue of $40 million, compared with $2 million to $3 million for the Highlands, which controls the Aspen Highlands Mountain. The revenue figures come from I. William Berry, executive editor of the Ski Industry Letter in Katonah, N.Y. Aspen Skiing declines to confirm the numbers.
Aspen Skiing controls operations at its three ski mountains and received almost 1.4 million skiers last winter. The company's skier visits grew by 6.9 percent last year, comfortably ahead of key Colorado rivals like Vail and Telluride.
Under the ownership of Marvin Davis, the Los Angeles oil billionaire who bought Aspen Skiing along with 20th Century Fox in 1981, Aspen Skiing helped foster the resort's image as a refuge for the pampered rich and famous.
 
 
Crown Family
 But seven months ago, Mr. Davis sold his half of Aspen Skiing to his partners, the Crown family, whose fortune is based on real estate and a substantial stock holding in General Dynamics, the big military contractor.
While Lester Crown, the 68-year-old patriarch of the family, said at first that the family would keep 100 percent of Aspen Skiing, it now plans to sell a stake to Mr. Hines if the Houston developer can win the Highlands. The potential stake is reportedly 10 to 15 percent, but Mr. Hines would not disclose details.
Aspen Skiing's rival, the Highlands, was founded in 1958 by Whipple Van Ness Jones, an eccentric businessman and an Aspen resident. "The Highlands is the only operating ski lift museum in the world," jokes Rick Jones, who operated the ski area for six years and is now a ski consultant. Rick Jones, the estranged grandson of Whip Jones, said the Highlands had been losing about $500,000 a year for the last decade.
When the Highlands started, it appeared to pose a threat to Aspen Skiing. Even as the Highlands became less competitive because of obsolete equipment, feuding between the two companies increased.
 
 
$11.4 Million Judgment
 The situation worsened when the elder Mr. Jones filed a restraint-of-trade suit against Aspen Skiing in the early 1980's, contending that the company was trying to drive him out of business. Mr. Jones won an $11.4 million judgment after the case went all the way to the United States Supreme Court, which sustained the award. The suit was filed against previous owners of Aspen Skiing but was settled by the Crown family and Mr. Davis.
A 1932 Harvard alumnus, Whip Jones last year donated the Highlands to Harvard as a gift in a charitable trust. He refers questions about the Highlands to Harvard officials.
The Highlands is "the best ski mountain in the area," said Mr. Berry of the Ski Industry Letter. "The Aspen Skiing Company has the chance to turn it into the fine ski area it should have been all these years," he said.
