HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Deficit Rose 8.3% In September, to $10.9 Billion

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
A widening trade gap with Japan and China and a rare shortfall with Mexico swelled the American trade deficit with the rest of the world by 8.3 percent in September, the Government said today.
A recovering American economy drew record imports of $49.8 billion, up 3.4 percent from a month earlier. Exports rose only 2.1 percent, to $38.8 billion, the Commerce Department said. The combination produced a monthly deficit of $10.9 billion. 
 So far this year, the trade gap is running at an annual rate of $117.3 billion, a substantial deterioration from the $84.5 billion last year and the worst since 1988, when it was $118.5 billion.
"The United States continues to heavily buy imports," reflecting a pickup in the American economy, said Allen Sinai, an economist with Economic Advisers Inc. "Meanwhile, still-stagnant economies around the world are hurting our exports."
Trade was one of the few areas of strength in the economy during the 1990-91 recession; now it is hurting growth and is not expected to improve until late next year or 1995. Slumps in Europe and Japan have cut into export sales while Americans enjoying an economic upturn have increasingly bought more foreign goods.
The report came as President Clinton met with Asian leaders in Seattle to promote expanded trade and only two days after the House approved the North American Free Trade Agreement on promises that it would increase exports to Mexico.
Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said in Seattle that the latest trade figures and the deficits with Japan and China spoke "directly to the reasons why we are meeting with our Pacific trading partners."
The September deficit with Japan was $5.3 billion, the worst since April; with China, $2.5 billion, and with all Pacific Rim countries, $8.5 billion.
The United States recorded a $101 million deficit with Mexico in September, the first since March 1991 and the worst since December 1990. That whittled the year-to-date American surplus with Mexico to $1.75 billion, compared with $4.4 billion for the corresponding period a year ago.
Bruce Steinberg, a Merrill Lynch economist, said the Mexican economy had slowed this year because of uncertainty over the trade agreement's passage and the Mexican Government's anti-inflation program. Now, he said, "Mexico's economy is likely to accelerate and the U.S. trade balance should go back into surplus fairly soon."
The deficit with Canada nearly doubled, to $1.1 billion, bringing the year-to-date gap to $7.7 billion, up from $5 billion for the first nine months of 1992. The deficit with Western Europe was $395 million in September and $315 million so far this year. Last year at this time the United States had a $7.2 billion year-to-date surplus with Europe.
The gain in imports in September reflected increases of $216 million in autos and auto parts and $192 million in crude oil. Imports also rose substantially for other petroleum products, iron and steel, computer accessories, civilian aircraft and jewelry.
Exports were bolstered by gains of $476 million in gold, $378 million in food and $124 million in telecommunications equipment, but civilian aircraft exports slumped $376 million.
The year-to-date deficit with Japan is $42.2 billion, larger than with any other country and up from $34.9 billion for the corresponding period last year. The second-worst deficit was with China, $16.7 billion for the year so far, up from $13.5 billion a year ago.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Drop Sharply; Is the Rally Over?

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The rally in the bond market, which has carried long-term interest rates to their lowest level in 25 years, may be over. Such a turn in the market would send home-mortgage rates higher and could make the stock market, already at its own record levels, jittery.
Such a declaration is risky, mainly because of the economy's erratic performance in the last several years. But at least that seemed to be the view yesterday as bond dealers sold and sold as if they were running for the exits. The yield on the 30-year bond rose as high as 6.36 percent, the highest level in more than three months. 
 The rest of the market also slumped as prices fell sharply across the board and yields rose. Fear of stronger economic growth at the end of this year, concern about inflation and worry that the Federal Reserve could move soon to raise short-term rates all played a role in the selloff.
Money managers are also selling to lock in nice profits for the year. And, most important now, the mood of the market is turning grim; even minor data that simply reaffirm what everyone seems to know -- that the economy is growing a little faster -- have become another reason to sell.
The selloff has sharpened the debate between those who think the rally is over and those argue that the decline in long-term rates will resume because the economy will grow at just a moderate pace next year while inflation remains in check.
"I don't see the case to say that we can set new lows on interest rates," said Nicholas Sargen, the chief investment officer at Prudential's Global Advisers, a global bond fund. "Even the old low of 5.75 percent -- that looks distant now."
John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers, takes the other view. "I don't want to say the rally is over," he said. "If we are right on the fundamentals, the U.S. is likely to go through 1994 -- the fourth year of an expansion -- without accelerating inflation, and that would be a positive surprise for the bond market."
What makes choosing sides difficult is that the outlooks are not very different. Both camps expect moderate growth next year at a slower pace than the 4 percent rate now expected in the fourth quarter. They both expect inflation, running at less than 3 percent this year, to remain in check.
Mr. Sargen, however, argues that inflation has to go even lower to get long-term interest rates to new lows. Mr. Lipsky expects that stable inflation with steady growth of about 3 percent will be enough to assure investors that inflation is not on the rise and enough of a "surprise" to push rates lower.
 
 
Trading Range Is Broken
 But for the near-term, that debate seems to make no difference any longer. The jump of the 30-year bond's yield to above 6.25 percent yesterday has already smashed the ceiling of the trading range that many optimists had been betting on.
"I did not expect this kind of selloff," said John R. Williams, managing director of global market economics at Bankers Trust and another analyst who still expects interest rates to resume their decline.
Mr. Sargen sold a lot of his United States bonds Thursday after it appeared that the market would not get a lift from the House's approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement. "You don't fight the tape," he said, referring to the wave of selling that has swamped the market. Expressing a view of many money managers that could actually accelerate the selloff, he added: "You move to the sidelines until the dust settles. The selloff may be overdone, but you can't be confident that the correction is over yet."
In trading in the secondary market around 5 P.M., the price of the 6.25 percent 30-year bond was off 16/32 point. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, was at 6.33 percent, up from 6.24 percent Thursday. Earlier, the bond had been off more than a point and a half with the yield at 6.36 percent.
Three weeks ago, the yield on the 30-year bond was at 5.96 percent. Its 25-year low was 5.78 percent on Oct. 15.
 
 
Fears of Fed Action
 The yield on the two-year note jumped to 4.20 percent, from 4.13 percent the day before. This and other short-term rates are being driven higher by fears that the Federal Reserve, the nation's central bank, will be forced by the stronger growth to raise its short-term interest-rate target above 3 percent, where it has been for more than a year.
This fear of a move by the Fed seemed to be heightened this week by a report released Thursday by the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, which predicted that the Fed would soon have to push its 3 percent interest rate target higher.
In the last three weeks, the yield on the two-year note has jumped from 4.01 percent. Its low for the year was 3.69 percent on Sept. 3.
The selling yesterday was not really touched off by any one event, but was more of a continuation of the downward trend. Some traders said the report on the trade deficit, which showed imports were increasing, was a cause. But like other recent data, it was just confirming what most analysts seemed to agree on already: that the economy will grow at an annual rate of about 4 percent in the last four months of the year.
The question now is what happens next year, but there will not even be many hints until well into January, which means the selling -- and, for certain, the volatility -- will continue.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Lego Picks California Site for Theme Park

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: CARLSBAD, Calif., Nov. 19

 BODY:
The maker of Lego plastic blocks plans to build an amusement park for children in this Southern California coastal town.
The Lego Group, the Danish company that makes the popular toy, said today that the Lego Family Park would feature miniature buildings and other creations made of Legos, the multicolored, interlocking plastic blocks. There will also be amusement park rides for young children.
 
 This will be the Danish company's second amusement park. Lego World, the family entertainment subsidiary of the Lego Group, opened Legoland Park in Billund, Denmark, in 1968.
The company, which had narrowed the potential sites for an American park to Carlsbad and Prince William County, Va., said it had chosen Carlsbad, about 30 miles north of San Diego, because of its favorable demographics and weather.
A spokesman for Lego said a recent decision by the Walt Disney Company to build an amusement park with an American history theme in Prince William County was not a factor in picking Carlsbad.
 
'Great News,' Governor Says
 Gov. Pete Wilson of California called the decision "great news" for the state, which is mired in a deep recession.
The Governor's office said the project was expected to generate annual economic benefits of about $76 million to the Carlsbad area. Construction of the park is expected to create about 800 jobs and $185 million in new investment, Governor Wilson's office said.
The 37-acre park, aimed at children aged 2 to 13 and their families, is to open in 1999. Construction is to begin in 1995, after an 18-month approval process, the spokesman said.
The park is being built on a vacant 424-acre site. In addition to the 37 acres required for the initial park phase, Lego will have 43 acres for roads, setbacks and parking, 28 acres for future expansion and 5 acres for support services.
Master plans by the Carltas Company, which owns the site, include a 700-room resort hotel and golf course, to be developed by Pointe International and Gosnell Builders, and a 38-acre biotechnology office park. Seventy-eight acres of flower fields at the site will be left untouched.
Lego, which is privately held, expects the year-round park to employ about 700 full- and part-time workers and attract about 1.8 million visitors in its first year.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rallies and Ends Day Up Against Yen and Mark

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The dollar rallied against most currencies yesterday, rising against the yen amid expectation of steps by Japan to stimulate its economy and cut its trade surplus with the United States.
An increase in American interest rates helped lift the dollar to a 14-week high against the German mark. 
 In New York trading, the dollar jumped to 108.45 yen, from 107.35 on Thursday. It also rose to 1.7192 marks, its highest level since Aug. 13, before finishing at 1.7148 marks, up from 1.7130 on Thursday.
Gold prices rose. Gold for December delivery gained $1.60, to $378.30 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
Traders bought dollars for yen, betting that Tokyo would take steps to jolt the country's slumping economy, thus spurring demand for American goods. Many expect Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa to announce an income-tax cut while he is at the Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting in Seattle.
 
High Expectations for U.S.
 "People think the U.S. will get what it wants -- free trade and economic stimulus in Japan," said David De Rosa, director of foreign-exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation. Without some action by the Japanese, American officials could start calling for a stronger yen again, he said.
Yesterday, the Commerce Department reported that the trade deficit rose 8.3 percent in September, to $10.9 billion, partly because of a $5.3 billion deficit with Japan.
Signs of strength in the American economy and rising interest rates sent the dollar higher against the mark yesterday, said John Hardy, managing director at Intercap Investments, which manages $20 million in a currency-trading fund. The 30-year Treasury bond surged to 6.33 percent, from 6.24 percent on Thursday.
Higher rates make dollar-denominated deposits more attractive.
Many traders expect Germany's Bundesbank to cut interest rates again before the end of the year to spur economic growth. Germany's central bank last cut interest rates on Oct. 21, when it lowered its key discount rate to 5.75 percent from 6.25 percent and cut the Lombard rate to 6.75 percent from 7.25 percent.
The British pound fell to $1.4732 in late New York trading, from $1.4785 on Thursday.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Beware the Odd Twists In Foreign Investments

BYLINE: By Francis Flaherty

 BODY:
AS more and more Americans invest abroad, there is something they should know: Kansas it's not.
Foreign markets are not as odd as Oz, of course. But in seeking profits from free trade agreements or Communism's eclipse, investors will encounter issues they need not worry about at home. 
 Currency is one. "Currency fluctuations increase the volatility of international stocks," said George D. Kinder, a financial adviser in Cambridge, Mass. "Take a foreign stock that may range between a 20 percent loss and a 20 percent gain. If the likely currency fluctuation is 5 percent either way, then the stock really has a 25 percent range on both sides."
This currency twist can enhance -- or derail -- stock performance. For the year ended in August, Tokyo's Nikkei index rose 16 percent, and the yen gained 21 percent against the dollar, yielding a combined 40 percent gain for American investors. But the London market's 32 percent jump in the period turned into just a tiny hop for Americans. The reason: the dollar rose 24 percent against the pound.
Many people ignore currency swings, but now may be the time to pay attention, said James B. Stack of Investech Research in Whitefish, Mont. With America's rebounding interest rates and low inflation, he said, "it's tough to see the dollar going anywhere but up against European currency over the next 12 to 18 months." However buoyant the European markets, such a swing might deep-six an American's profits.
Hedges can tame the currency risk, but they may not work, warned Brian S. Mattes, a vice president of the Vanguard Group of mutual funds. He suggested holding for the long term and diversifying.
"Economy correlations" is something else Auntie Em did not worry about, but international investors should. The markets of some countries move in tandem, some in opposite ways, and some follow no pattern. Generally, the larger economies have positive correlations with one another and zero to slightly negative correlations with emerging markets like India, Thailand and Greece.
By taking a stake in economies that are only loosely related, investors can lower their risk. With a position in emerging markets, for instance, an investor gets a hedge against trouble in his American portfolio. Campbell R. Harvey, an associate professor of finance at Duke University, is high on emerging markets anyway, but the hedging role heightens their value.
Even a stock mix in closely connected economies can soften market declines. When the United States market dropped about 20 years ago, Mr. Kinder said, an American investor could have cut his losses by a third if he had placed 25 percent of his portfolio in Japan and 25 percent in Canada. One reason: Canada's oil reserves cushioned the stock market there from "oil shocks."
Some conditions in foreign markets -- lackadaisical regulation, great price swings, political instability -- might cause a commotion in Topeka. Domestic investors who blanch at news of a mere corporate reorganization may want to stay home upon hearing Mr. Kinder's worries. "I'm heavily invested in Asia and excited," he said, "but the growing military in China concerns me a little."
Such risks add an exclamation point to that standard investment rule: Diversify! "People will read that Argentina's doing real well and invest a lot there," Professor Harvey said. But one-country investors "can lose their shirts," he warned. "Invest in a basket of countries."
Diversify in other ways, too. Select mutual funds that focus on different industries and different size companies, and that practice different investment philosophies.
"Find funds that hedge," Mr. Kinder said. "Use small-cap funds to enhance the rate of return, and use value funds to minimize price swings."
As in all money matters, the most important question is: How much? What part of a portfolio should be foreign? "The conventional wisdom was 10 to 20 percent," Mr. Kinder said. "But that range is moving up," to 20 percent to 25 percent, he said.
Whatever the recommendation, Americans are homebody investors. Sophisticated pension funds invest only 5 percent to 10 percent in foreign equities, and individuals far less.
Thinking more globally than most, Professor Harvey uses world stock value as a guide. For instance, with emerging markets representing $900 billion -- or nearly 10 percent -- of the world's $10 trillion in stock, he recommends giving them 6 percent to 20 percent of a portfolio.
This world-equity idea may explain past investment patterns. "International investment was an afterthought for Americans 20 years ago -- and with good reason," Professor Harvey said. "The U.S. share of world capitalization was peaking then at about two-thirds."
If world stock is the guide, what would a portfolio look like today? At September's end, the United States had 37 percent of world equity, Japan and the rest of Asia 35 percent and Europe most of the balance.

HEADLINE: Short Sales Outstanding Increase 3.7%, to a Record

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Rising stock market volume and volatile price movements were encouraging signs to investors who sold shares short last month.
Those conditions helped the number of shares sold short and not yet covered to rise 3.7 percent on the New York Stock Exchange, to a record 1.23 billion shares in the month that ended on Nov. 5, according to Big Board figures released yesterday. In September, the number of shares sold short fell for the first time this year. 
 On the American Stock Exchange, short interest also moved higher in the month that ended on Nov. 5, rising 1.7 percent, to 100.46 million shares. The total is the second highest on record at the exchange, surpassed only by the 104.5 million shares sold short in August.
 
 
Bets That Prices Will Fall
 Short-sellers borrow shares and sell them. Much of the heavy short-selling reflects bets that share prices will decline, enabling the seller to repurchase the shares at a lower price, repay the lender and pocket the difference.
"I was surprised that shorts had decreased positions" in the previous month, said Michael Ingraham, a vice president for investment analytical services at Alex. Brown & Sons in Baltimore. "I see this as a recovery and that now we are basically back on trend."
Rising interest rates and year-end profit taking have been pushing broad market averages lower in recent weeks, even as narrower measures like the Dow Jones industrial average have marched steadily higher. The volatility and the price decline are encouraging developments for short-sellers, who for the most part have had a dismal year as stock markets have risen to record highs.
 
 
Tool for Speculators
 In addition to betting on a decline in prices, short-selling is used to speculate on the success of a merger involving stock swaps.
To lock in a profit, arbitragers buy stock in the company being acquired and sell the acquiring company short.
Speculators have been using that technique with shares of Merck & Company, which on Thursday completed its takeover of Medco Containment Services Inc..
Since the deal was announced on July 28, short interest in Merck has surged. With more than 34 million shares sold short, Merck was the single largest short for the month.
After waning last month, bearish sentiment about RJR Nabisco snapped back strongly. The number of RJR shares sold short in the period nearly doubled, to 14.6 million.

HEADLINE: Neutral Stance by Fed Panel

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve maintained its policy of keeping interest rates steady at a Sept. 21 meeting of Fed policy makers, according to minutes of the meeting released today.
The Fed's Open Market Committee shifted to a neutral stance at a meeting on Aug. 17, abandoning its previous tilt in favor of raising interest rates to restrain inflation. 
 In deciding to keep interest rates steady at the September meeting, the Fed was responding to reports that showed inflation remained low after a bout of higher prices in January, February and April.
In its most recent report on inflation, the Government said consumer prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent in October, with increases of five-tenths or more in several major sectors.
At the September meeting, the Fed committee voted unanimously "to maintain the existing degree of pressure on reserve positions," the minutes said, citing a slower pace of consumer inflation and a decline in producer prices.
The minutes of each meeting are kept secret until after the committee holds its next meeting. The panel last met Tuesday, and analysts have speculated that the group again favored holding interest rates steady.
Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the House Banking Committee, wants the Fed to change procedures and announce the committee policy decisions shortly after each meeting.
According to the September minutes, panel members were confident that inflation would remain under control through the fall months. But beyond mid-November, they said, it was difficult to determine what moves they might have to take on interest rates.

HEADLINE: MORTGAGES;
Owners Offer Financing For Hard-to-Sell Homes

BYLINE: By Nick Ravo

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH housing sales have picked up and mortgages are available at enticingly low rates, vacation homes and hard-to-sell properties sometimes are easier to sell if their owners provide the financing. In part, that is because home lenders are reluctant to make new mortgages on some co-op apartments, condominiums and waterfront houses.
Caveats abound about seller-financing, sometimes referred to as taking back a mortgage or making a private mortgage. Real estate lawyers urge homeowners considering such a deal to assess the risks. 
 "First and foremost, the seller has to be sure that the buyer has the income stream to support the mortgage payments," said Angelo A. Mastrangelo, a lawyer in Rosedale, N.J. "They have to do the income and credit checks."
The seller must also make sure the sale price is in line with the appraised value of the home and the loan-to-value ratio is no more than 90 percent. "You want to be sure that the buyer puts some money in, so he doesn't take a walk," Mr. Mastrangelo said.
The buyer makes a down payment and monthly payments at an agreed-upon interest rate directly to the seller, not to a bank. Generally, the loan is for no more than five years, with the buyer expected to obtain other financing at the end of the term.
In many cases, financing a sale is an alternative to renting out a home that is difficult to sell. It works best for owners who do not need the proceeds to buy another home.
For some buyers, the technique is a way to buy a home when traditional lenders refuse to make a loan on the property. Other buyers may fail to qualify for a market-rate mortgage because they cannot make a sufficient down payment.
Sometimes, an owner finances all or part of a down payment, and the buyer takes out a traditional mortgage for the remainder. "It's supplemental," said William Selsberg, a lawyer in Stamford, Conn.
Mr. Mastrangelo warned that should a buyer default, the seller might have to take back the home and assume the payments.
He added that the buyer and the seller needed separate lawyers for the paperwork. Seller-financing, however, speeds up the closing process and eliminates expenses like points, the fees often charged by banks. Each point is equivalent to a percentage point of the loan.
Seller-financing was popular in the late 1970's and early 80's when high interest rates and house prices made mortgages difficult to get for some people. It was used less as interest rates declined.
In the early 90's, when homes became difficult to sell and banks were reluctant to lend, more sellers provided their own financing. With most lenders offering low rates today, seller-financing is generally provided for second homes and vacation homes.
"Someplace like Martha's Vineyard with a lot of properties on the market, lenders are leery," said Warren Lasko, executive vice president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, a Washington trade group.
Mr. Mastrangelo added, "If you own a vacation home, and you want to get top dollar for it, you should be prepared to use seller-financing because lenders are less likely to lend on those kind of properties."
Seller-financing is also common in the co-op market in New York, particularly for units of less than 600 square feet or for units in buildings that are less than 51 percent occupied by their owners. Many banks are reluctant to lend on these units, which have fallen in price over the last five years.
Similar problems plague condominiums in many areas. "There are lots of places where condos used to be worth a lot of money and have since taken a lot of decline in value," said Keith T. Gumbinger, an analyst for HSH Associates, a mortgage research company in Butler, N.J.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "A Seller's Checklist" gives tips for those considering offer of financing to prospective home buyers.

HEADLINE: Democracy Struggles in Africa;
Back to the Generals in Nigeria

 BODY:
The latest military coup in Nigeria is a cruel setback for democracy in Africa's most populous country and one of its richest. Thirty years ago Nigeria was among Africa's proudest political pioneers. Today it has become a stumbling laggard, mired in old-fashioned military rule while other parts of the continent move, however haltingly, toward democratic renewal.
The United States and Britain are right to condemn the coup and to consider further tightening the sanctions they imposed in June, when elections were abruptly canceled. Still, the main burden of continued struggle for democracy will fall on ordinary Nigerians who, like so many other Africans, are thoroughly fed up with strongman rule. 
 The old canard about Africans' supposed indifference to "Western-style" democratic systems has been disproved time and again in the past few years. From Benin to Zambia, people have demonstrated in the streets, walked off their jobs and otherwise risked their lives and livelihoods to demand multiparty elections.
Unfortunately, getting to election day has been only half the struggle. Many of the continent's dictatorships have tenaciously clung to power even after they have been voted out, or have sought to reimpose their grip by force before elected governments had a chance to consolidate themselves.
In June, Nigeria experienced the first kind of reversal. Gen. Ibrahim Babangida blocked the apparent electoral victory of Moshood Abiola. After massive protests, General Babangida stepped down and named a civilian, Ernest Shonekan, as Interim President. But Mr. Shonekan never convinced Nigerians he was more than a military puppet.
Now the civilian facade has been ripped away by Gen. Sani Abacha, a long-time military conspirator with a reputation for corruption. General Abacha's first moves ominously included abolishing all political parties, banning strikes and political gatherings and dissolving local civilian administrations.
Politics in Nigeria has long been troubled by jealousies among the country's three main ethnic groups -- the Hausa-Fulani from the north, the Yoruba from the southwest and the Ibo from the east. Mr. Abiola, a Yoruba, fell victim, in part, to these tensions. Although he won a national majority at the polls, he proved unacceptable to powerful sections of the Hausa-Fulani military elite.
But while electoral politics seemed headed toward a promising transcendence of ethnic divisions, the military now appears to have divided the nation anew. It has also divided itself, as generals fiercely compete for power and its profits. While these military rivalries may give civilians a new opening, they also heighten the risk of civil war.
Meanwhile, in one form or another, the struggle for democracy is sure to go on. History and continental trends are on the democrats' side. The United States should do all it can in their behalf.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Observer;
Easy On That Cucumber

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
When history honors the role played by victuals in the annals of the Great Republic, let it be recorded that it was the fruit-and-veggie bloc that saved the White House's bacon when the North American Free Trade Agreement was in jeopardy at the Capitol.
To say that the President bought a victory with oranges, tomatoes and cucumbers would be unkind to the Congressfolk of the garden and sunshine states. Mr. Clinton had predicted that many patriotic Congresspersons would bravely risk their political careers "to do what they think is right." 
 Justice compels us to concede that risking their political careers may have been what the fruit-and-veggie bloc were doing when they told the White House it could stick free trade in its ear unless tomatoes, cucumbers and Florida orange juice were protected from foreign competition.
The prima-facie evidence, however, suggests they were less interested in doing what was right for the republic than in doing what was right for businesses that flourish in their districts, or to put it in plainer English, for themselves.
Having been told for years by demographers and political analysts that the American farmer is as gone as the horse collar, I was astonished to learn from this event that it ain't so. The tomato farmer and the cucumber grower not only live, they also have power to make Congressmen force the President to excuse them from enjoying the blessings of free trade.
A cucumber lobby: Who would have guessed it? Could it have been founded by Representative J.J. (Jake) Pickle of Texas?
Not to be outdone in the grocery political competition, beef and wheat were also granted boons by the President. Representatives from wheat-producing areas and cattle zones had seemed strangely indifferent to statements that North American free trade would produce economic marvels.
Could it have been a rare case of Congressional unselfishness? Perhaps beef and wheat people were willing to sacrifice the benefits free trade would bring their constituents rather than vote against their colleagues in organized labor, who feared free trade would finish them off.
Not so, as it turned out. Beef and wheat were merely waiting for Mr. Clinton to assure them that if they would just vote for free trade he would help them avoid having to compete with other nations' freely traded wheat and beef.
And so the grocery coalition -- fruit and veg, beef and spaghetti -- was instrumental in giving Mr. Clinton his free-trade agreement. There is nothing remarkable about such bartering and buying of votes when a President wants something as desperately as Mr. Clinton wants the free-trade agreement.
In close-run fights the politician who holds out until the last moment often may walk away with so much Federal gravy that he will need a tank train to get it all out of Washington. The present fight, for instance, has been garnished with news that one Texas vote may cost the Treasury $1.4 billion for construction of airplanes the Pentagon doesn't want.
The public usually pays the final bill for these exercises, but an amazing exception occurred during the fight for the first Reagan tax cut in 1981. Then Democrats decided not to fight the big Reagan cuts; instead, they started competing with Republicans to make them even bigger.
Events rarely turn out so happily for the public, though Mr. Clinton keeps assuring us that we will all bless the day free trade comes to North America. Organized labor's disagreement is based on its rust-belt experience with industries that go abroad for cheap labor, leaving ruin and unemployment behind.
Mr. Clinton's prediction that North American free trade will invigorate the economy is the only reason he has given labor to love him. Concessions went to the grocery bloc, but not to the rust belt. Ironically, those concessions may result in raising grocery prices slightly for struggling rust-belt workers before the great economic revival begins.
After showing he can get along without Jesse Jackson, the President has now shown he can get along without organized labor. With this rough treatment of old populist elements of the Democratic Party, those who think something new is in the wind now hail him as "a new Democrat." What is that? Seems a little like an old Republican.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Westernizers, Statists and Bolsheviks

BYLINE: By Celestine Bohlen; Celestine Bohlen is a correspondent in the Moscow bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:

THE RISE OF RUSSIA AND THE FALL OF THE SOVIET EMPIRE
By John B. Dunlop.
360 pp. Princeton, N.J.:
Princeton University Press. $29.95. 
 IT has been only two years and a few months since President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian republic and his band of loyal democrats defied a coup d'etat, bringing down the Communist Party and, in due course, the Soviet state. Given the extraordinary speed of events in Russia these days, all that seems like old history now. The democrats, once the plucky underdogs, have since become the country's rulers, fallible, corruptible and given to falling out among themselves in spectacular fashion. Mr. Yeltsin, who stood atop a tank in defiance of the hard-line Communists, has now used tanks to finish off his opponents -- all of them former allies in the Russian Parliament that in May 1990 first elected him to lead the then-Soviet republic.
In short, the Russian story has grown more complicated in the last few years, a far cry from the battles of white hats and black hats that had the world riveted in the climactic years 1986-91. Back then, there was a sense -- conveyed in John B. Dunlop's detailed account of the period, "The Rise of Russia and the Fall of the Soviet Empire" -- that once the democrats prevailed, Russia would be free to achieve the twin goals of the anti-Communist movement, democracy and a market economy.
Instead, two years later, the country is still groping its way toward those goals, dodging obstacles that then were only faint outlines on the horizon. By early 1993, Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, quoted by Mr. Dunlop in his epilogue, was writing: "A new age has clearly begun, both for Russia and for the whole world. Russia lies utterly ravaged and poisoned; its people are in a state of unprecedented humiliation, and are on the brink of perishing physically, perhaps even biologically."
Mr. Dunlop, a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace, tells the story of how Mr. Yeltsin skillfully played the "Russian card" in his struggle against Mikhail S. Gorbachev, harnessing his ambitions to the rise of a new Russia while avoiding the nasty trap of Russian nationalism. Mr. Dunlop describes as well the debates over Russia's confused national identity among "Westernizers" (who want Russia to be a "normal" country and join the "civilized" world), statists (who argue that Russia should be more assertive about upholding its unique historical and geographical interests) and hard-core nationalist Bolsheviks (who yearn for a return of the Soviet empire, recast as Great Russia).
These portraits -- some of them inevitably outdated -- are interspersed with an exhaustive account of Russia's recent history, including a close and provocative look at the August 1991 coup. It is Mr. Dunlop's contention that the coup almost succeeded -- and that, in fact, the storming of the White House, or Parliament building, by troops under the command of hard-line Communists had actually begun in the early morning hours of Aug. 21. The author also raises perplexing questions about Mr. Gorbachev's role in the coup, particularly on the final day when the plotters flew down to the Crimea to meet him at his holiday dacha.
But for all the details, there is a strange flatness about the tale as Mr. Dunlop tells it. For one thing, his sources are almost all secondary. Except for two trips to the Soviet Union, one in 1987 and another in 1989, and occasional conversations with leading Russian political figures when they traveled to the West, Mr. Dunlop relies on the Russian (and to some extent the Western) press for his reporting.
Those sources are certainly ample -- and with his scholar's instinct, Mr. Dunlop makes good use of them. But without an author's own eyes and ears to serve as a guide, the result is in places an awkward, stiff and even random compendium of useful facts, rather than an interpretive narrative that could advance our understanding of the vast changes taking place in Russia.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
Out of Control

BYLINE: By William Safire

 BODY:
Under a cartoon of a man in underpants with a drink in hand racing along a tropical beach, The Economist headlined, "Don't you just love being out of control?" The cartoon character in the London-based magazine represented the recently privatized British utilities, freed from government's heavy hand, but the phrase is the latest extension of the psychological cliche of the year.
To be in control, as in "As of now, I am in control here in the White House," a phrase used in 1981 by Secretary of State Alexander Haig when Ronald Reagan was wounded, is to be boss. To have a blaze under control is what every firefighter hopes to announce. To be beyond control, as in "circumstances beyond my individual control," was a cop-out first used by Mr. Micawber in Charles Dickens's novel "David Copperfield." But to be out of control is to be damnably difficult in every field of endeavor. 
 Students are susceptible: "The campus is out of control," declared a Republican Assemblyman in 1969, as students rioted at the Berkeley campus of the University of California. Workers, too: a year later, the railroad union leader William Winpisinger testified that workers were "running right on the ragged edge of being out of control." And deficits lend themselves to the phrase: Representative Barber B. Conable Jr. of New York worried in 1981 about "keeping the budget deficit from getting out of control." A copywriter for Hefty lawn bags noted the phrase's power: "Lawn out of control? Better get a Hefty."
The familiar phrase lends itself to use as a compound modifier: An editorial in The New York Times in 1990 commented on a bill by the Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, "to put a lid on out-of-control campaign spending." In a recent TV Guide profile of the actress Loni Anderson, its writer, Mary Murphy, asked, "What about the stories branding Loni as a mercenary, an out-of-control shopper?" (A friend denied that, but only made things worse with "Once we went shopping for 12 hours and came back with nothing.")
The phrase was popularized by psychiatry. "The ego is in charge of feelings, actions and perceptions," explains Dr. E. Michael Ehlers of Bethesda, Md. "Out of control refers to any sort of ego failure. The phrase cuts across many types of disorders, from explosive behavior in psychotic disorders to compulsions and hysteria. The term probably predates psychiatry, but the use of ego functioning in relation to control dates from the late 1800's, the beginning of modern psychiatry."
Has the time come for this weary phrase to be consigned to the cemetery of stereotype? Ordinarily that order would issue from this department, but I don't want to be accused of being a control freak.
 
Pun Jab
 "Miss Bhutto has Punjab in her grasp, but Sind remains a problem." So goes a line farther back in The Economist, which I am reading because it has a new editor and is going through a news-magazine identity crisis, much as Time is doing here. (If it gets out of control, chaps, see Dr. Ehlers.)
Sind is the home province of Benazir Bhutto, who recently regained power in Pakistan. Though married and a mother, she is known by her maiden name, as befits the daughter of a slain Prime Minister, which is why The Economist calls her "Miss" Bhutto. The New York Times uses "Ms." Bhutto; at least it doesn't assert that she is single.
It's good to see Sind back in the news because it recalls the play on words that so delighted diplomats and linguists of a previous century.
Sir Charles James Napier was the British general sent to quell agitation in India in the early 1840's, and in 1843 -- some say without imperial orders -- moved to take the province of Sind, now part of Pakistan. Nervous diplomats in Westminster awaited the results of the battle of Hyderabad, key to the province. Then came the telegraphed message from Napier: the single Latin word peccavi. The Foreign Office broke into cheers because a knowledge of Latin was the mark of a good education in those days, and because Catholic rites used that word from the penitent seeking absolution from the confessor. Peccavi means "I have sinned."
Napier's message meant, of course, that he had taken the province of Sind. The historical scholar Mark Burnyeat of New York suggested that the general was sending yet another message: because he proceeded on his own initiative, risking overextension of his logistical lines, Napier was both boasting of his victory and mock-apologizing for going beyond his orders with "I have sinned."
You don't get generals using multilingual puns in their messages like that these days.
 
The Fuzz and The Wuzz
 Waking up the sleepy audience at the Radio-Television News Directors Association, Dan Rather of CBS lit into the "Hollywoodization" of news.
"Thoughtfully written analysis is out, 'live pops' are in," he said. (A live pop, also known as a live stand-up, refers to the ad-libbing that a broadcast correspondent in the field does on camera after a news anchor introduces the story. When the anchor says, "Now we're going to Charles, who's standing live in the dark where something happened three hours ago, but you can't see it now," the live pop is what Charles has to ad-lib because he hasn't come back to the studio to write his stand-up.)
Mr. Rather continued: "Hire lookers, not writers. Do powder puff, not probing, interviews. Stay away from controversial subjects. Kiss [vulgarism], move with the mass [rhymes with vulgarism], and for heaven and the ratings' sake don't make anybody mad. . . . Make nice, not news."
The pop that enlivened his speech to slanguists was Rather's complaint that "They've got us putting more fuzz and wuzz on the air." I was familiar with fuzz, defined in Godfrey Irwin's 1931 "American Tramp and Underworld Slang" as "a detective; a prison guard or turnkey. Here it is likely that 'fuzz' was originally 'fuss,' one hard to please or over-particular." But what about wuzz? Was this similarly derived from wuss? Patricia Ireland, president of the National Organization for Women, in commenting a few months ago about Hillary Clinton jokes, told The Boston Globe, "The overall theme is one of Bill Clinton being a wuss." She probably used this term as if it were synonymous with wimp, unaware of the etymology of wuss as rhyming slang meaning "like a woman" in a derogatory sense.
The CBS co-anchor, obviously drawn to rhyme in oratory, clarified his catchy phrase in a reply to a query from this department. " 'Fuzz and wuzz' refers to police ('fuzz') and dead bodies (was -- 'wuzz')." In slang, the past tense lives.

HEADLINE: SUNDAY VIEW;
Smashing America's Favorite Myths

BYLINE: By David Richards

 BODY:
Taking the exalted view of America, Lincoln spoke at Gettysburg of "a new nation, conceived in liberty and dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal." The playwright Robert Schenkkan, casting his sights lower, sees a country born of greed and deceit and single-mindedly devoted to the notion that all men are fleeceable. In "The Kentucky Cycle," which is finally getting a Broadway hearing more than a year after winning the 1992 Pulitzer Prize for drama, he tallies the costs of our national duplicity.
They are enormous. 
 Everything about this two-part, six-hour chronicle (at the Royale Theater) is outsized, in fact. Made up of nine one-act plays set in Eastern Kentucky, the work begins in 1775 when the pristine forest still belonged to the Indians and a few double-dealing fur traders. Then, in 30- and 40-year leaps, it finds its way down to 1975, by which point the land, not to mention its inhabitants, has been pillaged, raped and left for dead.
Size, of course, is no measure of excellence, only size. Still, if "The Kentucky Cycle" falls short of great playwriting, it qualifies as a vigorous piece of popular storytelling, filled with the kinds of surprises, reversals and sudden revelations that were standard fare in the theater when the theater made a point of reaching out to a broad range of customers.
The 21-member cast, headed by Stacy Keach, plays some six dozen characters -- many of them belonging to three feuding families who sink roots in the area and quickly slip into the patterns of skulduggery and retribution that will prevail for centuries. Mr. Keach, in a gruff and disheveled mode, makes his first appearance, minutes after the lights come up, as Michael Rowen, a volatile Irishman eager to forget his years as an indentured servant and grab some land of his own, whatever the consequences.
Later, he shows up as Michael's great-grandson Jed, a dirt-poor farmer who thinks he's making a killing when he sells the mining rights to the family homestead for $1 an acre. Later still, he's Michael's great-great-great-grandson Joshua, a local official of the United Mine Workers, quick to compromise until a mine shaft collapses and he understands that compromise can be deadly business.
All the cast members, moreover, are engaged in similar stretching exercises. As a major character ages, the role is apt to pass from one actor to the next -- which also suggests the daunting logistics of this endeavor. Nonetheless, Mr. Schenkkan and his director, Warner Shook, back off from little. The production depicts -- convincingly, too -- Civil War skirmishes, underground explosions, strikers coming under machine-gun fire from a passing train, plus slaughter in sundry other forms. Despite the title, "The Kentucky Cycle" is clearly meant to be more than the account of one region's woes. What happens in Appalachia, the playwright implies, is what has happened all across this avaricious country, wherever opportunity has struck and men have struck out at one another. The old myths about the heroic forging of America are being systematically dismantled, replaced by a panorama of rampant self-interest.
Although acted on a stark wooden stage with minimal scenery by Michael Olich -- a rough-hewn pediment marking a home, a square of gravel serving as a forgotten burial ground -- the enterprise often has the feel of a saga spun around campfire embers. (When the actors are not participating in the action, they are, you'll notice, sitting on benches at the sidelines, listening.) No spectator need feel left out.
A few of Mr. Schenkkan's characters go beyond types. Mary Anne Rowen Jackson, a 20th-century miner's wife whom poverty has robbed of everything but her pride, is the most memorable, especially as portrayed with uninflected strength and tight-lipped astringency by Jeanne Paulsen. Her transformation into a union leader, beating saucepans together with controlled fury and rallying the cowardly townsfolk to what has been, up to then, a lost cause, is one of the thrilling highlights of the play's second half.
MOSTLY, THOUGH, MR. Schenkkan relies upon figures of lesser dimensions -- a son (Scott MacDonald) who, under the veneer of oafishness, nurtures patricidal passions; a female slave (Gail Grate) who harbors a deep dark family secret; a speculator (Gregory Itzin) profiting from the economic chaos following the War of 1812 by buying up land and reducing its former owners to groveling sharecroppers.
The good guy/bad guy polarities of melodrama govern much of "The Kentucky Cycle," even if the vast majority of characters are schemers and the good guys don't arrive on the scene until the 20th century. In the words of one character, principles are only "one of those sweet nothin's the big boys whisper in your ear while they pull your pants down." The Civil War is presented as just another opportunity to settle personal vendettas or, in the case of William Clark Quantrill (Randy Oglesby), the Confederate raider, to kill for the mad thrill of killing. The bad guys, however, hide their villainy well while Mr. Schenkkan prepares his coups de theatre. Then, a knife glints in the light or the sharp click of a rifle being cocked disrupts the silence, and baseness reveals its dastardly features.
The effects are calculated. But the dramaturgical hammering and sawing that can make "The Kentucky Cycle" seem old-fashioned are also what make it stageworthy. Ambiguity, indecision, spiritual paralysis -- the hallmarks of much contemporary drama -- are in scant evidence. Some of the characters may share their portent-filled dreams directly with the audience and the playwright has written a lovely speech recollecting the scarlet azaleas, "the spark what lights the fuse for spring," that once exploded across the desolate mountainside. (Ms. Paulsen delivers it with a matter-of-factness that only enhances the poetry.)
On the whole, though, "The Kentucky Cycle" is the least ruminative of plays. Like the young country itself, it itches to get on with things and does so in a dominolike tumble of events.
Yet when I say "least ruminative," that is only partially true. Mr. Schenkkan does have a concern besides the despoliation of America. Even as he himself is undertaking a mammoth act of storytelling, he lets us know that he is leery of stories and their power to cajole.
In the best of the cycle's nine segments, "Tall Tales," which is set in 1890, a roving storyteller by the name of J. T. Wells (Mr. Itzin again) wheedles his way into the Rowen house, mesmerizes the daughter with his worldliness (he's been to New York City) and, between shots of corn likker from a Mason jar, charms her parents with the homeliness of his yarns. The stories, of course, are subterfuge. Wells is really an advance man for Standard Oil, which is hungry for coal. The Rowens, taken in, sign an agreement that will eventually turn their cherished farm into a slag heap.
More than chicanery is involved. Throughout "The Kentucky Cycle," family stories passed down from one generation to the next are altered and embellished with each recounting. Self-interest becomes altruism, cruelty ends up as courage. The truth is lost in the process. To the extent that we, too, are taken in by our treasured historical myths, Mr. Schenkkan believes, we set the country itself up for a dangerous fall.
The immediate appeal of "The Kentucky Cycle," however, is its galloping narrative, and the production comes stripped for action. Over and over again, the crude raked stage and the platforms to either side are transformed by Peter Maradudin's lighting and James Ragland's sound effects, which evoke, impressionistically, a myriad of rustic locales. Mr. Maradudin, in particular, provides primeval sunshine, moon-flecked shadows and just about every degree of illumination in between, and deserves the theatrical equivalent of combat pay. Frances Kenny, a talented costumer, limits her palette to browns, blacks, dirty whites, blood reds and a single yellow accent, the ridiculous plume on the hat of a Confederate dandy. The overall impression of monumental simplicity is misleading; sophisticated artists are at work.
Mr. Shook is after a similar simplicity from his actors -- no fuss, no bother -- and generally he gets it. Everyone operates out of recognizable motives, even if it sometimes takes awhile for the true motive to surface. The emotions on display may be uncomplicated but they are big.
Putting his dapper side on hold, Mr. Keach gives a series of scrappy, vividly chiseled performances. In the cycle's climax, he pours the accumulated frustration and rage of the preceding six hours into a single cry to a lone wolf on a far hill, urging the endangered beast to run for its life. The rousing alarm is, curiously, also a bellow of hope.
As a rule, the actors demonstrate their range not so much within a given part but by moving persuasively from one part to another. Mr. Itzin's affableness, as Standard Oil's front man, for example, proves all the more beguiling for the buried rancor he has shown earlier as that implacable speculator. Here, the accomplished Tuck Milligan is a barefoot boy with cheek, there, a middle-aged Jewish labor organizer with Job's patience. Some of the doubling and tripling only the program confirms for sure. In a work about trickery, you could say the actors are perpetrating gleeful deceptions of their own.
The gusto they bring to the assignment is, I suspect, not just the natural expression of characters caught up in the tumult of changing eras. It is also the gut response of unabashed troupers who relish the juicy melodrama they've been handed and can't wait to jump in.
That may be why, for all the villainy it records, there is ultimately something childlike about "The Kentucky Cycle." The company sits us down, fixes us in the eye and then, without apology or hesitation, dares to say, "Once upon a treacherous time . . ."

(Joan Marcus/"The Kentucky Cycle")(pg. 5); Stacy Keach, top, and Tuck Milligan in "The Kentucky Cycle" -- Uabashed troupers. (Joan Marcus/"The Kentucky Cycle")(pg. 14)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Avalon (Nee Trammell Crow) Runs Into Opposition

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
AVALON PROPERTIES, known until last Thursday as a Trammell Crow regional partnership, is a $500 million company with 7,000 rental apartments in 22 East Coast complexes from Virginia to the Canadian border. Since 1986 it has built 2,739 of them in Connecticut -- in Manchester, Middletown, Hamden, Shelton and Stamford.
On Thursday Avalon became a Real Estate Investment Trust, or REIT. It continues to occupy its New Canaan offices as headquarters of the northeast region, but is newly listed on the New York Stock Exchange as Avalon Properties. 
 A REIT is an investment vehicle for real-estate ownership that pays no Federal corporate income tax and, in most states, no state income tax either. It typically distributes nearly all its income, derived primarily from rents, to shareholders. It can manage property as well as own it or lend to it, and can also develop property. But if it sells property there are unfavorable tax consequences.
Avalon Properties in Connecticut is one of two former Trammell Crow partnerships that have become REITs. The other, Gables Residential of Atlanta, is not yet listed on the Exchange but soon will be. Both wanted to go public to be able to raise money through stock offerings and mutual funds because banks and traditional lenders had dried up.
Neither is now connected to the Dallas-based Trammell Crow, which preferred to remain a private construction and real estate management company.
"We have contracted for land accommodating 3,200 more units in the Northeast," said Samuel B. Fuller, Avalon's vice president. "About 1,200 will be in Connecticut."
The company concentrates solely on rentals, and its success has been considerable even through the recession. The attractively priced, low-rise New England village-style complexes tend to move swiftly through municipal-approval procedures, while prospective tenants appear at the sales offices as early as ground-breaking.
But warm receptions around the state have not been duplicated in the wealthy towns of southern Fairfield County, where Avalon has several proposals. In part, the company believes that resistance is based on a misunderstanding of "affordable" housing.
Avalon uses a state program designed to promote housing so described by allowing developers higher density in return for 20-year deed restrictions on 20 percent of their units. These must be offered at rents fixed by a state formula based on statistics from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development.
"What most people don't understand is that the affordable units are for people who pay rents upward of $1,000, not for people on welfare," said Mr. Fuller.
After a year of negotiations with New Canaan, Avalon's 104-unit project with 15,000 square feet of office and retail space on Elm Street was rejected earlier this year. The developer sued in Superior Court, and a hearing is expected to be scheduled next month. The dispute involves opposing views of parking and height regulations and a 14- by 400-foot strip along Elm Street that the town says it owns and Avalon says it does not.
IN New Canaan, and in Darien, where 35 acres have been optioned by the company but no plans have been submitted, the median income is $73,400, according to H.U.D. Avalon's three-bedroom units in New Canaan would rent for a maximum of $1,468, or the same as a market-rate one-bedroom unit. Maximum rents are established by taking 80 percent of the median income, then 30 percent of the 80 percent. Variations are possible under the formula depending on family size and the market.
"We might have to charge less," said Mr. Fuller.
In Wilton, the Planning and Zoning Commission approved Avalon's requested zone change, clearing the way for a 120-unit project on 12 acres. But Nancy Burton, a lawyer representing the owner of an abutting property, filed an appeal last month in Stamford Superior Court claiming that the site is in a flood zone of the Norwalk River and inappropriate for high-density development.
Rents in Wilton, under the formula, would be, for example, $1,414 a month for a family of four in a three-bedroom unit.
The Town of Trumbull rejected Avalon's application for 600 units in 1992, whereupon Trammell Crow sued the Planning and Zoning Commission. Last January Trumbull was ordered by the court to negotiate a settlement, resulting in a total of 340 units to be built on the 38-acre site in the spring of 1994.
"It's the first multifamily rental complex in town," said Joan Gruce, Planning and Zoning Administrator. "Nobody wants it, but we have no choice."
Trumbull's median income of $50,200 establishes a maximum rent of $1,004.
In its litigation, the developer relied on the 1989 state Housing Appeals Law, which puts the burden of proof on a town to show that a development in which 20 percent of its units are "affordable" would be injurious to the community. Before 1989 the developer had to prove to the planning and zoning commission that a project was within regulations or would do no harm if zoning concessions were granted.
"There is a concentration of cases in Fairfield County because that's where the least amount of affordable housing exists in the state," said Timothy Hollister, Avalon's lawyer in Hartford.
WHILE Stamford is part of Fairfield County's Gold Coast, it is exempt from the Housing Appeals Law because it has more than the 10 percent minimum of affordable housing that the state mandates for all 169 towns. In 1985, as part of a master-plan study, Stamford determined that it needed 2,500 downtown apartments in all price ranges, but "because of the recession only about a fifth of that number was built," said Robin Stein, acting Director of Planning.
In 1989 Avalon built Town Glen near the city center, with 215 garden apartments surrounding a landscaped court and swimming pool. Like most Trammell Crow properties it has a fitness room, racquetball court, clubhouse, underground parking, security and in-house management. Each apartment is fully applianced, carpeted and painted or wallpapered, and has a private deck. Rents range from the high $900's for one bedroom to $1,600 for two bedrooms and loft.
Avalon's newest venture is Town Grove, a 382-unit complex similar to Town Glen, on a 4-acre site in downtown Stamford. The land is held in foreclosure by a division of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. "We have it under contract and will purchase it when the city approves a zone change," said Mr. Fuller. That could happen within the next few months. Rents would be be similar to those at Town Glen.
The company's narrow focus on rentals makes sense to John Knight, professor of finance and real estate at the University of Connecticut, who believes that more people are renting and fewer are buying homes in spite of current sales spurred by low interest rates and prices.
"There are major contributing trends," he said. "One is the recognition that people recognize that they cannot assume, as they did for decades, that prices will go up indefinitely, and by a predictable percentage.
"Then there is the labor market. People don't stay in one job for 30 years any more, nor in one place, except perhaps for doctors, lawyers, real estate brokers and other regionally based professionals. While some people will always be homeowners, globally competitive markets that are evolving don't provide job security."
Avalon targets exactly the sort of transitional population that Professor Knight cites, its tenants typically turning over every three years, and its units constantly at or near 100 percent occupied.

HEADLINE: Studio Owners Struggle to Find Buyers

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
LORI KOCH, a lawyer, is one of the innumerable New Yorkers trapped in a studio that has become a financial straitjacket. Her 570-square-foot apartment, which she bought in 1989, is in a doorman condominium at 295 Greenwich Street at the corner of Chambers Street on the southwestern edge of TriBeCa, a few blocks north of the World Financial Center.
Like many young professionals in the 80's, Ms. Koch dearly wanted to own real estate. She paid well for it, too. Her studio cost $175,000. It's now worth about $90,000 -- if she could find a buyer who could get a mortgage. And while similar apartments in her building are renting for about $1,000 a month, her own monthly costs for carrying her mortgage and paying taxes and monthly fees for building operations total about $1,900. 
 "It's a nightmare," said Ms. Koch, who is 29 years old. "I can't sell it. I can't move. And I can't rent it for anything near my carrying costs."
Since the high point of the real estate boom in the middle 80's, sale prices for studios have plummeted by as much as 60 percent, leading the more moderate decline in prices of co-ops and condominiums generally.
Compounding the problems of those who are trying to sell is the stance of banks, which are reluctant to give loans on smaller studio apartments or on units in buildings that are not primarily occupied by tenant-owners. And potential buyers who might once have had to settle for studios now find that the prices of one-bedroom apartments are within reach.
The average price per room of a co-op studio in Manhattan, which was $66,984 for 1989, had fallen 41.7 percent, to $39,080, as of Aug. 31, according to a survey by Douglas Elliman Real Estate in Manhattan. In real estate surveys, co-op studios are generally considered to have two to two and a half rooms.
For condominiums, prices fell 26.7 percent, to $252 a square foot, as of Aug. 31, from $344 a square foot for 1989, according to the Douglas Elliman report.
A similar situation prevails elsewhere in New York City and in suburban communities, brokers report. "The values are just not there anymore for studios," said Margaret S. Scott, president of Mortgage Advisory Services, a mortgage broker in Manhattan. "There are too many of them."
When the more hard-pressed owners seek out advice on what to do, they are often advised to make an effort to restructure their debt, preferably by banding together with others in the building who have similar problems.
"I don't think there is an alternative to a workout except for the bankruptcy option, but only if you are really in the hole," said Edward T. Braverman, a real estate lawyer in Manhattan.
FOR those in not quite such dire straits, Mr. Braverman suggested cutting losses as quickly as possible. "In this kind of market, the best way to get your money back is to buy something else of a much better quality and when the market rebounds you make back more of your loss than you would have by holding on to something that was a bad deal in the first place," he said.
"The studios were such a bad deal," he added. "There is such a large volume in the city and the prices are not going to increase as quickly or to the same extent as larger apartments."
Some studio owners have turned their one-room units into more-marketable one-bedroom apartments by adding a wall or two. Owners should be aware, though, that in most cases structural alterations cannot be made without the approval of the co-op board or condominium association.
Co-op boards could even be cited for violations because the building may no longer comply with its certificate of occupancy as the number of rooms on that floor would have changed.
The board would also want to make sure that the alterations were safe and would not damage neighboring apartments or those above or below.
The future looked rosier when the purchases were initially made. Young buyers thought of themselves as taking the traditional first step on the ladder of homeownership. Other buyers were perhaps older and wealthier suburbanites, purchasing a Manhattan pied-a-terre for intermittent use. Still others were corporations buying for use by personnel traveling through New York, or investors planning to rent apartments out. Many of these buyers, under no pressure to sell, are presumably holding on and waiting for an eventual market upturn.
In the present market, however, the desirability of studios for buyers is hurt by what economists and real estate brokers call "the substitution effect."
Alan Rogers, a managing partner at Douglas Elliman, said that many first-time buyers today were moving into one-bedroom apartments instead of studios. "It doesn't make much sense to buy a studio when you can get a one-bedroom for $100,000 to $200,000," he said. "Why go for one less room? There is a great value in one-bedroom apartments today, especially with low interest rates. For an extra $30,000, why not buy a one-bedroom?"
Sales, particularly those in some co-op buildings, are also being hurt by high monthly maintenance payments required by some co-ops, and by the refusal of lenders to finance properties smaller than 600 square feet or those in buildings with owner-occupancy rates below 51 percent.
Lenders are also increasingly reluctant to finance apartments in walk-ups and buildings where there are fewer than 10 units. Potential difficulty in selling the units is the chief reason.
"There are loans that some lenders just won't touch," Ms. Scott said. "Studios are increasingly in that category. As a result, borrowers who want to buy them are really having a difficult time finding loans."
Though prices for studio apartments in both co-ops and condominiums have been heading down, the gap in relative value between the two seems to be widening, with the studio-co-ops losing ground. In a survey conducted by the Halstead Property Company in Manhattan in the first quarter of 1991, the average condominium studio sold for 30 percent more than a co-op studio. In the first quarter of 1993, the average condominium studio sold for 92 percent more.
Clark Halstead, managing partner of Halstead, attributed the price difference to the underlying building mortgages that are typical in co-ops. The actual cost of a co-op is the purchase price for the shares plus a pro rata share of the underlying debt. Condominiums, however, do not have underlying mortgages, so the entire cost of a unit resides in the purchase price.
Mr. Halstead said that, generally, underlying debt added about 20 to 25 percent to the price of a co-op. This accounts for the higher cost of condominiums, but not for the growing spread in prices, particularly among studios. He said that much of the appeal of condominium over co-op studios lay in the ability to sell or rent them without board approval.
Besides screening prospective buyers, many co-op boards also have policies that either forbid subtenants or allow them for only one or two years.
ULTIMATELY, Mr. Halstead said, this means that in a declining market for sales and a rising market for rentals, condominium studio owners are able to rent. Co-op studio owners, on the other hand, are forced to sell, often for prices much below the purchase price; to remain in their unit or to move out and continue paying the maintenance.
"Co-ops lost more value in the down cycle than condos," Mr. Halstead said. "Condos are a better-grade investment. This is particularly apparent in the studio and one-bedroom units, which were the hardest hit in the recession."
Barbara Braderman is one of the many New Yorkers who own a studio co-op and can rent their units for no longer than two years. Her 600-square-foot unit at 363 East 76th Street is being offered for sale at $85,000. She estimated it was worth about $110,000 in the mid-80's.
"I had an offer two years ago for $86,000," she said. "But things have gotten worse since then. I'm sure I won't get $85,000."
Ms. Braderman currently lives in her studio and wants to sell because the bank where she works as a computer systems manager is expected to cut its workforce soon and she plans to leave the area if she loses her position.
"I've had a few people look, but they say the price is too high," she said. She would not say what she paid for it.
Betsy Tuft is also having trouble selling her 625-square-foot alcove studio on East 85th Street near the East River. . It is being offered at $75,000; the maintenance is $528 a month. "People look, but no call-backs," she said.
Ms. Tuft won't say what she paid for her unit in 1980; it was an insider price. She did say, though, that she could have sold it for about $140,000 in the late 80's. So she lives in another unit in the buildin and has been renting out the alcove studio unit. On Dec. 1, however, her tenant moves out and, under the rules of her co-op, she will no longer be able to rent it, but she will be liable for the monthly maintenance.
She said that two units in her building had been foreclosed because the owners had been unable to sell them and were barred from renting them out for longer than two years. "I'll manage," she said. "I'll do the best I can. Maybe I'll lower the price."
Renee Jaffess of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., is in a similar situation. For the last year she has been been renting out a 560-square-foot studio in a doorman building at 251 East 51st Street and Second Avenue in Manhattan. She bought the unit in 1976. Like Ms. Tuft, she will not disclose how much she paid for the unit, but she estimates it was worth as much as $140,000 in the mid-80's. The maintenance is $521.11.
She is now offering it for $65,000 and is considering a woman's bid of $58,000. The woman "is concerned about the maintenance," Ms. Jaffess said. "She is concerned about its going up."
Ms. Jaffess's co-op board has let her to rent out the unit for the last year and has refused an extension. "They just wouldn't," she said.
The experience has soured Ms. Jaffess on the New York real estate market. "I would never buy an apartment again in Manhattan," she said.
THE situation could be worse. Ms. Koch, the owner of the TriBeCa studio, not only can't sell her unit or rent it out for any amount close to her monthly costs, but she also has a balloon mortgage with the sponsor that requires her to refinance soon and make a $35,000 payment; she made only a $5,000 downpayment in 1989.
With the apartment now worth about $85,000 less than the outstanding mortgage, many owners might think twice about making a $35,000 down payment to keep the apartment. Ms. Koch, though, is willing. She just doesn't have the $35,000.
"Because of the economy, my salary hasn't increased the way I thought it would," she said.
Ms. Koch has asked to have the debt restructured or renegotiated, but the sponsor has declined and is threatening foreclosure. In similar cases, a homeowner would consider allowing a foreclosure to go forward or even filing for bankruptcy protection. Ms. Koch's troubles are compounded, though, by the fact that her sister, also a homeowner, is a co-signer on her mortgage.
"No one ever thought things would turn out like this," Ms. Koch said.
But a housing market is rarely bereft of buyers entirely, and Manhattan studios often have the advantage of highly desirable locations.
One such buyer recently was Eleonora Minkovsky, an insurance executive from Philadelphia. She paid all cash for a 600-square-foot alcove studio in a doorman building at 167 East 67th Street for $75,000; the maintenance is $424. Ms. Minkovsky's daughter, Julia, plans to live in the studio while participating in an executive training program at Bloomingdale's.
It was cheaper to buy than to rent a comparable apartment, Ms. Minkovsky said. "Rents in that neighborhood were $1,100 to $1,300 a month," she said.
The possibility of not being able to sell or rent out the unit doesn't trouble her, either. "People are afraid that they won't be able to sell," she said. "But we decided to ignore that. In two or three years, we'll see what happens."

HEADLINE: Habitats/TriBeCa Rowhouses;
A Sale on Harrison St.

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON

 BODY:
THEY'VE always looked incongruous -- stalwart foes of relentless progress, dwarfed by the massive Independence Plaza housing complex in TriBeCa.
A row of fine Federal town houses on Harrison Street, off Greenwich Street, the nine two-and-a-half story houses look new -- almost like Williamsburgh reproductions. 
 For the first time since they were gutted and auctioned by the city in the late 70's, one of them is to be resold. It is the smallest in the dormered row, the corner house at 25 Harrison.
In 1976, the city embarked on what one reporter called "the first, and probably the last" venture of its kind. While six of these late-18th- and early-19th-century houses would remain in the midst of the urban renewal area, three others would be moved to form an enclave in the midst of the new moderate-income high-rise housing development.
The houses were vacant and abandoned. Some had been used as warehouses. The little brick house with the beaded white clapboard side was moved from 314 Washington Street and put on the corner, next to two others that had been moved from sites nearby.
Judging from news reports, the city's action was controversial, mainly because of the cost: $600,000 to restore the exteriors of the nine houses and $250,000 to move three from sites farther down Washington Street. They then were sold to private citizens at $35,000 to $72,000 each.
At the time, Roger Starr, the administrator of the city's housing agency, then known as the Housing and Development Administration, said that without money from Federal, state and city governments "these wonderful old buildings would have remained . . . deteriorated, dusty, imperfectly adapted to incongruous commercial uses, and waiting only for an upturn in land values to crumble under the hammer of a land auctioneer."
Those first homeowners were pioneers. The area -- not yet known generally as TriBeCa -- was bleak at night, not the thriving neighborhood of loft residences it has become.
The new owners had to deal with structures that were little more than brick shells. There were no interior partitions, and no plumbing or wiring. Barton Fleishman, who bought the largest of the houses for $72,000, said the other day that he eventually spent about $200,000 to make it livable.
Randolph Winchester King Jr., the lawyer who started trying to buy the small house on the corner in December 1976 and finally succeeded in 1978, paid $48,000 for his shell. He calls his first year of renovations "the Year of Living Dangerously."
He put the house on the market last January. The prospective buyer, Barrie Mandel, a real estate agent, said that Mr. King had originally asked $850,000.
As a broker, Ms. Mandel showed the house to customers but wanted to buy it herself. She and her husband, Dr. Harvey Schneier, an internist, and their three children were renting in the same row, two houses down.
"I said to the broker when the house comes down to the low fives I'll buy it," said Ms. Mandel. "The broker said 'Yeah, you and the rest of the world.' But he called me and told me when the house was reduced to $595,000." She brought her husband to look at it. They now have a contract to pay $535,000.
In the back, a bluestone patio leads into a private open garden, punctuated by rose arbors and boxwood hedges. In the back of 25 Harrison is a large crabapple tree whose white flowers blanket the bluestone in spring and whose hard little red fruits crush up against the house's small paned windows in autumn.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Town house at 25 Harrison Street, in contract at $535,000. (Rachel Cobb for The New York Times)
