HEADLINE: A Leader's Lessons From Adversity Unite Town and Gown

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN

 BODY:
THE president of Eastern Connecticut State University, David G. Carter, roams about the campus greeting students by name, usually accompanied by a little personal message or friendly banter.
"Did you ever clean up that spot on the carpet in your room? I'll drop some 'Miracle Clean' off and you can get to it." "You been hitting the books this week? Yeah, sure." 
 His ability to couple students' names with their dormitories, interests, even specific grades, is an art he honed in his childhood, he explained, except then he was etching numbers into his memory on a daily basis.
 
Delinquency and Hustling in Early Years
 He was running numbers, as early as when he was 8 years old. And he was very good at it, never keeping any written records that might be used as evidence against him by the police in Dayton, Ohio, who frowned on people, and most certainly on children, engaging in the illegal business of betting on numbers.
Today, Mr. Carter, who is now 51, said he uses his photographic memory for more constructive and legal purposes though he doesn't mind talking about his early life, of the numbers racket, of delinquency, of hustling for a living in one of the major slums of Middle America where he grew up. He saw people killed. He saw people maimed. He saw people going nowhere, and when he looked in the mirror one of them was him.
The downhill slide of his boyhood started when he was 5 and his family's home, above a grocery store his father owned, was destroyed in a fire. His mother was badly burned. He was burned on his face and hands and spent nine months in a hospital, then tried to hide his scarred hands by wearing gloves. Within a year, his father was dead of a heart attack while still trying to rebuild the store. His mother, a strong, religious woman who had always believed in the work ethic, was disfigured. And the family had gone from middle class to very poor. "It was so bad once that my mother and my brother, Joe, and I all slept in the same bed, along with a BB gun for shooting the rats."
 
Encouraged to Go to College
 As willing as he is to talk about a time that had more than its share of horrors, he is equally willing to talk about the many people who helped him climb out of the slum in Dayton, particularly two sisters, white schoolteachers named Ruth and Catherine Everitt, who saw something in a black youngster often in trouble or suspended from school that most others, particularly the authorities, were missing. The women helped him, giving him jobs to do and then overpaying him, he said, but mostly by encouraging him to do something better with his life, including going to college. One day he decided to quit hustling and try that. And he was hooked.
A few decades later, with degrees from three Ohio universities, including a doctorate in philosophy from Ohio State University, he went home to Dayton. The former delinquent was now the superintendent of the city school system.
Today, he sounds almost like a Horatio Alger character, transferred into the 20th century. The two schoolteachers "taught me people could be benefactors, not adversaries," he said. "All the people who helped me, they touched me and they gave me an obligation to touch someone else. That's what matters in life."
That's his message, and if you don't get it, he will just keep trying. He has the energy, seemingly an unlimited supply of it. "I know I'm hyperactive," he said. "That's a disadvantage of learning from adversity. You try too hard. I don't want to fail."
After the job in Dayton and teaching positions at two Pennsylvania universities, Mr. Carter arrived in Connecticut. He was the associate vice president for academic affairs at the University of Connecticut five years ago when he was offered the job of president of Eastern Connecticut State University.
The opportunity both enthralled and dismayed him. The good part, he said, was that it was a small university, about 4,000 students, a place where he could really get to know students and faculty members. The bad part was that it was virtually unknown, tucked away on a hill that rises up from the center of the small city of Willimantic, an isolated place of higher education in a blue-collar city, physically there but not really part of it. Even the main entrance, off Hill Street, was hard to find.
 
Eliminated Portable Classrooms
 In addition, its physical plant was somewhat less than adequate. David Carter's voice still goes up an octave or two when he talks about that: "They had these portable classrooms. They were probably put up 40 years ago. You were lucky you didn't go right through the floor when you walked in, they were that bad. If you value people, you don't put them in places like that."
He got rid of the portable classrooms. Five years after he took over the university, the initial phase of a $138 million renovation of the college has been completed, including a new dormitory and a new classroom building, with a target date of 2005 for the remainder.
He has even planted neat rows of flowers in the central area. The university president is much addicted to neatness, starting with himself -- shoes shined to a gloss, crease in pants like a knife -- and extending into all corners of his domain. As he travels about the campus, he likes to drop in at dormitories unannounced. He will knock on a door, yell "Hey, it's me," as if everyone inside should know by the voice who it is, and most do. He winces when he sees disarray, congratulates the occupants when one of the apartments is neat and clean. Neatness, he likes, order he likes.
 
Got Money From the State
 One major question is how, in a period of extreme austerity, Mr. Carter has been able to get the money out of the state for major capital improvements while other institutions, including the big University of Connecticut in the next town, are screaming for money. He smiled at the question and discoursed at length. The overall answer seemed to be that you have got to know how to hustle to get money out of the General Assembly, with the addenda that there are bad hustles and good hustles and this is a good hustle. He can fire off statistic after statistic in the effort to demonstrate that Eastern deserves special consideration. "Sixty percent of our students are the first members of their families who ever went to college. We have 34 nations from around the world represented here. Our minority percentage is up to 14 now."
Other state universities may be losing students but not Eastern. The gain is not dramatic: total enrollment of 4,576 this fall in contrast to 4,495 in the fall of 1992. But the figures do go against the trend.
The president has also brought the university closer to Willimantic than it had been in the past. Willimantic is a very poor place. The huge fortress-like buildings of American Thread Company sit vacant at one end of Main Street, ghosts of a textile industry that long ago went South. Now Willimantic, part of the town of Windham, is plagued with high unemployment and attendant social ills.
 
Community-Oriented College
 During a school year every student "has to perform eight hours of community service," Mr. Carter said, "some of them do 300 hours."
Windham's First Selectman, Walter M. Pawelkiewicz said he first met Mr. Carter when he was studying for a doctorate at the University of Connecticut and Mr. Carter was teaching education courses. Now he credits him for a new spirit of cooperation between the community and the university.
"Singlehandedly, he has transformed the university into a model of a community-oriented college," Mr. Pawelkiewicz said. "We have students interning in all our service agencies and schools. We have a town-gown meeting twice a month. For the first time, the town is involved in campus expansion and development of programs. Generally, people at an urban college talk a good game but don't produce. He produces."
And up on the hill, David Carter studies the master plan for his university, explaining every facet of it with obvious delight. He likes the place. He likes his job. "I'm a blessed man," he said. "I wasn't even supposed to go to college."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1488 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: November 14-19

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
The Trade Vote's Over, But the Debate Isn't
It's all over but the celebrations, the name-calling, the second-guessing -- so it's far from over. With Bill Clinton sprinting to the tape in his lobbying marathon, the House passed the North American Free Trade Agreement last week, by a surprisingly comfortable 34-vote margin. But the vote didn't banish the ambiguities -- the main one being, will this nation lose or gain jobs? (Check back in a decade or so on that one.) There was no ambiguity to the President's victory. The only questions were whether he cut too many side deals for votes, whether he squandered too much political capital. Another clear winner: President Salinas of Mexico. The pact could vault Mexico into the big leagues. A clear loser: organized labor, which went all out to defeat the pact. 

Bulletin: Women Work, Too
When it comes to statistics, the Government is quick on the draw. A month ends, and out come data on unemployment, consumer confidence, you name it. But if Washington realizes some numbers are flawed, it takes a lot longer to shift its huge, rusty gears. Realizing back in 1986 that its joblessness surveys were missing a lot of women, the Labor Department started pondering an overhaul. But not till last week did it come up with a fix. The survey, it seems, often asks women if they were "keeping house or something else," while asking men if they were "working or something else." That bias led many women who were seeking work to be skipped, because you're unemployed only if you're actively job-hunting. But come January, the department said, the surveys will be fixed, the bias gone . . . and the numbers probably higher: By the new count, the total rate for the year ending in August was 7.6 percent, not 7.1.
 
Yes, it was clearly equality-of-the-sexes week. Even the Roman Catholic Church, not what you'd normally call a crusader for women's rights, got into the act, as the nation's bishops came up with the revolutionary idea that men should share fully in child rearing and housework. So, guys, get with it: Turn off that football game and change that diaper.
 
What's Good for Real Estate . . .
A sure sign of the recession a few years back was that no one was buying houses. Who, after all, would make such a daunting investmest in an iffy economy? So as evidence mounts that we're inching, statistic by statistic, back toward prosperity, perhaps the most heartening news is in housing: Last week came a report that builders broke ground in October at the fastest rate in over three years. It's now expected that 1.1 million homes will be built this year, almost up to the level of 1987, back when "safe as houses" still meant something.
 
And the numbers kept rolling in last week: Industrial production rose 0.8 percent in October, the fifth straight gain and the biggest rise in nearly a year. Sales of domestic cars surged 12.4 percent in early November.
 
What Government Fat, Mr. Gore?
The Administration is overflowing with ideas for spending money; the only problem is where to get it. Al Gore offered a suggestion last month, a "reinventing" that would streamline Government and save a hefty $108 billion. It sounded good. Cut the fat, and use the savings for noble causes like fighting crime. But last week the Congressional Budget Office said: Wait a second, those numbers don't quite add up. While the Administration had predicted that the first phase of the streamlining would save $6 billion, the budget office -- which generally uses stricter accounting rules -- said the savings would be only about 5 percent of that. Oh, well, there's always a tax increase.
 
COMPANIES
 
The Perfect Way To Hurt an Airline
How do you hit an airline where it hurts? Simple. Just ground its planes over Thanksgiving, when Americans have this uncontrollable craving to eat pumpkin pie somewhere else -- anywhere, as long as it's a plane ride away. So last week American Airlines' flight attendants -- amid disputes over scheduling, wages and benefits, among other things -- did just that, vowing to strike till the turkey's cold. Travel was a mess if you had an American ticket. But for the flight attendants, it's a big gamble: American insists strikers will be replaced.
 
G.M. Hands Over a Nest Egg
It's amazing the sums that a little creative bookkeeping can conjure up. A big thorn in General Motors' side is the huge gap -- about $24 billion -- between what it has promised to retirees and what it has set aside. But last week it said it had found a way to throw $5.7 billion into the pot fairly painlessly. It wants to donate 185 million class E shares, which are tied to the performance of its Electronic Data Systems unit, to the pension plan, and somehow it says it can do it without diluting earnings for current class E shareholders. One wonders what other little nest eggs are tucked away in its books for a rainy day.
 
G.M. felt so confident last week that it even said its North American operations, on which it has lost billions in recent years, could actually turn a profit next year. Investors must have been convinced, because G.M. stock hit a yearly high, ending the week at $54.25.
 
Baxter Feels the Health Pinch
As the health care dinosaur flails about in this changing world, its tail keeps knocking things over. Cost pressure has forced cuts in surgeries and hospital stays, and those cuts have rippled through to a top hospital supply company, Baxter International. Baxter said last week that it was cutting 4,500 jobs.
 
Prudential Insurance's Turn
Prudential Insurance already had its hands full when its brokerage subsidiary agreed to pay $371 million to settle S.E.C. fraud charges. But last week accusations of fraud rose to the parent, as a top Prudential executive sued the company, saying it had routinely defrauded institutional investors in a real estate fund. The executive, Mark Jorgensen, asserts that various properties, like the New York Hilton, were carried on the books at inflated values -- to make the fund look better. And when he blew the whistle, he said, he was demoted.
 
Bias Penalty for Shawmut
If you're white and apply for a mortgage, you have a 15 percent chance of rejection; if you're black or Hispanic, the odds are about twice as bad. The Federal Reserve wants this to stop, and, citing possible lending bias, has stymied one bank's expansion plans. Like many banks these days, Shawmut National of Hartford wants to grow by acquiring, but last week the Fed turned down its purchase of the New Dartmouth Bank of Manchester, N.H.
 
Southwest Buys Boeing Jets
Southwest Airlines has redefined air travel by using only smaller jetliners that carry about 130 passengers. So if such planes are the wave of the future, Boeing now seems assured of a place in that future. Last week Southwest ordered 63 Boeing 737-X jets, the new version of the planes it uses now. The order, worth around $2.5 billion, is a signal that Boeing is not going to be left in the dust by Airbus Industrie. And it shows that Southwest has no intention of disappearing into the sunset: It's the largest order in its 22-year history.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
No Rest for a Trade Warrior
President Clinton was on a roll last week, and it was called free trade. No sooner had he sealed a House victory on opening his own hemisphere's borders than he sped to Seattle, for a meeting of a new trade group for Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation, to try to bring Asia into the fold. Mr. Clinton didn't forget the home front. "Make no mistake," he said. "Ultimately this meeting is about the jobs and futures and incomes of the American people."
 
In U.S. Eyes, China Equals Trade
The trade angle also reigned supreme last week when the Administration agreed to sell China an $8 million supercomputer and lift a ban on components for nuclear power plants. The White House sought no concessions on, say, human rights or nuclear-weapons testing. All it wants, it seems, is a big chunk of China's huge market. That's good news for General Electric, which already has a foot in China's nuclear power door, and for Cray Research, maker of that supercomputer. But to critics like Senator Paul Simon, "It's a mistake. We have to be firmer with China."
 
Chrysler Sells a Costly Toy
Well, Chrysler is past its midlife crisis, that odd period when the American male takes his mind off a receding hairline by buying a red sports car. When Chrysler felt this urge six years ago, it went for the top, buying the maker of the ultimate fantasy machine -- the Lamborghini. But now that it's settled down -- and doing quite well at it -- it has no time for such whims, especially as the market collapsed for cars whose prices look more at home in real estate listings. And where is the fanciful money flowing these days? An Indonesian group is buying the Italian car maker.

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Reading the Road: 3 for the Holidays

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
O.K., boys and girls, remember study hall? Remember tablets and yellow Dixon pencils and how we spent the time sketching dream cars?
Some of us were going to be designers and work in Detroit and flesh out those drawings. Show them. Or at least, if you were like me, you were going to be a commercial artist, maybe the successor to Fred Harmon, who drew Red Ryder and Little Beaver. 
 In most cases, it didn't happen. But Philip Trachtman followed through, and he has had various careers, all of them in art and ranging from advertising to founding and running the Art Institute of Philadelphia.
Through it all, too, he has maintained his love for automobiles and has peddled cartoons to national magazines. Now, at age 69, he has put a bunch of them together in a funny paperback called "Motor Mania," and he sees a new career ahead.
"I think there's a very broad interest in old cars or cars with sentimental value," he said on the phone from his home in Princeton, N.J. "As people age, the cars of their youth become collectible. And who knows when the models from the 70's or 80's will look good."
All he has to do is last, he said.
In the meantime, there probably will be more like this 64-page collection, published by Paramount Press of Princeton. The $9.75 book can be ordered by dialing 800-508-9515. It is about 9 inches square and slim enough to roll and wrap as a surprise stocking gift for Christmas.
The cars are beautifully drawn and the cartoons are New Yorkeresque. There is, too, a "goofy glossary of demented definitions," which includes words like "defuse" (to make or become harmless or powerless, as when your car quit because defuse burned out).
Corny, yes, but when you are a committed car nut, well. . . .
Another new book -- this one a hardcover and a true gem -- is "Where the Road and the Sky Collide," published by Henry Holt & Company and available for $22.50 in most bookstores.
It is subtitled "America Through the Eyes of Its Drivers," and the author is listed as K. T. Berger, although the K stands for Kevin and the T stands for Todd, California brothers who call themselves car biologists and who previously penned "Zen Driving."
Oddly, given that we have a pair of writers, the viewpoint is first-person singular, but the style works beautifully, and this just might be the most readable automobile book around. That is both because of an ear (four ears, actually) for language and because its 368 pages deal with people and places more than with hardware.
The idea was to send out thousands of questionnaires with the help of J. D. Power & Associates, then to make a tour of the country in a Dodge minivan and talk to some of the respondents about their "agonies and ecstasies on the king's highways."
They wanted to know about the impact of the automobile, about its current state and about whether it might be teetering on the slippery edge of extinction.
"One hundred years after its invention," they write, "the car is in big trouble. Traffic and its attendant emotional stress (six-shooters and Valium in the glove compartment) rank as the most dramatic problem of driving today, but no less consequential is the economic stress -- the ever-increasing expense of owning and operating an automobile."
Driving alone costs our city governments $60 billion a year, they say, and then there is the $55 billion spent each year on imported oil and the billions that the economy loses as workers everywhere sit in traffic, producing nothing but fumes and wallowing in angst.
Yet the Berger Boys like cars, and it shows. Meet, for instance, the former street racer with his tales of a Corvette-powered Porsche (after an accident with the Porsche, a bus driver stops to help and says: "I just knew you were in trouble when you passed me backward."). Or Macon Fry, a 35-year-old teacher of autistic students in New Orleans.
"His house was constructed of bargeboard and other odd assortments of whatever was handy," the Bergers write. " 'Whatever you need,' Macon said, 'sooner or later floats down. You just have to ask yourself how bad do you want it and will it float. Then you wait.' "
Out on the levee is Macon's battered green '57 Ford F-100, the pickup that's as dear to his heart as the swamp. But his feel for city streets is something else: "New Orleans, he said, was an exotic area to drive around in. After he'd been upcountry, he always loved coming back to the city." But the actual driving experience soon wore thin.
"There's potholes that my girlfriend's Hyundai can easily fall into. I mean, her Hyundai's great for going and traveling around the state, but here in the city, you'd best have a truck or something big like an Oldsmobile where, at worst, maybe only the front end's gonna fall in."
Along the way, the Bergers also meet truckers, New York cabbies, Detroit executives, traffic planners and environmentalists, and they make the experience fascinating. This is one trip not to be missed.
Another odyssey, less grand but no less pertinent, is documented in "Solo: Life With an Electric Car," by Noel Perrin, a professor of environmental studies at Dartmouth College who decided to reverse history by driving east to the future from California. The 192-page volume, published by W. W. Norton & Company, is available for $18.95 in stores or by calling 800-233-4830.
Solo is the name of Perrin's electric car, a converted 1985 Ford Escort in which he attempts a lone cross-country trip. Unfortunately, the red station wagon has a range of less than 60 miles, and Perrin soon longs for internal combustion.
"What an electric car has is a voltage gauge," he writes. "And what is a volt, besides a memorial to Count Volta? It's a unit of force, not of quantity, and a little bit comparable to the speed with which a river is flowing, as opposed to the volume of water in it. I find it hard to think in volts."
He also finds it hard to find fill-ups, and he winds up making the trip neither solo nor by amps alone. More than that I won't say, because part of the book's charm is the uncertainty of the endeavor, but Perrin's narrative carries us right along.
In California, he hears "neat," "cool" and "terrific," and he notes that Californians either are "the politest of all Americans, or else there is a genuine and widespread interest in alternative vehicles." Indeed there is -- although he experiences scorn in Utah and skepticism in Wyoming. Elsewhere, he meets kindred spirits, and a close look at the history and future of the electric automobile sets out both problems and prospects.
The author made the trip two years ago, but he still has the little red wagon, using it for the daily 13-mile commute from his home in Thetford, Vt., to Dartmouth, across the border in Hanover, N.H.
Solo remains inexpensive and Perrin has discovered other advantages as the driver of a zero-pollution vehicle, not least the fact that he has been given a rare reserved parking spot on the campus. It's the one by the building's exterior electrical outlet.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Latin America Finds Harmony in Convergence

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
ON the face of it, the North American Free Trade Agreement approved by the House of Representatives last week after a long and acrimonious debate is a document narrow in scope, affecting only commercial relations with Mexico and Canada. But its passage was greeted with relief and excitement throughout Latin America and the Caribbean, where there is similar movement toward a closer relationship with the United States -- movement that would likely have been derailed had the trade pact been rejected.
Just a decade ago, it would have been difficult to imagine Latin American leaders, with Mexico in the lead, clamoring for closer economic, political and cultural ties with the Colossus of the North, their historical nemesis. But a new breed of pragmatic reformer has emerged in country after country in recent years to put into practice the twin virtues of democracy and open markets that Washington had long been preaching. To them, Nafta was a test of both the sincerity and reliability of the United States. 
 Thus there was alarm throughout the region when it seemed that Congress might hesitate, and jubilation when the Clinton Administration triumphed. "This was not a handshake at arm's length," said Mark Rosenberg, director of the Latin American and Caribbean Center at Florida International University here. "This was an embrace, and Latin America knows it."
In ways both symbolic and practical, Nafta therefore consolidates the profound changes in attitude and approach that have already occurred in Latin America, and creates new opportunities for convergence with the United States. Enrique Iglesias, president of the Inter-American Development Bank, a Washington-based organization that last year alone lent $6 billion for projects like roads, sanitation and small businesses, said he regards Nafta as the most significant American initiative toward Latin America in his lifetime -- far more important, he said, than Franklin Roosevelt's Good Neighbor policy or John Kennedy's Alliance for Progress.
"For us, Nafta means we really count for the first time," Mr. Iglesias, a former foreign minister of Uruguay, said after watching the debate and vote from the gallery of the House Wednesday night. "In a world of uncertainties, it is reassuring to leaders of the region to know that we can bet on the friendship of the United States. We now become partners in a joint venture, and that gives us an anchor for the economic reform process."
But Hernando de Soto, a Peruvian who is the author of "The Other Path," a best-seller throughout Latin America that has become the bible of economic reformers, predicted that "the political consequences of Nafta will be even more interesting than the economic ones, at least in the short term." In the same way that Spaniards became Europeanized by joining the European Community after decades of authoritarian rule, he said, "the virtues of a modern society" now have a chance to prevail in Latin American nations that long struggled under the twin burdens of military rule and economic policies that enriched only the elite.
It was the collapse of that system under a mountain of debt in the early 1980's that led to what Latin Americans call the Lost Decade, 10 years of economic stagnation, declining wages and net outflows of capital that made the poor poorer and destroyed the middle class. More out of desperation than confidence, newly enfranchised voters throughout the region turned to young civilian leaders who prescribed austerity and argued that the United States, though a contributor to the region's problems, could also be part of a solution.
Now, with Nafta in place and ideological tensions diminished, those polished technocrats can see light at the end of the tunnel and the possibility of resurrecting a consumer-minded middle class. As Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada, the President of Bolivia, phrased it in a plea on behalf of the pact to Congress a week before the vote, the world's largest trading bloc "will be like a sun, and the rest of our economies will be like planets in orbit around it," basking in its glow and stimulated to remove barriers among themselves.
Mr. Sanchez de Lozada recognizes that for the time being, Mexico will enjoy an advantage over other Latin American countries and is likely to attract the lion's share of American investment and attention. But "as we achieve certain standards and certain levels of growth and maturity and in our economies," he also said, his and other countries eventually will also gain "access to this wonderful system of free trade, standardization of democratic practices, labor laws and environmental sensitivity."
Having spent so much political capital getting Congress to approve free trade with Mexico, Mr. Clinton may not be inclined to move quickly on requests from Chile and Argentina, the most likely candidates to follow in Mexico's steps, during his first term. But at the very least, the embrace of Mexico encourages reformers throughout Latin America to continue, if not accelerate, efforts to open up and modernize their societies.
That shot in the arm is especially important in the dozen countries with presidential elections scheduled over the next year, beginning with Honduras later this month and ending with Brazil next fall. "These changes do not get unanimity," Mr. Iglesias observed. "There are debates all over, and that is why with this sort of opening by the United States, reformism gets a boost. It shows there is life after the sacrifices we are making now."
 
Cultural Momentum
 But even as that political debate goes on, the momentum toward integration builds, thanks in large part to advances in communications and transportation. MTV, CNN, HBO, and ESPN, all now available in Spanish, are avidly consumed from Monterrey to Mendoza, and faxes and electronic mail have also reduced the distance between North and South America. The traffic flows in both directions, with visitors from Caracas or Buenos Aires increasingly coming to Miami, Houston and Los Angeles to shop, open businesses, buy real estate, keep doctors' appointments or just attend a baseball game.
In such a world, absolute sovereignty becomes impossible and interdependence seems the order of the day. No wonder, then, that Puerto Rico, which last week voted narrowly to remain an autonomous commonwealth tied to the United States rather than seek statehood, feels less defensive about its status and is even offering itself as a model for relations between the two Americas. "Other Latin American countries are seeking to break down the barriers of sovereignty and enter into an economic association with the United States," Rafael Luis Morales, a 35-year-old teacher in the mountain town of Aibonito, said proudly last month. "But we Puerto Ricans already have that, and it has done wonders for us."
Of course, if the shift to open markets does not deliver improvements in living standards, or if the United States to move forward, Latin America might be tempted to flirt again with populist authoritarianism. But, Mr. de Soto said, "a cultural barrier of sorts has been broken" on both sides with Nafta and it would be hard to return to the patterns of the past. "Having broken through the mental barrier, steps toward full integration now come much more naturally. All of a sudden, it's not that big a problem, gringos and Latinos getting together."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1173 words

HEADLINE: Clinton Puts a Foot In the Opening Door Of the Global Market

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: SEATTLE

 BODY:
WHAT may be the biggest rethinking of American policy toward Asia since the days of Gen. Douglas MacArthur is finally under way, and President Clinton began to outline it last week just inside a giant airplane hangar at the Boeing Company.
Boeing is, after all, the country's largest exporter, and as Mr. Clinton told a cheering throng, its booming Asian business is a model for companies across America. China alone now buys one of every six of its planes; Asian airlines own half of all the 747's ever made. But there is a less-discussed price. The fuselage of Boeing's newest jet, still 18 months from delivery, isn't built by Boeing, but by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries at the plant in Nagoya, Japan, that spit out Zeros for World War II. Just as America insisted in the 1980's that Japan build its cars in America, the rest of the world has caught on to the concept of "local content." So Boeing has announced 28,000 layoffs here while some of its Pacific partners are hiring. To keep its opportunities for growth alive, there is no other choice. Such are the realities that Bill Clinton and his economic strategists have begun to acknowledge in a new vision of American relations with Asia -- a vision that Mr. Clinton spelled out forcefully at the meeting of Pacific leaders that concluded here this weekend. It is a vision that implies tradeoffs and job displacements far more wrenching than any posed by the North American Free Trade Agreement, which the House approved last week after a Herculean display of Presidential persuasion. 
 Underlying Mr. Clinton's approach is a far more subtle appreciation of the realities of economic interdependence than any past American administration has articulated.
Previous presidents have steered clear of the politically uncomfortable fact that Mr. Clinton addressed head-on on Friday: Creating a job for a factory worker in Seattle may first require creating six jobs in Jakarta. The new world order, Mr. Clinton suggested, seamlessly integrates security and economics. Indeed, he touted the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum -- the little-known economic consulting group under whose auspices the Pacific leaders gathered -- as something of a latter-day NATO. He said "our place in the world will be determined as much by the skills of our workers as by the strength of our weapons, as much by our ability to pull down foreign trade barriers as our ability to breach distant ramparts."
In political terms, of course, much of this oratory is about building on Nafta, Mr. Clinton's first big foreign policy win. Secretary of State Warren Christopher said Nafta should be the first out in a "triple play," one that now turns to economic integration of the Pacific and then to tearing down still more trade barriers under a new, much delayed global trade accord, which faces a deadline in mid-December.
Whether he succeeds at that or fails, Mr. Clinton last week became the first President to describe a strategy for the Pacific that truly moves beyond America's huge military presence there. He said Asia's nations "have gone from being dominoes to dynamos," suggesting that America's biggest fear now is that it will be relegated to low-paid guard at the factory gate; Asia's fear, in contrast, is that America's interest will wither as its troops are withdrawn in line with new strategic and economic imperatives.
At the same time, the breadth of Mr. Clinton's vision of a Pacific community -- encompassing Pacific-wide free trade zones and new economic freedoms matched by greater individual freedoms -- clearly left many participants apprehensive. The Indonesians and the Chinese in particular fear an American-dominated organization that will not only present a marketing opportunity but will also pose a political threat.
"Clinton really took everyone by surprise," one of Japan's top industrial planners said. "No one expected such a comprehensive vision, or such lofty goals." Just a year ago, participants noted, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d wrote of the need to preserve the "wheel and spoke" system of alliances in Asia, with the United States at the center.
But that system was collapsing even as Mr. Baker was reinventing it. Years ago it began yielding to a network of relationships that were driven not by government-to-government agreements, the way the European Community was built, but by company-to-company alliances that reached from Tokyo to electronics plants in Thailand and Malaysia, and from Taipei to family-run factories in southern China and Hong Kong.
Those links are now so well established, in a region where America has long under-invested, that Mr. Clinton's new strategy clearly faces major obstacles.
One is that his leverage is limited. A hard truth about economic foreign policy is that there are no aircraft carriers to slip into position to make a point. Ask anyone who has negotiated with Japan over trade in the last 20 years; changing the economic habits of another country is a painstakingly slow business. And when it comes to the key political issue, creating jobs, real policy is often set piecemeal at the corporate level.
"We can put rocks in the stream, but we can't stop the water from flowing around those rocks," Jeffrey Garten, the new Under Secretary of Commerce, said here. "This week in Seattle is about lending some order to international transactions that are growing anyway, but they cannot be stopped."
And increasingly, those transactions undercut efforts to use economics as a foreign-policy lever. Mr. Christopher, defending the decision to sell a supercomputer to the Chinese for the first time since the Tiananmen Square killings in 1989, said on Friday that the United States had to close a $19-billion trade deficit with China. Human-rights symbolism notwithstanding, he said, if we didn't sell the machines, someone else would.
Another challenge is changing the psychology of American business. Ten years of lectures about how Americans must do more to interact with Asian cultures have yet to penetrate very deeply into many American boardrooms. Echoing a Japanese criticism, Mr. Clinton last week castigated American companies for their inward-looking ways.
But one of the politically uncomfortable facts about moving more vigorously into foreign markets is that it frequently requires multimillion-dollar, job-creating investments outside the United States on a scale that would terrify Nafta's opponents.
While no one will say so explicitly, Boeing's decision to build 20 percent of every new 777 jet in Nagoya is part of the quid pro quo to get Japan's big airlines to buy the plane. Boeing acknowledges that such arrangements effectively mean an export of jobs to Asia, but says that on average 85 percent of the content of its planes remains American-made.
"If I don't scratch their industrial itch, Airbus will, or they will do it themselves," says Larry Clarkson, Boeing's top official for international sales. "So far, we have kept them from becoming competitors."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Nafta: The Whys And Wherefores

BYLINE: By David Rosenbaum

 BODY:
IT was one of the most emotional sessions in Congress in years. Partisan loyalties and personal friendships went by the boards. After 13 hours of debate and more than 250 speeches, the House of Representatives voted Wednesday, 234 to 200, to put the North American Free Trade Agreement into effect beginning Jan. 1. David Rosenbaum pulls together a sampler of what was said:
 
"Bill Johnson owns the largest Caterpillar distributorship in the West. There is currently a 20 percent tariff on his products sold in Mexico. Caterpillar has 50 percent of the market. The other half is dominated by Komatsu Company of Japan. Bill says, 'Imagine what will happen when the 20 percent tariff comes off our tractors and it remains on the ones from Japan.' "
-- Jerry Lewis
Republican of California
For the agreement
 
"The Maine footwear industry, the largest in the nation, has lost over 9,000 jobs to countries like Mexico, whose work forces are dominated by low-wage jobs. Similar horror stories can be told about textiles, fisheries and our lumber industry."
-- Olympia J. Snowe
Republican of Maine
Against
 
"Some people may say that I have a democracy fetish. I do not believe that I have one. I think it is irresponsible to enter into a single market with something other than a representative democracy."
-- Lincoln Diaz-Balart
Republican of Florida
Against
 
"I share blood with the Mexican people. And the xenophobic, anti-Mexico slurs that have made the rounds here, including from some Members of the House, I resent that. I resent that very much. . . . We cannot expect to Americanize the world."
-- E. (Kika) de la Garza
Democrat of Texas
For
 
"Hattie Smith worked for U.S. Auto Radiator for 12 years, earning $7.60 an hour. As her last duty before she was fired, Hattie was sent to Mexico to train her 65-cents-an-hour replacements -- 13-year-old girls working without protective gear."
-- William D. Ford
Democrat of Michigan
Against
 
"It is not possible for this nation to be politically international and at the same time economically isolationist. It is like asking one Siamese twin to do a high dive while the other plays the piano."
-- Amo Houghton
Republican of New York
For
 
"After seeing decades of deprivation and adversity in our society, I have come to the conclusion that we need some new solutions to the age-old problems of unemployment and the lack of economic opportunity."
-- Carrie Meek
Democrat of Florida
For
 
"We need entry-level jobs in this country."
-- Bruce F. Vento
Democrat of Minnesota
Against

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
After Clinton's Sermon Blacks Are Looking For Action, Not Amens

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE Temple Church of God in Christ in Memphis was hot and the 900 people in the pews were sweating. Some 20,000 others were watching on closed circuit television at the downtown convention center. Bill Clinton had come to speak.
The anticipation was almost palpable, and the President did not disappoint. From the pulpit of the historic church where the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. delivered his last sermon, Mr. Clinton -- a white man in a church full of black people -- decided to talk about black-on-black crime. 
 Crime, drugs and violence, he said, are destroying the nation. And the ravages of that cycle, he said, are stunting growth, in the black community in particular.
"The freedom to die before you're a teen-ager is not what Martin Luther King lived and died for," he said.
Mr. Clinton was not telling the ministers anything they did not already know, but the President's speech seemed a risky undertaking nevertheless.
Most people are not fond of hearing anyone else detail their shortcomings. And in a society that has been crippled by racial conflict for hundreds of years, his words carried the weight of troubled history, especially when delivered in the cadence of a son of the South.
But Mr. Clinton had calculated the risks. He may care deeply about crime in the cities, but he also knows a political opportunity when he sees one. The Rev. Jesse Jackson has been very vocal on the subject of crime and violence. And members of the Congressional Black Caucus have prodded Mr. Clinton to be more outspoken.
Although he was praised for stepping into the virtually uncharted territory of race and crime, he may have raised expectations beyond his ability to deliver. Crime, like politics, is local. There is only so much a President can do or may be willing to do to turn back a tide that is rooted in joblessness, hopelessness and despair.
Mr. Clinton's aides have said that, for now, he plans to use his office as a bully pulpit to give voice to a painful issue. Many others say that will not be enough.
Representative Charles B. Rangel, the New York Democrat who has been pressing the Administration to spend more time addressing narcotics and crime, said the speech touched a chord in the black community. "We have not spoken out about the cancers we have in our own bodies," he said. "And all of them weren't planted there by the majority. I would say that 10 years ago we would have run him out of there. But the violence has reached a point where we need help. And jail is not the help we need."
Politics also played a role in Mr. Clinton's calculated risk. Mr. Rangel was told in advance about the speech because White House advisers were trying to win his vote on the hotly contested free trade package. And after the President's speech, Mr. Rangel said, he received a phone call from Ambassador Walter F. Mondale in Tokyo, asking him if the President's impassioned comments did not signal that he deserved support on Nafta.
"I said, 'He made an appeal for Martin Luther King's vote, not mine,' " Mr. Rangel said, chuckling.
Mr. Rangel voted against Nafta. And on crime, he is demanding more than the President is yet willing to commit. He and others are unhappy with the anti-crime bill passed by the Senate last week because it focuses more on punishment than prevention. The bill, which is headed for a conference with the House, calls for $22 billion for more police officers on the streets and more prisons. The Brady bill, which would require a five-day wait for handgun purchases, was derailed by a Republican filibuster.
 
Looking for Solutions
 Mr. Jackson said the President should be assembling solutions including funding for development banks and job training programs and filling vacancies that affect equal employment and civil rights. "The bully pulpit must be preaching policy and plan and priority," he said. "Reagan used the bully pulpit to cut taxes. He didn't just use it to do abstract preaching."
Still, there is relief that Mr. Clinton is talking about the issue at all, which is more than other recent Presidents have been willing to do. Hillary Rodham Clinton said recently that she personally supported Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to tax ammunition. And in an interview in Rolling Stone, Mr. Clinton suggests that he would support legislation to make it more difficult for gun dealers to get licenses.
He also said he would be interested in supporting a proposal of Senator Herb Kohl of Wisconsin to prohibit gun ownership for people under 18, nationalizing Virginia's law that limits handgun purchases to one a month and banning assault weapons. "People are scared," he said in the magazine interview. "It is very difficult for me to give a speech on the global economy and all my retraining and investment ideas when people don't even think their kids can go to school safely. It is a very basic thing. It unites people across very deep divides."
The polls back Mr. Clinton up.
"Speeches like the one he gave last Saturday are very much out of his soul and his history," said Stanley Greenberg, the President's pollster. But Mr. Greenberg is in a position to know that the President is also responding to polls demonstrating the deep-seated concerns Americans have about crime.
In the latest New York Times/CBS News survey of public opinion, 16 percent cited crime and violence as "the most important problem facing this country today," up from 1 percent when President Clinton was inaugurated in January. That puts it on an equal level with unemployment, jobs, the economy and health care.
If the words Mr. Clinton uttered in Memphis persuaded many, in and beyond the congregation, that he has begun to absorb the size of the task before him, others were waiting to hear more.
If the President is willing to support a five-day waiting period on handgun purchases, why not an outright ban? If he is willing to talk a good game about keeping teen-agers from shooting each other, then is he willing to support significant new spending for job training programs? Paraphrasing scripture in much the same way Mr. Clinton did in Memphis, Mr. Jackson said: "The words must become flesh."

HEADLINE: A Thousand Days and 30 Years;
From Man to Martyr to Myth

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER

 BODY:
THIRTY years after John Fitzgerald Kennedy's murder in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963, Americans continue to hold the 35th President in improbably high regard -- not just as a man of star quality, whose life was cut short in a moment whose origins are still debated, but as a national leader ranked in some polls with or above Abraham Lincoln and Franklin D. Roosevelt.
Yet John Kennedy's "Thousand Days" in the Presidency were marked less by historic achievements than by continual crises -- the Bay of Pigs fiasco; Berlin; the world's first nuclear confrontation; the beginnings of the war in Vietnam; the heated collisions of white authority and black civil rights demonstrators in the Southern states. Nor were Kennedy's responses always sure. 
 In his last months in office, for example, he concluded the first nuclear test-ban treaty with the Soviet Union. But in his early months he had ordered a massive military buildup that contributed heavily to the Soviet-American arms race. He was reluctant to expend political capital on behalf of black demonstrators, whose persistence made him impatient, and was forced mostly by events into his clashes with Southern recalcitrants like Governors George Wallace of Alabama and Ross Barnett of Mississippi.
The overall record of his Presidency, though in many respects admirable, hardly accounts for Kennedy's high standing three decades later -- a standing all the more unlikely because the years since his death have seen continuing assaults on his personal and political reputations.
His dalliances with women before and during his White House years have become public knowledge. Books like "A Question of Character: A Life of John F. Kennedy" by Thomas C. Reeves and Nigel Hamilton's "J.F.K.: Reckless Youth" have pictured him as privileged, pampered, often irresponsible and insensitive. Inadequately answered charges persist that he and his brother, Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy, repeatedly sought the assassination of Fidel Castro. The author Richard Reeves makes it clear in "President Kennedy: Profile in Power" that Kennedy consistently deceived the public about his health, enduring almost constant pain and sometimes resorting to "feel good" injections during his campaign and Presidency.
 
Changes in Atmosphere
 The nation's political and social atmospheres, moreover, have changed greatly since John Kennedy's time. The election of Ronald Reagan in 1980 signaled a national embrace of conservatism after decades of the New Deal liberalism that Kennedy was mistakenly believed to exemplify (his party, save its Southerners, was further to the left than he wanted to be). And the growth of the urban underclass, with the rising incidence of urban crime, has chilled attitudes toward black Americans, with whose improved status the 35th President is indelibly linked.
All this, or less, would have dulled the public's regard for any other former President. How has John F. Kennedy, while not exactly a candidate for Mount Rushmore, prevailed over predictable eclipse? The most important reason, undoubtedly, is the almost mythic manner of his death.
The hero cut down at the height of his glory (though Kennedy was in something of a political slump in the fall of 1963) is a staple of legend-making. And when such a fate befalls a figure of youth and beauty, the legend becomes even more of a romantic drama -- heightened, in Kennedy's case, by the mundane fact that few Americans in 1963 had witnessed, even imagined, the murder of a President.
By then, in fact, the Presidency was an office exalted almost beyond mortality -- by the personality and prominence of Franklin Roosevelt in Depression and war; by Truman's and Eisenhower's cold war leadership of the so-called free world, and by the President's command of nuclear weapons.
As the inheritor of that exalted place, John F. Kennedy became something like a young American emperor: it could hardly be imagined by a fascinated public that he or any President was vulnerable to a human hand. But he was -- a nearly unbelievable fact that spawned dozens of conspiracy theories for a people unable to accept the idea that a deed so momentous did not have equally momentous origins.
The assassination in Dallas, moreover, marked the real arrival of television, history's mightiest conveyor of unforgettable images and moments. Only that autumn, the two major networks, still relatively primitive, had inaugurated 30-minute evening news broadcasts (with John Kennedy the guest star on each program). But from the moment the shots rang out in Dealey Plaza through the funeral services three days later, the networks stayed continuously on the air, steadily focused on the searing drama -- bringing the nation together, as perhaps never before, in its time of shock and grief. Television, blazoning the events of that weekend on the memories of most Americans then living, became the national nervous system.
Kennedy, then in his third year of office, was believed by many to be growing in stature, moving toward a higher statesmanship, an impression since cultivated in the numerous memoirs of his associates. The limited test-ban treaty, concluded only weeks before the fatal shots were fired, seemed ample evidence. So more than a few Americans believe today, some passionately, that a President growing in office would not have taken the nation so deeply into Vietnam as his successor did.
Nor does Vietnam provide the only such wishful idea. Even if Nov. 22, 1963, is taken only as a benchmark in time and what followed a coincidence, it was not long thereafter that things began to go wrong for Americans. The nation's youth began to drop out and turn on, the war in Vietnam became an endless nightmare, cities burned in the "long hot summers" of black revolt, Robert Kennedy and Martin Luther King fell before other assassins, world economic supremacy trickled away, crime turned cities into huddles of fear, Watergate destroyed a President and faith in Presidents, hostages and burning helicopters in Iran shattered illusions of American might.
Ironically, all that enhanced the Kennedy legend. Many Americans believed, on faith rather than evidence, that if John Kennedy had not been cut down as he was coming into his prime, if Bobby Kennedy had been there to follow him, these disasters could somehow have been avoided. The worse things seemed to become, the more such Americans missed something they identified with the Kennedy brothers, if in belief rather than fact.
John Kennedy had declared in his inaugural address that "a new generation of Americans, born in this century" had come to power with him. After the stolid years of the 50's and the Eisenhower Administration, the change seemed welcome to that "new generation"; and a third of a century later, in a time of political revulsion, many graying oldsters still mourn a lost leader and the idea of a new age that never came. They will never know if it ever would have.
His most dedicated opponents, moreover, conceded that Kennedy was an engaging man -- not the least of his political assets. His Presidential news conferences were the first to be televised live and regularly, and for millions of viewers they established -- often by the alchemy of "news management" -- his articulatenesshis wit, his sophistication, his apparent mastery of the details of government and diplomacy. No President ever had had the exposure in action that television gave him, and to Americans he became more familiar and recognizable, as have all Presidents since, than the local mayor or Congressman.
Finally, as idolaters often overstate, detractors frequently underrate the Kennedy record in office. It was by no means negligible. He broke, for instance, the centuries-old taboo against a Roman Catholic President, exposing other taboos to the light of reason. He became the first President to call the struggle of American blacks for full equality "a moral issue" -- brave words at the time, earning him a special place in the respect and affection of black Americans.
And though Kennedy's cold warrior inaugural address is more widely quoted, his most memorable words came in the last months of his life, in his speech on June 10, 1963, at American University. He called on the nation, in what was then a risky and challenging change from years of hostility, to re-examine its attitude toward the Soviet Union.
"In the final analysis," he declared, "our most basic common link is that we all inhabit this small planet. We all breathe the same air. We all cherish our children's future. And we are all mortal."
So we all are, as was John Fitzgerald Kennedy. Despite the imperial trappings of the Presidency and his own glittering aura, he knew that well enough. But in the soul-shaking years since his death, as between disillusionment and legend, Americans have chosen legend -- as if to hold in memory their own sense of themselves and their country as they most wished them to be, as they used to believe they were.

HEADLINE: The French, Disneyed and Jurassick, Fear Erosion

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
FOR the French, the dinosaurs were the last straw.
First the Berlin Wall fell, and with it the relevance of the French "force de frappe," or nuclear bomb. Then European unity, the cornerstone of French foreign policy for a decade, disintegrated amid currency turmoil, soaring unemployment and a shaming paralysis before the Balkan war. Then came Mickey Mouse, prompting talk of a "cultural Chernobyl" at Euro Disney. Next GATT -- the onomatepoetic acronym for talks on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade -- turned horrible. Finally, those "Jurassic Park" dinosaurs, peering from billboards and merchandised at the 279 McDonald's restaurants in France, rounded out a dim sense that French cultural, commercial and strategic anchors have come unstuck. 
 So it was small comfort for Gallic pride when Euro Disney revealed a disaster this month, announcing losses of $900 million for its first full year of operation and hinting at possible failure. French newspapers took note but nobody crowed. With 11.8 percent of the work force now jobless, another company in trouble was merely more bad news.
The theme park's doldrums are linked more to the European recession and Disney's severe misjudgment of the hotel market than to any visceral incompatibility between Mickey Mouse and the French, although Disney's initial ban on booze and insistence that employees wear "appropriate undergarments" did nothing to mollify an already prickly national sensibility.
That prickliness has been much in evidence of late. The French are going through a bad patch, a recurrence of the intermittent insecurity and questioning that seem to afflict the French soul. Recession and a drumbeat of layoffs from the likes of Michelin and Renault have contributed to this mood. But jobs have been disappearing elsewhere in Europe, too, without producing anything quite like the current French Angst.
Behind the disquiet there lurks that maddeningly vague but pervasive notion that de Gaulle expressed as "une certaine idee de la France." Just what that certain idea is may never be pinned down. But it has a lot to do with a sense of grandeur and civilizing mission as well as a desire to embody intellectual and artistic uplift.
So it is not enough for France to be just another relatively prosperous middle-sized country. It needs a central role, and in projects like the Grand Louvre, completed this week, it has shown that it still has the capacity and imagination to stir international admiration with its public enterprises.
"France needs a 'grand projet' -- an overarching mission," said Jean-Marie Rouart, an author and chief literary critic of Le Figaro. "Napoleon led us across Europe, de Gaulle made us dream, but now we have nothing. Or rather, what we have is American materialism and commercialism as sole world canon."
Because it was perceived as a consummate illustration of this canon, "Jurassic Park" caused a great outburst last month. It was Euro Disney all over again. The dinosaurs were portrayed as monsters intent on gobbling up French culture.
Jacques Toubon, Culture Minister, said the movie illustrated why France must be allowed a "cultural exception" in any new General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The exception would allow France to go on subsidizing its cinema and limiting American shows on television. "The alternative," he warned, "is for non-American production to be crushed completely."
Once again, a longing for a different past was evident beneath the surface. Hemingway came to France, as did Fitzgerald and Henry Miller, because inspiration lurked in Paris. Malraux, Gide, Camus, Sartre, Sarraute were international figures. And today?
"There is less and less of France abroad, and more and more that is foreign in France," said Dominique Moisi, deputy director of the French Institute for International Relations. "One minute it's dinosaurs, the next North African immigrants, but it's the same basic anxiety."
That concern -- over a disappearing culture, a lost national identity, an absence of purpose -- also lurks behind all the disputes over grain exports and other agricultural matters that have poisoned the GATT talks. In the French psyche, it is the "paysan," and with him all of rural tradition, that is being threatened by the steamroller of free trade.
But to travel around France today is to see a country that has prospered enormously from open trade and its position as the world's fourth-largest exporter. There is a tremendous gap between the current national anguish and the country's sheer opulence, from the richness of its fields to the elegance of its cities.
That anguish stems from France's intellectual contempt for material values. It wants to stand for an idea; that is the nation's raison d'etre. The idea should be universal -- as Hollywood and Mickey Mouse are today -- but somehow at the opposite end of the moral spectrum from Jurassic Park. But just what that galvanizing idea is escapes the French for now and leaves them waiting morosely for what they see as an ominous millennium.

HEADLINE: Public Colleges Draw More Support As Vital to Train Local Work Force

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 20

 BODY:
The corporations that began moving to lower Fairfield County a generation ago are paying increasing attention to the quality of the area's public colleges as vital ingredients to the area's economic prosperity.
While New York, with the nation's greatest concentration of Fortune 500 headquarters, has Columbia and New York University among others, lower Fairfield County, which ranks third in Fortune 500 headquarters, has only a commuter branch of the University of Connecticut here and a two-year college, Norwalk Community-Technical College. 
 Those two small colleges, however, are seen as increasingly important to the area's economy's becoming self-sustaining, now that the corporate migration has ended and long-term prosperity appears to depend on smaller businesses that will need a well-educated local population.
 
No Longer Taken for Granted
 After years of being taken for granted, the colleges are being promoted as vital to educating and retraining the county's residents for a rapidly changing workplace. Businesses and corporations are adopting the community college as one of their own. And they are promoting a plan to move the UConn branch to a new campus in downtown Stamford and greatly expand its undergraduate and graduate programs.
The goal, officials say, is not to create a new prestigious institution to compete with traditional four-year colleges, but to serve the hometown needs of the area's businesses and residents, especially adults already in the work force.
"This is part of a broader process of filling in southwestern Connecticut," said Christopher Bruhl, president of the Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association. "Just as we are seeing institutions of higher education being strengthened and expanded, we are seeing cultural institutions being created, the child-care network growing, the dramatic upgrading of our hospitals."
Neither college is much older than the county's corporate era. Norwalk Community College and Norwalk State Technical College were founded in 1961 and merged in 1992. The UConn branch opened in 1962 as a feeder for the main campus in Storrs, at the northeastern end of the state.
 
More Business Ties
 For decades, though, the corporate growth had little effect on them. Norwalk Community rented space in a former factory until 1991, when local businesses and politicians finally won a new $23 million campus.
In the 1970's, UConn-Stamford was allowed to offer a few degrees, but it remained isolated on a cramped campus in suburban North Stamford. Finally, in 1990, a local advisory committee recommended an expanded curriculum and a downtown site to the university's Board of Trustees.
The trustees have now authorized $93 million in bonds, and the Legislature has appropriated $10 million to buy a site. Also, the committee estimated that a fund drive could raise $10 million to $15 million more.
The UConn proposal has critics. Professors at Storrs have questioned whether an expanded branch would drain their resources and students. Some students fear their liberal-arts refuge is being captured by downtown business interests.
 
Help for Commuting Students

 Supporters say these concerns miss the point. "The motivation," said the advisory committee's chairman, L. C. Heist, "is more to provide something for the people who are here, and who can't travel great distances, who can't pay for private institutions, who need to work while they're going to school.
"At the moment, if you have a job opening, you can find plenty of people who will come and take it," said Mr. Heist, the president of Champion International Corporation. "Our concern is, are there people in Fairfield County who could take those jobs?"
That concern has also brought growing support to Norwalk Community-Technical, where 80 percent of the 5,100 people enrolled in credit courses are part-time students and where some 4,000 more people take non-credit courses.
Norwalk began wooing employers in the 1980's, offering to train their workers. It provided instructors for subjects like English as a second language and computer use.
 
A Model Contract
 "It's a different world for supervisors today, with discrimination laws, a complex work force and a growing emphasis on self-directed work teams," said Frank Morgan, Norwalk's dean of continuing education. "They were promoted because they were good at their old jobs. They may have no idea how to do their new ones."
What quickly became a model, however, was a contract for the college to provide basic literacy and math classes to several hundred assembly workers at Pitney Bowes.
As Pitney Bowes began making a new generation of computerized mailing machines, it also wanted to replace the traditional assembly line with teams of workers who could make decisions on their own.
On the old line, said Kevin Connolly, the director of manufacturing operations, "I could have done the same thing every day for 20 years, and if the guy next to me and I didn't like each other, we wouldn't say two words all day long. It wasn't necessary."
Now team members would have to talk to each other. They would need new skills, like the ability to read blueprints. But in deciding where to start, Pitney Bowes discovered that 40 percent of the 1,100 workers could not read at a fourth-grade level and that 70 percent lacked math skills.
The company turned to Norwalk Community, and in 1988 27 instructors began literacy and math classes at the factory. Nearly everyone has met the initial goals, and now the college and company are discussing courses to raise reading and writing levels further.
Many employees say the training has made a difference in their personal lives as well. Lula Preci of Fairfield, who has been with Pitney Bowes since 1984, said she both understood and remembered more of what she reads. And she learned how to balance her checkbook.
 
Help for Immigrants
 Antoine Greffard, who came to the United States from Haiti in 1974 and started at Pitney Bowes in 1978, said the literacy classes had improved his spoken English, in part by encouraging him to take out a library card for the first time and read more.
And both Ms. Preci and Mr. Greffard said they were more self-confident. "It's made a difference to me outside of work, because now I'm going to tell you exactly what I'm feeling," Mr. Greffard said.
So far Norwalk has worked with about 25 corporations. The retraining at Pitney Bowes is seen as a model in part because the benefits to both the company and its employees are so obvious. Employers need adaptable employees like Ms. Preci and Mr. Greffard; the workers, in turn, are much more employable.
"In the end," Mr. Bruhl said, "the only thing a company owns is its capacity to innovate, and that comes from people having the training and the skills to change. Your people need to have the lifelong ability to be constantly developed and nurtured and stimulated through education."

HEADLINE: THE PACIFIC SUMMIT: Reporter's Notebook;
Among the Totem Poles, An Unusual Gathering

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BLAKE ISLAND, Wash., Nov. 20

 BODY:
The White House wanted this summit conference, the first-ever gathering of the major nations of the Pacific, to look different -- something well beyond the usual guys-in-suits assemblies in formal settings.
What they got, on a raw Puget Sound day, was a cross between Twin Peaks and the Renaissance Weekend-cum-networking retreat that Bill Clinton used to attend on the other coast. 
 It was all sweaters and plaid shirts as the leaders of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum gathered inside an Indian long house on this uninhabited island of 475 acres, eight miles from Seattle. Even the Sultan of Brunei, considered the richest man in the world, looked like just another weekender on his Northwest holiday as he entered the long house here with the other world leaders.
The leaders noshed on salmon and blackberry cobbler inside the cedar-planked long house, which served the coastal Salish tribes, on an island where Chief Seattle was born more than 200 years ago.
Surrounded by the ageless glare of Indian totem poles, the leaders put aside the more factious issues of trade, tariffs and human rights to talk about the basic bonds that unite them. That may turn out to be nothing more than the Pacific Ocean, which laps against the most dynamic economic region in the world.
 
Will They Sing 'Kumbaya'?
 "Smooth sailing," Mr. Clinton said as he led the leaders single-file off the passenger ferry Tyee and into the lodge.
"I don't know if they are going to be holding hands and singing 'Kumbaya,' but this is just what the President had in mind," said Lorraine Voles, a White House spokeswoman. "This is all about getting to know each other."
It has been said that people dressed in down coats sometimes look like hand grenades with feet. Bundled against the Puget Sound chill, some of the Asian leaders looked as though they were fresh from an Eddie Bauer catalogue.
Inside the long house, the leaders sat in a semicircle under carved cedar Indian masks and canoe paddles, Mr. Clinton as the leader-moderator.
Business, Mr. Clinton has said with considerable bluntness over these last two days, is really what this get-together is all about. They may have talked about human rights in China, but the real concern is American apples for the Japanese market and Boeing 747's for anyone in the Pacific who needs one.
Mr. Clinton said earlier that he didn't mind being compared to a rug merchant. "I'm not ashamed that I've asked other countries to buy Boeing airplanes," he said.
 
Espresso and Grunge
 From the unrelenting politeness of the natives to the ubiquitous espresso carts, Seattle has been a culture shock to the Asian press and the White House advance team.
Early on in the week, Asian delegates milled around the free espresso offered in the convention center headquarters, befuddled by the array of choices of coffee, a local cliche.
But by Friday, everyone seemed hooked, and a caffeinated quirkiness prevailed. Even the President joined in, ordering, in response to a shout from a cart vendor, a "double shot decaf latte."
Awaiting the arrival of the leaders, foreign journalists could consult one of several "story concierges." But the suggestions that they visit the Microsoft Company Campus, the Boeing factory plant and the Space Needle were not enough. Many reporters wanted to know where they could find "grunge music" and how they could get to Snoqualmie Falls, where the cult international television hit "Twin Peaks" was filmed.
 
Waiting on the Sultan

As the home of Bill Gates, who was listed last year as the wealthiest man in America but has since slipped to No. 2, Seattle has gotten used to can-you-top-this stories about the wealth of the co-founder of Microsoft. But there has been a near frenzy of rumor and office talk about the Sultan of Brunei, whose fortune, estimated at $35 billion, makes him the wealthiest man in the world,
On his latest trip abroad, a visit to Cyprus, he reportedly left a tip of $170,000 with the hotel staff .
When this news hit Seattle several weeks ago, people were flooding the Four Seasons Olympic Hotel with fervid requests to act as bellboy or bellboy's assistant for a day. But the hotel staff has remained intact, and mum.
