HEADLINE: THE PACIFIC SUMMIT;
Godfather to Pacific Era? Clinton Succeeds by Merely Getting Asians to Meet

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Nov. 20

 BODY:
If Harry S. Truman was the midwife who attended at the birth of new Atlantic institutions such as NATO in the years following victory in World War II, President Clinton pictures himself as the godfather of new linkages in the Pacific in the aftermath of the cold war.
But in the last half-century, Asia has usually been more intractable for the United States than Europe, and this week's pioneering summit meeting of Pacific Rim leaders showed that shaping its future remains difficult.
 
 Mr. Clinton did not stumble here. It was no piddling achievement merely to get the leaders of Indonesia, Taiwan, China, South Korea and other countries together -- something that probably could not have been accomplished as recently as two years ago. In that sense, as Robert E. Rubin, a top presidential economic adviser, put it this week, "The meeting is the message."
"Meeting now and agreeing to meet again suggests the power of the social and economic forces propelling very different societies toward closer association," said Michel Oksenberg, president of the East-West Center in Honolulu. "Those forces are much greater than most of us understand, but it is still very hard to elicit a definitive response from most of these governments and therefore very hard to record measurable progress."
Nowhere more so than in the troubled relationship between Beijing and Washington. Mr. Clinton is touchingly ardent in his efforts to get along with the nation he described here as "home to one of every five people who live on this planet, and the world's fastest-growing major economy." He sees trade with China as a magic elixir that can cure many American economic ills.
But China gave no ground at all on human rights. It provided no fig-leaf to cover President Clinton's nakedness before those in the United States who demand concessions as the price of trade benefits. Indeed, in a press briefing on Friday, Qian Qichen, the Chinese Foreign Minister, stonewalled like a Soviet spokesman of the Brezhnev era. Regarding several of Mr. Clinton's proposed human-rights reforms, he said stolidly, there had been no discussion at all and no need for any, because China's policies were immutable.
It may be true, as Mr. Clinton hinted, that this was just posturing, Chinese-style, for consumption at home. It may be that with the country's paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping, in deteriorating health, and with the jostling for succession well under way, no one official can make a commitment, and President Jiang Zemin acted here more as a conduit to his colleagues in Beijing than as a decision-maker.
If so, the real result of the talks between Mr. Jiang and Mr. Clinton, the most significant contact between the two countries since the Tiananmen Square massacre of 1989, may not be known for several days or several weeks. Striking a far more conciliatory note than that struck by his delegation in Seattle, Mr. Jiang told a group of visiting Americans in Beijing last month that he had "every confidence that we will find our way through this."
But it is also true that the Chinese leader failed to follow up his recent promise to give "positive consideration" to permitting envoys of the International Committee of the Red Cross to visit his nation's 3,000 political prisoners. Some Western human rights workers had predicted that Mr. Jiang would announce plans to release some prisoners and to establish legal procedures for the rest to appeal their cases, but as far as is known, he did not.
Indeed, an Asian diplomat who has played a key role in the negotiations here characterized the attitude in the Chinese camp here as "very tough, very unyielding." Without explicitly threatening to leave the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation group, he said, the Chinese were saying that nothing would be accomplished until Washington stopped trying to link trade with human rights.
President Clinton tried one small gesture of decoupling, approving the sale to the Chinese of a relatively unsophisticated Cray supercomputer that was previously blocked. But he is committed not to renew special trade benefits, known as most-favored nation status, unless China eases its handling of dissidents. The benefits come up for renewal in June.
At the moment, the advantage appears to lie with the Chinese. Few in Washington think that Mr. Clinton would risk his grand vision for Asia, to say nothing of jeopardizing current trade with China, by withdrawing trade privileges; in fact, some see most favored nation status as the nuclear bomb of the 1990's -- a weapon so fearful that no one dares detonate it.
 
 
Bluff by Christopher?
 Secretary of State Warren Christopher said after Mr. Clinton's meeting with Mr. Jiang that concessions made now and early next year would weigh more heavily in Washington's decision than those made at the 11th hour next May. But that sounded like a bluff. In cold political terms, the Chinese can probably indulge with impunity their predilection for last-minute gestures, because late and well-publicized concessions from Beijing could hardly be met by Washington with a mutually damaging withdrawal of benefits.
The Chinese and other Pacific ministers meeting here this week surprised some of the doubters when they agreed to a common front on the global trade talks, proposing a list of further cuts in tariffs and challenging European participants to get moving. In a region where consensus rather than majority rule is the dominant mode, organizations move at the pace of their most cautious members and such forceful statements are uncommon.
Whether or not the action helps to break the deadlock in the global negotiations, aimed at strengthening the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, it was hailed by the Administration as a sign of what can be achieved.
Unfortunately for Mr. Clinton's larger purposes, most of the leaders made abundantly clear their opposition to the early creation of a Pacific free-trade zone, which would include the world's three largest economies, those of the United States, Japan and China, and account for half of the world's gross national product as well as 40 percent of world trade.
Nobuo Matsunaga, Japan's former Ambassador to the United States who is here as his Government's special envoy to the Pacific Rim talks, said that it would take 5 to 10 years for the free-trade idea to mature. The recommendation for a faster pace by the so-called Eminent Persons Group, a panel of private citizens headed by the American economist C. Fred Bergsten, was speedily consigned to the limbo where old position-papers dwell.
"If Mr. Clinton tries to rush us, he will fail, and the whole idea will fail as well," Ambassador Matsunaga said. "He must be patient."

HEADLINE: U.S. Aid Hasn't Stopped Drug Flow From South America, Experts Say

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Nov. 20

 BODY:
It was the summer of 1989, and drug lords were gunning down presidential candidates in Colombia and flooding American cities with cocaine. Declaring that there was "no match for an angry America," President Bush announced that he was expanding the war on drugs.
Though his main pledge was to crack down on street sales, Mr. Bush also asked Congress to increase spending to help cut off the drug supply at its source in Peru, Colombia and Bolivia. 
 Four years and roughly $2 billion later, drug policy experts interviewed throughout the Andes share a conclusion: The flow of drugs from South America to North America has not slowed.
"We haven't had any real impact on the drug flow," one official at the United States Embassy here said. He noted that Peru seized 7 tons of cocaine and cocaine base last year out of an estimated 650 tons produced there. "That's peanuts," he said.
 
Failed Campaigns
 American drug enforcement agents have tried forcible eradication of crops of coca leaf, the essential ingredient of cocaine; substituting other crops for coca; destroying cocaine laboratories, and tightening customs controls on refining chemicals. They have patrolled the skies to interdict flights by drug planes and widened investigations of money laundering by traffickers.
But in a market dictated by supply and demand, the American-financed efforts have at best raised operating costs in a highly profitable business. In one indication that there is no shortage on the streets, the prices and purity levels of illegal drugs sold in the United States have remained relatively stable over the last four years.
Today Washington is sending crossed signals to South America on the future of the drug war. Clinton Administration officials are talking about "tracking down the bees in the hive" and devoting more money to catching cocaine traffickers in the source countries.
"We can't stop our efforts -- that would be to doom a number of these countries to even greater attack by narco-traffickers," said Timothy E. Wirth, a State Department counselor who advises the White House on drug policy.
 
Congress Cuts Funds
 But Congress is cutting aid to Peru, Bolivia, Colombia and Ecuador for military and police action to block drug shipments by about one third this year, to roughly $90 million. Overall American aid for anti-drug efforts in Peru, Colombia and Bolivia is also declining.
"The Clinton Administration is afraid to say that an international drug war can't work," said Kevin B. Zeese, vice president of the Drugs Policy Foundation, a Washington-based group.
The reaction in the Andean countries has been muted. Many South Americans say their governments joined the so-called drug war only to soothe the United States and were always skeptical that its enforcement strategies would work.
"Drugs are only on the agenda in Peru when Fujimori goes to the U.S. or when Lee Brown comes through Lima," said Roberto Lerner Stein, a local drug expert, referring to Alberto K. Fujimori, the Peruvian President. On the day that Mr. Brown, President Clinton's top drug policy official, visited Lima last August, Peru's Congress approved a bill requiring that convicted traffickers get life sentences.
A case study of the obstacles to enforcement is offered at Santa Lucia, a mountain base in Peru's Huallaga Valley that has cost American taxpayers about $100 million over the last five years. Four years ago, American Embassy officials talked enthusiastically of using Santa Lucia as a base for eradicating coca leaf cultivation in the valley, Peru's prime growing area.
 
Air and Land Attack
 Initially joint teams of Peruvians and Americans descended by helicopter to mountain slopes and attacked fields of coca bushes with weed cutters. But Shining Path guerrillas fired on the helicopters, forcing police officers to abandon the manual eradication exercise.
Then the United States experimented with aerial spraying of herbicides in an attempt to kill the crops. Peru's Government then blocked that move out of fear of driving unemployed and desperate peasants into the ranks of the Shining Path.
Cocaine laboratories and drug planes were the next targets. Guided by American-supplied radar, Peruvian Air Force pilots have shot down or forced down eight small planes used for trafficking this year -- a tiny fraction of the hundreds that are estimated to carry drugs from Peru annually.
And when cocaine trafficking is pressured in one area, it shifts to another. Colombian planes now often fly over Brazil before darting into Peru for pickups.
On the ground, traffickers have shifted refining operations in Peru from enormous factory-size laboratories to mobile, easily concealed jungle labs. To reduce transportation costs, leaders of Colombia's powerful cocaine cartels also increasingly refine cocaine in Bolivia. Cocaine now accounts for two-thirds of Bolivia's drug exports, up from one-third at the start of the drug war.
 
Change of Route
 Police efforts have also prompted traffickers to diversify their export routes. Today the lion's share of South America's cocaine exports slips through countries that are not significant producers, including Argentina, Brazil, Ecuador, Mexico and Venezuela.
On Nov. 6, the Venezuelan police broke up a trafficking ring that was reported to be shipping one ton of Colombian cocaine a month to the United States. Underscoring Venezuela's role as a transit country, United States officials acknowledged on Friday that a C.I.A. anti-drug program there accidently allowed a ton of nearly pure cocaine to be shipped to the United States in 1990.
Similarly, coca leaf cultivation in Peru has shifted out of helicopter range of Santa Lucia, which is in the Upper Huallaga River Valley. Moving into the central and lower valley, about 200,000 farmers now grow coca in an area that was largely rain forest only four years ago. New coca cultivation destroys 500,000 acres of Peru's Amazon rain forest every year, according to Peru's National Institute of Natural Resources, a Government agency.
"You can win in some areas, but then they are replaced by other areas," said Dr. Lerner, a Peruvian psychologist who studies drug issues here. "Supply depends on the consumer market."
Next month American drug advisers are to leave the Santa Lucia base as part of a 50 percent cut in total anti-drug aid to Peru. "By the end of the year we have to wrap it up," said one American official here. "We are already moving out equipment."
 
Peruvian Criticizes U.S.
 Mr. Fujimori, the Peruvian President, has bluntly criticized the Americans' anti-drug strategies. An agronomist by training, Mr. Fujimori has long argued that the best aid would be economic incentives to persuade coca leaf growers move to alternative crops.
"Many people would accept alternative crops, but there are no loans," Mr. Fujimori said in a recent news conference here. "For weapons, there's money. But to develop agriculture, there's no money."
In Colombia, which has the strongest economy of the Andean countries, President Cesar Gaviria recently told President Clinton that Colombia would make up any cuts in American aid from its own budget. One of the American-financed programs, an effort to reform and protect Colombia's judiciary, is highly popular with the public.
But, in Bolivia, the poorest nation of the region, officials warn that American aid is essential for maintaining anti-drug efforts.
Because Bolivian cocaine is also exported to Europe, Bolivia's new Minister of Government, German Quiroga, said in a recent interview that his country would have to turn to countries like France and Germany for help.
American drug enforcement officials interviewed early this month in Bolivia, Colombia, Peru and Venezuela preferred to emphasize individual successes in the anti-drug fight.
They note that Peruvian Air Force planes regularly fire on trafficking planes, sending them crashing into the Amazon jungle. In Colombia, the police have killed or jailed most of the top leaders of the Medellin cocaine cartel. In Bolivia, crop substitution programs have encouraged peasants to eradicate about 20 percent of the nation's coca plants since 1989.
 
Cocaine Still No. 1 Export
 But cocaine powder and semi-refined cocaine remain the largest single export items for Bolivia, Colombia and Peru. In Bolivia and Peru, about 5 percent of the population depend on coca crops as a livelihood. Peruvians grow about two-thirds of the world's coca leaf, a market share that has changed little during four years of the drug war.
"You can't declare war on three million peasants," said Hernando de Soto, who coordinated Peru's anti-drug strategy two years ago. "When I was Peru's drug czar, the only people I could talk to in Washington were cops or people who wanted peasants to raise silkworms."
After years of research, American and Peruvian Governments have failed to come up with a product that competes with coca leaf or with incentives that rival those of the Colombian cocaine cartels.
The cartels often provide agricultural credit. They pick up products at the farm gate. They pay cash. And they circumvent the red tape surrounding legal exports.
 
Little Farm Credit
 In contrast, Peru's cash-strapped Government provides virtually no farm credit. Guerrilla violence has damaged the nation's road and bridge networks to such an extent that Amazon farmers cannot afford to send products to cities like Lima on the Pacific Coast. Bureaucratic demands involving licensing and paperwork close export markets to all but the most sophisticated farmers.
Experts say that hundreds of millions of dollars in aid -- far more than Western nations are willing to provide -- would be needed to develop alternative agricultural programs and transportation systems to get the crops to market.
"In Lima, it is cheaper to import a redwood tree from California than to bring a log from the Amazon," Mr. de Soto said. "The peasants say they want to substitute coca. But to do that you have to create a market environment."
Not only has the coca leaf harvest defied Washington's wishes, but poppy fields are appearing in Colombia and Peru. Virtually unknown to the country five years ago, poppies are now grown on an estimated 75,000 acres in Colombia. Today, Colombia is second only to Burma in production of poppies for heroin.
 
Widespread Corruption
 Official corruption is also a challenge in countries where policemen make $90 a month and judges earn $200 a month. In Peru, 15 policemen were recently jailed on charges of accepting a $100,000 bribe in return for freeing one of the Huallaga Valley's biggest drug traffickers, a Colombian named Waldo Vargas, a day after he was detained in May.
In Colombia, a Deputy Attorney General, Guillermo Villa, was dismissed last month after it was discovered that he was a friend of Gilberto Rodriguez Orejuela, who with his brother, Miguel, controls the country's powerful Cali cocaine cartel.
In Venezuela, President Ramon J. Velasquez nearly resigned this month after he discovered that he had pardoned a major cocaine trafficker. The 78-year-old President maintains that one of his secretaries was to blame for slipping the pardon into a pile of documents awaiting signature. But the police are investigating reports that the family of the trafficker, Larry Tovar Acuna, paid $800,000 to win his release.
Although seizures of drug shipments actually declined throughout the Andes last year, United States officials argue that American aid has strengthened police forces and court systems in South America by fostering an attitude that drug-related payoffs are still scandalous.
"We have prevented the country from falling into the hands of the 'narcos,' " a United States Embassy official said in Bolivia. "If we leave Bolivia, corruption will go to all levels."

HEADLINE: Senators in Nigeria Balk at Military Takeover

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LAGOS, Nov. 20

 BODY:
In one of the first signs of open opposition to the Nigeria's new military ruler, 67 elected senators vowed today not to surrender their seats in the federal legislature, which has been dissolved. But they did not say how they would resist the new military government.
"The military must know that they are not armed to treat Nigerians and Nigeria like a conquered people and an occupied territory," the senators said in a statement. It was a rare show of unity for a chamber that had been sharply divided during the political crisis, which began with the nullification of the June 12 presidential election. The statement was issued after the senators were ejected from government-paid hotel rooms in Abuja, the capital. 
 "Every military administration justifies its takeover with claims to have the ability to clean up the society, but ends up being more corrupt than the preceding one," the statement said.
On Wednesday, Gen. Sani Abacha, the Defense Minister, ousted the interim civilian government of Ernest Shonekan. The next day he dissolved the federal legislature, the 30 state governments and all local councils, and also banned political activity. He promised to institute a new democratic system, but did not say when.
Nigeria was plunged into chaos when Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, who spent eight years promising a return to an elected civilian government, nullified the results of the June election.
The apparent winner of that vote, Moshood Abiola, in his first remarks since General Abacha's takeover, said today that he would have to consult with his advisers before deciding what action to take.
After canceling the results of the presidential election, General Babangida resigned under pressure and named Mr. Shonekan to succeed him. General Abacha said he was ousting Mr. Shonekan and dismantling democratic institutions to better deal with Nigeria's worsening economic woes and widespread civil unrest.
Nigeria has been in the grip of a nationwide general strike called to protest a sharp fuel price increase Mr. Shonekan imposed two weeks ago. Today, labor leaders met with the new government labor director, but Adamo Oshimole, deputy director of the National Labor Congress, said the government had spurned their demand to scale back the price increase.
General Abacha, who received military training from the United States and who helped lead coups in 1983 and 1985, met in Lagos today with the Ambassadors from the United States, France and Britain. A spokesman for the general said the talks were "frank and cordial." There was no immediate comment from the ambassadors.

HEADLINE: THE PACIFIC SUMMIT;
BOYCOTT IN ORDER, MALAYSIAN SAYS

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Nov. 20

 BODY:
As President Clinton played host this weekend to Government leaders from across Asia, one Prime Minister who declined his invitation to Seattle, Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, was pleased that he stayed home.
Prime Minister Mahathir, who is known here for his caustic anti-Western oratory and for his well-honed sense of political theater, insisted again today that he made the right decision in boycotting the summit meeting. 
 "I have no regrets," he told reporters in Kuala Lumpur, the futuristic capital of a nation that during his 13 years in office has been transformed into an economic dynamo. "I'm happy to be here."
He said that there were important reasons for his decision to reject President Clinton's invitation. The Prime Minister said that he was disappointed before the summit meeting by the cool response of the United States and other nations to an Asians-only economic grouping that he has championed.
 
A Publicity Bonus
 And was it also possible, he was asked, that by boycotting the Seattle meeting there was a publicity bonus for Malaysia, which otherwise might have been ignored at the summit?
"There is something to be said about that," Prime Minister Mahathir conceded, a large grin on his face as he explained his theory that it can be better for the leader of a small nation to be notorious than to be anonymous.
"When a country is doing well, is peaceful, nobody is interested," he said. "Perhaps you have to thumb your nose at people before they notice you. Perhaps that may be a strategy we will follow. We should arrest a few foreign journalists -- then we'll be noticed." He laughed again.
During Dr. Mahathir's tenure, Malaysia has produced prosperity where a generation ago there was only poverty. While the per capita income in Malaysia is only about $3,000 a year, it is growing rapidly. The economy has expanded at a rate of more than 8 percent in each of the last five years.
But freedom is limited here and the judicial system is often criticized by international human rights groups. The Government tolerates little dissent, and news organizations are timid in their coverage of government affairs.
 
Notorious Drug Laws
 Outside Asia, Malaysia has probably gained more notoriety for its drug laws -- which require the death penalty for trafficking in small amounts of narcotics, even when the accused are Western tourists -- than for anything else.
Within Asia at least, Dr. Mahathir -- he was educated as a physician -- should have no concerns about being noticed.
The influence of the 68-year-old leader in Southeast Asia is out of proportion to Malaysia's population of only 18 million people. "He might be willing to offend Western diplomats, but you'd never see him be rude to a Western businessman," said an American diplomat. "He understands the value of foreign investment and free markets."
Dr. Mahathir said today that he might have attended the Seattle meeting had there been more support from the West for the East Asian Economic Caucus, the all-Asian economic grouping that he devised three years ago.
He has promoted the caucus, which exists now as little more than a name, as a counterweight to the European Community and to efforts among the nations of North America to lower regional trade barriers.
The United States and other Western nations have sought to block the creation of a powerful East Asian economic group out of fear that it could become a trade bloc that would shut out Western powers.
While Prime Minister Mahathir has praised the Clinton Administration as "more accommodating" than the Bush Administration in its approach to Asia, he said today that he still feared Western powers were turning their foreign policies toward Asia "merely in order to have a share of the economic dynamism and the market potential."
"They should be focusing on Asia because Asia is an important part of the world," he said.

HEADLINE: Outlook for Cuba Grim, Study for State Dept. Says

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Nov. 20

 BODY:
A new report on Cuba paints a grim picture of the island's future, saying that attempts at economic reform now under way will probably lead to civil strife before the end of the decade.
The report, which was commissioned by the State Department, says President Fidel Castro and Cuba's Communist Party leadership are attempting limited free-market reforms modeled after those undertaken in China. It concludes, however, that a number of factors, from Mr. Castro's highly centralized rule to a reluctance by the Communist leadership to unleash market forces "will deny Cuba the economic benefits of the China scenario." 
 The 674 page report, titled "Transition in Cuba, New Challenges for U.S. Policy," is the product of nearly two years of work by a team of 17 academics. It was produced under the supervision of Lisandro Perez, a specialist in Cuban affairs at Florida International University in Miami.
Cuba's economy has stumbled badly since the demise of the former Soviet Union two years ago, shrinking more than half by some estimates. Hoping to arrest that decline, Havana has accelerated the pace of its own economic reforms, allowing citizens to form small private businesses, legally possess foreign currency and form their own agricultural cooperatives.
"Cuba's future will be grim, no matter what is the name of its ruler or the form of its political regime," the report says. "The most optimistic conclusions set the date for an appreciably more liberal, more democratic, and more prosperous Cuba no sooner than the beginning of the millennium."
In what the report describes as the two most likely scenarios for Cuba's immediate future, the island's leadership, unwilling to undertake bolder political and economic reforms for fear they would threaten their hold on power, will attempt to muddle through the present crisis, tinkering around the edges of a collapsing system.
In the first scenario, the Government faces a challenge, such as a coup attempt or food riots, perhaps as early as next year, and is able to survive.
The repressive measures needed to put down the challenge, however, spark civil conflict that quickly draws the involvement of the large Cuban American community in Florida. As the strife spreads, the report says, the United States may feel obliged to become militarily involved to help end the crisis and remove the Castro Government.
Under the second scenario, the Castro Government is able to hang on until late in the decade, but at the cost of continued economic deterioration and social decay. When challenged domestically, what would by then be a much weaker government collapses, much as happened in some of the countries of Eastern Europe.
"All the evidence available to us suggests that the willingness to undertake bold reforms is lacking," said Jorge Dominguez, a Harvard University professor who directed the political analyses in the report. "You have the possibility of a riot over food or an immigration crisis some time in the near future, or things could drag on for a while until the economy is gone, there is no more respect for the law and things just begin to collapse."
Another scenario, considered less likely, includes an attempt to follow the example of the ruling party of Mexico, which has opened its economy and allowed a limited form of political pluralism but manipulated the system to retain control.
Dissenting scholars of Cuban affairs say that while the country's situation is dire, it is by no means a foregone conclusion that the island's economic reforms are doomed to failure, or that its economy cannot be revived.
"A lot of what will determine the success of the China model is external to Cuba," said Andrew Zimbalist, an economist at Smith College. "What will the United States' European allies policies be toward the American embargo, which many find distasteful? How much oil will the Cubans discover? What will be the price of nickel in five years?
"I don't see any kind of economic miracle in the making," he added, "but the Cubans have enough balloons in the air so that some of them might fructify and create some strength."

HEADLINE: Rabies Fear Is the Latest Barrier to Deer Hunting

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANCRAM, N.Y., Nov. 19

 BODY:
For the first time in 20 years, Brian Yorck will not get up before dawn on Monday to go out hunting on the opening day of the deer season in southern New York State.
"My concern is the rabies problem," he said. 
 Although the number of rabid deer is relatively small -- only 13 confirmed cases in a deer population of almost a million -- some hunters like Mr. Yorck think there is no point in taking a chance.
The State Department of Environmental Conservation shares that concern -- to the point of issuing guidelines on how to handle carcasses for the tens of thousands of hunters who will be in the field for food or sport or camaraderie from Monday through Dec. 14.
 
Hunters Are Declining
 But the department, which regulates hunting in the state, is more worried about long-term trends like a continuing decline in hunters and a rapid growth in the deer population. That has both environmental and economic implications in a state where hunters contribute an estimated $100 million a year to the economy.
"Kids in their formative years are spending their time in malls, not in the woods," said Ed Feldman, an official in the state's Bureau of Fish and Wildlife.
The total number of licenses to hunt deer fell from 811,000 in 1985 to 694,000 in 1992, according to the state's big-game experts. This year's figures are not yet available.
The decline in hunting in New York State reflects a national trend, according to three researchers at Cornell University.
 
The Future Looks Bleak
 "The future of hunting looks bleak, given social values coupled with recent and projected trends in American demographics," said the researchers, Daniel J. Decker, Jody W. Enck and Tommy L. Brown, members of the Human Dimensions Research Unit of the Department of Natural Resources at Cornell.
The wildlife experts said hunting was declining for reasons as varied as a rise in single-parent families, with fewer opportunities for children to learn hunting from their fathers, and a decrease in land available for hunting because many property owners don't allow it.
In addition, the Cornell researchers quoted other studies reporting that many Americans feel killing animals for pleasure, male bonding, tradition or food is "simply inappropriate" in modern society.
Coincident with the decline in hunting has been an increase in the deer population of New York and other states to the point where deer are considered pests in many areas.
 
Mild Winters Cited
 James Glidden, head of the state's Big Game Unit, said the decline in hunting only partly explains the population rise. More important, he said, was a series of mild winters and a return of many farm fields to young forest growth that provides an ideal habitat for deer.
As a result, the statewide size of the deer herd has climbed to almost a million, up from 450,000 in 1978, too many for the natural range to support.
In their quest for food, hungry deer have invaded farmers' fields and suburban lawns as far south as Westchester County to eat shrubs near houses.
"They have reached the limit of toleration," said Glenn Cole, head of the conservation department's wildlife unit at New Paltz. "And the herd is getting bigger."
 
Females Are the Key
 Because controlling female deers is key to controlling the population, the state issues special permits for licensed hunters to shoot an antlerless deer in addition to a buck.
Last year, a record number of deer were killed -- 118,000 bucks and 115,000 does and fawns. Although the total of 233,000 was up from 213,000 the year before, it was not enough to cope with the increase in the deer population.
Of the deers killed last year, 64,000 were female adults, less than the department's target of 70,000. This year, it issued more special permits than ever before, with a target of 71,200 does.
But the 1993 hunting picture is clouded by the fear of rabies.
"Most hunters will never see a rabid deer," the department said.
Nonetheless, it issued guidelines for the safe handling of carcasses and recommended that venison be cooked at least to 140 degrees Fahrenheit to kill any bacteria or viruses that might be present.
"The likelihood of contracting rabies from deer is very slim," Mr. Cole said. "But some people are concerned and may not hunt. It could affect the take."

HEADLINE: On Sunday;
News, News And More For the Irish

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES

 BODY:
THERE are times when the patriot's game can seem confounding, even ludicrous, as with the $7.4 million Brink's robbery in which Federal agents have suddenly netted a veritable Sean O'Casey farce of circumstance and suspects: Bags of money scattered about a dim tenement apartment; an Irish revolutionary hiding out in America as a comic book dealer in Queens; an Irish-American cop -- long the New World role model for the Irish people -- arrested as a worker at the plundered Brink's depot, and a classically ascetic Irish priest, beloved as "Father Pat" who toiled for decades among the least of our urban brethren down in the Lower East Side, arrested as a principal in the outsized caper.
All have denied the charge of being found in possession of bags of the stolen fortune, let alone actually stealing it. But with the great playwright O'Casey dead and buried there's no witty way to be imagined out of all this, only the plodding process of criminal justice. 
 "Hollywood couldn't have done it better," says Brian Rohan, who scooped the city last week in the Irish Voice with an exclusive interview with the Rev. Patrick Moloney proclaiming his innocence from his holding cell, before the priest made bail. "Father Pat's a great guy, a sweet guy, but I would have a problem putting him in charge of tonight's dinner, let alone a Brink's heist," says Mr. Rohan, who, as a ubiquitous reporter in the city's resurgent Irish community, fairly summarizes the general puzzlement and wariness at this story.
No one loves an odd tale that shreds a few of life's cliches more than the Irish do; they specialize in this to the point of having co-opted the English language of their colonial occupiers and reforged it into a blazing Irish art. But this story of Father Pat has some unpromising edges, not the least of which is the suspicion, far from proven, that much of the Brink's loot might have been intended for the Irish Republican Army's continuing guerrilla war against the British presence in Northern Ireland.
The I.R.A. itself and official supporters of the reunification cause in this country have quickly, angrily denied all such suspicions. To be found looting this land of traditional sanctuary would risk perverting decades of tolerance here for the long-running cause of Irish nationalism. It would be more Realpolitik debacle than O'Casey farce. And this at a time of considerably renewed interest in the cause among the flow of ever-arriving young Irish immigrants.
Most usually pay little attention to the Northern troubles as they grow up in the Southern republic and face its overwhelming economic problems and the bittersweet choice to emigrate. Once in New York, many look back if not in anger, then in greater need of detail about their larger Irish history. Thus hundreds of them, bolstered by older generations of Irish-Americans, held a surprisingly large demonstration recently outside the British consulate to contend that the London Government has been half-hearted about a promising new peace initiative under way lately in the North.
For all the interest in the Father Pat story, it still had to share even greater front-page space in the city's Irish newspapers last week with the peace initiative's developments. Non-Irish just tuning in for the priest's tale could read all about the considerable controversy generated by President Clinton again barring a visa for Gerry Adams. He is the leader of Sinn Finn, the political arm of the I.R.A., and is deeply involved in the peace talks as an articulate yet enigmatic man who denies the White House charge that he also takes part in the I.R.A.'s more violent stratagems.
"I don't think the Empire State Building will crumble if Gerry Adams is let in," was the visitor's observation from Boston of Tim Pat Coogan, an eminent Irish journalist who is a cold-eyed expert on I.R.A. history.
Barred visas, fragile peace hopes, agonizing death of innocents back home: That's the traditional Irish-American story, of course, not this odd tale of Father Pat and the Brink's heist. Resourceful as all other city newcomers chafing at the hyphen in their status, the Irish fortunately topped all of the above for sheer storytelling dynamics by the end of the week with the exciting tale of Jack's Lads. That's the popular nickname of the Irish republic's soccer team, which narrowly avoided playoff elimination to qualify for a greatly coveted place in the 1994 World Cup tournament to be held in the United States.
To qualify, Jack's Lads, ranked 11th in the world, barely managed a tie with the lower rated Northern Irish team in a peaceful, sporting game that mixed Irish and British players in as poetic a form of good news imaginable for the city's Irish community. Jack's Lads will be coming, in person, not merely through the dish antennas dotting the city's pub tops. What a relief from this business about stolen millions and aberrational Irishness.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 538 words

HEADLINE: North Korea's Opening

 BODY:
Nervous commentators fear that North Korea is about to develop nuclear weapons, leading them to urge immediate sanctions or even bombing raids to take out the regime's nuclear facilities. But President Clinton is adopting a sound diplomatic strategy for coaxing North Korea to give up its nuclear ambitions.
The U.S. and South Korea will cancel the provocative Team Spirit military exercises they conduct annually if North Korea opens its nuclear sites to regular inspection and resumes talks with South Korea. That could set the stage for trading U.S. diplomatic recognition for a verifiable end to North Korea's nuclear program -- which in turn could lead to aid and investment from abroad. 
 North Korea has said it will resolve the nuclear issue if the U.S. takes steps to "renounce its nuclear threat" -- a veiled reference to Team Spirit. Mr. Clinton is offering the opening Pyongyang has long sought. Now it must live up to its word.
North Korea signed the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty in 1985. But it did not allow the International Atomic Energy Agency to inspect its nuclear facilities until 1992, after the U.S. withdrew its nuclear warheads from South Korea. North and South Korea also agreed to ban reprocessing of plutonium on the peninsula. Such reprocessing is needed to convert spent nuclear reactor fuel into weapons-grade plutonium.
But North Korea has never agreed to arrangements to verify the North-South accord. And when I.A.E.A. inspectors turned up evidence that the North's reactor may have been operating longer -- and produced more spent fuel -- than the North had said, Pyongyang barred special inspections of its nuclear waste sites that could have helped clear up the discrepancy. It also suspended regular inspections, claiming that the I.A.E.A. was being unfair and that the U.S. and South Korea were still making nuclear threats.
These actions immediately raised suspicions that North Korea was stalling inspections while it rushed ahead with bomb-making. But there is no evidence that its reprocessing plant has begun operating. Its backtracking may have been just a bargaining tactic to get the best deal for giving up its nuclear program. Mr. Clinton's diplomacy will test that proposition.
Impatient hawks have urged tougher measures, like bombing North Korea's nuclear facilities. But U.S. intelligence suspects the North may have secret sites. If so, they cannot be targeted.
Others urge immediate imposition of sanctions by the United Nations. While North Korea's economy is one of the most self-sufficient in the world, it does depend on imported oil for 10 percent of its energy needs. An oil cutoff would require cooperation from China both in the Security Council and on its border with North Korea.
But neither Beijing nor Seoul wants to see North Korea collapse, sending refugees or its army spilling across their borders. So sanctions will be applied only as a last resort.
That's why Mr. Clinton is rightly resisting pressure to get tough with Pyongyang. Instead, he's taking a calculated political risk that the North means what it says. But Pyongyang should not be under any illusion: if it continues to balk, tougher measures are sure to follow.

HEADLINE: Trade Pact Offers Chance to Export Our Ideals

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"This country's greatness was not built on cheap labor," Representative Richard A. Gephardt stated in the waning hours of the debate on the North American Free Trade Agreement. That statement does a disservice to the working people of this country and to history.
This country was most definitely built on cheap labor. From African slave laborers to indentured servants, convicts, children, Chinese chain gangs, Irish labor camps, lofts of Eastern European Jews and more, the great expansion and consolidation of this country's land holdings and economy were built on the cheapest labor available and paid for by trading fear for hope and the workers' present for their children's future. 
 Mr. Gephardt's complaints of Mexican labor and labor laws could have been made against United States labor and labor laws in this century, when wages were criminally low, workplaces were treacherous and often deadly, and unions were illegal.
Since World War II, workers have watched their increasingly bloated union leadership, Mr. Gephardt's allies, bargain away thousands of jobs in collusion with increasingly bloated corporate leadership.
Some American jobs have been going and will continue to go to Mexico, free trade agreement or no, and it is cynicism for Mr. Gephardt to allow his supporters to believe otherwise.
Now that the North American Free Trade Agreement has passed, Mr. Gephardt and his cronies owe it to those he claims to represent to take advantage of what may be gained. Lane Kirkland of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has vowed not to forget those who voted in favor of the trade agreement. He should stop wasting his members' pension money on this selfish vendetta; there is more on the line than his machismo. In addition to the goods, services and foodstuffs that we can export to Mexico and the rest of the world, we should be exporting our principles of government and trade unionism.
 
DAVID ELLIOTT KIDD
New York, Nov. 18, 1993

HEADLINE: Trade Pact Offers Chance to Export Our Ideals;

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Gary Hufbauer's attack on the A.F.L.-C.I.O. for opposing the North American Free Trade Agreement (Op-Ed, Nov. 15) distorts organized labor's position on global trade. 
The labor movement fought for strong side agreements, including labor, social and environmental standards. That's not what we got. The Congressional strategy to pass the trade agreement depended on strong pro-business Republican support and maintaining the support of the authoritarian Salinas regime in Mexico. Both of these precluded side agreements that could protect workers in the United States and Mexico.

Our union will continue to argue for a trading policy based on a high-wage strategy that takes advantage of the productivity of United States workers. The free trade agreement is not the answer to our economic problems.
 
JACK SHEINKMAN

and Textile Workers Union

HEADLINE: Trade Pact Offers Chance to Export Our Ideals;
Nothing for the Poor

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am disappointed that your Nov. 16 editorial implied I would vote against the North American Free Trade Agreement because I am running scared. It is hard to believe you could conclude that the approximately $60,000 I received from labor political action committees each election cycle, less than 25 percent of my contributions, would sway my decision. Especially when my constituents have never given me less than 80 percent of their support in the last 20 years. 
 I believe that the North American Free Trade Agreement is an important move toward free trade. It will accomplish its goals. The economy of all of North America will improve with new jobs in all three countries.
There is no question that some American jobs will be lost. But, unlike organized labor, I believe that in any event many of these jobs will be lost in time. While I regret acceleration of the loss, that is not enough reason for me to oppose the trade agreement.
I opposed the free trade agreement because not enough is being done to make sure that all Americans will be able to take advantage of the new jobs it will create. There are in this country too many people who are without education and training to qualify for these new opportunities. They are the people living in poverty and surrounded by despair and drugs.
Until I see an effort to make it possible for the poor of this country to share in the bounty I will oppose the North American Free Trade Agreement.
 
CHARLES B. RANGEL
Member of Congress, 15th Dist., N.Y.
Washington, Nov. 17, 1993

HEADLINE: Without Earlier Drama, Trade Accord Is Passed

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
With little of the drama or emotion that characterized the debate in the House on Wednesday, the Senate gave final Congressional approval tonight to the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Under the accord, tariffs and other trade barriers between the United States, Canada and Mexico will be gradually removed beginning on Jan. 1, creating the largest free-trade zone in the world. 
 The Senate approved the legislation to put the accord into effect by a vote of 61 to 38. Politically, it was the most important issue of the year for President Clinton and Congress. But passage in the Senate was never in doubt, the way it had been in the House, where it passed on Wednesday by a vote of 234 to 200.
As was the case in the House, party loyalty in the Senate was abandoned and the President prevailed on the strength of Republican support. Voting for the measure were 27 Democrats and 34 Republicans. Voting against it were 28 Democrats and 10 Republicans.
 
Hope for an Expanded Market
 "I do not believe that this Nafta is necessarily going to produce jobs immediately," said Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, "but it offers the hope that an expanded market will expand employment in our country."
Taking a different view was Senator Herb Kohl, Democrat of Wisconsin, who said, "If we do not lose jobs, which we will, it certainly will have a depressing effect on the wage structure in this country."
The trade measure created some unusual alliances. The Democratic leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, and the Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, supported the legislation. Senators Carol Moseley Braun, Democrat of Illinois, and Jesse A. Helms, Republican of North Carolina, were joined in opposition.
 
A 15-Pound Agreement
 The outcome tonight did not turn on the arcane provisions of the 15-pound agreement, which would abolish some tariffs immediately and phase out others over 5, 10 or 15 years.
Nor did it really turn on the question of jobs. Depending on whether the projections of proponents or opponents are right, the accord will either lead to a few hundred thousand net new jobs in the United States or cost the country a few hundred thousand jobs. In either case, that is insignificant to an economy with about 120 million workers.
But the trade pact came to stand for the economic changes that are sweeping the country in the aftermath of the cold war: more demand for American products abroad and for foreign goods here; the shrinking military industries; ever fewer blue-collar jobs, and increased opportunities for workers who are highly educated and masters of new technology.
Those changes are promising to many Americans but frightening to many others. Businesses seeking new markets for their exports were strong supporters of the accord. Labor unions were vigorously opposed.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "The Trade Pact at a Glance"
 
THE NORTH AMERICAN FREE TRADE AGREEMENT would bind the economies of Canada, Mexico and the United States. It would take effect on Jan. 1, 1994, and would eliminate various taxes and rules to allow goods and services to be sold freely from the Arctic to Acapulco. Because the United States and Canada entered into a free-trade agreement on Jan. 1, 1989, the North American pact would mainly affect trade between Mexico and the United States and between Mexico and Canada.
 
HOW THE DRAFT CHANGED: The Clinton Administration negotiated two side agreements and several special deals benefiting United States industrial and agricultural interests as various as sugar beet and orange juice producers and makers of household appliances. The three countries agreed to cooperate in monitoring environmental abuses; they also agreed to a process for investigating of labor abuses, a compromise union leaders found too weak.
 
WHAT IT ISN'T: The free-trade zone created by the agreement would not involve common tariffs and other trade barriers toward the rest of the world. Nor would it include efforts to combine currencies, welfare programs and immigration policies.
 
THE KEY: Tariffs: Taxes that the Federal Government collects on goods from other countries. The agreement would phase out tariffs immediately or, in some cases, over 5, 10 or 15 years. Mexican tariffs on American goods average 10 percent.
 
AFFECTED INDUSTRIES
 
Agriculture: The United States and Mexico would eliminate 57 percent of their trade barriers immediately, the rest over 15 years.
 
Auto makers: Would eliminate or cut tariffs on vehicles assembled in each country. Mexico would eliminate import quotas on automobiles.
 
Banks and brokerages: Mexico would virtually dismantle its ban on American banks, and American securities firms would be allowed to increase their investment in the Mexican market.
 
Textiles: Would eliminate many Mexican tariffs immediately and American and Canadian tariffs of up to 30 percent over 10 years.
 
Energy: American drilling companies would be allowed to share in profits from oil strikes in Mexico.
 
Trucking: Mexican and American truck drivers would be allowed to drive their rigs in each other's countries by the end of the century.

HEADLINE: TRADE VOTE EFFECT MAY EBB OVER TIME

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Of all the politicians who President Clinton said had "put their political careers on the line" in voting for the North American Free Trade Agreement, Representative Sam Farr could have topped the list.
Mr. Farr, a Democrat from Carmel, Calif., is a newcomer to Congress who barely made it in the first place. He had to fight off more than two dozen rivals in a primary before winning a special election in June. 
 And, because he reneged this week on his campaign pledge to oppose the trade accord, unions that were critical to his victory are now offering to mount an all-out effort in 1994 to help Bill Monning, a Democrat who was Mr. Farr's closest rival in the open primary, challenge Mr. Farr.
But Mr. Monning is not sure he wants to take on Mr. Farr again. "The question I would raise, hypothetically, is, three months from now, how much of the electorate is going to remember the Nafta vote?" he asked.
 
Political Bravado
 For all the cries of betrayal from the unions, for Ross Perot's chest-beating threats that "we'll remember in November," and for all of Mr. Clinton's bravado about political courage, it is by no means certain that many lawmakers who voted for the pact will be turned out by the voters.
Despite the bare-knuckle politics in Washington over trade, the voting public has not seemed deeply moved. Since the battles were more within the parties than between Democrats and Republicans, it may be that only in the closest races, particularly primaries, that the influence of labor or of backers of Mr. Perot might make a difference.
"We'll have two lifetimes in politics between now and the election," Vice President Al Gore said in an interview. "Those who are angry about the vote today may themselves feel differently after a few months."
 
Playing Down Fears
 Representative Bill Paxon of upstate New York, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, played down the notion that supporters of the pact are frightened. "Most members take the view that there's a lot of water to go over the dam between now and next November," he said.
The greater impact may be in 1996. Two opponents of the agreement, Mr. Perot and Patrick J. Buchanan, who sought the Republican nomination last year, might be emboldened by polls showing support for the pact has diminished with some Republican voters.
On the Democratic side, the fight has torn the party's traditional coalition, perhaps leaving Mr. Clinton more open to a challenge from the left in the 1996 primaries. An analysis of the House vote by the Economic Policy Institute, a union-backed research group, found that by supporting the agreement Mr. Clinton "has alienated his base, including voters in the suburbs, in the middle class and in swing states."
 
Reassuring Lawmakers
 But the President's immediate political concern is reassuring lawmakers who voted with him that he will do what he can to help them next year. In a letter he signed Wednesday night to each of the 234 Democrats and Republicans who voted for the agreement, Mr. Clinton wrote, "The historic nature of Nafta and the intense feelings on both sides of the issue and on both sides of the aisle mean it would be best for the House and for our political system if this issue were not re-fought in the 1994 Congressional elections."
Rather than debating the trade accord itself in next year's race, it may be more likely that candidates will use it to make other points. Mr. Perot, for one, is already stirring up anti-Government sentiment among his supporters by citing the deal-making that led to the agreement's passage. The biggest fear for Democrats is that their challengers would blame the trade pact for anything bad that happens in a district.
Knowing that unions can carry their influence only so far, some labor officials said they want to focus on defeating a few vulnerable incumbents, like Mr. Farr. "It's disturbing," the congressman said of such plans. "I've been in the California legislature and had a 94 percent voting record for labor."
 
White House Help
 Mr. Farr, who said he voted for the agreement because he had concluded that it would ultimately lead to more jobs for his district on the central California coast, said that Robert Reich, the Labor Secretary, had agreed to come to the district to explain the pact to labor and business groups. "There's an open door to the White House if you ask for assistance," said Mr. Farr, whose predecessor, Leon E. Panetta, is the Federal budget director.
While Mr. Farr gotabout a third of his campaign contributions from labor groups he still could be formidable, because he can now count on big donations from political action committees tied to business.
 
Leaning on the PAC's
 That weighs on the mind of Mr. Monning, a lawyer in Salinas, Calif. "Clinton and Panetta will probably make up the difference, in terms of leaning on those PAC's that wanted Nafta," he said.
Rex Hardesty, a spokesman for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., agreed that the financial clout of unions can easily be countered by business groups. But he warned against underestimating the unions. "They're not factoring in the 'we'll go fishing, we'll sit on our hands' quotient," he said. "There's no way to quantify what it costs to a candidate when labor sits on its hands."

HEADLINE: SENATE CONFIRMS A SCIENCES CHIEF

BYLINE: By NATALIE ANGIER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Slipping in a vote between more fractious issues like gun control and trade treaties, the Senate early this morning confirmed Dr. Harold E. Varmus, a Nobel laureate, as leader of the country's most prominent biomedical research organization, the National Institutes of Health.
Dr. Varmus, a professor of microbiology and biochemistry at the University of California at San Francisco, is internationally renowned for his work on the genes that cause cancer, the devious mechanisms of viruses and other basic puzzles of biology. 
 He takes over as director from Dr. Ruth Kirschstein, who will stay on as Deputy Director. Dr. Kirschstein has been the interim head of the institutes since the departure of Dr. Bernadine Healy, who resigned in June after persistent complaints from politicians and scientists about her argumentative style and her awkward handling of investigations into scientific fraud.
 
Overseeing $11 Billion Budget
 In assuming the post, Dr. Varmus, 53, will command a sprawling operation with an $11 billion annual budget that finances most of the biomedical research carried out at universities and companies around the nation.
The largely administrative job is a big shift for Dr. Varmus, who has spent most of his career in a laboratory. But he has served on many policy-making panels over the years.
Dr. Varmus said in an interview today that he learned of his confirmation after returning from a late-night showing of "The Remains of the Day," a movie based on the elegantly precise novel by Kazuo Ishiguro.
Dr. Varmus has an unusual background for a scientist of his stature, having earned his bachelor's degree in English from Amherst College and a master's in English literature from Harvard University. He went on to earn a medical degree from Columbia University and did post-doctoral training at the National Institutes of Health.
Researchers are elated to see one of their own take the helm of the Government body that feeds them. N.I.H. directors generally have been clinicians rather than pure scientists. "We in the trenches are really optimistic," said Dr. Jeff Boyd, head of the gynecological pathobiology group at the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences, one of the 18 institutes that make up the N.I.H. "I've been here for 17 years, and I must say this level of excitement has not existed before."
 
Candidate of Clarity
 Dr. Samuel Broder, director of the National Cancer Institute, said: "Appointing Harold Varmus as Director provides an unmistakable signal that we will have a strong basic research agenda. He's not a compromise candidate. He's a candidate of crystalline clarity. He'll have enormous credibility, and credibility is everything in this town."
But if credibility is everything, it is not the only thing. Dr. Varmus, as well as many who are watching him, know how difficult it will be to turn around an organization that has been plagued by problems, including recent complaints by N.I.H. scientists of racial discrimination and sexual harassment.
He will also have to resolve disputes over issues like how much biomedical research should be freewheeling and curiosity-driven, and how much aimed at finding cures for specific diseases or swiftly generating new products and technologies to strengthen the country's economic base. In an era when every Government science program is being squeezed, financing is a major concern.
"One of the things I'm concerned about is that there's been a pretty strong surge of enthusiasm for Harold, who's one of our own, a fundamental investigator," said Dr. J. Michael Bishop, who shared the Nobel Prize with Dr. Varmus in 1989 for their studies of cancer genes. "I hope that doesn't mean people will think he can double the budget and turn things around overnight."
 
Focusing on Immediate Needs
 Rather than seeking great new sources of wealth, or sketching out grand visions of the future of the institutes, Dr. Varmus said he would try to focus on immediate needs and manageable goals. His responsibilities fall into two broad categories.
First, he must consider the institutes' extramural program, the 89 percent of the budget that goes toward supporting biomedical research and education at universities, companies and other organizations throughout the country. Most biomedical research in America, from studying embryonic development in a model animal like a fruit fly, to testing a new immune therapy on human patients, is supported by grants from the N.I.H.
Secondly, Dr. Varmus must oversee intramural work, the research and other programs carried out at the 18 institutes on the Bethesda campus and satellite sites.
As the nation's leading spokesman for biomedicine everywhere, Dr. Varmus's main task, as he sees it, will be to set a tone, to promote the importance of basic research, to emphasize that the spinoffs from basic research have already been profound, and will only get greater.
"His challenge will be to get people excited again about basic science," said Dr. Florence Haseltine, director of the Center for Population Research. "I worry that biomedicine could get so complacent that it risks getting the knees cut out from under it."
As an example, she cited the Superconducting Supercollider, which Congress killed in part because physicists failed to make a strong enough case for its importance.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%);

HEADLINE: Around U.S., Citizens Fight to Take Streets Back

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Never has the Rev. Michael Pfleger seen so much heartbreak and violence in the inner-city neighborhood around his Roman Catholic church here. But he and his parish are not waiting for the police or the government or the cavalry to come to their rescue.
If they were to wait for help to arrive, Father Pfleger says, the young thugs on the corner might be old men with little thugs of their own. 
 So the parishioners have taken to the streets to discourage drug deals and convince gang members that there is a better way. They have started tutoring programs, found jobs for the jobless and have helped shut down some of the liquor stores that sold alcohol to their children.
They are fed up with the sorrow and the suffering that surrounds them. And they are not alone.
 
Government's Impotence
 All across the country, ordinary citizens faced with extraordinary troubles are patroling their streets, feeding their hungry, treating their addicted. It can be dangerous duty, but night after night they come out of their homes to save their communities in a celebration of people power and a condemnation of the government's impotence.
For too long, they say, they have waited and prayed and paid taxes for their elected officials to make a difference, only to see their neighborhoods crumble from neglect and their children shot down on the way to school.
In recent days and weeks these citizens have been praised and prodded by politicians and preachers to do even more for themselves.
From the pulpit of the church in Memphis, where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. delivered his last sermon, President Clinton made an emotional appeal last week for people to take responsibility for the social ills around them.
The Rev. Jesse Jackson has been saying the same thing for months to black teen-agers in cities from Washington to Oakland, Calif. Ending the violence in the inner city, he says, is "the new frontier of the civil rights movement."
 
'Please Stop the Killing'
 With bold hearts and empty pockets, grass-roots groups, started around kitchen tables, in church basements or mosques, have been doing for self for years. They have done it because they want to and because they have to. They haunt street-corner drug markets in Washington, patrol mean streets in Atlanta, teach peace in Detroit and distribute food to the homeless in Harlem.
In Greenville, S.C., it is midnight basketball leagues. In Glenwood, Ill., it is dress sales to help send needy children to college or trade school; in San Francisco, rap sessions between the elderly and the youngsters who terrify them at the first hint of dusk.
In Little Rock, Ark., a mock graveyard with 42 white wooden crosses reminds everyone how crucial this crusade of neighbor helping neighbor has become. A sign between the crosses reads: "For goodness' sake, brothers and sisters, please stop the killing."
It is a plea heard around the country.
In Chicago, Father Pfleger said: "The violence and despair is definitely worse than it's ever been. But it's stirred a kind of rebirth of people saying they're not going to take it anymore. People are organizing."
But Father Pfleger said no one should believe that brave citizens can replace in any way trained police officers, social workers and drug counselors.
 
Pressuring Government
 "We need to organize and work as a force to make government and law enforcement do what they are supposed to do," Father Pfleger said. "Instead of one person calling the police when they see a drug deal happening, 22 people should call. The squeaky wheel gets the oil."
Robert Fisher, a professor of social work at the University of Houston, said there were all kinds of grass-roots efforts against violence these days, including Women Against Violence Everywhere, gay groups trying to fight hate crimes, the continued proliferation of neighborhood watch groups.
In middle-class and affluent areas, residents often fight crime with their pocket books, paying for additional security officers and higher fences.
In poorer inner-city neighborhoods, where the sound of gunfire and mourning is loudest, church and small community groups are at the front lines.
"All of this, in many ways, is a positive sign, a typically American response" Professor Fisher said. "Voluntary efforts tend to be more democratic and more responsive to citizens' needs."
 
'Unnoticed and Unrecognized'
 But Professor Fisher said the surge in grass-roots groups had a much darker side.
"Ultimately," he said, "it's a response to the irresponsibility of the public sector and of the society at large refusing to really address the issue of crime and specifically the cause of crime."
This movement of resistance against thugs and terror, poverty and governmental neglect is nothing new in the inner city.
But in recent years, out of necessity and fear, more and more people and groups have banded together to protect themselves from the storm raging through the streets, said Robert L. Woodson, president of the National Center for Neighborhood Enterprise in Washington.
"There are more of these groups springing up now than ever before," he said. "But some of them have been around for 20 years. They go unnoticed and unrecognized."
They do their best, often with budgets stitched together with donations, bake sales and faith.
 
Scholarships for Youths
 The memory of her murdered son keeps Addie Mix going when she is tired after working her full-time job as a public school teacher and when there are still a million and one chores to do before the scholarship dinner.
Mrs. Mix is the co-founder of a two-year-old nonprofit group, Reclaim Our Youth, or R.A.Y., in Glenwood, a southern suburb of Chicago. She began the group with friends after her son was shot to death during his freshman year at a small private college in Texas.
"When something like that happens," Mrs. Mix said, "you either get better or you get worse."
So far this year, R.A.Y. has awarded two $1,000 college scholarships and a $500 stipend for a student entering trade school. In the summer the group runs a camp for children.
There are about 25 members of R.A.Y., most of them teachers. They hold meetings in their homes, where the $5 monthly dues and any donations are collected.
"We are handicapped because of lack of funds, but we just decided we weren't going to let anything get into our way," Mrs. Mix said. "You can always find excuses not to do something."
As these groups try do more than chase bad guys away from their homes and street corners, the word "holistic" keeps coming up.
To Deloyd Parker, the director of the Shape Community Center in Houston, crime and violence are symptoms of larger problems that include unemployment, poverty, crumbling schools and the lack of affordable housing.
"Everyone is going into this thing about violence," he said. "And trust me, violence is symptomatic, and most of what is being addressed are symptoms. When we start focusing more on the causes than the symptoms we'll be in better shape."
But the symptoms are breaking out all over.
 
Taking Youths Off Streets
 A Y.M.C.A. in Buffalo is trying to do something about that with an eight-team basketball league for 120 inner-city youngsters that began last month.
The teams are coached by lawyers, and the games are refereed by judges and police officers. The lawyers are paying all of the league's expenses.
"A lot of these kids, if they weren't in this league, they'd be out there doing something," said the Y.M.C.A.'s director, Larry Stitts.
Before playing the games on Friday nights, the players must attend a workshop where guest speakers talk to them about life and law.
Four years ago in Little Rock, a dozen neighbors, including State Representative William L. Walker Jr., got together to patrol streets where gangs, guns and drugs ruled the night.
But in the last year, the group has been idle, mainly because, Mr. Walker said, it received no assistance from businesses or government to provide jobs, food or housing to the troubled young people on the street.
"Everyone says they're concerned about crime, but whenever these kids try to change, there's nothing available for them to go to," Mr. Walker said. "No jobs, and no one gives them a chance."
He added: "These guys are hungry. They need shelter. They needs jobs, but the community as a whole was not there for them."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: 14TH STREET;
Amid Dispute, Work to Start On Housing for Homeless

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
After three years of sharp local debate, crews will start construction this week on a 12-story apartment house for 94 homeless and low-income families on East 13th Street, along with an adjacent complex of retail shops on 14th Street.
The apartment project, Genesis II, will include medical care, day care, recreation, classes and counseling for its residents. The sponsor is Housing Enterprise for the Less Privileged, a nonprofit organization founded by Andrew M. Cuomo, the son of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. 
 Opponents are still fighting the project in court as an illegal use of public money and have appealed to Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani to halt the work when he takes office. But the sponsor, HELP, says the project has final City Council approval and Mr. Giuliani would not be able to change it. His transition office had no comment.
The site is a rubble-strewn lot, vacant for two decades, running from 114 East 14th Street through the block to 113 East 13th Street. The Koch administration tried to develop luxury housing there, and later the site was considered for public housing.
"This space has been a sore spot, a haven for drugs and a public hazard," said Maria Cuomo Cole, who took over HELP after her brother became an Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in the Clinton Administration. "Now it will revitalize the neighborhood."
Occupancy is planned for early 1995. The city and state will provide $3 million to build the shops and $14 million for the apartments. No leases have been signed yet. Shop rents will go to the city; apartment rents, from $400 to $750 for one to three bedrooms, will pay operating expenses.
The sale of $14 million in tax credits will finance the social-service programs, including advice for parents, job training and computer classes. There will also be a roof garden above the two-story shops and a playground between the buildings.
Half the apartments will be for families from temporary shelters; the rest will be for low-income residents (a family of four can earn up to $27,000 a year). People from the neighborhood will receive preference.
City Councilman Antonio Pagan said that Mr. Cuomo "has bullied this project through against the will of the community." Another opponent, Joanna D. Underwood, president of the East 13th Street Community Association, said the money would provide more housing instantly if used to buy or rent existing apartments. She also argued that "putting a whole group of families with instabilities into one high-rise building" harms them and burdens the neighborhood.
Her association filed two suits, one now awaiting its first ruling and the other on appeal after being rejected. They contend that the sponsors used a condemnation procedure to avoid the city's land-use review process and an auction of the property for the top bid.
Proponents call the project an innovative way to aid the neighborhood and the needy, with services to foster self-sufficiency. They say it conforms to zoning, was the subject of 16 hearings and is legal. BRUCE LAMBERT
