HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
The Recruiting Trenches

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
AT 0950 hours on a recent weekday, Staff Sgt. Allen X. Johnson is deep into his square wooden box filled with information cards on prospective recruits. Across the desk in the Army's recruiting station on East Fordham Road in the Bronx, the station commander, Sgt. 1st Class Richard Day, runs down a checklist and peppers Sergeant Johnson with questions.
"Garcia?" 
 "He failed the test; needs to study on his math ability."
"That bad?"
 "Terrible."
All right, forget Garcia. On to a slippery prospect named Evans. "That's a wrong phone number," Sergeant Day says. "I tried it myself."
Sergeant Johnson agrees. "I did a house call on him," he says, smiling. "The address is bogus, too. They do that sometimes."
Together the sergeants work their way down the names, throwing out the prospects who have scored below the 31st percentile on the Army's battery of aptitude tests or who turn out to have medical problems or criminal records. They make notes to call those who have shown interest but need extra persuasion or who have actually signed contracts but are having cold feet.
At 1030 hours, Sergeant Johnson is squared away and ready to head out for a day of meeting, greeting, persuading and advising anyone between 17 and 35 who shows the slightest inclination to listen. The sergeants call this prospecting, and it takes them to schools, shopping centers, unemployment offices, post offices and restaurants -- anywhere that people gather.
The Army may be downsizing, but it still needs recruits. And to get the recruits, it needs recruiters, more than 200 of them working the New York City area alone. Sergeant Johnson is one of them.
The job is repetitive and grueling. Sergeant Johnson wears the Army uniform, but his assignment puts him in that grand door-to-door fellowship that embraces insurance salesmen, Jehovah's Witnesses and peddlers of encyclopedias, people who wake up each morning and know they will encounter a full day of suspicion and rejection.
"You have to go through about 100 people before you get five people to qualify," Sergeant Johnson says, unperturbed. "Sure, there are days when you get up and you'll be dragging a little bit, but then you get out there in the community and see the smiles, and everything's O.K."
Well, mostly O.K. True, recruiting was up for the year ending Sept. 30. The New York battalion signed 608 more recruits than the previous year, when 4,252 enlisted. On the other hand, recruiters have been under siege. On Wednesday a state court handed down a decision that may bar them from state colleges and universities. Responding to a suit filed by a lesbian student at the State University at Buffalo, the court ruled that the military's policy toward gay men and lesbians, who can serve only if they keep their sexual orientation secret, violates an executive order prohibiting discrimination by state agencies on such a basis. A SUNY spokesman said they have not decided whether to appeal the decision.
If the ruling stands, recruiters like Sergeant Johnson will have to come up with some new, creative approaches. No one said the Army would be easy.
Sergeant Johnson, 29, is a wiry Washingtonian with nine years in the service. He is now 22 months into a three-year tour of duty as a recruiter, after which he will return to his usual job of personnel administration. He is assigned to Metro Company, one of five units that make up the batallion responsible for the New York City area. The Fordham Road recruiting station, one of the largest in the city, covers 17.5 square miles of the east-central and northeastern Bronx. With six Army recruiters and one Army Reserve recruiter, Fordham was given the mission, in the last fiscal year, of providing 81 recruits and 52 reservists. It supplied 107 and 49.
Sergeant Johnson's speaking style, deliberate and calm, reflects countless hours of delivering the same message to thousands of young men and women who he firmly believes have everything to gain from a hitch in the Army. "Even if you don't join," he says, "you can still get something from the Army's message: 'Be all you can be.' That applies no matter what you do in life."
Ready to roll, Sergeant Johnson teams up with Staff Sgt. Keilow K. King. The two men stuff a green plastic Army bag with brochures about benefits and programs. In an oversize briefcase they carry cardboard advertising displays.
The team is pumped up. A passer-by eating a slice of pizza asks directions. Sergeant King obliges, then tries to persuade the man to drop in at the recruiting station.
The first visit is to DeWitt Clinton High School, a regular stop on the recruiting route.
The recuiting station keeps in close touch with high schools. It even sends over the 26th Army Band for concerts, then works the crowd with recruiters, who also make a point of attending football and basketball games.
"Basically, this is a community job," said Sergeant Johnson. "We have to learn about the community and be in the community."
In the high school cafeteria, students wander over to a table that Sergeant Johnson and Sergeant King have turned into a neatly organized recruiting table. Both men move quickly from small talk to the pertinent questions: How old are you? Are you doing well in school? What kind of career do you have in mind? Do you want to go to college?
The two recuiters explain that the Army can help, with college loans of up to $30,000 for some four-year enlistees, a powerful inducement. It can provide training in 250 job categories. No need to act now. Under the Delayed Enlistment Program, students can sign on the dotted line but enter the service a year later. "We don't want people to leave school," Sergeant Johnson said.
The students make a rush toward the free plastic Army bags and bumper stickers. Several talk briefly with the recruiters and accept a business card or fill out a form to receive information. A few say they will drop by the recruiting station. Others drift off. Sergeant Johnson ends one conversation by looking into the eyes of a student and saying, "Be all you can be."
After about an hour the two men gather their materials and head off to the school library to replenish the green Army box, which sits about 10 feet from the blue Navy box, with fresh brochures.
Then onward to Bronx Community College, where the students approach more warily. Some express political objections to the military or recount the unpleasant experiences of a friend. Others are clearly interested, however, in seeing exactly what the Army can do for their education.
After about 90 minutes at the college, it's time to head back to the station to do paperwork until 5 P.M. Then "red time" kicks in: one hour of phone calling from lists of high school seniors with the goal of enticing two prospects into the station.
Today has been pretty good, Sergeant Johnson says. Some decent prospects, at least a dozen cards filled out, and plenty of face-to-face contact, which always generates the highest percentage of prospects. Sergeant Johnson has put the word out. It's short and simple: Be all you can be.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Basically, this is a community job," said Staff Sgt. Allen X. Johnson, one of more than 200 recruiters in the New York City area. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE PACIFIC SUMMIT;
Leaders at Summit Seek Strong Pacific Community

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Nov. 20

 BODY:
President Clinton played host to a Pacific Rim club meeting today, gathering 13 Asian-Pacific leaders in an Indian long house on a windswept island to preach the gospel of open markets and to secure America's foothold in the world's fastest growing economic community.
Mr. Clinton said the free-flowing talks with his counterparts -- the largest such gathering ever of Asian leaders -- had laid the basis for an Asian-Pacific "community" that would play an "increasingly vital role for our nation and the world" by working together to expand trade, lower tariffs and create new high-tech jobs. 
 "At least now, for the first time," Mr. Clinton told reporters during a break in the six hours of talks, "our region has the means to hold serious policy discussions on such questions as how to remove trade barriers and how to sustain robust growth.
"If you ask me to summarize in a sentence what we have agreed, it is this: We have agreed that the Asia-Pacific region should be a united one, not divided. We have agreed that our economic policies should be open, not closed."
 
Open Economic Policies
 "We have also agreed that we should begin to express that conviction by doing everything we possibly can," Mr. Clinton said, to get a good global trade agreement by Dec. 15 that would reduce tariffs and set rules for international commerce.
Dressed in a brown leather bomber-style jacket, lumberjack shirt, brown slacks and boots, Mr. Clinton greeted his guests at the Seattle docks at dawn to carry them by Coast Guard ferry to Blake Island -- like a weekend outdoorsman taking a few fraternity brothers out for a picnic. Only China's President, Jiang Zemin, didn't quite get into the swing of today's L. L. Bean diplomatic dress code, coming in a business suit.
Japan's Prime Minister, Morihiro Hosokawa, who is considered something of a fashion plate in Tokyo, showed up in an aviator's scarf, and Kim Young Sam, South Korea's President, wore a Korean cardigan sweater. President Fidel V. Ramos of the Philippines wore black leather gloves in which he jauntily twirled a cigar.
Their casual dress, though, belied the fact that these were the leaders of some of the world's most populous nations, countries that control half of the world's total output of goods and services.
"I hope we will all exchange telephone numbers and fax machine numbers," President Ramos said.
Once on the remote island in the middle of Puget Sound, eight miles off the coast of Seattle, Mr. Clinton and the leaders retreated to a long house in Tillicum Village, a replica of a Native American settlement, where they entered into an unstructured discussion on the future of their Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum.
Warmed by a space heater during a raw Seattle morning, they were seated in chairs in a circle, each accompanied only by their translators and a single aide.
One official remarked that if the world has become a global village, its Main Street, where the business is booming, is now somewhere around the South China Sea, at the heart of the collection of Asian-Pacific nations gathered here.
As the Pacific Rim leaders waved hello to the cameras from the balcony of the log building with Mr. Clinton standing in their midst, they almost seemed to be waving hello to the American public, and underscoring the President's argument that American jobs and markets will increasingly be coming from Latin America and the Orient, not from across the Atlantic.
 
Largest Gathering Since 1966>
 It was the biggest gathering of Asian and Pacific leaders since President Lyndon Johnson convened a summit meeting in 1966 in Manila to enlist support for the Vietnam War. But this gathering was a striking contrast to the East-West get-togethers that have so dominated global politics during the cold war. Here the issue was not the balance of power, but the balance of trade. Here the acronyms being tossed around were not Start, NATO or C.F.E., but APEC, Asean and G.N.P. Here the question being asked most by reporters was not who blinked, but who paid?
Indeed, many officials seemed to feel a certain electricity in the air here that comes from witnessing the creation of a grouping of powers that all the participants appear to believe is going to be important -- though no one is quite sure what shape it will take.
The Asian-Pacific nations are deeply wary about being herded together too tightly by the United States, because they fear both its political domination and its insistence on expanding human rights along with expanding trade. Japan's Foreign Minister, Tsutomu Hata, reflected that wariness when he told reporters that APEC should evolve through "incremental gradualism by consensus."
The unusual combination of energy and ambiguity that surrounded this meeting was captured in a "vision statement" issued by the leaders at the close of their session. It was long on vision and short on specifics.
"In this post-cold-war era, we have an opportunity to build a new economic foundation for the Asia-Pacific that harnesses the energy of our diverse economies, strengthens cooperation and promotes prosperity," it said. "Our meeting reflects the emergence of a new voice for the Asia-Pacific in world affairs."
 
'Cooperative Solutions'>
 It said that APEC envisaged a community of Asia-Pacific economies that will work together to promote "cooperative solutions" to global economic problems, an open international trading system, improved education and training and advances in telecommunications and transportation among member states.
Mr. Clinton said the leaders had agreed to gather next year in Indonesia for a second regional summit meeting. The importance of such annual meetings, say American officials, is that it will begin to give more of a structure and permanence to this Asian-American alliance.
During today's discussions President Kim of South Korea quoted a Korean proverb: "The beginning is half the job done."
A White House spokeswoman, Dee Dee Myers, said the next meeting will take place in November or December 1994 following Congressional elections in the United States.
 What Mr. Clinton hoped to achieve most from this summit meeting -- and appears to have accomplished is to insure that America is not slowly locked out of this emerging Asian economic Main Street, which is growing twice as fast as Europe.
The Asians, for their part seem anxious to make sure that they also have a strong link with the emerging North American free trade zone. American officials also hoped that the prospect of an American-Asian trading association would force the Europeans to make the last concessions needed to complete the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade -- the worldwide trade agreement -- by Dec. 15. "The message to Europe" from this meeting, Mr. Clinton said, "is we want this to be a united but open community and we want Europe to work with us to get a good GATT agreement. We want them to join us in a new world trading system."
On Thursday, APEC added Mexico and Papua New Guinea to its roster and agreed to add Chile next year. In addition to those newcomers, current members are: Australia, Brunei, Canada, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, New Zealand, the Phillipines, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand and the United States.
While American officials expressed satisfaction with the results of this week's summit, it did underscore the tension between Washington's three priorities in Asia -- expanding trade, promoting human rights and democratization and stemming missile proliferation.
None of the Asian-Pacific leaders share America's enthusiasm for making trade benefits contingent on human rights performance. And the more the United States pushes to expand trade in the region to create jobs back home, the more leverage the Chinese and others have in resisting American demands on human rights.
American officials said that despite the good public face that Mr. Clinton tried to put on his meeting Friday with the Chinese president -- saying that they had at least begun a dialogue about human rights and other issues -- the Chinese leader in fact gave Mr. Clinton nothing whatsoever.
With the Chinese now running a $19 billion dollar trade surplus with Washington, and doing business in almost all 50 states, they seem increasingly confident that Congress will not strip them of their trade benefits because it would cost too many jobs in too many parts of America -- particularly Seattle, whose Boeing Aircraft company now does 14 percent of its business with China.
 
China Sees U.S. as Codependent
 China's Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, bluntly told reporters that this issue of whether or not the United States will renew China's low trading tariffs in June -- depending on its human rights behavior -- is a relic of the past, because Washington is now as dependent on the trade for creating middle-class jobs as China is.
"It is not the case of a special advantage to one side or a special disadvantage to the other," Mr. Qichen said, when asked if he feared that Washington would not renew China's most-favored-nation trade beneifts. "We do not approve of the practice of linking things which have nothing to do with trade issues."
Mike Jendrezejczyk, head of Asia Watch, a human-rights monitoring organization, said he was struck by "the amazing confidence the Chinese now have that trade will take care all their problems in America."

HEADLINE: SENATE APPROVES BRADY LEGISLATION AND TRADE ACCORD

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
The Senate passed the Brady gun control bill and the North American Free Trade Agreement tonight and finished its major work for the year.
That left the House still struggling to conclude the first session of the 103d Congress as it faced tough fights Sunday and Monday over campaign finance and lobbying legislation and a measure to impose $90 billion in further budget cuts. 
 But with tonight's action this session established itself as one that produced more legislation than any in the last several years. Besides the trade agreement, the likely enactment of the gun bill and the $496 billion deficit reduction measure voted last summer, Congress also passed significant legislation on family leave, national service, student loans and easier voter registration.
 
Compromise Opens Way
 The 63-to-36 vote to impose a five-day waiting period on the purchase of handguns came after a day of negotiations in which Republicans dropped the filibuster they had successfully maintained Friday night in exchange for an amendment that amounted to a political fig leaf.
To pass the bill, which supporters had conceded was all but dead, proponents agreed that the waiting period would be in force for four years, unless the Attorney General decided a fifth year was necessary. Earlier they had insisted on five years. But Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, told the Senate he would go back to five years in conference with the House, which passed a version of it two weeks ago.
Final enactment later this month is likely, although Mr. Biden's admission that he would not fight for the amendment infuriated some Republicans, and they could delay action until next year. Under the bill, a handgun purchase would be delayed for five working days, unless a state imposed a longer waiting period.
The Brady bill, which had been bottled up by opponents for seven years, is named for James S. Brady, the White House press secretary wounded in the assassination attempt on President Ronald Reagan in 1981.
 
Republicans Claim Credit
 The vote on the trade agreement was 61 to 38, with 27 Democrats and 34 Republicans in favor and 28 Democrats and 10 Republicans against it.
It was sent to President Clinton after Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine told the Senate that the measure was a significant token that "this nation will actively engage the challenges of this post-cold war world."
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, claimed credit for his party for the decision, because, while the outcome was not in doubt in the Senate, in the House Republicans provided the critical votes while most Democrats opposed the bill. "By remaining true to our historic commitment to the philosophy of free trade, open markets and job creation, we made the difference, and we did what was right for America," he said.
Eager to wrap up the session, senators hung around the chamber for hours on end instead of going back to their offices, though proceedings were occasionally interrupted by shouts from the cloakrooms, where many senators exulted at the exciting finish of the football game between Boston College and Notre Dame.
 
Health Care Bill Introduced
 The major event in the House today was not legislative action but the long-delayed introduction of President Clinton's health care bill. It appeared that the measure differed only in minor detail from the bill presented to Congress, but not formally introduced, in late October.
House leaders struggled to get the 100 co-sponsors that the Administration's leader on health care, Hillary Rodham Clinton, had insisted they produce. But they did it with 95 regular members of the House, and the delegates from American Samoa, the District of Columbia, Guam, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.
There were no speeches on the introduction. But Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, issued a statement maintaining that the bill would be passed next year and would "do away -- forever -- with the anxiety that too many Americans feel today about their health insurance: that it will cost more than they can afford; that they can't get coverage or will lose it; that it won't cover what they need."
The measure was also expected to be introduced in the Senate before all senators leave the capital. They will return in late January for the second session of this Congress.
 
Breaking a Roadblock
 Before the Senate could get to the trade measure, it had to clear a major obstacle, Senator Phil Gramm's effort to tie up a bill providing $1.1 billion in emergency unemployment benefits for the long-term jobless.
The Senator had sought to force Congress to include in the bill a cut of 252,000 Federal employees. The cut was proposed in the Administration's "reinventing government" plan.
But the Senate defeated Mr. Gramm's proposal, 63 to 36, then passed the conference measure by 79 to 20 before sending it back to the House, where approval seems certain.
Although the Senate had added the jobs provision and the House had taken nonbinding votes to include it, opposition by Government employee unions and Democratic leaders kept it from being part of the final compromise.
 
Many Small Bills
 By 54 to 45, the Senate also voted to allow the Resolution Trust Corporation to spend $18.3 billion to bail out failed thrifts. As a condition for the release of more than $10 billion, the measure requires the Treasury Secretary to certify that the agency has complied with a number of management reforms, including a tightening of contracting oversight. The measure still awaits action in the House.
Besides the introduction of the health care bill, the House indulged in a flurry of noncontroversial legislating, with several bills, like the Fountain Darter Preservation Act and the Chinook Salmon Broodstock program, being passed in as little as a minute. And a long debate began, though no vote was taken, over a bill to make the District of Columbia the nation's 51st state, the state of New Columbia. That measure seems to have no chance of passage.
Off the floor the biggest activity was in a Democratic caucus of two and a half hours to assemble votes for the bills to change the campaign finance and lobbying disclosure laws.
The campaign measure would create voluntary spending limits of up to $800,000 in House races, with vouchers for up to $200,000 worth of communications spending -- mail and broadcast -- to be given to candidates who accept the spending limits.
 
Bill Faces Obstacle
 The measure, which is similar to one passed last year in the certainty that President George Bush would veto it, as he did, is scheduled to come before the House on Sunday.
But Representative Mike Synar, an Oklahoma Democrat who has supported public financing in the past, has contended that he has the votes to block consideration of the bill. He maintains that it would be better to pass a much simpler bill, one that reduces contribution limits by political action committees to $1,000 from $5,000 and by individuals to $500 from $1,000.
Mr. Synar said today that he had 60 to 70 Democratic backers to prevent the leadership bill from coming up, which would be enough if he got the solid Republican support that was promised on the procedural vote over taking the bill up. But he said the leaders might yet turn the issue around.
Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts said there was overwhelming support for the leadership plan. "Women and blacks particularly said the other alternatives put them at a disadvantage," he said, adding that they argued that they depend on "cooperative fund-raising" while their opponents depend on wealthy individual contributors. The Synar bill would ban the "bundling" of individual contributions by organizations like Emily's List, which backs Democratic women who support abortion rights.
The discussion on lobbying reform took the form of a long question-and-answer session between caucus members and Representative John Bryant of Texas, whose subcommittee is working on the issue. "There were a lot of concerns expressed about how the lobby reform would work," said Representative Martin Frost. "Members had trouble following the bill."
Representative Bryant passed out a simple table to explain what would be allowed or banned. All travel paid for by lobbyists, for example, would still be allowed but would have to be disclosed in considerably more detail than it is now. Meals could not be paid for by lobbyists, but could be provided by another company representative, even if the lobbyist was present.

HEADLINE: Now It's Japan's Turn to Play Catch-Up

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
LAST month, Takenori Kanzaki, head of Japan's Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications, summoned top executives from about 100 communications companies to an early morning meeting and showed them a videotape prepared by his agency.
The tape opened with President Clinton and Vice President Gore in Silicon Valley, talking about plans for the so-called information superhighway. It then showed American scientists working on an interactive television project. There were glimpses as well of the installation of optical fibers to increase capacity of an American cable TV system and of an American service that delivers personalized electronic newspapers to computer users. "America is again aiming to gain world leadership with the superhighway plan," the narrator intoned. 
 A few years ago, such a scare tactic might have been used in the United States to warn of Japan's impending conquest of some new market. But when it comes to advanced telecommunications, it is Japan that is now waking up to the fact that it is far behind the United States, at a great risk to its economy. And Mr. Kanzaki's ministry, far from being the solution, is blamed by many experts for being part of the problem, having overregulated Japan's telecommunications industry and smothered innovation.
In the United States, for instance, the use of electronic mail and computer networks is exploding, providing a new forum for commerce, speeding corporate decision-making and allowing scientists to swap data.
But in many Japanese offices, papers are still piled high and the number of personal computers per 100 workers (just 9.9) is only one-fourth that of the United States. Of the PC's that are there, only 13.4 percent can communicate with other computers within a company, through so-called local area networks, compared with 55.7 percent in the United States. And California alone has six times as many computers connected to the Internet, the worldwide network that is growing like a weed, as all of Japan.
"We are almost 10 years behind the United States" in networking, said Tateo Arimoto, an official of the Science and Technology Agency.
 
Other Big Gaps
 In the United States, cable television is evolving into a conduit for hundreds of channels, video on demand and two-way educational programming, among other things.
But in Japan, fewer than 3 percent of households receive cable programming compared with 60 percent in the United States. And while American cable companies like Tele-Communications Inc. and Time Warner Inc. are strong and busy forging alliances, Japan's cable companies remain small and for the most part are too unsophisticated even to provide pay-per-view services.
And in the United States, wireless communications are beginning to stretch the boundaries of the office, allowing people to stay in touch from anywhere, anytime. But in Japan the relative number of users of cellular phones is less than one-third of that in the United States. And there is little of the entrepreneurial activity found in the United States aimed at wireless transmission of data.
Developing its own information infrastructure is vital to Japan for several reasons. For one, new services like interactive television or huge computerized data bases can be big businesses in and of themselves.
Moreover, advanced communications can improve the productivity of existing businesses or assist in scientific research. Gobs of data from satellites studying the earth remain unusable by many scientists in Japan for lack of a high-speed network to deliver the information, said Hiroshi Mizuta of the National Space Development Agency.
Japan's lack of sophisticated networks could also threaten its world-leading electronics companies. With their home market underdeveloped, such companies will have to design their most advanced portable phones, video equipment and telephone switches for use abroad, which is a little more difficult.
For the same reason, Japanese companies missed the market for machines known as routers, electronic "traffic cops" used to connect smaller computer networks into bigger ones. A future product they might trail in -- unless they work with American companies -- is the cable converter that could well control the flow of information into the home.
 
The Missing Link
 Indeed, electronic distribution of video, games, music and computer data could be a competitive threat to Japanese hardware, such as video- game machines, CD-ROM players and videocassette recorders. Japanese companies like Sony and Matsushita, which have already expanded beyond hardware to software, or programming, through purchases of Hollywood movie studios, now must ponder whether they are still missing a link -- distribution.
Both Sony and Matsushita have talked recently with John Malone, head of T.C.I. He is said to be interested in purchasing a stake in one of their movie studios, which would give one of them a tie-up in the cable business. A Sony executive said the company is interested in cable. But Tsuzo Murase, executive vice president of Matsushita, said his company is not interested in buying into cable nor in selling its studio, MCA Inc.
One reason Japan is lagging, particularly in computer communications, is cultural. Typing Japanese is difficult, making personal computers less convenient than sending handwritten messages on fax machines.
The Japanese also value face-to-face communications. Ikuo Nishioka, who became the head of the Intel Corporation's Japanese subsidiary a year or so ago after a career at the Sharp Corporation, said he was "astonished" at Intel's use of electronic mail. When he completed his orientation visit to Intel's headquarters in Santa Clara, Calif., he said goodbye to other executives instantly by sending them messages. "In Japan," he said, "it would take two weeks to say goodbye," by arranging appointments.
At the International Superconductivity Technology Center, a Government-backed research lab here, the cultural problem is of another sort. The laboratory's director forbids the use of electronic mail, afraid that confidential information will leak out.
Other problems include the fact that it costs 5 to 10 times as much to lease a data line here as it does in the United States, said Izumi Aizu of the Tokyo-based Center for Global Communications. And Tokyo has been reluctant to support the Internet because it does not use a communications standard the Government has been backing.
 
Biggest Problem
 That is indicative of the biggest problem, many experts say: The Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications has ruled over the industry with a heavy hand and has been slow to authorize new services. Such tight regulation might have helped protect Japan's market from foreign competition, but it has also stifled the innovation spurred by the more open market in the United States.
A few years ago, for instance, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company tried to introduce a service here that would allow consumers to use a computer modem while talking on the phone. But regulation was so strict the company gave up.
"What's lagging is not the technology," said Roger Moore, president of the Japanese operations of Canada's Northern Telecom Ltd. "What's lagging has been more the changes in the competitive environment."
Japanese companies, after all, are among the leading manufacturers of cellular telephones. The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, Japan's main phone company, and competitors like the DDI Corporation are making good progress on newer digital cellular service and the next generation of mobile phone service.
But because of Government regulation, rates for cellular phone service in Japan are among the highest in the world and customers must rent their phones from the service supplier, paying about $600 a year for a phone that could be purchased for half that amount in the United States.
Cable television has suffered because the telecommunications ministry decided to back a still commercially unsuccessful effort to transmit television programs from satellites to homes. Cable was relegated to being a local service aimed mainly at improving television reception. It was not until 1989 that satellites were used to distribute programs to cable systems, allowing for the development of nationwide cable programming services similar to MTV and Cable News Network. And a controlling interest in a cable company can be held only by an investor based in that company's service area, a rule that will soon change but has left cable operators small and Balkanized.
"We don't have capital" in the industry, said Yasushige Nishimura, who is in charge of the cable business at the Sumitomo Corporation. "We don't have personnel resources. We don't have expertise."
 
Government's View
 Responding to criticism, Masaharu Matsumoto, deputy director of the cablecast division of the telecommunications ministry, said cable TV in Japan is less regulated than in the United States. Cable operators here, he said, do not pay franchise fees and do not have ceilings on their rates.
To be sure, in terms of technology and deregulation of its telephone system, Japan is hardly in last place and is ahead of some European countries such as France and Germany. And much of the frenzy of industry activity in the United States, including the recent rash of alliances, might not result in profitable businesses.
Japan also has a capacity to advance rapidly once it decides what it must do. And that dawning is now occurring. Earlier this month the Social and Economic Congress of Japan, a group that has the ear of the powerful Ministry of International Trade and Industry, submitted an "emergency" proposal to the Government saying Japan is "decisively behind" in telecommunications and needs a program to catch up.
Already cable TV, computer network and cellular phone use has accelerated. And deregulation is gradually occurring, pushed by Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa. The rule requiring cellular subscribers to lease their phones will be gone by April, for instance.
Expertise is also being imported, giving American and European companies a chance to break into the Japanese market. Last week, the Nynex Corporation said it planned to build advanced cable systems in partnership with the Tomen Corporation, a trading company. T.C.I. has taken a stake in a cable programming service controlled by Sumitomo. And N.T.T., to tap into American technology, made an investment this month in Nextel Communications, a mobile radio company.
The telecommunications ministry's showing of the Clinton-Gore video last month was meant to garner industry support for a pilot project in which optical fiber will be installed in 300 homes near Kyoto to test delivery of video on demand, video telephones and other services.
But there is a debate here, as in the United States, about whether development of the information superhighway should be the role of Government or of industry. Within the Government, there is also a bitter war for control between the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications and the trade ministry.
N.T.T., which was privatized in 1985, says it can wire the entire country with optical fiber by itself by the year 2015. It is experimenting with new services like super high-definition television, which is twice as sharp as existing HDTV and would allow medical images to be transmitted with enough clarity for diagnosis by doctors in other locations.
N.T.T. estimates that providing optical fiber to every home and business will cost $400 billion, an amount it says it can manage. But others have their doubts and there are reports the start of the fiber plan is being postponed. N.T.T.'s profits have been decimated by competition in the long-distance business and by regulations that have held down local rates.
There are also doubts about whether such a high-capacity network can pay for itself. The telecommunications ministry must decide whether to allow N.T.T. to be in the video programming business. If it does not allow it, N.T.T. might never be able to make the optical fibers pay off. But if it does, N.T.T. might crush some fledgling cable television companies.
In electronic mail, Japan's problems are not only Government regulation, but also lack of the Government's usual participation in industrial development. In a reversal of roles, Washington underwrote the development of research networks in the United States while some frustrated scientists in Japan have had to hook up their own networks.
"Our Government doesn't understand the importance of internetworking yet," said Haruhisa Ishida, a professor in the computer center at the University of Tokyo.
To the extent Government agencies do have networks, they do not communicate with other agencies. A message from one to another might have to go through the United States.
 
Plugging In
 The Government is now planning to remedy that with an interagency network to connect 100 national research institutes, with eventual extensions to universities. But some scientists from industry and Government think that plan, which could cost about $40 million in the first three years, does not go far enough. They are suggesting a far more ambitious plan to allow researchers to use supercomputers through an extremely high-speed network. But this project, which could cost at least $300 million, has not yet received approval.
In business, use of networking is also starting to spread. Tadashi Sekizawa, president of Fujitsu Ltd., travels with a pocket computer to check his electronic mail. Japanese affiliates of A.T.&T. and the Intercon Systems Corporation of Herndon, Va., have just begun offering companies here access to the Internet.
And Japanese counterparts of Compuserve and Prodigy, the personal computer services, are also gaining popularity. The two main services, NEC's PC-VAN and Fujitsu's Nifty-Serve, did not start until 1987. Now each has more than 500,000 subscribers.
"When we started this business," said Takashi Yamakawa, general manager of the planning department at Nifty-Serve, "we were afraid that Japanese were too shy to express their private opinions in public spaces like forums."
Now, the on-line forums are overloaded with messages, a sign that a networking culture might not be all that foreign to Japan after all.
 
 
 
JAPAN'S MAVERICK MASTER OF THE INTERNET
 JUN MURAI is the father of the Internet in Japan, a role that has brought him a measure of fame but not always made him popular with the establishment.
Dr. Murai, who teaches at Keio University, began trying to connect Japan's computers to the world in 1984. As a first step, he had to develop Japanese language ability for the software used to control the Internet, the worldwide network.
A ball of energy, Dr. Murai started JU-Net and WIDE, nonprofit networks that connect universities and tie them into the Internet. He is also on Internet's architecture board.
All this has made the 38-year-old computer scientist a revered guru. A company called Intercon International recently advertised that he would be the speaker at a news conference in which it would introduce a service to connect Japanese businesses to the Internet. But Dr. Murai, who is known for having an overloaded appointment calendar, couldn't make it. "Some Japanese press didn't walk in the door when they saw Murai was not there," said Intercon's president, Roger Boisvert.
Some scientists, however, feel Dr. Murai is too powerful and he has had his share of clashes with the Government. He has been an adviser to Internet Initiative Japan, a startup that is trying to provide Internet connectivity to businesses but has so far failed to get a Government permit.
The WIDE network was developed with academic volunteers and corporate contributions, without waiting for the Government. Such a grass-roots effort has not always been appreciated by the Education Ministry, which is developing its own networks.
Dr. Murai said he has little patience with regulators. "Government people like to control things and I don't like to be controlled," he said.
Someday, Dr. Murai said, he would like to be a visiting scholar in the United States. "It's very interesting to see how people are using computers for their daily lives there, which is not happening in this country," he said.
Not surprisingly, computers play a big part in his daily life. His house is wired with a local area network so he can sit in his kitchen and connect to his computer room and by high-speed data lines to the world beyond. "My 8-year-old daughter communicates with me by e-mail," he said proudly.
His ultimate goal: "I want to connect all the computers in this world."
 
 
 
THE SHAKY SATELLITE GAMBIT
 INSTEAD of cable television, Japan has placed its bets on broadcasting directly from satellites to homes. But the satellite business has had trouble getting airborne.
The Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications decided on using a type of satellite that had a powerful signal but could carry only a few channels. It reserved two of those channels for NHK, the state-controlled broadcasting company. To provide programming for a third channel, the ministry in 1984 pooled investments of more than 200 companies into Japan Satellite Broadcasting under the leadership of a former ministry bureaucrat.
Today, Japan Satellite has only 1.4 million subscribers for its pay-television service, known as Wowow. That is less than half the 3 million needed to break even. Earlier this year Japan Satellite was rescued from financial straits by a group of banks and the president was replaced.
It wasn't until a few years ago that the ministry liberalized the use of a different type of satellite, previously used in Japan mainly for phone service. These satellites have a less powerful signal but can transmit far more channels. New companies, backed by Japan's giant trading companies, began using them to distribute cable programming. They are also starting to broadcast directly to homes in competition with the older satellites. But the two types of satellites require different receiving equipment, fracturing the market and confusing consumers.

HEADLINE: Now It's Japan's Turn to Play Catch-Up

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
LAST month, Takenori Kanzaki, head of Japan's Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications, summoned top executives from about 100 communications companies to an early morning meeting and showed them a videotape prepared by his agency.
The tape opened with President Clinton and Vice President Gore in Silicon Valley, talking about plans for the so-called information superhighway. It then showed American scientists working on an interactive television project. There were glimpses as well of the installation of optical fibers to increase capacity of an American cable TV system and of an American service that delivers personalized electronic newspapers to computer users. "America is again aiming to gain world leadership with the superhighway plan," the narrator intoned. 
 A few years ago, such a scare tactic might have been used in the United States to warn of Japan's impending conquest of some new market. But when it comes to advanced telecommunications, it is Japan that is now waking up to the fact that it is far behind the United States, at a great risk to its economy. And Mr. Kanzaki's ministry, far from being the solution, is blamed by many experts for being part of the problem, having overregulated Japan's telecommunications industry and smothered innovation.
In the United States, for instance, the use of electronic mail and computer networks is exploding, providing a new forum for commerce, speeding corporate decision-making and allowing scientists to swap data.
But in many Japanese offices, papers are still piled high and the number of personal computers per 100 workers (just 9.9) is only one-fourth that of the United States. Of the PC's that are there, only 13.4 percent can communicate with other computers within a company, through so-called local area networks, compared with 55.7 percent in the United States. And California alone has six times as many computers connected to the Internet, the worldwide network that is growing like a weed, as all of Japan.
"We are almost 10 years behind the United States" in networking, said Tateo Arimoto, an official of the Science and Technology Agency.
 
Other Big Gaps
 In the United States, cable television is evolving into a conduit for hundreds of channels, video on demand and two-way educational programming, among other things.
But in Japan, fewer than 3 percent of households receive cable programming compared with 60 percent in the United States. And while American cable companies like Tele-Communications Inc. and Time Warner Inc. are strong and busy forging alliances, Japan's cable companies remain small and for the most part are too unsophisticated even to provide pay-per-view services.
And in the United States, wireless communications are beginning to stretch the boundaries of the office, allowing people to stay in touch from anywhere, anytime. But in Japan the relative number of users of cellular phones is less than one-third of that in the United States. And there is little of the entrepreneurial activity found in the United States aimed at wireless transmission of data.
Developing its own information infrastructure is vital to Japan for several reasons. For one, new services like interactive television or huge computerized data bases can be big businesses in and of themselves.
Moreover, advanced communications can improve the productivity of existing businesses or assist in scientific research. Gobs of data from satellites studying the earth remain unusable by many scientists in Japan for lack of a high-speed network to deliver the information, said Hiroshi Mizuta of the National Space Development Agency.
Japan's lack of sophisticated networks could also threaten its world-leading electronics companies. With their home market underdeveloped, such companies will have to design their most advanced portable phones, video equipment and telephone switches for use abroad, which is a little more difficult.
For the same reason, Japanese companies missed the market for machines known as routers, electronic "traffic cops" used to connect smaller computer networks into bigger ones. A future product they might trail in -- unless they work with American companies -- is the cable converter that could well control the flow of information into the home.
 
The Missing Link
 Indeed, electronic distribution of video, games, music and computer data could be a competitive threat to Japanese hardware, such as video- game machines, CD-ROM players and videocassette recorders. Japanese companies like Sony and Matsushita, which have already expanded beyond hardware to software, or programming, through purchases of Hollywood movie studios, now must ponder whether they are still missing a link -- distribution.
Both Sony and Matsushita have talked recently with John Malone, head of T.C.I. He is said to be interested in purchasing a stake in one of their movie studios, which would give one of them a tie-up in the cable business. A Sony executive said the company is interested in cable. But Tsuzo Murase, executive vice president of Matsushita, said his company is not interested in buying into cable nor in selling its studio, MCA Inc.
One reason Japan is lagging, particularly in computer communications, is cultural. Typing Japanese is difficult, making personal computers less convenient than sending handwritten messages on fax machines.
The Japanese also value face-to-face communications. Ikuo Nishioka, who became the head of the Intel Corporation's Japanese subsidiary a year or so ago after a career at the Sharp Corporation, said he was "astonished" at Intel's use of electronic mail. When he completed his orientation visit to Intel's headquarters in Santa Clara, Calif., he said goodbye to other executives instantly by sending them messages. "In Japan," he said, "it would take two weeks to say goodbye," by arranging appointments.
At the International Superconductivity Technology Center, a Government-backed research lab here, the cultural problem is of another sort. The laboratory's director forbids the use of electronic mail, afraid that confidential information will leak out.
Other problems include the fact that it costs 5 to 10 times as much to lease a data line here as it does in the United States, said Izumi Aizu of the Tokyo-based Center for Global Communications. And Tokyo has been reluctant to support the Internet because it does not use a communications standard the Government has been backing.
 
Biggest Problem
 That is indicative of the biggest problem, many experts say: The Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications has ruled over the industry with a heavy hand and has been slow to authorize new services. Such tight regulation might have helped protect Japan's market from foreign competition, but it has also stifled the innovation spurred by the more open market in the United States.
A few years ago, for instance, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company tried to introduce a service here that would allow consumers to use a computer modem while talking on the phone. But regulation was so strict the company gave up.
"What's lagging is not the technology," said Roger Moore, president of the Japanese operations of Canada's Northern Telecom Ltd. "What's lagging has been more the changes in the competitive environment."
Japanese companies, after all, are among the leading manufacturers of cellular telephones. The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, Japan's main phone company, and competitors like the DDI Corporation are making good progress on newer digital cellular service and the next generation of mobile phone service.
But because of Government regulation, rates for cellular phone service in Japan are among the highest in the world and customers must rent their phones from the service supplier, paying about $600 a year for a phone that could be purchased for half that amount in the United States.
Cable television has suffered because the telecommunications ministry decided to back a still commercially unsuccessful effort to transmit television programs from satellites to homes. Cable was relegated to being a local service aimed mainly at improving television reception. It was not until 1989 that satellites were used to distribute programs to cable systems, allowing for the development of nationwide cable programming services similar to MTV and Cable News Network. And a controlling interest in a cable company can be held only by an investor based in that company's service area, a rule that will soon change but has left cable operators small and Balkanized.
"We don't have capital" in the industry, said Yasushige Nishimura, who is in charge of the cable business at the Sumitomo Corporation. "We don't have personnel resources. We don't have expertise."
 
Government's View
 Responding to criticism, Masaharu Matsumoto, deputy director of the cablecast division of the telecommunications ministry, said cable TV in Japan is less regulated than in the United States. Cable operators here, he said, do not pay franchise fees and do not have ceilings on their rates.
To be sure, in terms of technology and deregulation of its telephone system, Japan is hardly in last place and is ahead of some European countries such as France and Germany. And much of the frenzy of industry activity in the United States, including the recent rash of alliances, might not result in profitable businesses.
Japan also has a capacity to advance rapidly once it decides what it must do. And that dawning is now occurring. Earlier this month the Social and Economic Congress of Japan, a group that has the ear of the powerful Ministry of International Trade and Industry, submitted an "emergency" proposal to the Government saying Japan is "decisively behind" in telecommunications and needs a program to catch up.
Already cable TV, computer network and cellular phone use has accelerated. And deregulation is gradually occurring, pushed by Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa. The rule requiring cellular subscribers to lease their phones will be gone by April, for instance.
Expertise is also being imported, giving American and European companies a chance to break into the Japanese market. Last week, the Nynex Corporation said it planned to build advanced cable systems in partnership with the Tomen Corporation, a trading company. T.C.I. has taken a stake in a cable programming service controlled by Sumitomo. And N.T.T., to tap into American technology, made an investment this month in Nextel Communications, a mobile radio company.
The telecommunications ministry's showing of the Clinton-Gore video last month was meant to garner industry support for a pilot project in which optical fiber will be installed in 300 homes near Kyoto to test delivery of video on demand, video telephones and other services.
But there is a debate here, as in the United States, about whether development of the information superhighway should be the role of Government or of industry. Within the Government, there is also a bitter war for control between the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications and the trade ministry.
N.T.T., which was privatized in 1985, says it can wire the entire country with optical fiber by itself by the year 2015. It is experimenting with new services like super high-definition television, which is twice as sharp as existing HDTV and would allow medical images to be transmitted with enough clarity for diagnosis by doctors in other locations.
N.T.T. estimates that providing optical fiber to every home and business will cost $400 billion, an amount it says it can manage. But others have their doubts and there are reports the start of the fiber plan is being postponed. N.T.T.'s profits have been decimated by competition in the long-distance business and by regulations that have held down local rates.
There are also doubts about whether such a high-capacity network can pay for itself. The telecommunications ministry must decide whether to allow N.T.T. to be in the video programming business. If it does not allow it, N.T.T. might never be able to make the optical fibers pay off. But if it does, N.T.T. might crush some fledgling cable television companies.
In electronic mail, Japan's problems are not only Government regulation, but also lack of the Government's usual participation in industrial development. In a reversal of roles, Washington underwrote the development of research networks in the United States while some frustrated scientists in Japan have had to hook up their own networks.
"Our Government doesn't understand the importance of internetworking yet," said Haruhisa Ishida, a professor in the computer center at the University of Tokyo.
To the extent Government agencies do have networks, they do not communicate with other agencies. A message from one to another might have to go through the United States.
 
Plugging In
 The Government is now planning to remedy that with an interagency network to connect 100 national research institutes, with eventual extensions to universities. But some scientists from industry and Government think that plan, which could cost about $40 million in the first three years, does not go far enough. They are suggesting a far more ambitious plan to allow researchers to use supercomputers through an extremely high-speed network. But this project, which could cost at least $300 million, has not yet received approval.
In business, use of networking is also starting to spread. Tadashi Sekizawa, president of Fujitsu Ltd., travels with a pocket computer to check his electronic mail. Japanese affiliates of A.T.&T. and the Intercon Systems Corporation of Herndon, Va., have just begun offering companies here access to the Internet.
And Japanese counterparts of Compuserve and Prodigy, the personal computer services, are also gaining popularity. The two main services, NEC's PC-VAN and Fujitsu's Nifty-Serve, did not start until 1987. Now each has more than 500,000 subscribers.
"When we started this business," said Takashi Yamakawa, general manager of the planning department at Nifty-Serve, "we were afraid that Japanese were too shy to express their private opinions in public spaces like forums."
Now, the on-line forums are overloaded with messages, a sign that a networking culture might not be all that foreign to Japan after all.
 
 
 
JAPAN'S MAVERICK MASTER OF THE INTERNET
 JUN MURAI is the father of the Internet in Japan, a role that has brought him a measure of fame but not always made him popular with the establishment.
Dr. Murai, who teaches at Keio University, began trying to connect Japan's computers to the world in 1984. As a first step, he had to develop Japanese language ability for the software used to control the Internet, the worldwide network.
A ball of energy, Dr. Murai started JU-Net and WIDE, nonprofit networks that connect universities and tie them into the Internet. He is also on Internet's architecture board.
All this has made the 38-year-old computer scientist a revered guru. A company called Intercon International recently advertised that he would be the speaker at a news conference in which it would introduce a service to connect Japanese businesses to the Internet. But Dr. Murai, who is known for having an overloaded appointment calendar, couldn't make it. "Some Japanese press didn't walk in the door when they saw Murai was not there," said Intercon's president, Roger Boisvert.
Some scientists, however, feel Dr. Murai is too powerful and he has had his share of clashes with the Government. He has been an adviser to Internet Initiative Japan, a startup that is trying to provide Internet connectivity to businesses but has so far failed to get a Government permit.
The WIDE network was developed with academic volunteers and corporate contributions, without waiting for the Government. Such a grass-roots effort has not always been appreciated by the Education Ministry, which is developing its own networks.
Dr. Murai said he has little patience with regulators. "Government people like to control things and I don't like to be controlled," he said.
Someday, Dr. Murai said, he would like to be a visiting scholar in the United States. "It's very interesting to see how people are using computers for their daily lives there, which is not happening in this country," he said.
Not surprisingly, computers play a big part in his daily life. His house is wired with a local area network so he can sit in his kitchen and connect to his computer room and by high-speed data lines to the world beyond. "My 8-year-old daughter communicates with me by e-mail," he said proudly.
His ultimate goal: "I want to connect all the computers in this world."
 
 
 
THE SHAKY SATELLITE GAMBIT
 INSTEAD of cable television, Japan has placed its bets on broadcasting directly from satellites to homes. But the satellite business has had trouble getting airborne.
The Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications decided on using a type of satellite that had a powerful signal but could carry only a few channels. It reserved two of those channels for NHK, the state-controlled broadcasting company. To provide programming for a third channel, the ministry in 1984 pooled investments of more than 200 companies into Japan Satellite Broadcasting under the leadership of a former ministry bureaucrat.
Today, Japan Satellite has only 1.4 million subscribers for its pay-television service, known as Wowow. That is less than half the 3 million needed to break even. Earlier this year Japan Satellite was rescued from financial straits by a group of banks and the president was replaced.
It wasn't until a few years ago that the ministry liberalized the use of a different type of satellite, previously used in Japan mainly for phone service. These satellites have a less powerful signal but can transmit far more channels. New companies, backed by Japan's giant trading companies, began using them to distribute cable programming. They are also starting to broadcast directly to homes in competition with the older satellites. But the two types of satellites require different receiving equipment, fracturing the market and confusing consumers.

SECTION: Section 13; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: The Dining Game: 10 Inside Moves

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER

 BODY:
ONE of the more competitive sports in New York City is played out not in Shea or Yankee Stadium, but rather at the tables of the city's better restaurants. In a city where restaurants are the main arenas of social and business entertaining, you can't be blamed entirely if you begin to believe that you are where you eat.
Getting reservations, securing the right tables, receiving top-notch service, being treated as someone special -- all this is the helium that inflates our social balloons. Oh, yes, food is important, too -- sometimes. 
 Experienced diners, many on liberal expense accounts, have mastered the sport of making restaurants work for them. But even for the merely recreational diner, navigating the tricky shoals of New York City restaurants isn't all that difficult. It's like everything else in this town: You have to know how to play the game.
In the nine years that I spent as a restaurant critic for The New York Times, dining out 10 or more times a week -- and trying hard not to seem like someone -- I picked up some inside moves. Try them on. At the very least, eating out is more fun when you feel that you have an edge.
 
1. BECOMING A REGULAR
 Restaurants are not democratic institutions. Just as clothing stores and butcher shops have regular customers whom they treat with special care, so, too, does a restaurant have preferred customers. There is really nothing wrong with that. It's just good business. So keep in mind that because you do not get pecked on the cheek by the owner and seated at the best table is not necessarily a reason to feel slighted and complain.
An old maxim in dining circles states that the best restaurants are those in which you are well known. Your goal should be to become an insider at restaurants you like. This can be done by frequenting the place, chatting with the owner or maitre d'hotel, and generally moving into the establishment's family circle.
 
 
 
2. FINDING SOMEWHERE NEW: THE SNIFF-AND-RUN METHOD
 There are 15,000 restaurants in New York City; even the average avid diner's universe doesn't really hold more than a dozen. So how to find somewhere new? Pirouetting down the street looking at restaurant awnings is the worst method. You might as well just open the Yellow Pages, close your eyes, and put your finger on a place.
There is a better way. Every month or so, I join a friend, Tim Zagat of the Zagat Survey, in a driving tour of a New York neighborhood in which we visit 30 to 40 places a night. The purpose is to find new restaurants or to check up on old ones. When we see an establishment we want to investigate, we walk in, ask to see a menu and just stand on the fringe of the dining room and observe. (Even though we may look like a couple of Internal Revenue Service agents, standing there in dark suits and refusing to sit down, the owners are usually cordial.)
It is amazing how much you can deduce about a restaurant by spending just a minute inside. Is the room lively? Is it romantic? Is it suitable for discreet business conversations? Are the patrons eating with gusto and enjoying themselves? Does the menu look appealing and original, or just humdrum?
And -- this may be a surprise, but it is critical -- does the dining room smell good? Some places have an arresting aroma of garlic and olive oil or maybe charred steak. If a dining room smells like cleaning fluid, or worse, we head for the door. These sniff-and-run visits are astoundingly accurate, based on our experiences going back for dinner. Among those we discovered this way and returned to later for dinner are Becco, the family-style Italian restaurant on West 46th Street; Oceana on East 55th Street, Trois Jean on East 79th Street, and Zoe on Prince Street. We discounted countless others.
 
3. GETTING IN: THE 40 PERCENT SOLUTION
 That ultra-hot, hard-to-get-into place of the moment may not be as hard to get into as you think. Booked to the gills though they may be, many establishments find themselves with empty tables on weekends, when some people reserve at a few places and decide where to go at the last minute. If you are willing to take a chance, you can simply show up at a restaurant without a reservation at 8 P.M. or later. Restaurants generally hold a table for about 45 minutes, so by that time you may get the table of someone who had reserved for, say, 7 P.M. but never showed up.
Behind this bit of trickery is a surprising -- and, to many a restaurant owner, anguishing -- fact: On an average Saturday night, the top restaurants like Lutece, Le Bernardin and Le Cirque have "no show" rates of up to 40 percent. "And many of those customers have confirmed that afternoon by phone that they are coming," said Jean-Jacques Rachou, owner of La Cote Basque.
Gilbert Le Coze, owner and chef of Le Bernardin, estimates that on Saturday nights his no-show rate runs from 40 to 60 percent. He does overbook, he said, but not "heavily like the airlines, because what happens if everybody shows up some night?"
Indeed, nothing causes more chaos in a restaurant than people who make reservations and do not have the courtesy to cancel if they can't make it. (Note: If you are going to be more than, say, 15 minutes late, a phone call to the restaurant is greatly appreciated. Chances are they will remember you as a considerate customer and respond in kind.) If you have ever walked into a restaurant and been told it is full, while right in front of you are empty tables, that could be the reason.
 
 
4. TACTICAL TIPPING
 This is the most confusing aspect of eating out to many diners. Yet knowing how to tip -- neither niggardly nor lavishly in a show-off manner -- and whom to tip is another way of currying favor in restaurants.
Since waiters generally earn minimum wage, their income is derived primarily from tips. Therefore, unless you wind up wearing half of your meal or are ignored by the waiters, a standard 15 percent tip on the total pretax bill is expected. Many New Yorkers find it convenient to double the sales tax of 8.25 per cent to arrive at a 16.5 percent tip. If service is exceptionally good, however, a tip of 20 percent or more would be appropriate.
Payment for captains, who usually supervise teams of waiters, varies. In older and traditional establishments, captains often receive substantial salaries and keep all of their tips. In most new restaurants, however, captains earn slightly more than waiters but still depend on tips for much of their income. In these restaurants all tips are pooled. In either case diners should remember that the rule of thumb for restaurants with captains is 16 to 18 percent of the pretax total for waiters plus 5 percent for captains.
If, however, you want to single out a particular captain or waiter for extraordinary work, you can hand him or her cash upon leaving and say something like, "Thank you; this is for you." The amount should be commensurate with the bill, usually $10 to $20.
Maitres d'hotels do not usually receive tips unless they have performed specific favors, perhaps finding you a table on a busy night. In that case a cash gratuity is warranted, usually from $10 to $20.
Sommeliers are increasingly rare. If a restaurant has a sommelier and he or she is genuinely helpful, the rule of thumb is 10 percent of the cost of the wine. If the sommelier does little more than hand you the wine list and pour the first round, no tip is necessary.
Finally, here is a tactic that is rarely employed but can be astoundingly effective in making points with your favorite dining spot. One evening about 12 years ago I was working as a chef's assistant in a French restaurant when the owner came back to us and placed a bottle of Champagne on the counter. "The Smiths" (I don't recall their name) "want to thank you for a great meal."
This dumbfounded me as something about as likely as telling a toll booth attendant, "Keep the change." And you can imagine how we took care of the Smiths on their subsequent visits. The sous-chef was so touched I thought he was going to offer to drive them home.
 
 
5. STRATEGIC COMPLAINING
 Restaurant owners have an adage: A happy customer tells 10 friends; an unhappy one tells 20.
To get satisfaction when something goes wrong in a restaurant, you have to understand how they view the situation; the last thing restaurateurs need is an ugly brouhaha in the dining room. They are more inclined to settle any reasonable complaint on the spot -- that is, if they are approached with civility, not animosity. Bring your complaint to an authority figure, either the manager or the owner. Waiters often have no authority to act above a certain level, so don't waste your time fighting with them.
For instance, a well-run establishment will try to make amends for long delays in seating (say, more than 20 minutes) by buying you drinks or perhaps offering a complimentary course or a bottle of wine.
If you do not get satisfaction on the spot, the best recourse is to write a calm, reasoned letter to the owner. It's a good idea to send carbon copies to local restaurant critics, too. Letters are the most potent arrow in a diner's quiver. Countless times I have seen owners respond to the customer with a phone call or a letter and an invitation to return for dinner on the house. This is good customer relations, and good business.
If the problem involves sanitation in the dining room or the kitchen, that's another matter. Call the New York City Department of Health at (212) 285-9503.
 
 
6. HAVING IT YOUR WAY
 If you have a special request for a restaurant, say a vegetarian meal, you should ask at the time of making a reservation, not when you show up. Doing that at the last minute on a busy night can test the patience of the most genial chef. Occasionally you may crave a simple dish, say a hamburger or pasta with only olive oil and garlic, neither of which are on the menu. In that case, it isn't out of line to ask on the spot if it can be done.
 
7. GETTING A GOOD TABLE
 If you are ushered to an undesirable table -- actually, there should not be really undesirable tables in good restaurants -- politely ask the host if anything else is available. Restaurants are more flexible in seating than they admit. You may have to wait, but if it enhances your experience it is worth it. It is sometimes unreasonable to ask for a specific table, because it may be booked by regulars.
 
8. BEYOND BEAUJOLAIS
 Those who are not comfortable choosing a wine should ask the waiter for a suggestion, always specifying the price range. (The standard markup for wine is twice what you would pay in a wine shop, or three times wholesale.) Most restaurants have at least one person who can make recommendations.
But what if you do not like the wine you choose? The wine may be off, in which case the restaurant must take it back. Or it might be perfectly fine but not to your liking. In that case you should make it known to the waiter. If a restaurant has any class at all, it will replace the wine without comment. There is no law specifying that if you take more than two sips of the wine you must pay for it. It is essentially a matter of courtesy between the restaurant and the customer.
The same applies to food. If you are unhappy with a dish -- even if it is well prepared -- you should talk to the waiter or manager. As in the wine example, a professional restaurateur would never risk alienating a customer for the price of one dish.
 
9. BRINGING YOUR OWN
 From time to time you may find yourself with a special bottle of wine that you would like to drink over a fine meal at a restaurant. The only establishments that allow that as a matter of routine are those that do not serve alcohol. If you bring your wine, they will serve it, sometimes charging a small corkage fee, say $5. Getting other restaurants to allow this is not easy. Some refuse outright because every bottle of wine a customer brings in is a lost wine sale to the restaurant (and with markups of 200 percent or more, that could be a lot of lost revenue).
If you call ahead and ask, however, most will allow it. Corkage fees generally range from $10 to $25.
 
10. GOOD EATING, ON A BUDGET
 A common perception is that New York City is the country's priciest place to dine. Well, it can be, if you ignore the remarkable values that abound in this hard-pressed economy. For example, Gotham Bar and Grill, one of the city's most innovative American restaurants, offers a $19.94 lunch; Jo Jo, the trend-setting bistro on East 64th Street in Manhattan, has a $25 prix fixe lunch, as does its sister restaurant, Vong. Raphael, the handsome French restaurant on West 54th Street, offers a $29 prix fixe dinner, which is a value considering the quality offered, and the Hudson River Club overlooking New York Harbor serves a $24.94 prix fixe dinner that is well worth the price.
This is just a smattering of what is available. Even better bargains can be had by those who are willing to dine at off hours, say, before 7:30 P.M. or after 10 P.M. The special menus come and go, so it is always worthwhile to ask if any exist. You wouldn't take a cross-country airplane flight without checking on discount fares, so why ignore discounts in restaurants?
 
Where Anyone Can Feel Like a King

The best measure of service, of course, is the way a restaurant treats you when you're not a regular. Here, in alphabetical order, is a personal rundown of 10 restaurants that exemplify the best of service.
The preponderance of old-line French establishments is testimony to the long French tradition of fine service. Many of the waiters at these restaurants have been at it for 30 years or more.

CHANTERELLE 2 Harrison Street, at Hudson Street, Manhattan, (212) 966-6960 -- Hushed, formal and elegant, this small downtown French restaurant has an eagle-eyed staff that swoops down when needed and remains at a distant perch when not.
GOTHAM BAR AND GRILL 12 East 12th Street, Manhattan, (212) 620-4020 -- The casually dressed servers at this leading contemporary American restaurant observe all the fine points, and always with good cheer.
HARRY CIPRIANI 781 Fifth Avenue, at 59th Street, Manhattan, (212) 753-5566 -- Sharp and professional service has been the hallmark of all restaurants run by the Venetian-born Mr. Cipriani. This one is no exception.
LE CHANTILLY 106 East 57th Street, Manhattan, (212) 751-2931 -- The splendid dining room at this French restaurant is run by a pampering crew of mostly French waiters who are omnipresent but never obtrusive.
LE PERIGORD 405 East 52d Street, Manhattan, (212) 755-6244 -- A most congenial French restaurant with formal, black tie service. The seasoned staff could not be more accommodating or eager to please.
MARK'S The Mark Hotel, 25 East 77th Street, Manhattan, (212) 879-1864 -- The genteel, English ambiance at this fine hotel restaurant is made even more enjoyable by a knowledgeable, sophisticated service staff.
THE RIVER CAFE 1 Water Street, Brooklyn, (718) 522-5200 -- Service at this glamorous floating restaurant on the East River has been a model for how things are done right. The tradition continues.
THE SIGN OF THE DOVE 1110 Third Avenue, at 65th Street, Manhattan, (212) 861-8080 -- The romantic setting at this innovative French/American restaurant is enhanced by the low-key, highly proficient staff.
THE "21" CLUB 21 West 52d Street, Manhattan, (212) 582-7200 -- The clubby feeling here at this historic New York institution is conveyed by a warm and hard-working staff that makes regulars feel like family. First-time visitors are treated with care as well.
UNION SQUARE CAFE 21 East 16th Street, Manhattan, (212) 243-4020 -- The young, bright, highly trained staff here never loses its composure under relentless pressure. The perpetually smiling waiters and waitresses expose more ivory than a Steinway showroom.
 BRYAN MILLER
