HEADLINE: These Faithful Fans Always Know What Time It Is

BYLINE: By JUDY POKRAS

DATELINE: FLEMINGTON

 BODY:
IMAGINE this: parents in their 40's, with pre-teen-age children in tow, and both age groups singing and clapping to the silly antics of two men, one in his mid-70's, the other just shy of 70.
That was the improbable sight on a recent Saturday as Buffalo Bob and Clarabell performed children's songs from "The Howdy Doody Show" here at a Doodyville Historical Society convention at the Flemington Baptist Church. 
 Buffalo Bob Smith, who turns 76 on Saturday, wearing a fringed, rhinestone-studded frontiersman outfit, played piano and sang "It's Howdy Doody Time" and other favorites. Clarabell (Lew Anderson, 69) in full clown regalia, played clarinet and horsed around, and the duo drew laughs and rapt attention from the audience of about a dozen children and 60 graying adults.
Later, sitting at a table in the church, Buffalo Bob said he started on WNBC radio in March 1947, where he created the voice that eventually became Howdy Doody on television. It was at the suggestion of a producer that he called a Disney artist, Velma Dawson, who created Howdy's freckled face from the sound of Howdy's voice over the phone.
 
Valued Beyond Price
 Buffalo Bob said he keeps the original Howdy Doody marionette in a plastic display case "on a handsome pedestal" in his North Carolina home. When asked what the marionette's value is, he replied, "Well, what would you say your children are worth?"
The Doodyville Historical Society's convention was organized by the society's founder, Jeff Judson, 45, a pharmacist in Raritan Township, with the help of Joseph and Jeanne Cannavo of Swedesboro. Mr. Judson also edits the society's newsletter, The Howdy Doody Times.
The group, consisting mostly of middle-aged fans who are hoping for some kind of revival of "The Howdy Doody Show," began in 1978. It has about 360 members nationwide, Mr. Cannavo said.
The show ran from 1947 to 1960.
Convention attendees -- collectors of marionettes, videotapes and other memorabilia -- came from as far away as California and represented a wide variety of occupations. Fans included two physicians, a psychologist, an accountant, a college professor, a Methodist pastor, a muralist, an exterminator, a police dispatcher, working mothers, secretaries, sales people and others, including a few who were unemployed.
The convention featured a Howdy Doody memorabilia exchange, door prizes, rare film footage, appearances by characters from the show and those who worked behind the scenes, and a Howdy Doody trivia game. (Question: How many freckles did the original Howdy Doody have? Answer: 48, one for each state).
 
Look-Alike Contest
 The costume-contest winner was a redhead, David McLaughlin, 5, of Southampton, who had been transformed into a life-size look-alike of Howdy Doody, in jeans, plaid shirt, bandanna, gloves and cowboy boots.
Conventioneers were treated to drawings of their favorite Howdy Doody characters on the spot by Milt Neil, 79, the show's artist. Mr. Neil, born in Irvington and a Wayne resident since 1937, left Disney to work on "The Howdy Doody Show," where, with the show's writer, Eddie Kean, he designed Flub-a-Dub, Mr. Bluster, Dilly Dally and other puppets.
"Dilly Dally was the only puppet in the world that could wiggle his ears," he said.
Another member of the Howdy Doody team at the convention was Robert (Rip) Rippin, 74, the show's first director and later its producer. Mr. Rippin was born in Perth Amboy and has lived in Colonia since 1950, in "the house that Howdy Doody built," he said.
At the convention dinner, he introduced an old Army buddy, E. Roger Muir, the executive producer of "The Howdy Doody Show," whom the society was honoring.
Mr. Muir, 74, announced that he was talking with executives of NBC, which owns the basic rights to the characters, to produce a series of 90-minute home videos during the next several years and to build a "Doodyville U.S.A." theme park.
Doodyville would feature talking and electronic puppets, displays of the many premiums the show offered in its 13-year network run, and several 50-feet mini-theater "peanut galleries," each with a large-screen television monitor featuring one or two years of the show. From time to time, there would also be appearances of the show's characters.
"I hesitate to say we'll be back on the air, but I'm going to keep trying," Mr. Muir said. "We hope in the next three months we can crack the nut."
 
Network Reviews Options
 Patricia Schultz, an NBC vice president, said in a telephone interview that the network was continually reviewing proposals on how to revive "Howdy Doody" and was also "exploring a lot of different possibilities, like home video."
NBC recognizes that it has a valuable piece of property and a "very popular show and character in Howdy Doody," she said.
Mr. Cannavo said: "The Doodyville Historical Society intends to support Roger in whatever way it can. But the bottom line is, the society wants the show back on the air as soon as possible." He said he thought a theme park would have more merit if the show was actually on the air.
Mr. Cannavo said the society had three ideas for how the show could be brought back: broadcast reruns of the original 2,500 network shows, but with newly shot "intros and outros" featuring Buffalo Bob Smith and Howdy; broadcast reruns of the 135 shows that were shot in 1976 and 1977 for a syndication, or create new holiday specials, using the available members of the original cast and crew.
Mr. Cannavo said the society had collected more than 8,000 signatures in a petition to bring the show back. About 3,000 were collected by a Gloucester County Freeholder, Joseph L. Manganello, a society supporter.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in/Highland Park;
Well-Established, but Unpretentious

BYLINE: By JERRY CHESLOW

 BODY:
THE tiny Middlesex County borough of Highland Park has its traffic problems, and its business district could use a facelift. But those who live there find it comfortable and unpretentious, and it is a thriving community.
Its downtown -- Raritan Avenue -- is part of Route 27, one of New Jersey's most congested highways, and traffic there slows to a crawl in the rush hours. The Raritan Avenue business district, which is mainly turn-of-the-century, is within 10 miles of three major shopping centers, Menlo Park in Edison, Woodbridge Center in Woodbridge and the Brunswick Square Mall in East Brunswick. Yet it remains a prosperous business street with few empty stores. 
 Most houses -- and there have been few one-family houses built in the last 30 years -- are on narrow lots and the tax rate is the highest in Middlesex County, mostly because of a lack of industry.
Last year the owners of a Highland Park house assessed at $150,000 would have paid $4,660 in taxes, about 40 percent higher than the tax on a similarly valued home in Sayreville, which has the county's lowest tax rate.
But the houses retained their value through the housing slump and continue to command higher prices than those in most of the surrounding communities.
All Highland Park's school buildings are at least 30 years old and in need of renovation. Yet the students scored an average of 1,016 on their Scholastic Assessment Tests (college boards), the highest average score in Middlesex County.
"It's just as stable as the Rock of Gibraltar," said Thomas F. Boyle, the tax assessor. He added that while most other communities in Middlesex County had dropped in assessed valuation by as much as to 15 percent since 1981 because of the decline in property values, Highland Park had gone up by 9.98 percent.
To begin to understand the dynamics of Highland Park, one must stroll along Raritan Avenue on a warm Saturday morning. The sidewalk is crowded with mothers wheeling baby carriages, Orthodox Jewish men and boys wearing yarmulkes as they walk to services -- there are four synagogues in the borough -- children on bicycles and older people strolling.
Jews account for about 40 percent of the population, with the rest a mix of other white groups, blacks, Hispanics and Asians.
Reflecting the size of the Jewish community, Highland Park is one of the few New Jersey communities encircled by a symbolic fence, known as an eruv in Hebrew. It is a thin wire that is strung along telephone polls surrounding the town. According to Jewish law, Orthodox Jews may carry or wheel things on the Sabbath inside such an enclosure.
Mayor H. James Polos says that one of the secrets to Highland Park's success has always been the accessibility of its political leaders. As an example, he cites an incident in 1920 when Robert Wood Johnson, the founder of Johnson & Johnson, was Mayor.
"An angry resident called the Mayor at home to complain that his garbage was not collected," Mr. Polos said. "That night, Mayor Johnson pulled up in front of the man's house in his limousine and picked up the trash."
WHILE Mayor Polos does not own a limo and has never picked up a resident's trash, he says it is not unusual for him to be approached by residents in the supermarket. "They can talk to their elected officials and get results," he said, "and that makes them feel they have a real stake in the community."
One resident, David S. Levine, said that he was attracted to the borough and its downtown 10 years ago, when he and his wife, Frances, bought a four-bedroom colonial on Dennis Street. They had lived in a rental apartment in Old Bridge, N.J.
"My wife worked in town," he recalled, "and we just observed that it was a quaint, well-established, walking town. So we looked for a house here."
Mr. Levine, marketing director for a computer company in nearby South River, said he enjoyed living in Highland Park because "it is a safe town, where you are comfortable sending your children downtown to buy things."
The Levines have two daughters, 11 and 7 years old. Like many members of the Conservative Jewish community, they send their children to a Jewish private school -- the Solomon Schecter Day School of the Raritan Valley, in nearby East Brunswick. Many Orthodox Jewish residents send their children to the Rabbi Pesach Raymon Yeshiva, in Edison. The Schecter school runs from kindergarten through grade 7 and and the Raymon yeshiva from kindergarten through grade 8.
Milton Ziment, owner of ERA Ziment Realtors on Raritan Avenue, said prices for one-family homes ranged from about $100,000 for some small houses to more than $500,000 for a few new four- to five-bedroom colonials with views of Donaldson Park and the Raritan River.
Many 30- to 40-year-old four-bedroom colonials go for $200,000 to $400,000.
Mr. Ziment, citing figures from the Multiple Listing Service, said the market was improving in Highland Park. In 1991, 44 houses were sold in the borough in an average of 117 days each. So far this year, 51 houses have been sold; they were on the market for an average of 82 days and went for 94 percent of the asking price.
There are just a handful of town-house developments. One of the largest is L'Ambiance, near the border with Piscataway. Its 18 two-bedroom, two-bath units start at about $170,000, Mr. Ziment said.
The luxury condominium apartments market took a beating in the housing slump. In 1989, the eight-story, 83-unit River Ridge Terrace building on South Adelaide Avenue, was completed. The two-bedroom apartments started at $210,000. However, the developer could not sell them all and eventually auctioned off 20 apartments, some for half of the original asking price. Those apartments, which are the high end of the condominium market, now sell for about $120,000.
There are more than 3,000 rental apartments, mostly in the 20 garden-apartment complexes on the perimeter of the borough. Apartments are also available in two-story houses in the center of town. Mr. Ziment said rents ranged from $575 to $660 for one-bedroom and from $675 to $750 for two bedrooms.
Highland Park began as a religious community in 1681, when a group of dissident Baptists led by the Rev. Francis Drake, a descendant of the explorer-adventurer of the same name, arrived from nearby Piscataway and bought land from the Leni Lenape Indians.
In the Revolutionary War, in 1776, Hessian soldiers held a fort on the bluff overlooking the Raritan River and had artillery duels with Alexander Hamilton's battery, which was covering Washington's retreat from New Brunswick.
HIGHLAND PARK went through a growth spurt in 1835 when the New Jersey Railroad built a line from Jersey City to the Raritan River. The passengers had to get off the train and take a stagecoach over a bridge to New Brunswick. The name Highland Park was coined in 1885 by a Mr. Beekman because much of the land was wooded and overlooked the Raritan River
According to William F. Ducca, the borough historian, Highland Park seceded from Raritan Township (now Edison) in 1905 because the residents wanted their own school district. Currently, there are three schools: the k-2 Irving School, on South 11th Avenue; the 3-6 Bartle School, on Mansfield Street, and Highland Park High School, on North Fifth Avenue.
Superintendent of Schools Peter J. Bastardo said the district has received a $4 million low-interest loan from the New Jersey Economic Development Administration to bring the schools up to current codes.
Computers are introduced in kindergarten. By second grade each child is expected to write and publish a story on a desktop computer. Last year, the high school chemistry team won the state championship. Its football team won the state championship for small schools two years ago. Of the 1992 graduating class, 85 percent went on to higher education.
Today, much of Highland Park remains county parkland. It is sandwiched between the 90-acre Donaldson Park off South Second Avenue on the borough's southern tip, and the 473-acre Johnsons Park, on River Road. Both parks have ball fields, picnic grounds, tennis courts and ponds. Johnson Park also has a petting zoo.
Many of Highland Park's residents work in New Brunswick, where there are hospitals, medical laboratories and Johnson & Johnson and Rutgers University. Others are employed in neighboring Edison's Raritan Center industrial park or in Manhattan.
There is an abundance of restaurants on Raritan Avenue, among them a Charlie Brown's, Tabachnik's deli, Hunan East, the Northern Italian Radicchio, the Spanish-Mexican La Fonda and even a rabinically supervised kosher Dunkin' Donuts.
Highland Park has been home to two Nobel laureates. The late Selman A. Waksman was awarded the prize in medicine and physiology in 1952 for his work with antibiotics and Dr. Arno A. Penzias, who shared the 1978 prize in physics for his work related to the big bang theory, still lives there.

 BAND-AIDS AND BULLETS: Known to Highland Park residents as The Castle, Merriewold, off River Road, is a mansion that was completed in 1926 by J. Seward Johnson, son of one of the founders of the Johnson & Johnson pharmaceutical empire. The 25-room stone edifice was eventually sold to Charles Farmer, an engineer, and his wife, Barbara. In 1963, Charles murdered Barbara in their bedroom with a .32-caliber pistol. He told the court that she was having an affair with a sculptor and had spent more than $200,000 on a black magic center in Massachusetts. At the trial, he was found to be insane and was ordered confined to an institution. The Castle is now used as offices.

HEADLINE: Seeking a G.M. Package That Pleases Everyone

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: NORTH TARRYTOWN

 BODY:
WITH one hand, General Motors last month gave workers at the automotive plant here a brief reprieve, agreeing to keep its assembly lines busy for an extra year before closing for good. With the other, the country's largest auto maker delivered an ultimatum to officials in this Hudson River village: either revoke a precedent-setting local environmental-cleanup law or face legal action.
While workers at one of General Motors' oldest plants were relieved to have a year's grace to plan their futures, village leaders bridled at the get-tough legal stance the auto maker had taken with them. 
 Early this month, the auto maker made good on its ultimatum to the village and filed suit in United States District Court in Manhattan, seeking an injunction against the ordinance enacted last June in North Tarrytown, the Environmental Protection and Abandoned Industrial Property Reclamation Law.
That law, the first of its kind in the state and one of the first in the country, holds General Motors -- or any other large company leaving town -- responsible for cleaning up after itself. It is designed to prevent problems that have occurred in other waterfront communities, like nearby Hastings-on-Hudson, where large companies moved away and left behind environmental hazards, said the law's author, Donald W. Stever, a lawyer who lives in North Tarrytown.
In Hastings-on-Hudson, Anaconda Wire and Cable was situated on the waterfront until 1976. In 1989 a study revealed that it would cost $15 million to clean up polychlorinated biphenyls and heavy metals left in the ground by the company.
The law requires a company that is relocating to remove all hazards, like crude oil, oil derivatives, asbestos, polychlorinated biphenyls and pesticides. It is also designed to avoid "industrial neighborhood blight," created when companies leave their sites. In addition, the law requires a company to post a bond to cover the cost of building demolition, if necessary, and any other hazardous-waste removal.
 
'An Extreme Breach of Faith'
 Margaret G. Holmes, a General Motors spokeswoman, said that the auto maker was already complying with Federal and state regulations governing industrial sites and added that the company was simply protecting its legal position by filing the suit. She said that the Village Board of Trustees had agreed to rescind the law at a meeting this fall and then reneged and that the law was unduly stringent in comparison with existing state and Federal laws. General Motors was was not abrogating its responsibilities, she said.
But Mayor Sean Treacy saw the company's actions in a different light: "I call it an extreme breach of faith. Clearly, they want to walk away from us after 78 years in this village and show no moral responsibility. This should be a warning to other communities, 'Don't trust G.M.' "
Mayor Treacy and the Village Trustees had courted the auto maker's favor for more than a year in an effort to craft a departure package that would leave both sides satisfied when the company left town.
Ms. Holmes, who said General Motors was still open to negotiation and wanted to settle the lawsuit out of court, said that the suit challenges the village's regulation on several grounds. The law violates Federal interstate commerce regulations and unnecessarily replicatesstate and Federal laws, according to court papers.
 
Precedent for Other Communities
 But local ordinance is also perceived as an attempt to strong-arm the manufacturer, Ms. Holmes said: "It is not an environmental ordinance; it is a pretext for economic protectionism. It is aimed at keeping us in the village or forcing us to find someone else to take over the plant."
Mr. Stever denied the charges, saying that it was "important for the village to take control of its own destiny" to avoid the fate of other riverfront communities.
And Mayor Treacy observed that if the court upheld even parts of the law, it could set a precedent for other communities to follow in the future.
"It is foolish for them to take us into court," he said. "This can only give faith to other communities to enact similar laws to protect themselves."
In February last year, General Motors announced that it would close the 2.5-million-square-foot plant -- one-fourth larger than the World Trade Center -- even though it had been recently retooled for production of the plastic-bodied Chevrolet Lumina, Oldsmobile Silhouette and Pontiac Transport minivans. In part, disappointing sales of the futuristic-styled vehicles contributed to the decision.
 
Sales Have Picked Up
 Before the retooling in the late 1980's, an extensive package of local, county and state concessions -- estimated at $140 million in incentives, tax abatements, special programs and services -- had been offered to the company as an enticement to remain in North Tarrytown. General Motors accepted the package and made plans for a long stay.
But the company's expectations were not in line with the market's response to the minivans, which did not do well in the showroom. In light of this and other financial worries facing the beleaguered auto maker, it tagged the North Tarrytown plant and others for closing. The deadline for North Tarrytown was set for the summer of 1995.
In a concession last month, following four months of contract talks with the United Auto Workers, the manufacturer agreed to extend the deadline and another at a metal- stamping works in Kalamazoo, Mich. Now production of the minivans is scheduled to continue for another 12 months here, while General Motors' plant in Doraville, Ga., gears up for production of a new generation of the vehicles, which have been redesigned and are now selling well, Ms. Holmes said.
Meanwhile, the local economy has already begun to feel the impact of General Motors' planned departure. The first blow came when the workforce here, which stood at 3,450 in February last year, fell to 2,150 six months later when General Motors eliminated its second shift.
 
Village and Schools Will Lose Funds
 Merchants along Beekman Place -- where delicatessens, bars and other establishments line the street that leads down to the plant -- say business is off and that they are worried about their survival once the plant closes in two and a half years. The closing date, with the extension, is now the summer of 1996.
"We lost our afternoon trade when the plant went to a single shift, and once they leave altogether, it is going to make a big dent in our lunch trade," said Christopher Rezza, co-owner of Green County Importing Corporation, a grocery store and delicatessen. "In this economy, that's hard to take."
Government officials, too, are worried because the village and local school district will be losing the income from annual payments in lieu of taxes that the auto maker has been making to them. Last year General Motors paid North Tarrytown $1.1 million, or slightly more than 20 percent of the municipality's annual budget. Also last year, according to the agreement, the company wrote a check to the Union Free School District of the Tarrytowns for $1.9 million toward its budget of $22,669,062.
In the departure agreement hammered out before the lawsuit, General Motors had offered to continue local payments worth an estimated $5 million for two years after it closes the plant. For now, though, all deals are off until the matter of the local ordinance is settled, Ms. Holmes said.
 
A Better Mood at the Plant
 But while the village and the auto maker argue over in-ground pollutants, tax abatements and departure packages, workers like Angelo Valletta, 46, say they are worried about "more important things, like the rest of our lives."
"I'm talking about my retirement, what I'm going to do once this place shuts down," said Mr. Valletta, who has worked for General Motors for 28 years.
Mr. Valletta, a resident of New Windsor, in Orange County, said he was grateful for the year's extension at the plant, which would give him the 30 years he needed to be eligible for a retirement package. "It gives me time to think, to get ready," he said. "I want to sell my house and go to Florida, where it's cheaper to live."
He said the mood at the plant was upbeat since General Motors announced it would stay open a year past its original summer 1995 shutdown. It has given workers time to sign up for programs at a learning center at the plant, to sharpen their English and reading skills, he said.
 
A State Involvement
 "We keep telling everyone, 'Prepare yourself,' " said Mr. Valletta, a benefits worker for Local 664 of the United Auto Workers. "But you know, some people think this plant will never close. Who know's what's going to happen from one day to the next?"
The State Office of Economic Development is working with the auto maker and village officials to salvage the agreement worked out before the lawsuit was filed last month. "Hopefully, this is just a temporary parting of the ways," said Steven B. Vitoff, a spokesman for the office.
In addition to continuing some payments to the village, General Motors had also agreed, as part of the departure agreement, to sell a 1.5-acre riverfront parking lot to the village or a designee of the village, so that it could be developed as a source of tax revenues, and to help find tenants for the site.
Moreover, it said it would allow a part of the site to become part of a countywide Greenway linking village landmarks with parks and stretches of riverside property.
The village has until the first week in December to rescind the law and resume negotiations before General Motors moves forward on the suit, Ms. Holmes, the spokeswoman, said.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 14; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1476 words

HEADLINE: Swagger Was the Key to Life

BYLINE: By Nicholas Lemann; Nicholas Lemann is a national correspondent for The Atlantic Monthly and the author of "The Promised Land."

 BODY:

IN HISTORY'S SHADOW
An American Odyssey.
By John Connally with Mickey Herskowitz.
Illustrated. 386 pp. New York:
Hyperion. $24.95. 
 NOTHING John B. Connally ever did was as disarming as the way he behaved when he went bankrupt in the Texas real-estate bust of the late 1980's. It was a maximally humiliating situation: the confidant to Presidents and billionaires, 70 years old and still imperious, Connally had managed to fall into a financial ruin so complete that he had to sell off the furniture on his ranch. But he and his wife, Nellie, went so far as to serve as hosts at the auction of all their property. They never displayed bitterness or meanness; Connally even appeared in good-humored advertisements as a kind of living reminder that there is life and even a measure of dignity after bankruptcy.
"In History's Shadow: An American Odyssey" is a little like the auction. Connally's sense of his own stature was such that if he'd had his druthers, he might have produced a deadly serious memoir aimed at enhancing his historical reputation, like the books of Richard M. Nixon, Lyndon B. Johnson or Henry A. Kissinger -- or no memoir at all, just noble silence. Instead, before his death in June, he submitted with good cheer to the publishing routine that, for a famous person, pays best: the breezy as-told-to book laced with juicy tidbits. (The "to whom," in this case, is Mickey Herskowitz, who has previously written books with Bette Davis, Dan Rather and Howard Cosell.) There is far more material in these pages on what happened when Connally was wounded at John F. Kennedy's side in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963 -- a subject that Connally was proud of never having discussed publicly -- than on what he did in his three terms as Governor of Texas. Somehow, though, he emerges pretty gracefully from an exercise that could have embarrassed and diminished him. He gives up the goods -- including an account of the teen-age suicide of his firstborn child -- without ever seeming cheap, petty or bathetic.
Though he was raised in rural poverty, Connally spent his entire adult life as a Texas Ubermensch. He was elected president of the University of Texas Student Assembly on the same day in 1938 that Nellie was elected Sweetheart of the university; and a year later, at the age of 22, he was the chief aide to Texas's brightest young politician, Congressman Lyndon Johnson, and so was right in the middle of everything that important Texans were doing. Connally was so spectacularly handsome and commanding that he was being talked about as a prospective governor or even President not long before he was out of his 20's. He personified the great Texas progressions of his lifetime, from poor to rich, country to city, small-time to worldly.
Therefore the most interesting question about Connally is why he never got the part he looked and acted. It is a question that obviously occurred to Connally himself a time or two, and he answers it in his book in two ways, one direct and the other almost unconscious.
In Connally's mind, his Presidential prospects were a secondary casualty of Lee Harvey Oswald. (As assassination buffs know, Connally did not believe in the Warren Commission's "single bullet theory," but he says here that he did believe Oswald, acting alone, was the assassin. Oswald, he thinks, fired three shots, hitting Kennedy twice and himself once.) Had Kennedy been re-elected in 1964, the nation in 1968 could easily have turned to the popular Democratic Governor of Texas as a replacement. But Lyndon Johnson's Presidency left people in no mood to consider another Texan for the top job in the 1960's.
Connally's next big chance seemed to be 1976, at what would have been the end of Richard Nixon's second term; Mr. Nixon, he says, had made Gerald R. Ford Vice President on the understanding that Connally, who had become a Republican in 1973, would be the anointed successor. Watergate spoiled that plan. In 1980, the year Connally actually ran for the Republican nomination, he could not beat Ronald Reagan, partly because as a party switcher he was regarded with suspicion by Republicans and partly because he had been tried, though acquitted, on bribery charges. That was the end of the story, though he does offer as a parting shot the observation that Mr. Reagan was not "as good a president as I would have been."
The real problem, though, may have been the profound ambivalence about politics that is a running motif of "In History's Shadow." The Presidents Connally knew best -- John Kennedy, Lyndon Johnson, Richard Nixon -- were, for better or worse, completely dedicated to the profession of politics. But Connally was never willing to descend fully to the perilous depths of total commitment. He took nine years out of his rising period during the 1950's to work for Sid Richardson, the Texas wildcatter who founded what is now the Bass brothers fortune, because he feared "the desperation that comes with being a man of modest means in politics." He found it distasteful to go to football games with Johnson because all Johnson wanted to do there was talk politics. He urged Kennedy not to ride in the motorcade in Dallas because it would be "exhausting . . . a powerful psychic drain," and instead to save his energies for meeting with businessmen. He decided to leave the governorship because "whatever I was able to accomplish in solving the problems of the state, there would always be new problems" -- a thought it is impossible to imagine Lyndon Johnson having.
Connally metes out praise by way of variations on adjectives like firm, elegant, disciplined, sophisticated, ruthless, distant and, above all, tough -- proconsular words. He found something weak and petty about the basic practice of politics; he absorbed almost unthinkingly (because it fit his nature so perfectly) the main idea of the Texas Democratic Party in its all-powerful heyday in the post-World War II years, which was that the purpose of government is to help business. Connally's most lasting achievement is having helped to build the University of Texas into a national institution during his governorship, but he did this, he explains, only because "industry follows brainpower." His "message" in the 1980 campaign was, to Clinton-era sensibilities, shockingly narrow-gauged: "If you're not willing to get into the political arena and defend your business, to defend your interests, to defend this economic system, then you're not worthy to head any corporation in America, in my judgment."
When Connally erred, which was pretty often, it was in the direction of acting excessively decisive and tycoonlike. He advised Johnson to threaten to drop nuclear weapons on Hanoi, and Mr. Nixon to burn the Watergate tapes. In December 1990 he and a Texas oilman friend, on a private mission to free the Middle East hostages, called on Saddam Hussein in Baghdad ("He was calm, deliberate, restrained, and gave the impression of being totally in command of himself") and told him that "the average person in the United States or elsewhere knows little of your disagreement with the Kuwaitis" -- this as his country was gearing up for war over just that issue.
It is sometimes amazing how little he knew about life outside the Texas-Washington-corporate nexus; while describing his work wheedling Government jobs for constituents when he was an aide to Johnson, he tosses off as an aside that "those were the days before Civil Service" -- which actually was founded in 1883. No doubt Connally's piling up of $300 million in debt in the early 1980's was another example of his tendency to view swagger as the one key to life.
Once in 1973 Mr. Nixon invited Connally, who was practicing law in Texas at the time, after having served as Mr. Nixon's Secretary of the Treasury, to join him and Leonid Brezhnev on a cross-country flight on Air Force One, so that the Soviet leader could meet the man he probably would be dealing with in the late 1970's. "As we flew over the Grand Canyon, the three of us talked about matters relating to the rearrangement of the universe," Connally reports, the tone indicating that this was the milieu for which he was best suited. But the truth is that for most of his life Connally wound up playing, against type, the second lead to men you'd think he would have outshined: Lyndon Johnson, Sid Richardson, Richard Nixon; even in his final, real-estate phase, his protege, Ben Barnes, was the managing partner of the business. In the last pages of this book, Connally tosses bouquets to President Clinton, Ross Perot and Ann Richards, the Governor of Texas, perhaps to indicate his willingness to play consigliere. How could these people have been John Connally's bosses, instead of his being theirs? Because they were willing to put ambition ahead of dignity, and he wasn't.
